DOC.HEAD: Three Killed, Fourth Wounded As Police Foil McDonald's Robbery
DOC.TEXT: Three robbers burst into a fast-food restaurant, tied up the manager and attempted to flee with thousands of dollars, but were cut down and killed in a fusillade of police gunfire Monday, authorities said. A fourth person involved in the robbery at a McDonald's restaurant was wounded, said police Lt. Fred Nixon. None of the victims was immediately identified, but Nixon said the survivor was in serious condition at a Los Angeles hospital. Nine officers from the Police Department's special investigations section watched the robbery taking place around 2 a.m., and approached the men after they got into a getaway car, authorities said. The officers opened fire when one of the four raised what looked like a handgun and pointed it at them, said police Lt. Bill Hall, who heads the team that investigates shootings involving police. ``... All officers fired almost simultaneously,'' said Hall. The gun turned out to be a pellet gun, but to police it looked real, he said. ``I don't think you'd be likely to know the difference if you were looking down the barrel of one,'' Hall said. Officers recovered masks and several thousand dollars in cash from the car, Hall said. Police had been following the four, some of whom were believed involved in earlier restaurant robberies, said Officer Bill Frio. ``We had a couple of possible suspects identified, but not enough evidence to arrest and book them, so we were tailing them,'' he said. The four were followed from the beachfront community of Venice to Sun Valley, about 15 miles north of downtown, where Hall said officers watched them enter the closed restaurant. ``There was a female manager inside, alone, and the doors were all locked,'' said Hall. ``The suspects forced open a side door, tied her up and forced her to provide the combination of the safe.'' Hall said the manager called police when she saw the men approaching her restaurant, but it was decided to make the arrest afterward rather than interrupt the robbery because there had been no injuries in previous restaurant holdups.

DOC.HEAD: Buell, Alabiso Named to AP Photo Posts
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press has named a new executive photo editor and a presidential assistant to coordinate its recently announced electronic darkroom-PhotoStream project. President Louis D. Boccardi said Vincent J. Alabiso will become executive photo editor of the news cooperative and Harold G. Buell will be assistant to the president for electronic darkrooms and PhotoStream. Alabiso, director of photography for The Boston Globe and a former New England photo editor in the AP's Boston bureau, succeeds Buell, who has directed AP photo operations since 1968. The appointments, announced Monday, are effective March 19. The AP announced last month that it will be installing electronic darkrooms at its 950 LaserPhoto members. These darkrooms will provide newspapers with AP's high-speed digital PhotoStream system that will enable them to receive an AP black and white photo in less than a minute and a color photo in three minutes. ``Hal Buell has contributed enormously to the growth of our photo service, which now reaches 950 newspapers in the United States alone. I have asked him to bring that experience to the implementation of our PhotoStream and darkroom projects which are the most exciting steps we have taken in photos in recent history,'' Boccardi said. ``And in Vin Alabiso we bring back to the AP an outstanding photo editor who has now seen what we do from the newspaper's perspective. ``These moves, supported by the outstanding photo team we have in place, position us for the exciting years that lie ahead in the world of high-speed, high-quality news photography.'' Buell, 58, who has a master's degree from the Medill School of Journalism at Northwestern University, which he also attended as an undergraduate, has been in the photo department since 1957. He was named executive photo editor in 1968, and the title of assistant general manager was added in 1977. He has been instrumental in the concept and development of the PhotoStream system. Alabiso, 43, has been director of photography at the Globe since January 1987. A 1969 graduate from Northeastern University in Boston, Alabiso joined the AP in New York in 1975 and left the following year. He rejoined the AP in Boston in 1981 as photo editor and was named New England Newsphoto editor in 1983 before leaving in 1986 to join the Globe.

DOC.HEAD: VALENTINE'S: Red Letter Day for Roses and Chocolate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Oh, St. Valentine! How to capture the rapture? Does confection affirm affection? Do flowers floor? Or will it take a gold mine to get you to be mine? Valentine's Day _ colored rose red, punctuated with arrows from Cupid's bow, sweet as a bon bon and pretty as a bouquet _ actually has its roots in blood, gore, guts and gluttony. Historians say Valentine's Day began in the third century, when two Christian saints, both named Valentine, were executed. Because the martyrs' feast day, Feb. 14, was around the time of a pagan Roman festival called the Lupercalia, which celebrated fertility, St. Valentine was popularly designated the patron saint of lovers. It's been 1,720 years since the heathens had their way _ today, we shower oursweeties with perfume, jewelry, lingerie, candy and flowers. We'll also buy them pajamas, stuffed animals in all shapes, acrylic legs filled with German chocolate _ at $98 a limb at Macy's _ and Vietnamese potbellied pigs. Americans will give their Valentines $611 million worth of candy this year, about $2.50 in sweets for every man, woman and child, says Richard O'Connell, president of the National Confectioners Association. If that $611 million were translated into chocolate kisses at the New York City price of $5 a pound, about 93 kisses, it would buy 122.2 million pounds. If all those kisses were laid end to end, the chain of chocolate would circle the globe 6.4 times. If you don't want to make your baby a blimp, merchants have a few suggestions. Bloomingdale's has some ``really fun boxer shorts with hearts on them,'' said spokeswoman Jennifer Conner. They also have T-shirts with ``big red lips'' on them. The apparel will set you back about $20. Victoria's Secret, the mildly racy lingerie chain, offers toiletries for those who don't feel their relationships are up to intimate underthings. But business is still brisk in undies, said spokeswoman Laura Holbrook. ``Oversized satin T-shirts, silk camisoles and pants in rich gem colors like emerald, ruby, sapphire will be big,'' she said. A little more upscale, Bergdorf Goodman has red silk pajamas for $375, a matching robe for $375 and bath oil for $63 _ a mere $813 to get your sweetheart clean and ready for bed. Macy's Estate Jewelry department offers atomizers with cranberry-colored glass and sterling silver trim for $950. Always popular is the romantic staple _ a simple red rose. Seventy million roses will be sold for Valentine's Day, the biggest day of the year for rose sales, the Society of American Florists predicts. Eighty percent will be red, the rest mostly pink and yellow. The other Valentine tradition _ exchanging cards _ is booming, said Leslee Parsons, a spokeswoman for the American Greeting Corp. They expect more than 1 billion valentines to be given this year. School children give the most cards, she said. But back to the chocolate. The National Confectioner's Association says Americans' increasing health consciousness is actually boosting the industry. ``Americans are treating themselves to confections and sweets, but because they are more health conscious and working out, they don't feel as guilty,'' said spokesman Brian Muloney. ``In fact, there's more working out and pigging out.'' And there are some who will literally pig out. Paradise Pigs, which sells the latest trendy pet, Vietnamese potbellied pigs, says it has received orders for Valentine's Day pigs, which cost from $1,500 to $2,500 for males and about $5,000 for females. The pigs are prized because they stay small, ranging from 25 pounds to 150 pounds, and have sunny dispositions. ``For a lot of our customers, it's like having a kid,'' said Paradise Pig's owner, Kris Bryant. ``Husbands are buying them for their wives, men are buying them for their girlfriends.'' Bryant said her pigs try to knock the phone from her hand when they think she's been talking long enough; that might make them a good buy for parents of teen-agers. Be it a dozen roses or a porcine bundle of joy, most people will wonder about their Valentine's Day gift: Was it given sincerely or was it just an obligatory gesture? ``People spend a good deal of time wondering if a gift is sincere,'' said sociologist Hy Mariampolski. And givers also worry whether their presents will be enjoyed, he said. ``People are very insecure about gifts being appreciated so they fall into patterns of safe gift giving,'' said Mariampolski, who studies gift-giving habits for QualiData Research Inc. in New York. One way to make sure your gift is well-regarded is to personalize it, he said. ``It may be a bouquet of flowers,'' he said, ``but if a guy has it delivered to his girlfriend's doorstep by a strolling musician, it's going to be very special.''

DOC.HEAD: Participants Recalls The Trial That Changed South African History
An AP Extra
By DAVID CRARY
DOC.TEXT: In his first speech after leaving prison, Nelson Mandela repeated the most famous section of his last previous speech _ his statement from the dock at the 1964 Rivonia trial. It was a striking reminder of the importance of that trial, which resulted in life prison sentences for the core of the African National Congress' leadership. The trial took its name from the area near Johannesburg where Mandela's ANC colleagues were arrested in a police raid on a farmhouse used as a secret headquarters for the guerrilla movement. Mandela, already jailed for two years for his covert activities, and 10 other men went on trial, charged with sabotage and conspiring to overthrow the government. They faced possible execution if convicted. ``There was a very real fear of the death penalty,'' Arthur Chaskalson, one of the defense attorneys, said in an interview. ``Not until the last day were we sure it wouldn't be imposed.'' Several of the defendants, including Mandela, decided not to contest the sabotage charges. They contended the ANC's use of violence was a necessary last resort after the government rejected non-violent protest campaigns. Despite these admissions, the state summoned a parade of witnesses to bolster its case, including guerrillas-turned-infomers identifed as Mr. X and Mr. Y. Most witnesses ``lied shamelessly, purposefully and apparently to order,'' wrote Joel Joffe, another defense lawyer, in an unpublished account of the trial. He said most of the witnesses were held for long periods in solitary confinement and subjected to duress. Presiding in the high-ceilinged main chamber of Pretoria Supreme Court was Justice Quartus de Wet, described by Joffe as ``politically independent, but arrogant, prejudiced, tempermental.'' ``He was unquestionably sensitive to the needs of the white society which he believed in and upheld, and also of the government... He acted out their role, I think, unconsciously,'' Joffe wrote. Joffe later moved to Britain, where he became a businessman and a trustee of Oxfam, a private relief agency. Chaskalson and George Bizos, another member of the defense team, are among South Africa's most prominent civil rights lawyers. The head of their team, Bram Fischer, was arrested in September 1964, five months after the trial ended, on charges of membership in the outlawed Communist Party. He went underground while on bail, was caught in November 1965 and sentenced to life imprisonment. Stricken with cancer, he was allowed to move to a brother's home under house arrest, and died soon afterwards, in May 1975. Chaskalson said prison authorities took Fischer's ashes after he was cremated and never returned them to relatives. The prosecuter was Percy Yutar, described by Joffe as fond of ``bogus hysteria and fake dramatics.'' Yutar is still a practicing lawyer, but he refused to comment on the trial or Mandela's release. ``I'm not a politician, I'm a legal man,'' Yutar said. ``I don't discuss cases I have prosecuted.'' During the trial, Yutar scoffed at the ANC's assertion that it represented the wishes of the black majority. ``The deceit of the accused is amazing... They took it on themselves to tell the world that the Africans in South Africa are suppressed, oppressed and depressed,'' Yutar said. ``It is a great pity that the rank and file of the Bantu (blacks) in the country, who are peaceful, law-abiding, faithful and loyal, should have been duped by false promises.'' On April 20, 1964, Mandela entered the dock to explain why the ANC took up arms in pursuit of freedom. On Sunday, before tens of thousands of supporters in Cape Town, Mandela ended the first speech of his newfound freedom with the same words he used to conclude in Pretoria. ``During my lifetime, I have dedicated myself to this struggle of the African people. I have fought against white domination and I have fought against black domination,'' he said. ``I have cherished the ideal of a democratic and free society in which all persons live together in harmony and with equal opportunities. It is an ideal which I hope to live for and achieve, but, my Lord, if needs be, an ideal for which I am prepared to die.'' During the five-hour statement, recalled Joffe, ``the silence became more and more profound, until it seemed that no one in the court dared move or breathe.'' On June 12, 1964, Mandela and seven co-defendants were sentenced by de Wet to life in prison. He said sparing them from the gallows was the only leniency he could show. The defense lawyers, who had become close friends with the accused, felt both sadness and satisfaction. ``We'd done all we could,'' said Chaskalson. ``These were the leaders of the apartheid resistance. They conducted themselves with tremendous dignity _ they stated their cases so well, about why they went into revolt against the state.'' The only white man among those convicted, Dennis Goldberg, was freed in 1985 after he agreed to renounce violence. The others, except for Mandela, were freed unconditionally last October. De Wet is dead, as are Prime Minister Hendrik Verwoerd and Justice Minister B.J. Voster, who oversaw the police attempt to smash the ANC. All the convicted defendants are alive, the oldest being 80-year-old Govan Mbeki. Could it be said that, in some way, the defendants won the case, Chaskalson was asked. ``They certainly didn't lose,'' he replied. ``They had the moral high ground.''

DOC.HEAD: Will the Real St. Valentine Please Stand Up?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Valentine's Day
DOC.TEXT: The identity of the first St. Valentine is about as mysterious as love itself. Historians say Valentine's Day has its origins in the third century, when two Christian martyrs, both named Valentine, were executed. A pagan festival to fertility, called the Lupercalia, was still being celebrated at that time, and because it fell around the martyrs' Feb. 14 feast day, St. Valentine became the protector of lovers. The people of Terni, Italy, a steel-making town between Rome and Perugia, insist their St. Valentine was the one who started the annual day of love. The town's patron saint was beheaded Feb. 14 in the year 270, after having been imprisoned and whipped. Legend has it that Valentine had a garden where he let children play and lovers meet. While imprisoned, Valentine tied the keys of the garden gate to two pigeons with a message inviting the children to return to the garden. A version of the Terni story has Valentine, in his 76 years as bishop, giving lovers flowers from the garden. One couple who encountered the bishop enjoyed such a happy marriage that every couple wanted his blessing. The story is complicated by a second St. Valentine, also beheaded in the third century, in Rome, and who also has a feast day Feb. 14. But ``Valentine 2'' may not have been a saint at all. Some scholars say a church built on Rome's Via Flaminia by a man named Valentine somehow became known as St. Valentine's church, starting a legend about a non-existent saint. The Roman Catholic Church takes a neutral stance and designates no patron saint of lovers. The Vatican Congregation for the Causes of Saints says 17 Valentines are listed in the official encyclopedia of saints, including ones from Italy, France, Spain and Germany. Terni's bishop, Franco Gualdrini, also refuses to claim his town's saint as the definitive champion of love. ``It is a popular tradition,'' Gualdrini once said of the adulation St. Valentine now receives. ``Some things are proclaimed from above, some are proclaimed from below.''

DOC.HEAD: Apartheid Still Rules Mandela's New World
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: By BARRY RENFREW
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: When Nelson Mandela walks the streets of Johannesburg after 27 years in prison, he will see signs of dramatic change in the apartheid system. He will also see stark reminders of what has not changed. Mandela will see blacks in jobs and areas where they would have been banned a few years ago by apartheid laws enforcing segregation of the country's races. But he will still be banned from living in white areas, his grandchildren will be banned from white schools and he and his family will still be registered as blacks with no political rights. ``The black majority _ three quarters of the population _ still has no parliamentary vote and Pretoria shows no sign of getting rid of its ideological cornerstones,'' The Sowetan newspaper commented. Apartheid, the legal segregation of South Africa's whites, blacks, Asians and mixed-race people, still survives in many forms despite efforts by President F.W. de Klerk's to ease the system. The government says it has no immediate plans to abolish apartheid laws segregating residential areas and classifying people by race. Mandela said after leaving prison Sunday that South Africa could never have peace until all vestiges of apartheid were destroyed. ``Apartheid's destruction on our subcontinent is incalculable. The fabric of family life of millions of my people has been shattered,'' he said. De Klerk freed Mandela on Feb. 11 after legalizing the African National Congress and other anti-apartheid groups to try and clear the way for talks with the black majority on ending white rule and sharing political power. Johannesburg and other big cities have seen major changes in recent years as some apartheid laws have been repealed or are just ignored. Central areas of Johannesburg, once dominated by whites, are increasingly black and restaurants, shops, cinemas and other facilites are open to all races. Many aspects of so-called ``petty apartheid,'' such as separate public toilets, park benches and segregated restaurants, have disappeared. Some major apartheid laws have been abolished, including regulations requiring blacks to have passes to enter white areas and racial restrictions on jobs. Also gone are ``morality laws'' that imposed prison sentences on people of different races who married or had sex. It is a striking change from the days when all blacks were expected to address whites as ``boss.'' But the changes in Johannesburg and other relatively liberal cities have not been matched in many smaller towns and rural districts where many people live. Many blacks living around Victor Verster prison outside Cape Town where Mandela was held still call whites ``master'' or ``boss.'' When Mandela was jailed in 1962 the apartheid system segregating whites and blacks was approaching its peak. The white government said blacks could never be more than laborers and the racial superiority of whites was the de facto creed of the country. Hendrik Verwoerd, a former prime minister who did much to design and build apartheid, said during a 1954 Senate debate on black education: ``There is no place for him (blacks) above the level of certain forms of labor ... What is the use of teaching a Bantu (black) child mathematics when it cannot use it in practice.'' Hundreds of thousands of blacks were forcibly relocated from towns or good farmland to barren country areas to make room for whites. A typical schoolbook for white children taught that blacks were inferior. ``The white stands on a much higher plane of civilization and is more developed. Whites must so live, learn and work that we shall not sink to the cultural level of the non-white,'' it said. While de Klerk says he is committed to ending white-minority rule, he says it must not be replaced by ``black domination.'' The government has indicated it wants ``group rights'' or special status for whites in any deal with blacks. Mandela and other black leaders say only equal rights can ensure the rights of all South Africans and group rights would just be another form of apartheid. ``Today, the majority of South Africans, black and white, recognize that apartheid has no future. It has to be ended by our own decisive mass action in order to build peace and security,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: `Hard to Kill' with Steven Seagal, Nation's No. 1 Film
DOC.TEXT: Moviegoers found ``Hard to Kill'' easy to watch as the action-adventure film starring martial arts expert Steven Seagal chopped its way to the top of the box office with a $9.2 million opening last weekend. The story of a Los Angeles detective who wakes up from a seven-year coma and avenges his family's murder debuted impressively despite apparently being held in low regard by its studio and star. Warner Bros. failed to screen the film for critics, and even Seagal has badmouthed it repeatedly. The film collected $7,082 per screen to lead the top 10, Exhibitor Relations Co. said Monday. Cruising along in second place was ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' featuring Jessica Tandy and Morgan Freeman in a comedy about a Southern widow and her black chaffeur. The film grossed $6.5 million. Disney's remake of ``Stella,'' staring Bette Midler, fell from first to third with receipts of $3.7 million, followed by the anti-war saga ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' which slipped 25 percent to fourth place with sales of $3 million. The new picture, ``Loose Cannons,'' teaming Gene Hackman and Dan Aykroyd, came in fifth with $2.2 million. ``Stanley & Iris,'' the story of adult illiteracy with Jane Fonda and Robert De Niro, weakly debuted in sixth with $2.1 million. In seventh was the action-adventure movie ``Tango & Cash'' with $1.8 million. The black divorce comedy ``The War of the Roses'' landed in eighth place on a box-office collection of $1.73 million. The police thriller ``Internal Affairs'' was ninth with $1.71 million, and the ensemble drama ``Steel Magnolias'' was 10th on sales of $1.6 million. ``Time of the Gypsies,'' the last Columbia release developed by ousted studio head David Puttnam, opened on two screens with a very average haul of $23,476. The film has to be dubbed in every movie house in the world because the dialogue is composed in an extinct gypsy language. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Monday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Hard to Kill,'' Warner Bros., $9.2 million (weekend gross), 1,301 screens, $7,082 per screen, $9.2 million (total gross), one week in review. 2. ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' Tri-Star, $6.5 million, 1,302 screens, $4,988 per screen, $32.9 million, nine weeks. 3. ``Stella,'' Disney, $3.7 million, 1,213 screens, $3,010 per screen, $9.3 million, two weeks. 4. ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' Universal, $3 million, 1,295 screens, $2,320 per screen, $48.4 million, eight weeks. 5. ``Loose Cannons,'' Tri-Star, $2.2 million, 1,214 screens, $1,845 per screen, $2.2 million, one week. 6. ``Stanley & Iris,'' MGM-UA, $2.1 million, 907 screens, $2,318 per screen, $2.1 million, one week. 7. ``Tango & Cash,'' Warner Bros., $1.8 million, 1,288 screens, $1,384 per screen, $56.2 million, eight weeks. 8. ``The War of the Roses,'' 20th Century Fox, $1.73 million, 1,054 screens, $1,643 per screen, $77.5 million, 10 weeks. 9. ``Internal Affairs,'' Paramount, $1.71 million, 983 screens, $1,743 per screen, $22 million, five weeks. 10. ``Steel Magnolias,'' Tri-Star, $1.6 million, 1,328 screens, $1,210 per screen, $69.3 million, 13 weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Upheavals in East Bloc Diminish Support for Arab Radicals
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The fall of hard-line Communist governments across Eastern Europe will deprive the PLO and other Arab groups of weapons and training. Until recently, Romania, Czechoslovakia, East Germany and Poland provided varying degrees of material and political support to the PLO and other groups. The aid has now been halted or reduced. ``These countries provided training, weapons, served as host facilities for terrorist organizations and sometimes provided sabotage materials,'' said Mark Heller, an analyst at Tel Aviv University's Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies in Israel. ``I wouldn't be surprised if that activity stopped completely,'' he added. Poland, under the new government of Premier Tadeusz Mazowiecki, last year withdrew a small stipend it gave to the PLO's diplomatic mission in Warsaw. Czechoslovakia used to export $540 million worth of arms a year _ some of it to the Middle East _ but will halt all weapons exports when present agreements expire, Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier says. Polish officials say Warsaw intends to treat every Arab country equally and that ideology has been eliminated as a factor in Polish foreign relations. Krzysztof Plominski, the Foreign Ministry's deputy department director for Arab and African affairs, last month said Poland ``opposes any form of terrorism.'' U.S. government sources reported in early 1988 that the terrorist Abu Nidal had used a Warsaw trading office as a front for his organization. The office was closed, apparently at request of the Polish government. Czechoslovak and Romanian officials deny any aid to Arab radicals since their revolutions. ``Yes, there was military and training support to what you can call Libyan terrorists, but all of that has been suspended today,'' a Czechoslovak Foreign Ministry official told The Associated Press. He spoke on condition his name not be used. Czechoslovak officials said training camps for hundreds of Libyans and other Arab radicals existed in at least one Interior Ministry school near Kladno, 20 miles west of Prague. They said it is now closed. According to the Israeli Government Press Office, East Germany also provided training to PLO guerrillas, some of it was at the Friedrich Engels Academy in Dresden. In addition to helping radicals fight, Czechoslovakia and other countries often supplied material help to Mideast and North African countries. At least $1 billion worth of Czechoslovak machinery and construction projects were provided to Arab countries, according to official figures in Prague. Romania, which from the late 1970s trained hundreds of PLO guerrillas at bases in the Black Sea port of Constanta, the southern town of Calarasi and near Bucharest, said in January it had abrogated agreements concluded by toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. The Foreign Ministry said without further detail it discovered secret agreements that violated international law. Romania's former counter-intelligence chief, Gen. Ion Pacepa, who defected to the United States in 1978, said in his book ``Red Horizons'' that Bucharest gave the PLO arms and hundreds of forged passports. Romania, East Germany and Czechoslovakia all maintained cordial relations with PLO leader Yasser Arafat and regularly hosted him as a guest of state. In 1988 the PLO offices in those countries were elevated to the status of embassies. As an indication of how things are changing, Czechoslovakia resumed diplomatic relations with Israel last week and East Germany is considering reparations to Jews who suffered in the Holocaust of World War II. West German officials suspect the former East German leadership allowed Arab terrorists to cross into West Berlin. In April 1986, when two U.S. soldiers and a Turkish woman were killed and 230 people injured in the bombing of a West Berlin discotheque, West German and U.S. officials said they believed the attack was planned and executed by the Libyan embassy in East Berlin. Other terrorists acts carried out from East Berlin by Arabs included the bombing of the German Arab Friendship Society in West Berlin's Kreuzberg district in March 1986, believed to have been organized by a Syrian.

DOC.HEAD: ANC And South African Government Leaders Join In TV Debate
With PM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Seated in a Johannesburg television studio a few feet from an African National Congress leader, Foreign Minister Pik Botha of South Africa described followers of the black guerrilla movement as ``my friends.'' The ANC's Ahmed Kathrada, released a year ago after 26 years in jail, said nothing really had changed but that he didn't doubt the sincerity or integrity of the white government leaders. His face lined and somber, Jeff Masomola of the smaller, militant black nationalist Pan African Congress dismissed negotiations as futile. Only immediate universal suffrage for the 5-1 black majority, he said, ``will result in the taking over of this country by the people who own it.'' Veteran white liberal politician Helen Suzman chided Botha for ``making the sort of speeches I made 30 years ago.'' All were guests on the British Broadcasting Corp.'s ``Panorama'' current affairs program beamed live from Johannesburg in what the network said was the first such appearance by South African leaders from across almost the entire political spectrum. Only the far-right white opposition Conservative Party refused to come to the studio because its followers object to sitting in a room with ANC members. Conservative Party spokesman Koos van der Merwe made his contribution in a separate recording. ``He (Nelson Mandela) came out of that jail (on Sunday) without having given in one inch of his demands,'' said van der Merwe. ``They are not interested in peace or democracy. They want complete capitulation of the white people.'' No one raised their voices or interrupted throughout Monday night's nearly one-hour program. Apart from two giant drawings of ANC leader Nelson Mandela in the background, the atmosphere resembled that of a leisurely late night talk show about the modern novel. In the studio audience, several whites expressed unease or resentment about the insistence by Mandela, released on Sunday after 27 years in jail, that the armed struggle should continue. Some of the blacks wondered why, after decades of apartheid, blacks were now supposed to help allay white fears. But a black businessman suggested blacks and whites should each imagine how it felt to be the other at this momentous time in their country's history. A white student seated alongside a young black woman with the ANC colors pinned on her school uniform said he was confident of a future where race no longer mattered. Chief Mangosotho Buthelezi, leader of South Africa's largest tribe and its Inkhata movement, was equally confident that once round a negotiating table, South Africans would find a way. ``Blacks and whites in this country have become interdependent,'' said Buthelezi, who rejects ANC violence but refuses to take independece for his fragmented KwaZulu homeland under apartheid's now abandoned grand plan of giving the white minority permanent control. Challenged by van der Merwe from offstage to say whether the government was prepared to yield to ANC demands of universal suffrage in a unitary state, Botha looked weary. ``My government has insisted that whatever constitution is agreed upon must have majority support,'' said Botha. ``How we are going to do it will be for the various parties to decide.'' He paused and added, ``With all respect to my friends in the ANC, if they think for one moment that some of their policies are going to be accepted by a majority of South Africans, including black South Africans, I say to them they are going to be in for a surprise.''

DOC.HEAD: Beach Invaded by Oily Goo, Patched-Up Ship too Dirty to Move
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf, `On Monday ...,' to UPDATE with ship dropping anchor in Long Beach Harbor.
DOC.TEXT: Waves of grimy crude oil spilled by a tanker invaded a two-mile stretch of Southern California beach Monday near a refuge for endangered pelicans and other birds. Authorities closed about 10 miles of popular surfing and sunbathing beaches to the public for at least three weeks because of the health threat posed by fumes from the oil. Cleanup crews dispatched to the fouled Bolsa Chica State Beach discovered what authorities called the most serious beach pollution since the spill of an estimated 400,000 gallons Wednesday. The tanker American Trader apparently punctured itself twice on its own anchor as it maneuvered near a submerged pipeline about two miles offshore. ``We got hit with more oil overnight than we have in this whole process,'' said Tony Kozlowski, spokesman for cleanup coordinator British Petroleum Co. PLC, which chartered the tanker, American Trader. ``It was an unbelievable sight,'' Huntington Beach Mayor Tom Mays said after a helicopter tour. ``We got hit pretty bad last night and it's continuing today.'' Black waves glistening in the sun crashed to shore despite the efforts of a flotilla of boats working to trap the encroaching goo with containment booms. The oily onslaught is near the inland Bolsa Chica Wetlands, an ecological reserve that is home to the endangered California brown pelican as well as a temporary home to thousands of migratory birds and much marine life. At Bolsa Chica, 20 miles south of downtown Los Angeles, the slick ran along two miles of beach, about 30 feet wide and 2 inches deep. Smaller ribbons of oil 4 feet wide were reported near the Huntington Beach Pier about 5 miles to the south, the Coast Guard said. Cleanup crews worked along a 20-mile stretch of beach from Bolsa Chica south to Laguna Beach. The cleanup at Bolsa Chica was suspended briefly when workers began complaining of headaches and nausea from the oily fumes. But by midday, more than 400 cleanup workers were on the beach, Kozlowski said. ``There is no oil in the estuary,'' said Patrick Moore of the state Department of Fish and Game. ``But birds are leaving the wetlands and going to the ocean and bringing the oil back to the estuary.'' Seventy-one dead birds _ grebes, gulls, loons and pelicans _ have been found in the area, and another 222 oil-soaked birds were rescued alive and taken to a treatment center, Moore said. On Monday evening, the 811-foot American Tanker dropped anchor just inside the Long Beach Harbor breakwater after receiving Coast Guard permission to do so. The move had been delayed until the ship was declared clean enough to enter the harbor. Scuba divers applied temporary patches to two holes in the punctured hull Sunday, and authorities said the vessel passed ``watertight integrity'' tests. One-third of the estimated 400,000 gallons of Alaskan crude still menaced the coast, the Coast Guard said. Skimmers picked up 23 percent of the spill and 43 percent evaporated or naturally dissipated. City and state beaches from Anaheim Bay south through in Huntington Beach _ about 10 miles in all _ were closed for an indefinite period, with a three-week minimum. Authorities cited the danger of fumes from the oil. ``It is of vital importance to keep people off the beaches. The contaminated birds are frightened by the crowds on the beach and will not come ashore where they can be safely rescued,'' said biologist Esther Burkett of Fish and Game. U.S. Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., viewed the beaches from a helicopter, then criticized President Bush for telling a news conference Monday that the spill shouldn't be used to bolster arguments against offshore oil drilling. Bush said a tanker accident wasn't an indictment of drilling platform safety. ``The president should read the environmental impact statements by his own Department of the Interior, which point out that the more drilling platforms that you have, the more tankers you will need,'' said Cranston. On the beach, politicians, environmentalists and celebrities gathered to demand legislation at the federal and state levels requiring double hulls for tankers and other safeguards. ``It makes no difference what the damn cost is,'' actor James Garner said of the expense of double-hulled tankers. ``What matters is the environment. ... The money doesn't mean anything;, the environment does.'' Congress is considering laws requiring double-hulled tankers. On the state level, California Attorney General John Van de Kamp endorsed an initiative calling for a cleanup superfund.

DOC.HEAD: Royal Blush: Valentines Show Monarchs' Composed Passion
LaserPhoto LON1
DOC.TEXT: King Henry VIII's love letters to Anne Boleyn _ eight years before he ordered her beheaded _ are part of a display of royal valentines that show the soppy side of Britain's rulers. ``Mine own sweetheart, these shall be to advertise you of the great aloneness that I find here since your departing,'' said Henry's letter, signed H.R. and dated 1528. The R stands for Rex, Latin for king. The impulsive king's testaments of ardor are among 100 transcribed documents on view that span more than 450 years. Some of the letters are steamy, some heartfelt and many dispel historical cliches, said Michele Brown, curator of the valentine display, which is part of the Royal Britain exhibition at London's Barbican center. King Edward VII, who reigned from 1901-1910, was known as ``Edward the Caresser,'' for his involvement with mistresses, including actress Lillie Langtry, Ms. Brown said. ``While you'd expect him to be the great wooer with words, and his letters an absolute hotbed of passion and love, all he talks about is the weather,'' she said. However, his mother and father, Queen Victoria and Prince Albert, exchanged letters that contradict the sometimes icy image of the couple, the curator said. ``The textbook view is that Victoria was absolutely besotted by Albert and he was a cold fish and laid back and thought about England all of the time, but the letters are very revealing,'' Ms. Brown said. Albert wrote to Victoria just before they were married in 1840: ``Dearest, best beloved Victoria _ Already another dear, dear, letter from you which has wholly charmed me, for it once again tells me you love me, and proves that you love me truly and faithfully ... Do you remember how I warmed your dear little hands every day in the lovely little blue room? In quiet hours I live on such memories. Good, dear, charming Victoria, in my thoughts I am very much with you.'' The most recent letters in the exhibition are those of King Edward VIII, who abdicated the throne in 1936 to marry American divorcee Wallis Warfield Simpson. Addressing her as ``my own darling peaches,'' Edward wrote before they married: ``God! I love you my Wallis my beloved sweetheart, more and more and more. I'm holding so tight all the time until that dear lovely precious day. Oh! God make it come quickly and bless WE (Wallis and Edward) this year and always!'' The letters were published after the Duchess of Windsor died in 1986 because she wanted to correct the impression that she had lured the king from his throne. The copies were made from love letters found in the Public Record Office, the Royal Collection and other repositories, Ms. Brown said. ``The letters from Henry VIII to Anne Boleyn are in the Vatican library because they were relevant to his divorce, which led to the split of the Roman Catholic Church and the Church of England,'' Ms. Brown explained. Ms. Brown said she believes today's royals are unlikely to leave behind many interesting love letters. ``The letters (on display) are all well-thought out and composed, they're not the odd bashed out note,'' she said. ``I'm afraid the telephone has taken over now and there are very few love letters.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush: No More Gestures Toward South Africa For Now
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says he will await the expected visit of South African President F. W. de Klerk before deciding whether to respond to the release of Nelson Mandela by improving relations with that country. Bush is barred by law from lifting U.S. sanctions against South Africa until specific reforms are adopted, and there is strong support in Congress for keeping the sanctions in place as a lever to encourage additional dismantling of white supremacist rule. The sanctions impose severe restrictions on American investment in South Africa and purchases of the country's exports. The Congressional Black Caucus issued a statement Monday saying any talk of lifting the sanctions is premature. But there are other overtures the administration could make toward South Africa in recognition of de Klerk's fresh approach toward the country's black majority. The United States could make some gestures to ease South Africa's international isolation by dispatching a high-level emissary to Pretoria or by engaging in efforts to ease United Nations restrictions on dealing with that country. Although Bush seemed in no hurry to act on any options, there was little doubt Mandela's release and other gestures improved the atmosphere considerably between Washington and Pretoria. Bush alluded to the warming on Monday when he called Mandela's release after 27 years in prison ``another important sign that South Africa may soon begin negotiating a democratic non-racial society and at last be on the way to ending apartheid once and for all.'' The State Department said it was heartened by the moderate tone of Mandela's remarks since his release on Sunday. ``We found noteworthy his expression of hope that a climate conducive to a negotiated settlement would be created soon so that there may no longer be the need for armed struggle,'' it said. Official contacts between the two countries dropped off sharply after the sanctions were imposed by Congress in 1986 over then-President Reagan's veto. Now de Klerk is preparing to become the first South African president to visit the United States. The administration issued separate invitations to de Klerk and Mandela to visit Washington but no dates have been set. Bush told a news conference Monday he wants to discuss the sanctions issue with both de Klerk and Mandela and said the two South Africans also should negotiate. ``And then out of that, I think we'll have a much more realistic picture of what the United States might do in the future,'' he said. Bush added that a White House visit by de Klerk would be a ``major step'' in U.S.-South African relations, but that more substantive action would not be appropriate until afterward. Bush said he finds some of the sanctions counterproductive and played down the suggestion that they had a key role in inducing South Africa to signal moves toward a more equitable political system. ``What's really changed is the mindset of the South African leadership,'' Bush said. ``I think that we ought to give Mr. de Klerk certain credit for being able to look much more realistically about political change, and hopefully, more favorably about a society that eventually eliminates this racism that is equated with apartheid.'' As for the U.S. sanctions, the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act stipulated that before they could be lifted, South Africa had to free all political prisoners and meet at least three of four other conditions. De Klerk already has met one of the conditions by legalizing the African National Congress and other anti-apartheid groups. But Senate Democratic Leader George Mitchell of Maine said, ``The essence of these conditions is the dismantling of the South African laws which are the foundation of their system of racial segregation. ``No fundamental change has been made in that direction yet, and such change must occur before we can consider lifting sanctions,'' Mitchell said in a statement. Other conditions include release of other political prisoners; repeal of the state of emergency and freeing of all those detained under it; repeal of laws which restrict where non-whites can live and work, and government agreement to enter good-faith negotiations with representatives of the black majority.

DOC.HEAD: Building Soviet Opposition Parties an Unfamiliar Task
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: He is 32, an intense young man bent on political change, dealing in the familiar fare of issues, endorsements and voter opinion as he looks toward the 1990 campaign. Men and women like him do the daily business of U.S. politics as the executive directors of state Democratic and Republican parties. While their tasks are comparable, their challenges are not. For Arkadiy Murashev is secretary to a fledgling opposition movement in the Soviet Union, seeking to build a political party, not just manage one. Murashev, a Moscow physicist come to political life when his scientist colleagues nominated him for the Congress of People's Deputies, told of the work and aims of his movement in sometimes halting English. He was in Washington in what might seem unlikely company, on a 10-day visit sponsored by conservative political activists. The Free Congress Foundation and its president, Paul Weyrich, were his sponsors and guides at a series of sessions with conservative groups, government officials and members of Congress. Weyrich and six other conservative political tacticians went to Eastern Europe and to Moscow last fall on a two-week political training mission. Murashev was one of about 45 Soviet participants. The Soviet political rules changed while he was in Washington, as leaders of the Communist Party agreed to relinquish its guarantee of monopoly power and to permit the creation of opposition parties. ``We must move with the tide, must move with the people, and not be left behind by events,'' said government spokesman Gennadi Gerasimov. Murashev said the changes adapted to reality. ``This plenum declared the situation that already existed in the Soviet Union,'' he told a group of conservative activists and congressmen. ``And when we return, for us, it's no change.'' He is secretary of the Interregional Group, an opposition umbrella group claiming ties with about 400 of the 2,250 members of the Congress of People's Deputies. Its leading figure is Boris Yeltsin, the one member of the Communist Central Committee who voted against Mikhail S. Gorbachev's political reform plan because he contends it doesn't go far enough. Yeltsin wants an immediate change to a multi-party democratic system and a free market economy. Gorbachev has liberalized the Soviet political system gradually over the past five years, changes that permitted formation of the Interregional Group and other movements. The Congress of People's Deputies was created as part of the Gorbachev reform movement; it first met in 1989. The opposition has a foothold there; about 10 percent of its delegates are not members of the Communist Party. That legislative body meets again late in the spring and is to consider the constitutional changes the communist leadership agreed to last Wednesday. Strictly speaking, the Interregional Group is not a political party. ``Theoretically, they haven't had other parties,'' Weyrich said. ``But it has all the attributes of a party.'' The group sponsors and supports candidates in Soviet elections. It has a platform and takes positions on issues. It is organizing for regional elections late this winter and early in the spring, balloting comparable to state legislative elections in the United States. Murashev won his seat in the Congress of People's Deputies last year, with 54 percent of the vote in a four-way race. Among the rivals he beat to win a five-year term was the district Communist Party secretary. At the time, Murashev was a candidate for Communist Party membership, a process that takes a year. When he became eligible in December, Murashev said, he declined membership. ``I refused to be a communist after that.'' By his account, the competition in Soviet elections so far has been dominated by personalities and their chosen issues. ``Tell me, this candidate, is he against Yeltsin or with him?'' Murashev said voters would ask him. He said people also look for lists of candidates favored by the Interregional Group. ``They say if you give us the list of candidates, we will be voting for them,'' he said. Murashev thinks more formal party structures will follow soon, beginning with the equivalent of a European social democratic party. That's already happening in independence-minded Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. At first, he said, the fledgling opposition parties probably will cooperate, going into competition with one another as the process matures. For all the speed of reform so far, that may take time. The Communist Party may yield its constitutional dominance, but it will still have the money, the manpower, the organization, the know-how, all the components of political power. It also has jobs _ patronage on a scale no American political boss could have imagined. Obstacles notwithstanding, Murashev told the conservatives that Soviet political reform cannot be undone now. ``The process in the Soviet Union has gone so far, it has become irreversible,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 26 years.

DOC.HEAD: Banks Need to Do Better Job on Real Estate Portfolio, Regulator Says
DOC.TEXT: Banks with growing portfolios of sour real estate loans need to do a better job, a top federal regulator says. ``Over the last year ... examination activity has revealed a significant number of fundamental deficiencies and negative trends in national bank real estate lending which require immediate attention,'' Comptroller of the Currency Robert L. Clarke said in a strongly worded memorandum released Monday. The memo to board members and chief executive officers at 4,200 nationally charted banks singled out three areas for criticism. First, ``basic lending principles have been ignored or compromised to increase volume and achieve higher levels of interest and fee income,'' Clarke said. In particular, banks are not requiring borrowers to invest enough of their own money in real estate projects. Second, ``too many banks have failed to obtain accurate, independent and timely appraisals'' of the real estate projects to which they are lending. And third, some banks are engaging in practices that make it difficult to determine when a real estate project is going bad. Those include inflating the loan amount so borrowers can cover the interest payments in the early years of the loan and operating with incomplete or non-existent foreclosure policies. Clarke's warning follows earlier reports of a big increase in real estate problems in New England and Arizona, on top of existing problems in the oil-producing states of Texas, Oklahoma and Louisiana. The level of sour real estate loans at national banks in New England hit $2 billion at the end of September, representing 6 percent of their real estate portfolio, quadruple the default rate of two years ago. In Arizona, national banks listed $825 million in bad real estate loans, 20 percent of the total. Bank of New England Corp., the region's second-largest bank holding company, alone reported a $1.05 billion loss in 1989, raising questions among analysts about whether it can survive. Bank management should ``initiate corrective action promptly,'' Clarke said. Examiners have ``been and will continue to be aggressive ... (and) have been instructed to recommend formal enforcement actions as appropriate.'' The get-tough policy of his examiners has prompted complaints from builders and others in New England that reliable and solvent borrowers were being denied credit. Clarke said nothing in the memo ``is intended to discourage sound real estate ... lending'' and that ``the vast majority of national banks have not deviated from traditional high lending standards.''

DOC.HEAD: Labor Wants More Time to Mull Abortion Issue
DOC.TEXT: The AFL-CIO is likely to continue a decade of dodging the abortion issue, even though some elements of the labor federation want to adopt a pro-choice stand at next week's winter meeting in Florida. ``We have enough to say grace over without taking on the abortion issue,'' said Duke McVey, president of the Missouri State Labor Council AFL-CIO. Still, behind-the-scenes maneuvering on whether the 14.1 million member federation should support legalized abortion or sit the issue out is expected to dominate much of the Executive Council meeting in Bal Harbour, where the AFL-CIO's 33-member board gathers each February. Pro-choice union officials fear the council, which has sidestepped a stand for more than a decade, will ultimately stay neutral. ``The majority of them are male. They're not children; they're getting up there in years and are kind of fixed in their attitudes. They may not want to bite on this,'' said Jay Foreman, executive vice president of the United Food and Commercial Workers International Union. ``The question is whether they want to take any risks.'' Foreman and other pro-choice labor leaders think the issue has workplace ramifications because it affects the economic well-being of working women and raises questions of health care coverage and the ability of health care workers to do their job. But other union officials, including McVey, say abortion ``has nothing to do with 40 hours a week or 20 bucks an hour.'' ``It splits our members and it doesn't address wages, hours or conditions of employment,'' McVey said. A number of rank-and-file union members ``feel very strongly about the issue. They don't support their union doing that kind of activity and they don't want to pay dues to a union that does,'' McVey said. Yet several pro-choice union leaders noted the AFL-CIO historically has gotten involved in issues not directly related to collective bargaining, such as civil rights and school busing. Pro-choice union officials, trying to counter a National Right to Life letter-writing campaign that asks the AFL-CIO to refuse to take a stand, are pressing for adoption of a pro-choice resolution. That would put the federation in line with the stance taken by many of its political allies, such as the Democratic Party and various women's and civil rights groups. At a convention last fall of delegates from all 90 AFL-CIO unions, the delegates declined to adopt any of the half dozen pro-choice resolutions submitted, and instead referred them to the Executive Council. There is no organized move afoot for the federation to condemn abortion. William Wynn, president of the United Food and Commercial Workers International Union and a pro-choice member of the council, chairs the committee that will determine whether the federation should take a position. Wynn predicted the committee ``will be able to come to a definitive conclusion that will be responsive to everybody's feelings, everybody's emotions. I tend to believe we have the intelligence to do that.'' He said the panel might be able to adopt a pro-choice position as long as it agreed on language acknowledging moral and religious concerns. But if the panel fails to recommend a pro-choice position, it would likely draft a statement explaining why the federation should stay away from the issue, he said. Sponsors of last fall's pro-choice resolutions urged the council to act by the February meeting. That would have allowed labor to use the decision as it begins making early decisions on 1990 political candidates. But even the strongest pro-choice officials said abortion would not serve as a litmus test for candidates. ``It's not critical to the election cycle. We're not a single-issue group,'' Foreman said. Anti-abortion candidates ``who were with us in every other way'' could still win labor's endorsement, he said. The labor movement has longstanding ties to the Roman Catholic Church, and some opponents of last fall's pro-choice resolutions said that taking such a stand could hurt union organizing among blue-collar Catholics.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Sylvester Stallone, John Travolta, Pia Zadora and Bo Derek were among the nominees for Razzie Awards for the decade's most dreadful performers. The Golden Raspberry Foundation, a group of film fans who celebrate the worst in cinema, announced nominees Monday for the 10th Razzie Awards. Christopher Atkins, Ryan O'Neal, Prince, Stallone and Travolta were nominated for worst actor of the decade. The nominees for worst actress of the '80s were Miss Derek, Faye Dunaway, Madonna, Brooke Shields and Miss Zadora. The nominees for worst new star of the decade nominees were Atkins, Madonna, Prince, Miss Zadora and Diana Scarwid of ``Silkwood.'' Nominated as the worst films of the 1980s were Miss Derek's ``Bolero,'' ``Howard the Duck,'' Miss Zadora's ``The Lonely Lady,'' Miss Dunaway's ``Mommie Dearest'' and ``Star Trek V.'' The nominations are determined by ballots from more than 275 Raspberry Foundation members in 22 states, Canada and Switzerland, the foundation said. The awards will be presented on March 25, the night before the Academy Awards.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Former baseball commissioner Bowie Kuhn said he and his wife moved to Florida to start a new life, not to hide from creditors of his former law firm. ``The decline and ultimate failure of Myerson & Kuhn was a traumatic experience for both of us and its aftereffects continue to be,'' Kuhn said Monday. ``We both felt a change of environs was a necessity for our happiness and health. The months we have spent in Florida have thoroughly pursuaded us of the wisdom of this decision.'' Myerson & Kuhn collapsed in December and Marine Midland bank claims the firm owes it $3.1 million in outstanding loans. The firm charged in court papers last week that Kuhn sold his house in Ridgewood, N.J., and moved to Pontre Vedra Beach, Fla., in an attempt to put his assets out of reach. Florida law does not allow residences to be attached. Kuhn denied the charges. ``The intimations in the press that I have hidden from the Myerson & Kuhn creditors are unfair,'' Kuhn said in a statement. The former commissioner said he had created a Florida corporation named the Kent Group Inc., and that he would become a consultant through the corporation in sports and other business areas.

Roger Ailes, a top media adviser for Presidents Bush and Reagan, has teamed up with columnist Liz Smith of the Daily News to make two TV specials. Ailes is serving as executive producer of the specials, which have the working title of ``Liz Smith Profiles,'' according to Jeff Erdell, a spokesman for Times Square Studios, where the specials were taped. One show is about veteran CBS correspondent Mike Wallace, the other about singer Wayne Newton, Erdell said Monday. He said the Fox network expects to broadcast the shows this spring. Dom Giofre, a Fox spokesman, said the shows are regarded as a pilot for possible series.

The Rev. Jerry Falwell, who once battled to keep Jim Bakker away from PTL, says the 45-year prison sentence given to the fallen television evangelist is too harsh. ``No doubt a debt to society had to be paid, but 45 years is unreasonable,'' Falwell said Sunday night before preaching at Calvary Church. U.S. District Judge Robert Potter sentenced Bakker in October for defrauding followers who had sent him $158 million in exchange for lodging guarantees at PTL's Heritage USA Christian retreat in nearby Fort Mill, S.C. Falwell took over at PTL following Bakker's March 1987 resignation in a sex and money scandal involving former church secretary Jessica Hahn. Falwell resigned six months later, after Bakker announced he wanted to return to the ministry. ``I think everybody here _ including the court _ just got caught up in the spectacular nature of what was going on,'' Falwell said. ``Had Bakker's sentence been 10 to 15 years, I don't think there would have been a grumble anywhere in the country.''

Pete Seeger will give a benefit concert Saturday to celebrate the 90th birthday of author Meridel Le Sueur, who documented people's struggles during the Depression. ``Pete Seeger. I've known him for 60 years. ... He was part of the struggle, like Woody Guthrie,'' said Le Sueur, who turns 90 on Feb. 22. ``I had people's speech, they had people's song. For the people you've grown with in militant struggle, there's an affection you can't express.'' Le Sueur broke into the mainstream in 1927 with the publication of her short story ``Persephone'' in Dial magazine. Her career flowered in the 1930s, when her works were published in many journals, newspapers and magazines, and reached a peak in 1940 with the publication of ``Salute to Spring,'' an anthology praised by Sinclair Lewis and Carl Sandburg.

Andy Rooney says he's been getting ``incredible'' support from colleagues and strangers since his suspension by CBS for racial remarks attributed to him by a magazine. ``It's like being at your own funeral. People I didn't even know liked me have come to my support,'' Rooney said Monday. A CBS spokesman said the network's audience services unit has received about 2,600 phone calls backing Rooney and 45 supporting his suspension. Rooney last week was ordered suspended for three months by CBS News President David Burke after The Advocate, a biweekly homosexual-oriented magazine based in Los Angeles, quoted him as saying blacks have watered down their genes because ``the less intelligent ones are the ones that have the most children.'' The 69-year-old humorist has denied the remarks.

DOC.HEAD: Legislator's Contest Draws 500 Suggestions For New Laws
DOC.TEXT: Illinois residents who entered a legislator's ``There Ought To Be A Law Contest'' say they want more public toilets, lower taxes, a change in election scheduling and no kissing in cars. State Rep. Larry Wennlund said Monday that 500 such ideas have arrived at his New Lenox office in response to the contest he calls an experiment in ``real grassroots democracy.'' Eileen Bludeau of Oak Park suggested election days be scheduled on Sundays so more people could vote. And C.H. West of Northbrook said there ought to be a law against talking on car phones while driving. ``People have good ideas _ good, practical ideas,'' said Wennlund, whose northern Illinois district includes some of Chicago's southern suburbs. ``This is just a way to get those ideas to somebody who can do something about them.'' The Republican legislator advertised the contest last month, asking entrants to tell him in 100 words or less what laws the state should pass. The contest closed Jan. 31 and a winner will be announced in two weeks, with judging based on ``the practicality and the worthiness of the idea,'' he said. Wennlund said the winners, chosen from adult and student categories, will get a trip to the Capitol in Springfield next month. They'll be invited to spend a day on the floor of the House of Representatives with Wennlund and watch their proposal be introduced as legislation. The largest number of entries dealt with ideas for lower property taxes, and most of those were from the elderly, Wennlund said. Another popular suggestion _ making up about 10 percent of the entries _ was for a recycling bill charging deposits for returnable bottles. And then there were these suggestions: ``There ought to be a law that citizens use their common sense. Thank you,'' said Eileen Slater, 70, of Chicago. There ought to be a law that every business serving the public be required to provide a public bathroom, one entrant said, adding the argument that, ``When you have to go, you have to go.'' From the second grade at Lincoln Elementary School in a Monmouth came: ``No drinking in Illinois, no drugs, no kissing in cars.'' And from the somewhat more mature set at the school _ the third graders _ there was: ``No naked movies on TV. No playboy channel in Illinois'' and ``No school for 300 years.''

DOC.HEAD: Dairy Group Says Farm Proposal Would Cause Volatile Milk Prices
DOC.TEXT: The National Milk Producers Federation says the administration's dairy plan in the 1990 farm bill could result in greater price instability for producers and consumers. The Bush proposal would continue the Agriculture Department's current basic milk price support formula but also seeks more flexibility in adjusting supports in line with market conditions. ``This plan would only create more instability in the dairy industry, with wilder swings in consumer prices and the loss of dairy farmers throughout the country,'' said Tom Camerlo, president of the National Milk Producers Federation. Camerlo said in the federation's newsletter that the plan amounts to ``even more and deeper price cuts'' for dairy farmers. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter unveiled the administration's farm bill proposals last week. Dairy price supports are carried out indirectly through USDA purchases of surplus manufactured dairy products _ butter, cheese and non-fat dry milk _ so that prices paid to farmers by dealers can be maintained at or above specified support levels. The current program authorized by the 1985 farm law allows milk price supports to be raised or lowered according to market conditions when USDA purchases are above or below designated trigger levels. As it is now, if USDA estimates annual dairy purchases at 2.5 billion pounds of milk equivalent or less, the basic price support rate must be raised by 50 cents per 100 pounds on Jan. 1. But if annual purchases are expected to exceed 5 billion pounds, the support prices is lowered 50 cents. No change is made if purchases are between 2.5 billion and 5 billion pounds of milk equivalent. ``Government surplus purchases have fallen from 12.3 billion pounds, milk equivalent, milkfat basis, in fiscal 1986 to a projected 8 billion pounds in fiscal 1990,'' the proposal said. Meanwhile inventories of government-owned dairy surpluses have declined to less than half of what they were in 1986, and the annual cost of the dairy support program has dropped from $2.3 billion in 1986 to a projected $500 million in the 1990 fiscal year. Under the Bush proposal, annual adjustments could be made in increments of 25 to 50 cents per 100 pounds of milk instead of the flat 50-cent increase or decrease. And it would allow stiffer reductions if USDA purchases rose above 7.5 billion pounds of milk equivalent, including cuts of 50 to 75 cents between 7.5 billion and 10 billion pounds, and $1 for purchases over 10 billion pounds. Currently, including a 50-cent cut on Jan. 1, the basic milk support is $10.10 per 100 pounds. According to a projection developed by National Milk Producers Federation economists, the administration's proposal could result in back-to-back $1 price support cuts in 1990 and 1991. ``These cuts would drop the dairy support price to $8.10 per hundredweight in less than two years,'' the federation said.

An Agriculture Department report says the number of workers employed by farmers declined seasonally in January and was down about 2 percent from a year earlier. The quarterly report said Monday the hired work force on farms was estimated at 690,000 during the week of Jan. 7-13, down from 983,000 in October. A year ago in January the work force was 701,000. Those did not include 143,000 ``agricultural service'' workers provided by crew chiefs and labor contractors. In October, those totaled 308,000 worker, and in January 1989 they were estimated at 152,000. Mostly dry weather and above-normal temperatures prevailed across the nation during the Jan. 7-13 survey week, the report said. The report said the national figures for hired workers had a sampling error of 3.7 percent. Average pay for all workers hired directly by farmers was reported at $5.70 per hour, up from $5.42 in October and $5.51 a year ago, the report said. For workers hired by contractors, there was no national wage rate available. However, workers in California were reported at $6.20 per hour, compared with $6.41 in October and $6.42 a year ago. Florida workers averaged $6.23 per hour, compared with $5.15 in October and $5.79 a year earlier.

U.S. honey production dropped 21 percent last year to 169 million pounds, according to a report by the Agriculture Department. About 3.3 million colonies produced honey in 1989, a 3 percent increase from 1988, the report said. But the average yield per colony was only 51.1 pounds, down from 66.3 pounds in 1988. ``Adverse conditions were encountered in most states and included wet weather, restrictions on movement early in the year, dry weather, disease and mite infestations throughout the year,'' the report said. Prices for the 1989 crop averaged 48.4 cents per pound, down 1.6 cents from 1988, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 37,107.03, down 181.11 points, or 0.49 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Newly Discovered Sousa March To Get American Premiere At Yale
DOC.TEXT: A newly discovered march by John Philip Sousa, written two years before his death and featuring a drum cadence that recalls his famous ``Semper Fidelis,'' will have its American premiere Friday at Yale. The work was discovered among the bandmaster's possessions at the Library of Congress in Washington by a Sousa researcher, Loras Schissel, who completed the nearly finished piece with the Sousa family's permission. Sousa, who died in 1932, wrote about 130 marches. His most famous works include ``Semper Fidelis'' (1888), ``Washington Post'' (1889) and ``Stars and Stripes Forever'' (1897). The ``Untitled March,'' which will be performed by the 70-member Yale Concert Band at the end of an evening program, has ``all the parts of a Sousa march you'd expect,'' said Thomas Duffy, director of the university bands. Keith Brion of Hamden, a freelance symphony conductor who specializes in Sousa concerts and who prepared a performance edition of the march for the Yale band, said Monday he believes the newly found work is one of Sousa's better marches, although ``the jury is not in.'' The 3{-minute march also will be played by the Yale band at Carnegie Hall in New York City on Feb. 27. On first hearing, the march sounds closest to Sousa's Marine march, said Duffy. But the work has more modern harmonies than Sousa's earlier works, Duffy and Brion said. All but a couple of measures were completed by Sousa, so the work that will be played is in no sense a reconstruction, Duffy said. Brion conducted the world premiere in October in Stockholm with the Stockholm Symphonic Wind Orchestra. The performance was carried on national television. The march is being performed at Yale in memory of John Philip Sousa III, the composer's grandson, who died last month. Yale was seeking the grandson's permission to perform the work when the school found out he had died, Duffy said. The band subsequently was granted the right to play the piece by Sousa's great-grandson, John Philip Sousa IV, who lives in Los Angeles. The bandmaster who became known as the ``March King'' was the leader of the U.S. Marine Corps Band from 1880 to 1892. He left that position to form his own band, which gained wide popularity. The music has remained popular because Sousa had ``an inspired gift for melody and rhythm,'' Brion said.

DOC.HEAD: FDA to Allow Last-Resort Use of Symbion Devices
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved for last-resort use the artificial heart developed by Dr. Robert Jarvik, modifying a decision made last month, the University of Arizona said Monday. The FDA last month withdrew its approval of the device both as a permanent implant and as a temporary bridge to transplantation, saying there were ``serious deficiencies'' with its manufacture. The agency also withdrew its approval of the acute ventricular assist device, which helps the natural heart pump. The artificial heart was initially called the Jarvik-7, but Jarvik no longer is associated with Symbion Inc. of Tempe, Ariz., which markets the product as the Symbion-7. Symbion also markets the second device. University Medical Center said in a statement Monday that the FDA now would not object to the devices being used as a last resort if all other approved alterntative treatments have failed or were deemed inappropriate and when no other life-saving device is available to save a patient's life. In response to last month's decision, Dr. Jack G. Copeland, director of the medical center's artificial heart and transplant programs, said he might go ahead and use the devices if the need arose. The effect of their withdrawal would be ``to deprive potentially hundreds of critically ill patients of a chance for life,'' Copeland said. The president and chief executive officer of Symbion, Richard W. Alder, confirmed Monday night that the FDA had mofidied its earlier decision and would permit last-resort, live-saving uses ``under certain, very prescribed conditions.'' The change was outlined in a letter the agency sent fairly recently to organizations, including the medical center, which had been using the devices on an investigative basis, he said. Alder said Symbion and FDA officials were arranging meetings to try to resolve issues remaining from last month's decision. ``We are pleased that the FDA has recognized the value of the devices as a last resort for critically ill patients. The use of this equipment is vital to save lives,'' Copeland said Monday. Copeland said he had called FDA officials ``as an individual physician'' after its initial letter and told them, ```Now we're in limbo again. Every time we put this device in somebody's gonna say that we're defying the FDA, and we know scientifically that they're good devices. ``I felt that it was an untenable position they were putting us into,'' Copeland added. He said FDA officials told him ``they thought I had a point.'' Copeland said he is certain the agency also must have been contacted by other surgeons. He said the FDA officials ``are reasonable people; I think they came up with a reasonable decision.''

DOC.HEAD: HHS Secretary Cancels Test Program After Complaints Raised
DOC.TEXT: Federal officials thought they had found a way to help evaluate the effectiveness of a new law extending transitional Medicaid and child-care benefits to some public assistance recipients who get jobs. But to compare the effects of the new benefits with the old, they would have to deny the new benefits to some people. That's how the Department of Health and Human Services came to approve the Texas Welfare Reform Demonstration project, according to HHS officials. ``This gave us an opportunity to have something to contribute to our knowledge,'' said Mike Fishman, acting deputy of income security policy at HHS. But HHS Secretary Louis Sullivan on Monday night ordered the pilot project revised. ``No person receiving welfare in the state of Texas has been denied or will be denied benefits to which they are entitled under federal law,'' he said. The initial version of the project actually began last July, providing 12 months of extended Medicaid and child care benefits to most of the 8,000 participants who got jobs or entered training programs. But 800 of the participants were eligible only for the four months of extended transitional benefits available to all other recipients of Aid to Families with Dependent Children and Medicaid who are not in a pilot program. The purpose of the study was to see whether the added benefits helped keep people off the welfare rolls. Officials wanted to see whether extended benefits encouraged people to take and remain in entry-level jobs that are unlikely to offer medical insurance or child care benefits immediately. This kind of experiment has long been used in science, medicine and industry as a tool of evaluation, and has been used for more than 20 years in social research to measure the effectiveness of social policies. And like other most other social experiments the government has allowed, it was set up so that the ``experimental group'' was getting added benefits while the ``control group'' got only the level of benefits already offered. However, the project had been designed before Congress passed a bill giving all people on AFDC and Medicaid 12 months of extended transitional benefits beginning April 1 of this year. Thus if the Texas pilot project had continued beyond April 1, that would have meant the 800 people now in the ``control'' group would continue to get only four months benefits _ even though, starting April 1, federal law would entitle them to 12 months. HHS officials suggested to Texas officials that they propose continuing the program. Texas did, and HHS approved it, ``in the interest of understanding the effects of increased transitional benefits,'' Fishman said. But after the plans were outlined in a Dallas Morning News story on Sunday that was distributed nationwide, HHS officials began getting calls and Sullivan called off the plans. Officials said Sullivan was unaware of the project's provisions until then. When they were outlined to him, he made it clear ``he does not want this type of provision included in any of our programs,'' said Martin Gerry, assistant secretary for planning and evaluation. Gerry said he knew of no current HHS programs that deny benefits entitled by federal law. Five other states _ Ohio, Washington state, New York, New Jersey and Wisconsin _ were conducting similar demonstration projects, which also have had to be revised. None has proposed to continue the current transitional benefits past the April 1 effective date of the new benefits as set in law.

DOC.HEAD: Show Honoring Ella Fitzgerald Long and Good
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will stand for PMs.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY7
DOC.TEXT: Ella Fitzgerald, honored at a benefit concert for the American Heart Association, had some surprises in store for herself _ and for her audience. She was surprised when Quincy Jones and Oscar Peterson, who hadn't been announced as being part of the concert, showed up and took part. But the Monday night audience got the best surprise when, near the end of four hours, the 71-year-old Miss Fitzgerald, who had been seated in Avery Fisher Hall, was escorted to the stage. They expected a brief thank-you, but, instead, Miss Fitzgerald began singing ``Honeysuckle Rose.'' Then she thanked the musicians _ and added: ``I think we could do another one.'' The audience screamed its delight. She sang ``Lady Be Good,'' inserting in the lyrics a call for Joe Williams to join her. He motioned for Clark Terry to step out from the trumpet section, and the three traded scat phrases till minutes to midnight. The ``Hearts for Ella'' band, led by Benny Carter, was alone enough to delight a jazz fan. It included Stan Getz, Phil Woods, David Sanborn, James Moody, Jon Faddis, Red Rodney, Al Grey, Hank Jones, Ray Brown and Louis Bellson. One of its gems was ``Stompin' at the Savoy.'' Quincy Jones conducted his ``Stockholm Sweetenin'.'' Classical violinist Itzhak Perlman provided several of the evening's high points. He and Bobby McFerrin did a swinging ``Blue Skies.''
