Then he played hot fiddle with Melissa Manchester, Janis Spiegel and Cheryl Bentyne in the Boswell Sisters' 1931 arrangement of ``It's You.'' After pianist Oscar Peterson played ``Who Can I Turn To?'', he and Perlman dueted on a ravishing ``Summertime.'' The band, Peterson and Perlman played ``Stormy Weather,'' after which Benny Carter summed up, ``It don't get much better than that.'' Trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie played and sang a tender ``I Waited for You.'' The Copasetics and teen sensation Savion Glover tapdanced. Cab Calloway sang Miss Fitzgerald's ``A-Tisket, A-Tasket.'' Pianist Tommy Flannagan, her music director for 10 years, played ``Mr. Paganini.'' George Shearing told about playing intermission piano at the Three Deuces when Hank Jones and Ray Brown were accompanying Miss Fitzgerald. He played ``Ella's (Lulu's) Back in Town.'' Lena Horne, cohost with Perlman, said her uncle told her, at 18, not to copy Ella Fitzgerald. She told him, ``Every woman who wants to be a singer wants to sing like Ella Fitzgerald.'' The New York Heart Association intends to establish the Ella Fitzgerald Research Fellowship with money raised at the benefit.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Slightly Lower, Stocks Down in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar inched down against the yen Tuesday, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange lost ground. The dollar closed at 144.48 yen , down 0.24 yen from last Friday's close of 144.72 yen. After opening at 144.53 yen, the dollar was traded between 144.35 and 144.63 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which shed 228.10 points Friday, fell another 181.11 points, or 0.48 percent, to close at 37,107.03 yen. Financial markets in Japan were closed Monday for a national holiday. Currency dealers said there was no discernable movement on the exchange market due to a lack of new market-moving news. Trading ``remained almost locked,'' although there was some dollar-buying by oil importers for settlements after the three-day weekend in Japan, said Akihiko Hori, a dealer with Mitsui Bank. Hori said dollar-yen rates will not fluctuate much until after the general election for Japan's lower house of Parliament on Sunday. Similarly, on the stock market, share prices generally remained weak as many investors retreated to the sidelines with the lower house elections only five days away, securities traders said. Investors also were discouraged by a 29.06-point decline in the Dow Jones industrial average overnight, said a dealer with a major Japanese securities firm, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: The Harvard Business School, whose graduates ritually wave dollar bills over their heads at commencement, has admitted the first four Soviets to its MBA class of 1992 to learn the ABCs of capitalism. ``If the ruble is convertible by then, I will wave a ruble, if not, the red flag,'' said Aleksei Maximov, 30, one of the four selected for the school's two-year master of business administration program. They have been given five-month positions in U.S. companies to gain hands-on experience in capitalism before entering Harvard. Maximov, who was a research associate in a Soviet think tank, is an intern at S.C. Johnson and Son Inc. in Racine, Wis., studying American marketing and product management techniques. Joseph Bakaleynick, 38, had been a chief financial officer for a tractor factory before his stint at Braxton Associates, a Boston-based consulting firm associated with Deloitte & Touche. Aleskei Kolesnikov, 27, who traveled abroad for the U.S.S.R. Chamber of Commerce and Industry, now works at Johnson & Johnson, of New Brunswick, N.J. And Besik Sikharulidze, 25, headed a scientific consulting firm in Tbilisi, Soviet Georgia, and is now working at Pioneer Hi-Bred International, an agribusiness technology firm in Des Moines, Iowa. Giving Soviets exposure to U.S. business practices could prove invaluable to Americans who try to move into the Soviet economy later, said Scott Fraser, a partner in Deloitte & Touche who said he first suggested that Harvard seek out Soviet applicants. ``My sense is if American industry waits too long, they will get left in the lurch,'' he said. After working at the U.S. firms, the Soviets will take classes at Harvard's summer school and then enter the MBA program. Upon graduation, they have agreed to return to the Soviet Union and work for a state-run enterprise for five years.

Nissan Motor Corp. finally lifted the advertising lid on its Infiniti luxury cars, showing off the vehicles instead of rocks, birds and pussy willows. Nissan was criticized by some automotive advertising analysts for its unusual ad campaign last year. While an announcer spoke softly, viewers saw such pastoral scenes as countrysides or fields. Viewers didn't see the car. Similarly, print ads were car-less. Now, the second stage of the advertising campaign will air in less than 45 television markets, those where the company has dealerships, company officials said Monday. ``If you had to do advertising to get a name established, we did that in spades,'' said Thomas Mignanelli, executive vice president of U.S. sales.

The quest seemed simple enough _ find the meaning of a single sentence from a Santa Clara County Transportation Agency memorandum. But the sentence under consideration wasn't your everyday, public agency-generated gobbledygook. The passage, as offered Monday by the Peninsula Times Tribune, read: ``A final and balancing change order resulting from monetary adjustments in bid items as provided for in the Contract Documents under the sections dealing with `measurement and payment' requires a simple majority vote by the Board if the contract amount is not being exceeded or if such adjustments are made pursuant to the supplemental work allowance item of the Contract Documents.'' Diane McKenna, a county supervisor, said: ``I think I got the `simple majority vote.' But I don't think I understood all the provisions.'' More to the point was William Penn, vice president of the Society for the Preservation of the English Language and Literature. ``Oh my God! That's almost incomprehensible. I'd have to see it in print and rewrite it into real English,'' he said. Scotty Bruce, who approved the memo as the Transportation Agency's deputy director for design and construction, translated the proposal: ``The board is being asked to agree to the amount of work done on a project and the appropriate payment.'' Scott Rice, San Jose State University English professor: ``Oh Lord!''

DOC.HEAD: Reagan To Give Taped Testimony For Poindexter Trial
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan will give videotaped testimony Friday in a Los Angeles courtroom to lawyers for former national security adviser John Poindexter and Iran-Contra prosecutors. U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene on Monday rejected proposals by Richard Beckler, one of Poindexter's lawyers, to delay the questioning of Reagan until the government finished presenting its case and to have Reagan come to Washington to give the testimony. Greene said he would ``consider the president's wishes'' and was prepared to travel to California for the testimony. In order to edit the Reagan tape and to attempt to resolve disputes over some 150 classified documents, Greene moved back the start of the trial two weeks to March 5. Poindexter is charged with conspiracy, obstructing Congress and making false statements in the Iran-Contra scandal. Greene also rejected a suggestion by Reagan lawyer Theodore Olson that the former president be questioned at his office in Los Angeles. The federal courthouse has more space and also has secure facilities to house classified documents, said the judge. Seven news organizations want the press and public admitted to the deposition, but Greene said he doubts he will let them in because of concern over possible disclosure of classified information. He will rule on the news media's request before Friday. A week ago, the judge said Beckler would be permitted to ask Reagan 154 questions plus follow-ups. The former president agreed Friday to submit to the deposition, reserving the option to invoke executive privilege to specific questions. Iran-Contra prosecutors will be permitted to cross-examine the ex-president. Participating in the deposition will be prosecutors from the office of independent counsel Lawrence Walsh, Poindexter's lawyers, attorneys for the Justice Department, lawyers for Reagan, representatives from U.S. intelligence agencies and the judge. The list of questions has been reviewed by intelligence agencies and appears to pose few problems, with the exception of half a dozen questions which could lead into sensitive foreign policy matters. Reagan will be well prepared for the deposition. He knows Poindexter's questions in advance. Reagan's lawyers on Friday received three secret proffers Poindexter submitted to the court some time ago detailing what information he expects to elicit from the former president. Poindexter, in turn, will not have access to certain information about Reagan. Reagan's former national security adviser has been unable to get some 33 diary entries from Reagan because the ex-president invoked executive privilege last week. That dispute won't be resolved until next month at the earliest. In addition, Poindexter cannot gain access to answers which Reagan supplied to written questions by Iran-Contra prosecutors. Also, Poindexter's lawyers say they have had only limited success in reviewing notes taken by Reagan. Poindexter lawyer Fred Robinson said some notes taken by Reagan regarding the Iran-Contra affair are stored at the National Archives. Greene said he wanted a report today from the Justice Department and Iran-Contra prosecutors on ``the status and availability of the president's notes.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Sees Progress in Arms Talks, Stands Adamant on Troop Levels
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is hailing ``solid progress'' on arms talks but standing firm on his troop cut proposal despite Mikhail S. Gorbachev's contention that it would leave the Soviet Union outmanned in Europe. Bush, at a White House news conference Monday, predicted his summit in late June with the Soviet president ``will be a major success.'' He said Secretary of State James A. Baker III ``made solid progress in pushing the U.S.-Soviet agenda forward'' during his trip to Moscow last week. But even as Bush applauded the Soviet Communist Party's moves ``toward pluralism'' and Gorbachev's ``statesmanlike view'' on German unity, he acknowledged he was unwilling to accept the Soviet leader's counterproposal on troop cuts in Europe. And as Bush insisted a united Germany must be part of NATO, Gorbachev was quoted by an East German news agency as saying a united Germany within NATO was unacceptable. National security adviser Brent Scowcroft said Monday night, ``That's not exactly what'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III was told was told'' during his visit to Moscow last week. ``It was not really as positive as that,'' Scowcroft said after a state dinner for the president of the Congo. Bush expressed misgivings about economic sanctions against South Africa, saying ``some are counterproductive.'' But he said ``I'm bound by law'' to keep the sanctions in place until South Africa's white minority government takes further steps to eliminate its racist apartheid rule. He called the freeing of Nelson Mandela ``clearly a very positive sign'' and expressed appreciation for South African President F.W. de Klerk and his ``new brand of leadership.'' On troop cuts in Europe, Bush said he was sticking with the proposal he made Jan. 31 that Soviet troops be cut to 195,000 and U.S. troops to 225,000. Gorbachev last week the Soviet and U.S. troop levels should be the same. But Bush said, ``We've got a big ocean between us and Western Europe. ... I don't think we need to have exact linkage from this point on.'' His argument is that in time of war, the Soviets could easily reinforce their troops in Central Europe from their own territory, while the United States would have to fly or ship troops in from this country. But he said, ``I wouldn't call it an impasse. This is the way it works when you're discussing these arms control things.'' Bush said he hoped treaties on reducing long-range nuclear weapons and chemical weapons would be ``substantially completed'' by the June summit, and there would be progress as well toward signing a troop reduction agreement. He said all three treaties might not be completed by June, however. Gorbachev's troop counterproposal would mean the withdrawal of an additional 30,000 U.S. soldiers Bush wants to keep in Britain, Spain and Turkey. But, said Bush, ``Those (Soviet) troops are not wanted in Eastern Europe anymore. Our troops are wanted by the free world.'' Bush suggested that even if a united Germany belongs in NATO _ as West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl has said _ Western alliance forces may not be deployed inside what is now East Germany. ``There's some flexibility on deployment of NATO forces into Eastern Europe. Nobody wants to threaten the Soviet Union,'' he said. Asked about links between Mandela's African National Congress and communist organizations, Bush said: ``I think these communist parties for the most part are sliding downhill. What's coming uphill is democracy and freedom.'' He said he differs with the ANC on its support for nationalizing South African industries. Socialism, he said, is ``folding its hand and going over to the other side all across the world.'' On other issues Bush: _Said he would decide ``fairly soon'' whether to permit the sale of leases for offshore drilling on the California Coast. The onetime Houston oilman said that, despite last week's tanker spill, ``I'll be damned if I think we ought to shut down offshore drilling everywhere.'' _Called ``counterproductive'' a new Chinese government requirement that students spend five years working at home before studying abroad. _Said he would tell the presidents of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia at Thursday's drug summit in Colombia that the United States was making ``major efforts'' to curb U.S. demand for cocaine.

DOC.HEAD: D.C. Mayor Will Extend Stay at Florida Clinic
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry, facing drug charges at home, intends to stay in a Florida substance-abuse facility longer than the single 28-day treatment cycle, according to city government sources. The sources, who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity, said Barry will stay at the Hanley-Hazelden Clinic until at least Feb. 28 and may complete a second 28-day treatment cycle. The mayor entered the facility Jan. 22. Officials at the center have declined in the past to discuss Barry's treatment. They have said, however, that it was not unusual for patients to remain longer than 28 days. Barry was arrested Jan. 18 on a misdemeanor cocaine-possession charge. A grand jury has been hearing evidence in the mayor's case for months. The Washington Post reported in today's editions that a grand jury investigating allegations of drug use by Barry will be asked to return a multi-count indictment this week. WJLA-TV said Monday that two counts would allege perjury and five counts drug use. Federal sources would not confirm the station's report, saying only that they expect the grand jury to return an indictment, probably next week. Barry entered the Florida center for what an aide described as primarily treatment of alcoholism. Barry publicly acknowledged during a church service on Sunday having an alcohol dependency problem but did not mention cocaine, according to another worshipper. One government aide said city officials and the mayor's political advisers agreed with the doctor's recommendations that the mayor remain in Florida beyond 28 days. ``They (Hanley-Hazelden physicians) have determined that he really requires additional treatment,'' said a city official familiar with the discussions. ``The longer the mayor stays down there, the better he will be able to convince people that he has genuinely been seeking treatment,'' said one political adviser. ``This is really the better thing for him.''

DOC.HEAD: After Nearly 30 Years, Interstate 90 is Almost Completed
DOC.TEXT: After nearly three decades, Interstate 90's ``ramps to nowhere'' are being linked at the western end of the Boston-to-Seattle route. The ramps, once the butt of jokes, were built in the early 1960s as part of the ambitious, 2,465-mile transcontinental highway system. The suspended roadway, which is west of the north-south Interstate 5, caught the driver's eyes _ as if it was designed for daredevil Evel Knievel. Then the last few miles of I-90 were laid across Lake Washington, improving traffic between suburban Bellevue and Seattle at a cost of $1.45 billion, and the entire complex is scheduled for completion in the winter of 1991. The highway's giant concrete tentacles extend into the commercial area south of downtown and to the Kingdome, home of the Seahawks and Mariners sports teams. It will be finished for $68.9 million. The viaducts also will carry bus traffic into a new bus tunnel built under downtown and ready for service this September. The roadway was to be finished in the 1960s, but the delay has allowed for the design to be updated, said Ollie Harding, the Washington Department of Transportation's project boss. Bus and car-pool lanes can be converted to use by light-rail transit if commuter trains ever come to Seattle. After the devastating San Francisco quake in October, a decision was made to strengthen a portion of an existing double-decked portion of the roadway by installing reinforced steel rods, Harding said.

DOC.HEAD: Widow Hopes Community Recovers; Classmates Mourn Slain Friends
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Funeral of one victim scheduled to begin at noon EST.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA1
DOC.TEXT: A widow whose husband and two daughters were shot to death in a bowling alley massacre mourns for her family and for her town, which was shattered by the execution-style killings. Audrey Teran's anguished cry _ ``Why my little babies?'' _ is being heard throughout what was once a sleepy town 45 miles from the Mexican border. ``Our entire community is shocked by the events of Saturday,'' said Roman Catholic Bishop Ricardo Ramirez. ``I want to express our deepest and sincerest sympathy to the families of those murdered. The tragedy should move us all to a greater appreciation of life itself. Each day is precious and to be protected, especially the lives of our children and youth.'' At University Hills Elementary School, where Mrs. Teran's slain 6-year-old daughter, Paula Holguin, had gone to school, principal Vince Rivera agonized over what to tell the youngsters. ``You're thrusting something at them that they really don't understand. They see it on TV ... and that's fantasy, but this is reality. How can they understand that?'' he said. A funeral Mass was scheduled today for part-time bowling alley employee Amy Houser, 13, at Immaculate Heart of Mary Cathedral. Saturday's killings, along with an unrelated slaying the same day, brought the number of homicide victims in this city of 55,000 people to six this year _ triple the number for all of last year. Police say no killings during the past 20 years have been as brutal as the slayings of the Houser girl and Mrs. Teran's husband, Steven, 26, and her daughters, Paula 6, and Valerie, 2. ``It's not the city it was when I used to roam the streets,'' said police Capt. Fred Rubio. Robbers confronted Teran at the Las Cruces Bowl on Saturday morning. The two gunmen made seven people lie down in the bowling alley's office, shot each in the back of the head, set a fire and fled with $5,000, police said. Two adults and a 12-year-old girl survived and were listed in serious condition Monday at Memorial General Hospital. ``Lately, I've seen an increase in homicides,'' Dona Ana County Sheriff Cooney Sarracino said Monday, ``but you don't see many execution-style murders, and this is execution style. I've seen where three or four people were killed, but not little kids.'' Police said they have been inundated with hundreds of tips to aid the search for the gunmen, but no arrests had been made. A black bow and ribbon has been placed on the entrance of a cosmetology school where the 24-year-old Mrs. Teran works. And the bowling alley marquee urged passersby to pray for the victims. At the young victims' schools, officials tried to help classmates understand the tragedy. ``I have lots of wet eyes this morning, especially at the eighth grade level,'' said Dorris Hamilton, principal of Lynn Middle School, where Amy Houser and the wounded 12-year-old attended classes. Teran, who had recently graduated from New Mexico State University with a degree in criminal justice, worked weeknights at the bowling alley and daytime shifts on weekends. On Saturdays, he would take his daughter, Valerie, and stepdaughter, Paula, with him because the couple had trouble finding a baby sitter, Mrs. Teran said. While she decried the senselessness of the killings, Mrs. Teran thanked the community for its support. ``I hope they can put it behind them,'' she said. Mrs. Teran said she hopes her children and husband did not suffer. Police have said the 2-year-old was alive when paramedics took her from the bowling alley. She was pronounced dead at the hospital minutes later. ``It kills me that I couldn't have been there with her. I just hope she was not in a lot of pain,'' Mrs. Teran said. ``I believe he and my daughters, my girls, they're all in heaven,'' Mrs. Teran said. ``God has a mission for them. He took the girls with him because he didn't want to leave them to suffer.'' A funeral Mass for the Teran family members will be held Wednesday.

DOC.BYLINE: New Communist Platform: A Bill of Rights _ Protection From the State
DOC.TEXT: In its revolutionary new platform, the ruling Communist Party casts aside Marxist economic theory by accepting private property and backs a strong presidency that would further erode its 72-year grip on power. The platform advocates a bill of rights to protect the individual against abuses of the state in a country where Stalinist authorities stripped millions of peasants of land and had political opponents murdered by the thousands. The document, approved during a landmark meeting last week and published Monday, represents President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's boldest break with Communist orthodoxy and contradicts public statements he made just months ago. The official Tass news agency said leaders called Monday for a special session of the Congress of People's Deputies in the ``near future'' to strength the office of presidency, which would solidify Gorbachev's hold on power. The country's highest executive body, the presidium of the Supreme Soviet, ``unanimously favored the establishment of democratic presidential power in our country,'' Tass reported. It also said without elaboration that the presidium wanted the Congress _ which was seated last spring in the country's first contested elections in seven decades _ to consider the ownership of property and strengthening the Soviet government. Gorbachev had called for the Congress to convene in June. The statement did not say whether the president should be directly elected by voters, but one of Gorbachev's key allies _ Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze _ said last week that a nationwide popular election might be possible. In deciding on sweeping changes, the platform says the party took into account the new hunger of citizens for democracy and reform, as expressed by mass rallies and local political organizing all over the country. The new platform abandons the Communists' ideological roots: ``The Communist Party of the Soviet Union believes the existence of individual property, including ownership of the means of production, does not contradict the modern stage in the country's economic development.'' Marxist theory holds that factories and other means of producing goods must be owned by the state rather than individuals because private ownership inevitably results in one person exploiting the labor of another. The platform says state-owned property should be turned over to worker control through leasing, contracts, joint-stock holdings and other methods. Communists intend to create and economy ``based on a diversity of property forms, competition between independent manufacturers, a developed financial system and on the powerful stimuli of personal and collective interest,'' the platform says. At last week's meeting, the Communist Party's policy-making Central Committee voted to relinquish the party's guaranteed leading role and accept that it must compete with other parties for the right to govern. The authority of the party, which Gorbachev heads as general secretary, is in steep decline as citizens angered at mismanagement and official corruption hold it responsible for the dismal state of the economy. Communist central authority also faces increased challenges from secessionist movements throughout the restive union and at the polls, where Communists are expected to show poorly in local elections this spring. Popular revolutions have in the past year thrown out Communist leaders in Moscow's former Eastern European satellites. Central planning has left the Soviet Union unable to provide its people with adequate food, housing and consumer goods, and the platform says the system has been ``characterized by monopoly, lack of initiative, wastefulness, mismanagement and disregard for consumers interests.'' The young Soviet state under Lenin's leadership confiscated most private property after the 1917 revolution, and Stalin's drive to strip peasants of their land through collectivization in the 1930s claimed millions of lives through famine, deportation and summary execution. The platform did not make clear in what sense the party still considers itself to be Communist, but pays homage to the creative spirit of Marxism and the philospohy's humanistic outlook. It said the party is committed to protect ``a citizen's personality and honor, the immunity of his home and property, the secrecy of correspondence.'' The platform backs freedoms of conscience, religion, assembly, speech, the press and citizen ``participation in running the affairs of society and the state.'' Soviet laws long have promised wide political freedoms, but until Gorbachev came to power in 1985 the Communists dominated every aspect of life and persecuted critics and potential challengers. In a departure from one of the Marxist slogans once used to justify rule by terror and liquidation of the middle class, the party dismissed the concept of a dictatorship of the proletariat, saying: ``The rule-of-law state of the whole people has no room for dictatorship by any class.'' The platform introduces the concept of competition _ once taboo among Communist ideologists _ as a necessary tool for regulating prices and ensuring availability of goods and services. It calls for legislation to break up state monopolies, trade, credit services and insurance businesses to permit competitive consumer services. As recently as November, Gorbachev stated firm opposition to permitting Soviet citizens to hold private property. But he has changed signals on several issues in recent weeks. In January, he reversed his longstanding opposition to the party giving up its guaranteed monopoly on power. All constitutional questions, such as powers of the presidency, must be decided by the Congress, which is supposed to meet briefly twice a year. Under reforms pushed through by Gorbachev in December 1988, the president is chosen by the Congress.

DOC.HEAD: New Strains in U.S.-Philippine Ties A Prelude To Bases Talks, Cheney Visit
DOC.TEXT: Cutbacks in U.S. economic aid and rare American criticism of President Corazon Aquino's stewardship have strained relations with Washington, which helped save her from military mutineers two months ago. The new strains have emerged as the two governments prepare for talks, possibly next month, on extending the lease on the six U.S. military bases, which expires next year. In the clearest sign of tension, Mrs. Aquino announced Sunday that she would refuse to meet Defense Secretary Richard Cheney when he visits the Philippines next week. She cited recent statements from American officials, who blamed the December coup attempt in part on corruption and inefficiency in her government. Mrs. Aquino claims the mutineers were simply trying to ``grab power'' and that their criticisms had no validity. ``I believe I have been a victim of inaccurate reporting, not from the Philippine press but from the American press,'' Mrs. Aquino told reporters Monday. ``I believe it is best at this time to just instruct (Defense) Secretary (Fidel) Ramos on whatever there is to say to Secretary Cheney.'' On Dec. 1, U.S. Air Force F-4 Phantom jets flew air cover for government forces battling mutineers seeking to overthrow Mrs. Aquino. Although the jets never fired a shot, it is widely believed that U.S. intervention was decisive in defeating the mutiny because of the psychological impact of such strong American support for Mrs. Aquino. Since the coup attempt, however, U.S. officials have publicly criticized the Aquino government for failing to curb corruption and deliver basic services to the country's 58 million people. ``The greatest deterrent to future coup attempts will be forceful, sustained action by the government to address those grievances shared by the rebels and the populace,'' Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Carl Ford told the House subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific last month. Commenting on Ford's testimony, Mrs. Aquino said: ``I do not agree with him on the matter of the grievances of the coup plotters that they cite graft and corruption and other grievances. All of the six coup attempts were basically to grab power and not to submit themselves to the democratic processes.'' Ford's statement marked a significant departure from what U.S. diplomats say had been an unofficial policy of never criticizing Mrs. Aquino publicly. Criticism by American officials always makes a significant impact here. Most Filipinos believe as an article of faith that Washington orchestrates events in their country and that criticism signals diminishing U.S. support. Adding to the strain was the Bush administration's failure to fulfill a pledge made during talks in 1988 on allowing Clark Air Base, the Subic Bay naval base and four smaller installations to remain through the end of their lease. During the talks, then-Secretary of State George Shultz agreed to seek $962 million in economic aid to the Philippines over two years. This year, the Bush administration asked Congress to provide the Philippines with $200 million in military assistance and $160 million in economic support. But Congress cut the overall request by $96 million. Any agreement extending the bases beyond 1991 must be approved by two-thirds of the 23-member Senate. The chamber's president, Jovito Salonga, suggested talks be postponed until the cuts are restored. On Monday, Rep. Ramon Mitra, speaker of the House of Representatives, said he would sponsor a resolution urging Mrs. Aquino to postpone bases talks until the United States restores aid cuts and halts its ``black propaganda.''

DOC.HEAD: Survey Finds Few Cheatin' Hearts
DOC.TEXT: This just in for Valentine's Day: nine of 10 people in a survey claimed they had never been unfaithful, and four of five said they would marry the same person again, given the chance. The Gallup survey, commissioned by Psychology Today and two television shows, King World's Inside Edition and ABC's Home Show, was released Monday. Three of four respondents said their spouse is their best friend, and 64 percent said their marriage was ``very happy.'' Pollsters contacted 657 randomly selected, married men and women nationwide shortly before Christmas. The margin of error was plus or minus 4 percentage points. The report on the findings, by the Rev. Andrew M. Greeley and T. George Harris, called the widespread belief that married people are often unfaithful an example of ``pluralistic ignorance _ erroneous, cognitive beliefs shaped by some individuals about other individuals.'' The report also put forth the theory ``the availability of divorce for those who are unhappy has increased the average level of happiness in the pool of couples who remain married.'' The survey attributed marital happiness primarily to three factors: communication; cooperation in housework, child rearing and respect of each other's work; and romance. For instance: _71 percent said they're trying very hard to improve their marriage. _55 percent of male respondents and 47 percent of female strongly believe their spouse is romantic. _39 percent said they work very hard to improve their sex life. _53 percent of women respondents and 47 percent of men strongly agreed that their spouse is a skilled lover. _32 percent of women and 26 percent of men said their spouse is imaginative about sex. The survey found so much bliss in America that 10 percent of the respondents agreed strongly their spouse is sometimes ``like a god'' to them. Eighteen percent of women agreed at least somewhat with the statement _ and 37 percent of men did. Other findings: _81 percent of men and 72 percent of women strongly believe their spouse is good looking. _82 percent believe their spouse is good with children, and 63 percent strongly disagree that children take the fun out of marriage. _70 percent disagree that as ``the years go on, much of the fun goes out of marriage.''

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts from Soviet Communist Party Platform
With PM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from the Soviet Communist Party Platform adopted by the Central Committee last week and published by Tass.
DOC.HEAD: HUMAN RIGHTS
DOC.TEXT: The party seeks to place man in the center of social development, providing him with worthy living and working conditions, guaranteeing him social justice, political liberty and possibilities for comprehensive development and spiritual fulfillment, and regards this as its main goal. This is exactly what should determine social progress. The Soviet Communist Party stands for the earliest formulation of legal acts guaranteeing the rights and freedoms of citizens. The recognition of personal liberty as the key and vital value and an about-face to guarantee the entire complex of human rights is perestroika's most important accomplishment. Now it is necessary to consolidate these rights, to rest them on a solid material, legal and political foundation. The party will uphold: _ Reliable legislative protection of a citizen's personality and honor, the immunity of his home and property, the secrecy of correspondence and telephone conversations, _ Stronger guarantees to realize the right to work, including payment according to the quantity and quality of work done and its final results. The formation of a mechanism to maintain employment, training and re-training of personnel and adequate material support for those who are forced to change their trade, profession or place of work, _ The development and strengthening of the political rights of citizens: participation in running the affairs of society and the state, freedom of speech, the press, meetings and demonstrations and the formation of public organizations. Law and order and requirements of Soviet laws should be strictly observed, _ Freedom for creative activities and attitude to talent as a national asset. _ Man's free self-determination in the spiritual sphere, the freedom of conscience and religion. Without abandoning its world outlook, the party will step up the dialogue between atheists and believers and pursue a policy that offers all churches the opportunity to freely operate within the law, contributing to mutual understanding between people, _ A higher role of the court of law in protecting civil rights, the establishment of public-state commissions exercising law-enforcing activities, The CPSU (Communist Party of the Soviet Union) puts priority on the adoption of laws in the near future on the press and other mass media, freedom of conscience and religious associations, public associations, the order of emigration from and immigration to the U.S.S.R., Soviet citizenship, languages of Soviet peoples and other legislative acts that will guarantee the political and personal rights of citizens... Every means envisaged by law should be used to combat crime, while the presumption of innocence and the right to protection and juridical norms should be strictly observed.
DOC.HEAD: FOOD AND AGRICULTURE
DOC.TEXT: The solution of the food problem should rest on the development of all forms of economic management in agriculture. State-run, cooperative and individual farms and diverse forms of management, based on contract, leasing and other principles, should be given equal possibilities.
DOC.HEAD: CONSUMERS AND FINANCE
DOC.TEXT: We continue to focus on efforts to increase the production of consumer goods. The CPSU will help implement measures to help satiate the market. The party advocates an effective finance recovery program, including such measures as the encouragement of deposits in savings banks at increased interest rates, the development of the insurance business, the distribution of state loan bonds on advantageous terms, the selling of dwellings, advance payments by the population for durable goods they plan to buy in the future and the selling of stocks and other securities ... More flexible economic instruments and quotas will be needed to prevent unfounded incomes and the issue of money in excess of the supply of goods.
DOC.HEAD: PROPERTY AND ECONOMY
DOC.TEXT: The CPSU believes the existence of individual property, including ownership of the means of production, does not contradict the modern stage in the country's economic development ... One of the most difficult aspects of the economic reform is finding an organic combination of plan and market methods to regulate economic activity. Modern production is impossible without a centralized planned management. This essentially socialist principle of economic management has been adopted by many countries. However, it is crucially important to determine the precise degree and methods of such management. Unlike in the past, when the plan attempted to encompass the entire process of production and distribution, there is now a need for a procedure in which planned, centralized economic management will be exercised through prices, taxes, interest rates, credits, payments etc. ... The creation of a full-fledged market economy requires the formation of markets of consumer products, capital goods, securities, investment, currencies and research and development, and an early reform of the financial, monetary and credit systems. The restructuring of price formation is a sine qua non condition for the market to start regulating the economy. The artificial price levels and proportions, the burden of ineffective subsidies for some and ruinous deductions from others provide false reference-points for economic management. They confound the assessment of management's effect, perpetuate scientific and technological backwardness and prevent the efficient utilization of the advantages of the international division of labor.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: MOSCOW: of labor.
DOC.TEXT: Competition between product manufacturers, including foreign firms, must become an important factor regulating and restraining the growth of prices.
DOC.HEAD: ENVIRONMENT
DOC.TEXT: The protection of nature is the protection of man. Toward the close of the 20th century, environmental protection has become a categoric imperative for preserving life on the Earth. We must introduce world standards in this country and take an active part in international ecological cooperation. The rapid industrial growth of the U.S.S.R., coupled with an attitude of neglect toward conservation measures, has led to grave pockets of ecological disaster. Urgent measures and large investments are required to rectify the situation.
DOC.HEAD: SOURCE OF POWER
DOC.TEXT: The party's policy proceeds from the recognition of the sovereign will of the people as the only source of power. The rule-of-law state of the whole people has no room for dictatorship by any class, and even less so for the power of a management bureaucracy.
DOC.HEAD: ELECTIONS
DOC.TEXT: The electoral system should be brought in line with the principles of universal, equal, direct suffrage. We wish elections to become an honest competition between representatives of all the sections of society, of individuals and ideas submitted to the judgment of voters by the party, public organizations and movements and individual candidates. The development of society does not preclude the possibility of forming parties. The procedure for their formation will be established by law and reflected in the constitution of the U.S.S.R. The formation and activity of organizations and movements that expound violence and inter-ethnic strife and that pursue extremist, unconstitutional aims should be prohibited by law. The Soviet Communist Party does not claim a monopoly and is prepared for a political dialogue and cooperation with everyone who favors the renewal of socialist society.
DOC.HEAD: STATE AUTHORITY
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Communist Party holds that the separation of legislative, executive and judiciary powers is fundamentally important to the government's efficiency. In Lenin's words, we should combine the advantages of the Soviet system with the advantages of (parliamentary government).
DOC.HEAD: THE PRESIDENCY
DOC.TEXT: The question of instituting the post of head of state _ president _ responsible to the Congress of U.S.S.R. People's Deputies and having the necessary powers is posed by society ever more insistently. A president is needed to maintain the country's stable development, to speed up perestroika, to guarantee its irreversibility, to ensure the normal and effective functioning of all state and public institutions in the process of democratization, to ensure law and citizens' security, to protect the Soviet Union's interests and to represent our state on the international arena.
DOC.HEAD: DEFENSE
DOC.TEXT: A rule-of-law state presupposes effective political guidance of the defense, the accountability of the military department to the supreme civil authorities, and maximum openness in the activity of the military department, taking into account the level of confidence among states. Internal security. In view of the need to protect state frontiers, counteract foreign intelligence agencies, protect the Soviet constitutional system and the rights of citizens, we should be attentive to the needs of frontier and internal troops, which fulfill complex and at times dangerous duties. Remaining vital to the maintenance of public order, interior and state security bodies should operate strictly within the law and under control of elective government bodies.
DOC.HEAD: ETHNIC RELATIONS AND THE RIGHT TO SECEDE
DOC.TEXT: The principle of the self-determination of nations in a renewed Soviet federation presupposes the freedom of national-state entities to choose forms by which to structure life, institutions and symbols of statehood. Our ideal is not unification, but unity in diversity. The party reaffirms its commitment to Lenin's principle of the right of nations to self-determination, including secession, and favors the adoption of a law on a mechanism for the exercise of this right. At the same time we are convinced that the weakening and disruption of reciprocally diverse and interrelated ties could lead to negative consequences for all peoples, to say nothing about individual destinies, consequences that are very difficult to foresee. That is why we resolutely oppose separatist slogans and movements that would lead to the destruction of the great multi-ethnic democratic state.
DOC.HEAD: PARTY DEMOCRACY
DOC.TEXT: There is a need for rethinking the principle of democratic centralism. It should no longer be treated in such a way that it can be used to implement barrack-room, hierarchical discipline. There is no other way to overcome Communists' dissatisfaction with their role in the policy and activity of the party. There is no other way to restore in each of them a sense of dignity and inner-freedom.

DOC.HEAD: Ivana Ups the Ante: Prenuptial Not Enough
DOC.NOTE: Eds: minor in editing in final two grafs, including DELETION of extraneous `the' in next-to-last graf
DOC.TEXT: He built a billion-dollar empire of hotels and real estate, owns a casino and an airline that bear his name, and wrote a best seller called ``The Art of the Deal.'' But the art of making a marriage work appears to have eluded Donald Trump. He and his wife, Ivana, have split after nearly 13 years of marriage _ proving once again that money can't buy you love. In fact, money is a source of contention between the two, despite a prenuptial agreement under which she was to get custody of their three children, the Greenwich, Conn., mansion, and $25 million. Trump, 43, is worth considerably more _ $1.7 billion to $4 billion, depending on who's counting. Ivana's lawyer, Michael Kennedy, issued a statement Monday saying: ``We do not consider the so-called prenuptial agreement to be serious. It will have no relevance to a court because it is unconscionable and fraudulent.'' In response, Donald's spokesman said: ``The prenuptial agreement signed by Donald and Ivana Trump is a long and detailed document which covers all aspects and is 100 percent enforceable in courts of law. The agreement they have was updated approximately two years ago. Prior to that, this agreement has been updated on numerous other occasions throughout the years.'' While lawyers and image-makers battle it out with press releases, tabloids and TV stations _ always enamored of the tuxedoed Trump and the bejeweled, begowned Ivana _ lap it up. The New York Post today reported that Donald locked Ivana out of her office Monday at the Plaza Hotel. The Post, citing unidentified sources, also reported that some of Ivana's jewelry is missing. Trump had given her the jobs of running the Plaza and the Trump Castle in Atlantic City, N.J., for a salary, as he put it, of ``One dollar plus all the dresses she can buy.'' It was not clear whether Ivana, a former Czechoslovakian ski racer and sometime model who turns 41 next week, will continue with her hotel work. On Monday, the Post quoted Donald saying that Ivana's ``level of arrogance has grown steadily worse in recent years. The bottom line is I don't want to create another Leona Helmsley.'' Mrs. Helmsley is the self-described hotel queen recently convicted of tax evasion; at her trial, former employees described her as ill-tempered and demanding. ``I have told Ivana, `Whatever Leona would do, do the opposite. Be nice to everybody.' And she is nice, anyway,'' Trump told Playboy magazine in an interview in the March issue. Nice aside, Trump told columnist Liz Smith, who broke the story of the breakup in Sunday's Daily News: ``It is better for Ivana and me to separate at this time. But I am leaving because I want to leave. ``Ivana is a wonderful woman and a very good woman and I like her. We might even get back together. I can't say we won't. ... And as for those other women I have been linked with, well, I want to say that we are all just friends and that's as far as it goes,'' Trump said. Pictures of those other women were plastered across a page of the New York Post: actresses Catherine Oxenberg and Marla Maples and skater Peggy Fleming across the top of a page. New York newspapers trotted out _ as evidence of trouble in Trump paradise _ the story of Ivana, in an Aspen restaurant over the holidays, reportedly warning Maples, a former Miss Georgia runnerup and star of a movie called ``Maximum Overdrive,'' to stay away from Donald. The Trumps were then seen arguing on the slopes. A few days later, Maples reportedly told Ivana: ``I love him and if you don't, why don't you let him go?'' the Post said.

DOC.HEAD: Four Charged With Harassing Sheik For Back Pay
DOC.TEXT: Three gun-toting police officers and a private detective were arrested after confronting a flamboyant Saudi sheik in a dispute over $14,000 in back wages, authorities said. The four, who had been Sheik Mohammed al-Fassi's bodyguards, were charged with false imprisonment after they were lured back to his rented home with a promise of a $5,000 payment, police said. Three of the men came to al-Fassi's central Florida home Sunday armed with pistols; the other was in a car with a sawed-off shotgun, said Osceola County Sheriff Jon Lane. Al-Fassi said one of the men put a gun on a table and hinted they could harm his children if they were not paid the back wages they said they were owed for work at the sheik's mansion in Miami Beach, police said. The men left when al-Fassi promised they would be paid by today. But police decided to set a trap for the four after al-Fassi complained of being harassed. Al-Fassi called North Miami police officer Neal Cuevas, and told him the four could have $5,000 right away. Deputies staking out the house arrested the four when they returned later Sunday. In addition to Cuevas, 35, the others arrested were officers Frank Irvine, 32; Vito Santangelo, 40; and private detective Ronald Raflowitz, 38. The men posted bond of $1,000 each. They face a maximum of seven years in prison if convicted. Santangelo was suspended without pay by the South Miami Police Department. Cuevas and Irvine retained their jobs with the North Miami police pending further investigation, said North Miami Deputy Police Chief Donald Sjoland.

DOC.HEAD: One Marine Dead, Another Injured After Ejecting From Planes
DOC.TEXT: A Marine pilot died after ejecting during the crash of his AV-8B Harrier attack jet, a Marine Corps spokesman said. Another flier also ejected from a twin-engine reconnaissance plane that landed safely, and the Marine Corps was investigating whether the ejections were linked, said Capt. Kevin Murphy. Names of the fliers were not released. The planes, assigned to the 2nd Marine Aircraft Wing in Cherry Point, N.C., were on training missions at the sprawling desert base 125 miles east of Los Angeles. The pilot of the single-seat Harrier ejected Monday morning before the craft crashed in a remote area, said Murphy. The pilot was taken to the Naval Hospital, where he died more than an hour later, Murphy said. At about the time the Harrier pilot ejected, the aerial observer in a two-seat Marine OV-10 Bronco observation plane ejected. The Bronco's pilot landed the plane safely, and the observer who had ejected was taken to the hospital, where he was in fair condition under observation, said Murphy.

DOC.HEAD: Egypt, U.N. Plan To Rebuild Former Center of Greek, Jewish Literature
DOC.TEXT: The United Nations and Egypt have begun a campaign to rebuild the Alexandria Library, which stored the roots of Greek and Jewish civilization before its destruction 17 centuries ago. In the hotel where Agatha Christie wrote part of ``Death on the Nile,'' international royalty, politicians and cultural celebrities gathered Monday to endorse a $90 million fund-raising drive. Sheik Zayed Bin Sultan al-Nahyan, president of the United Arab Emirates, kicked it off with a pledge of $20 million. The re-creation of Alexander the Great's library will cost nearly $150 million, including more than $60 million from Egypt in the form of equipment and the purchase of the Mediterranean seafront site. Egypt, which owes foreign creditors $50 billion, ``has decided to carry out this colossal work and give it top priority in spite of ... the challenge it faces for realizing comprehensive economic reform,'' President Hosni Mubarak said. ``Egypt can never relinquish its pioneer civilizational role, which it should play by virtue of its history and location,'' Mubarak said. ``This is what the world expects of (Egypt).'' The general director of the U.N. Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, Egypt's co-sponsor for the project, admitted the cost is high but said fostering knowledge, ``the supreme resource,'' is worth it. ``There are those who will say $150 million is a high price to pay ... when so many apparently more pressing needs clamor for our attention,'' said Federico Mayor, a Spaniard. ``Are we to place a lower value on a library than on a superbomber? At a time when the disarmament momentum is growing, the promotion of knowledge deserves to be one of the first peace dividends.'' Construction is scheduled to begin on the mammoth library complex late this year, with completion in mid-1995. The complex will cover 722,000 square feet, including 277,800 square feet for the 10-story library itself. Museums, a planetarium, a center for book and manuscript preservation and related facilities are planned. Mubarak's wife, Suzanne, who is leading the project, said it ``concerns every man, everywhere, no matter his geographical position, political affiliation or religious creed.'' The original Bibliotheca Alexandrina thrived for centuries as a seat of scientific, cultural and academic lore. It was in Alexandria that Euclid thrived, Jewish scholars translated the Old Testament from Hebrew into Greek and Homer's works were collected. Well-established by 285 B.C., the library's 500,000 volumes remained at the heart of Mediterranean academic life until it was destroyed in a series of fires in wartime and riots. The destruction was so complete that its site and design still are debated. President Francois Mitterrand of France, Princess Caroline of Monaco and Greek actress Melina Mercouri also attended Monday's session at the Old Cataract Hotel.

DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 1st Graf of 2nd item to delete extraneous matter
DOC.HEAD: Bush Greets Congo President
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is urging Congolese President Denis Sassou-Nguesso to keep promoting peace in Angola and praising him for ``the growing health of free markets and free ideas'' in the Congo. At a state dinner Monday night honoring the president of the People's Republic of the Congo, Bush said Sassou had helped make Southern Africa ``a more peaceful and stable place. ``Namibia will soon be independent. The new beginnings in South Africa may help end an old evil, apartheid,'' said Bush. ``And in Angola, as Cuban troops are leaving, our search for national reconciliation has intensified.'' He urged Sassou to use his ``respected voice'' to pursue peace and self-determination for the people in Angola. Bush said the Congo, once closely aligned with Moscow, ``has taken some welcome steps, encouraging private enterprise, placing some limits on the power of single-party rule and opening the legislature to non-party groups.'' Bush raised a glass to toast Sassou's health, success and ``the growing health of free markets and free ideas in your homeland.'' Sassou applauded Bush's role in leading the world to a more peaceful era, saying, ``History will note that the U.S.-USSR dialogue of the 90s helped sketch out the 21st century.''
DOC.HEAD: Pool of School Volunteers Changing
DOC.TEXT: The old image of school volunteers raising money with bake sales and coaching sports teams needs to be broadened to include business executives and retirees who do everything from tutoring to counseling. On the other hand, the National Research Council study issued Monday also found that public schools with high minority enrollment use few, if any, volunteers of any type. ``Volunteers in Public Schools'' found that some 1.3 million people were school volunteers during the 1987-88 school year. About 60 percent of public schools and 65 percent of private schools reported having volunteers. ``Twenty to 30 years ago most school volunteers were mothers of school children, but this source has been reduced as women have moved into paid employment,'' the study said. ``Increasingly, people from the business community, retired citizens and college students have been actively recruited by school systems, and these groups now constitute a substantial portion of volunteers.'' Public schools with high minority enrollment _ 50 percent or more _ were less likely to use volunteers and reported fewer on average than did schools with lower minority enrollment, said the study.
DOC.HEAD: Bush Praises Scouts
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, sporting the Silver Buffalo scouting medallion around his neck, says Boy Scouting teaches ``lessons that last a lifetime.'' At a White House ceremony Monday honoring scouting's 80th anniversary, Bush was presented the National Boy Scouts Organization's highest award, the Silver Buffalo, and wore during his brief remarks. The president said he was observing a tradition ``that dates all the way back to 1910, when President Taft received the first Boy Scout delegation right here in the White House.'' ``Scouting is more than learning how to build a campfire or tie a knot,'' Bush told a group of scouts and their leaders. ``Scouting teaches a love of outdoors and appreciation of our environment; it teaches the spirit of serving others and self respect. And let me make it pure and simple: It teaches lessons that last a lifetime.'' Bush was given the Silver Buffalo medallion as well as the first copy of the new edition of the Boy Scout Handbook, which scout leaders said is second only to the Bible in terms of copies printed.

DOC.HEAD: Three Girls Make History By Joining The Scouts
DOC.TEXT: Three girls looking for more strenuous hikes, bike rides and rock climbing have signed up with the Scouts, breaking an all-boys tradition in British scouting that dates from its foundation in 1908. ``I am really thrilled that we are being allowed to join at last,'' said Nicola Lowes, a former Girl Guide, as she and two friends signed membership certificates Monday night. ``We have nothing against the Guides but we found it a bit tame,'' 14-year-old Nicola told reporters in Wark, a village in northeast England. The move follows the decision announced Thursday by Britain's chief scout, Garth Morrison, to admit girls. Nicola, Christel Wilson, 15, and Gillian Ridley, 14, applied to join the Wark Scout troop in October. Nicola said they were ``looking forward to playing tough games with the boys and going on hikes, rock climbing, bike rides and all the things the lads do.'' Bob Hogarth, leader of the Wark troop, said he and the 12 boys in the troop aged 10 to 15 favored having them in, but the girls were rejected because of the all-boys rule. Geoff Richardson, the region's Scout commissioner, said that like boys who join, the girls will have to undergo basic training before being invested as full members. Morrison said on Thursday that it would be left to each local Scout troop to decide whether to admit girls. He described it as ``an important move and a move in the right direction.'' Dr. June Paterson-Brown, chief commissioner of Britain's Girl Guides Association, said the move made her angry. ``If they try to poach our girls, then it will make things very difficult.'' The Boy Scouts of America movement has allowed girls aged between 6 and 15 in its Explorer Division for about 19 years. Lord Baden-Powell, the British soldier who founded the Scout movement with his 1908 manual ``Scouting for Boys,'' originally envisaged it as a body of young lookouts to keep an enemy under surveillance.

DOC.HEAD: Silber Defends Remarks About Racism Among Jews
DOC.TEXT: Democratic gubernatorial candidate John R. Silber sparked protests from Jewish organizations after saying he encountered racism among Jews when he once considered converting. In an article in The Boston Sunday Globe, Silber, who is on leave as president of Boston University, said he considered converting to Judaism in 1948, but decided against it because of their treatment of converts. ``I thought about it, and then found out that the racism of Jews is quite phenomenal,'' Silber told the newspaper last week. ``If you are goyim considering becoming a Jew, you are going to be second-class in that synagogue, and I didn't have any interest at all in moving into that congregation as a second-class citizen.'' In a statement Monday, Silber attempted to explain his comments and said, ``I have never suggested that Judaism is racist.'' But Jewish leaders decried Silber's comments. ``What may have been true of his own experience in 1948 with a certain number of Jews in a particular congregation can hardly be accepted as the basis for a generalization,'' said Leonard Zakim, executive director of the New England chapter of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith. However, Zakim conceded that while Silber's words might have been ill-chosen, the comments do not diminish the candidate's work on behalf of the Jewish people. ``I don't think it changes the fact of his friendship toward the Jewish community and Israel,'' Zakim said. Joel Reck, president of the Jewish Community Relations Council of Greater Boston, said Silber ``is, and has always been, close to and a friend and supporter of Jews, Judaism and Israel.'' Silber, who after 1948 discovered his father was Jewish, was deterred from joining a synagogue by ``the reluctance of members of that congregation to accept him because his mother was not Jewish,'' his statement said Monday. ``Nothing in that experience diminished my deep respect for Judaism and my concern, affection and support for the Jewish people and for Israel, a concern that has been demonstrated with consistency throughout my adult life,'' the statement said. But state Rep. David B. Cohen, president of the New England region of the American Jewish Congress, protested Silber's comments. ``Any time anyone characterizes members of an ethnic or religious group with a broad-brush generality, he is engaging in just that type of stereotyping and prejudice that we are trying to remove from the American political scene. ... I am astonished, disturbed and disappointed that the term racism was used in this context,'' Cohen said. Lawrence D. Lowenthal, executive director of the local American Jewish Committee, said Silber's remarks about Jews ``are simply blatant insults to the Jewish community.''

DOC.HEAD: Search Teams Hunt for Four Skiers Believed Buried in Avalanche
DOC.TEXT: Hopes dimmed for four cross-country skiers feared buried in a massive avalanche two days ago as about 50 people set out today to search a half-mile stretch of deep show. ``It looks pretty bleak,'' Bob Haney, chief warden for Banff National Park, said Monday after a day of ground and aerial surveillance led rescuers to areas deemed remotely possible where they could have been. ``They indicated quite a number of places,'' Haney said. ``We dug down with no positive results. It all brings us back to this one massive slide path.'' Officials called Sunday's avalanche one of the largest in recent history. Monday's search was hampered by snow driven by a biting wind that sent temperatures plunging. Four tracking dogs searched a 6-mile-long trail for any scent of the four along the slopes about 50 miles west of Calgary. ``The avalanche path itself looked like a lunar landscape with some snow slabs the size of my truck,'' said reporter Chris Dawson of the Calgary Herald. ``It was an absolutely sobering experience. I can tell you my heart was in my throat.'' The searchers expected to advance short distances today and shove long, thin, high-tension rods into the snow until they reach ground level or strike a body. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police said the missing skiers were Charles Coombes, 55, a physics professor at the University of Calgary; his wife, Clara, 56; Verne Powell, 49, an engineer with TransAlta Utilities; and Charles Lorenzo, 58, a composing room employee at the Calgary Herald. A fifth person, Lilie Collins, 50, turned back before the avalanche because of fatigue.

DOC.HEAD: Aoun Calls Up Reservists, Clashes in East Beirut
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 5th pvs, `By police...' to UPDATE with report of Aoun-Geagea call. Picks up 6th pvs, `The command...'
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Michel Aoun called up reserve forces today in apparent preparation for an assault to overrun part of the Christian enclave north of Beirut and cripple a rival Christian militia. Aoun's gunners and militiamen of Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces dueled with howitzers and mortars in east Beirut and the snow-blanketed mountains northeast of the capital in the 15th day of the intra-Christian showdown. The Lebanese Red Cross committee issued radio appeals for urgent blood donations and police reported early in the day that rescuers removed 18 rotting corpses from east Beirut streets. A police spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations, said nine people were killed and 22 wounded in the fighting today between Aoun's fighters and Geagea's militiamen in east Beirut and Kesrouan province. By police count the overall toll stood at 498 killed and 1,724 wounded since the struggle began Jan. 30 for domination of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave. Geagea, in an interview with the Arabic service of Radio Monte Carlo, said Monday he had talked to Aoun by telephone and asked for peace negotiaions. ``I told the general that we should negotiate to put an end to this useless war, but I cannot accept to be annihilated,'' Geagea said. He did not say when the conversation took place. The command of Aoun's estimated 19,000-strong army, in a communique, called up reservists and volunteers who received training in the use of weapons during a six-month confrontation with the Syrians last summer. The additional fighters, the communique said, will be ``immediately armed to join their units.'' It did not give further details. Aoun is believed to have a reserve force of about 2,000 retired military personnel in addition to a 4,000 volunteer-reserve fighters. Beirut's prestigious An-Nahar newspaper said the intra-Christian confrontation was heading for a ``swift, conclusive battle.'' It said Aoun wanted to overrun the Kesrouan province, a traditional stronghold for Geagea's 6,000-strong militia, to seize the harbor facilities and Central Bank offices in Jounieh, 12{ miles from Beirut. Military sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, also said Aoun appeared determined to dislodge Geagea's militia from its main power base in Kesrouan. One source said Aoun's gunners were maintaining artillery barrages and a series of hit-and-run attacks against the militia in Kesrouan to run down their enemy's ``ammunition and effort before the major battle.'' There have been no significant gains in territory since the confrontation shifted to the Kesrouan province on Saturday, the source noted. Police reported civilians were fleeing the mountain resorts of Ajaltoun, Bekfaya and Daraya despite heavy snows to escape the battle everybody seems to expect. President Elias Hrawi appealed Monday to the superpowers, France and the Vatican to support possible intervention by his Syrian-backed troops to halt the fighting. Hrawi made a similar appeal last week. Beirut newspapers said Pope John Paul II and France, traditional protector of Lebanon's Christians, warned against Syrian military intervention. Aoun does not recognize Hrawi's Christian-Moslem government, which is backed by Syria. He also has vowed to drive the Syrians, who support the Moslem militias of west Beirut, from Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Teachers to Leave Classrooms to Press Salary Demands
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Washington teachers are pressing for higher salaries with a one-day walkout today, while the governor expressed sympathy but rejected a pay boost this winter. About 200,000 students faced a winter's day off with the planned walkout by by 13,000 teachers in 35 of the state's 296 school districts. Eight thousand other teachers pledged to attend after-hour rallies and marches. A similar stalemate is developing in West Virgina, where thousands of teachers have said they would leave their classrooms Thursday to protest low wages and education funding despite the governor's stand the state has no money for them. In Washington state, Seattle's 43,000 students were among those facing a day off. The protest was mostly confined to western Washington, but teachers everywhere were angry over Gov. Booth Gardner's decision to ignore the organization's request for immediate 10 percent pay increases, union officials said Monday. ``We want the public to understand we're reaching a crisis point in Washington,'' said Teresa Moore, spokeswoman for the 49,000-member Washington Education Association. But a group called Citizens United for Better Education denounced the walkouts. ``I don't think it sets a good example for a third grader when their teacher is standing on the street corner chanting, `Hell, no, we want more,''' said Fred Brown, president of the Woodinville-based group. The Legislature approved a two-step pay boost of 10 percent last year. The union wants another 10 percent _ a retroactive 6 percent for this school year and 4 percent in the fall. Such an increase would cost about $225 million, which union officials said could be financed by a $611 million state budget surplus. Gardner, a Democrat who has called himself ``the education governor,'' told a rally of about 250 school board members and school administrators Monday that he is committed to developing a world-class education system. But he said the state budget surplus is a one-time phenomenon, and nothing on which to base continuing salary increases. Gardner said he wants to keep one third of the windfall in reserve, spend one third on children's programs such as school improvements and hiring more child protective services workers and use the rest to cover other needs such as as cost increases in social programs and general government. But the union said teacher salaries should be a priority. ``Salaries have dropped from fourth in the nation a few years ago to 21st today,'' Moore said. ``That has an impact on national competitiveness, the ability to keep good teachers, and also an impact on how we can attract new people into the profession.'' The average teacher is being paid about $33,100, plus $2,100 in supplemental pay for extra chores, acording to the governor's Office of Financial Management. Starting pay is about $18,000. In West Virginia, at least 2,400 union teachers in five counties had voted by Monday night to walk out Thursday for a rally at the Capitol. Union teachers in nine other counties also voted to walk out, but their numbers were not known. ``The momentum is growing,'' said West Virginia Education Association Vice President Jennie Shaffer. West Virginia's 22,000 teachers earn an average of $21,904 a year, which ranks 48th nationally, according to union leaders. Gov. Gaston Caperton has not included a pay raise in his 1990-91 budget. ``The governor has said over and over and over again'' that there is no money for teacher raises in 1990-91, spokesman G.C. Morse said Monday night. ``There's gotta be a point where people realize we're not making this up.'' But Mary Carden, president of the Boone County Education Association, said: ``There's a myth that the state is broke, and we're not buying into it. ... We've had two governors who said they wanted to help education and they haven't done it.''

DOC.HEAD: Arctic Air Chills West, Midwest; Alaskan Cold Snap Ends
DOC.TEXT: The seven-week warm streak in the West and Plains shattered today as arctic air drove temperatures far below the record-setting readings set earlier this week. The southern Plains, Southeast and Gulf states, however, looked for the heat to continue. Temperatures along the front range of the northern Rockies were predicted to fall by as much as 50 degrees and tumble to below zero today in the upper Midwest. Alaska enjoyed a warming trend today as an 18-day cold snap ended with cloudiness and higher temperatures spreading across the state. Temperatures within the Arctic Circle were expected to rise above zero for the first time since the third week of January. Today's forecast called for cold, moist winds to dump snow from Montana to northeastern Colorado and parts of Nebraska. Mountain snow was predicted today for parts of California, Washington, Utah and Idaho. The arctic front cooled avalanche threats in Washington's Cascades and flood threats on the Chehalis River. The Northeast should be cloudy, windy and warmer today. Some snow may precede a warm front into New England. The eastern Great Lakes looked for colder weather and showers, with rain turning to ice. Flurries were predicted around Lake Superior's snow belt. Balmy weather prevailed in the nation's midsection on Monday, with 20 cities _ including seven in Iowa _ setting record highs for the date. Temperatures soared into the 70s as far north as Nebraska and Iowa. Minneapolis, Minn., eclipsed the previous high of 47 degrees with a reading of 59. High winds were expected today in parts of Nevada and in Southern California's mountains and deserts. Clouds draped much of the north-central and western states. Snow fell from the Pacific Northwest to the northern and central Rockies. The high for the nation Monday was 87 degrees at Laredo, Texas. DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose in early European trading today. Gold prices were mixed. Foreign currency dealers said the dollar was benefiting from the West German mark's weakness. The mark has been depressed by uncertainty over prospects of a West German-East German monetary union, which dealers fear would weaken the currency. ``The big news about opening the frontier between East and West Germany, which caused the mark to strengthen so rapidly, is already out,'' said one trader in Milan, Italy. ``Now the tough questions are ahead. The question of monetary union has tremendous problems attached ... It's natural that the mark has weakened a bit, and that the dollar has taken some of its strength.'' In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.24 yen to a closing 144.48 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 144.65 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: _ 1.6830 West German marks, up from 1.6695 _ 1.5035 Swiss francs, up from 1.4960 _ 5.7278 French francs, up from 5.6785 _ 1.8969 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8890 _ 1,252 Italian lire, up from 1,242 _ 1.20 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2023 In London, the dollar rose against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.6849, compared with $1.696 late Monday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $420.40 a troy ounce, up from $419.50 bid late Monday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $419.75. In Zurich, the bid price was $419.60, up from $419 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $5.17 to close at a bid $419.58. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.34 a troy ounce, from Monday's $5.32.

DOC.HEAD: Jury: Monsanto Not Liable for Toxic Waste Site
DOC.TEXT: Jurors cleared Monsanto Co. of any liability in a lawsuit brought by more than 200 homeowners who feared chemical waste dumped by the company near their homes endangered their health. ``I just don't believe this. I'm in shock,'' said Judy Romeo, who abandoned her home of four years about five months ago. ``I'm going to go home and have a good cry.'' The 222 homeowners sought $355 million in damages from Monsanto, which is the chief user of the Brio Waste Site near their subdivision. The plaintiffs asked for $1.6 million each, which they said was equivalent to Monsanto's daily profit margin. But jurors in the unanimous verdict Monday said the plaintiffs had failed to show that it was unsafe to live in the Southbend subdivision southeast of Houston. ``It was a very, very difficult decision,'' said jury foreman Alfred Morales. ``I would have to say that there was lack of evidence, in my opinion, that we were looking at.'' Juror Jim Stecker said, ``I believe that it is safe to live out there.'' Homeowner Herb Bateman disagreed. He said he moved his family from the subdivision in August because, ``We felt our lives and our children's lives were in danger.'' Michael Waldeck, an attorney for the homeowners, said he would appeal. The jury's verdict came after nearly a week of deliberations and four months of testimony in state district court. The homeowners said the Brio waste site has led to medical problems ranging from upset stomachs to headaches. Some residents testified they feared contracting cancer in the future because they live so close to the waste site. Monsanto denied responsibility for any injuries, saying it is one of many companies that has used the dump site.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Reported Dead in Tadzhikistan, Trouble Spreads to Suburbs
DOC.TEXT: Soviet soldiers and armored vehicles controlled the center of Tadzhikistan's capital today but rioting that claimed the lives of seven people and injured scores was spreading to the suburbs, a journalist reported. Rioting broke out in the central Asian republic's capital of Dushanbe on Monday after rumors spread that Armenian refugees from ethnic violence in the Caucasus were being given preference for new housing at the expense of natives. The rioters smashed windows and set fire to the ground floor of the republic's Communist Party headquarters and attacked stores and passers-by, said Anatoly Larenov, a correspondent for the national newspaper Vozdushny Transport. Seven people were killed and 79 hospitalized with injuries, he said. Musafar Madzhidov, correspondent for official radio and television in Dushanbe, said rioting broke out after two rallies in a 24-hour period prompted by the rumors of preferential housing. Members of the crowd shouted, ``Down with the Armenians,'' he said. The Soviet news agency Tass reported Monday night that a state of emergency was declared in the city to quell ``mass disorders and pogroms, and acts of arson and looting.'' It said a 10 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew was imposed. It was the latest violent flare-up in ethnic unrest that has spread throughout the Soviet Union's southern rim in recent months as Moscow loosens control and allows nationalist mass movements to gain strength and challenge Communist authorities. Larenov said in a telephone interview that the center of Dushanbe was quiet today after the curfew ended for the night. Tanks and soldiers were stationed in front of the party headquarters, banks and other institutions, and the center of the city was under military control. But he said trouble was spreading to the suburbs of Dushanbe, a city of more than 500,000 people. Larenov said officials had evacuated Armenian families before the trouble started Monday, and that most of the anger was directed at Russian-speaking people. A list of those killed did not appear to include any Armenian names. Armenians, a predominantly Christian people, have been involved for the last two years in bloody dispute with predominantly Moslem Azerbaijanis over control of the Nagorno-Karabakh region of Azerbaijan. More than 200 people have been killed in the southern Caucasus republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan since Jan. 13. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev sent thousands of soldiers into the area to end a nationalist revolt in the Azerbaijani capital of Baku and end attacks on Armenians. Until Monday, there had been no reports that the trouble had spread to the predominantly Moslem republics of Soviet Central Asia such as Tadzhikistan.
