Madzhidov said that Tadzhikistan's Communist Party leader, Kakhar Makhkamov, appeared before a crowd that gathered Sunday outside party headquarters in Dushanbe and asked for 24 hours to investigate rumors Armenian refugees had been guaranteed housing in new suburbs while Tadzhiks were kept waiting. Another crowd gathered on Monday, but ignored his report that all but one Armenian refugee already had left Dushanbe, he said by telephone. They pelted the party headquarters with stones, breaking all the windows, and then went on a rampage through shops located nearby, he said. Police fired in the air to disperse the crowd, but the rioting continued until armored vehicles brought soldiers into the city center, Madzhidov said. Families in Tadzhikistan, a small mountainous republic bordering China and Afghanistan, traditionally are large, and there is a critical shortage of housing. Some of the mainly Moslem Tadzhiks also remain homeless after an earthquake in the republic in January 1989 that killed scores of people.

DOC.HEAD: Tadzhikistan at a Glance
With PM-Soviet-Unrest
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures about Tadzhikistan:

THE LAND _ Tadzhikistan covers 55,240 square miles, bordered on the north by Uzbekistan and the Kirghiz republic, the east by Chinese Turkestan and the south by Afghanistan. Its huge mountain glaciers are the source of many rapid rivers and the republic contains rich pasture lands.

THE PEOPLE _ Nearly 60 percent of the republic's 4.8 million residents are Tadzhiks who speak an Iranian dialect little different from Persian, but most Tadzhiks are Sunni Moslems, not Shiites like the Iranians. About 23 percent of the people are Uzbeks, who live in the northwest, and 10.5 percent are Russian or Ukrainian.

THE ECONOMY _ The major occupations are farming, horticulture and cattle breeding, but large industrial enterprises have been established that include mining and textile factories. Tadzhikistan produces apricots, olives, figs, olives, pomegranates and many other kinds of fruit. The Gissar sheep is famous for its meat and fat, and the Karakul for its wool.

HISTORY _ Tadzhiks are considered the descendants of the original Aryan population of Turkestan. The Tadzhik Soviet Socialist Republic was formed from those regions of Bokhara and Turkestan where most of the population was Tadzhik, and became part of the Soviet Union on Dec. 5, 1929.

DOC.HEAD: Virginia State Legislators Endorse Smoking Bill
DOC.TEXT: The House of Delegates has given preliminary approval to a bill to restrict smoking, despite some legislators' fears of the political consequences in this tobacco-growing state. ``Seldom in my career have I built my own political gallows and provided the rope,'' Delegate Charles Hawkins, a Republican from Pittsylvania County, said Monday. ``If I vote for this, I might be doing that.'' The bill, which was passed in a voice vote Monday and is due for a final House vote Tuesday, was approved over the objection of health lobbyists and legislators who backed a bill calling for stricter smoking regulation. If it's approved in the final House vote, the bill would have to be reconciled with a more stringent bill recently approved by the Senate. ``We're in a position to negotiate, which is better than nothing,'' said Sen. Thomas J. Michie Jr., who sponsored the Senate bill. In addition to requiring no-smoking areas in government buildings, the bill's main impact would set standards for local no-smoking ordinances. Local governments would be allowed to demand no-smoking areas in restaurants and ban smoking in elevators, schools, indoor service lines and school buses. But local ordinances could not regulate smoking in businesses with less than 10,000 square feet of floor space _ so-called mom and pop stores. Nor could they regulate smoking in privately owned meeting rooms, in theaters or on public transportation. The bill also does not address smoking in private work areas. A rejected rival bill, similar to that already approved by the Senate, would have allowed workers to declare their areas smoke-free by a two-thirds vote.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Decries ABA Resolutions on Investigations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf, Attorney General, to CORRECT Ayer's title to Deputy Attorney General sted Attorney General
DOC.TEXT: New American Bar Association resolutions passed over Justice Department objections would restrict the ability of federal investigators to subpoena lawyers or talk to their clients. The resolutions dealing with the sensitive area of attorney-client privilege were passed on voice votes Monday at the ABA's midyear meeting in Los Angeles. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh dispatched Deputy Attorney General Donald B. Ayer to appeal to the delegates to vote down the resolution. But ABA officials said the 11th-hour lobbying came only after the Justice Department refused for more than a year to discuss the issues. The resolutions were the result of increased concern among the nation's lawyers that federal prosecutors and criminal investigators are violating the confidential relationship between attorneys and clients. One resolution called for the Justice Department to obtain court approval before issuing grand jury subpoenas for attorneys. Such subpoenas must be authorized by senior Justice Department officials and have become more frequent over the last decade with the increased investigation of white-collar crime and drug trafficking. A second resolution criticized a memorandum issued last June by Thornburgh that says federal prosecutors and agents investigating a case may talk to people represented by counsel without getting the permission of the lawyer. The ABA says this practice violates its Model Code of Professional Responsibility as well as many state and local bar ethics codes. The attorney general disputed that and said the Justice Department would resist attempts by state and local bar groups to impose ethics regulations ``to curb legitimate federal law enforcement techniques.'' Thornburgh argued that the ABA's restrictive interpretation of the code of conduct could hamper legitimate law enforcement efforts, such as contacts by Justice Department lawyers investigating procurement fraud and employees of defense contractors. ``A restrictive application of these local bar rules would enable company counsel to control the government's access to the company's employees,'' the attorney general wrote. The ABA report adopted along with the resolution said Thornburgh's policy ``presents a substantive and substantial threat to the administration of justice.'' ``Suffice it to say, I don't agree with that characterization,'' Thornburgh told reporters in Washington before the ABA vote. Justice Department spokesman David Runkel said the resolutions would ``have no immediate impact, and our views hold.'' The Justice Department would wage a state-by-state fight against any changes in the ethics code to inhibit federal prosecutors. On the issue of attorney subpoenas, Ayer told delegates in a letter the resolution ``would substantially impede criminal investigations.'' ``The more difficult we make it to obtain unprivileged information from attorneys, the more criminal enterprises will seek out and hide behind unwitting or unscrupulous lawyers,'' Ayer wrote. Michael Ross, chairman of the ABA's grand jury section, said the Justice Department sought a last-minute meeting to discuss the issue after refusing to do so for 18 months. ``The war on drugs has convinced the government that the only constituency it has to answer to is the man on the street,'' said Ross, a former federal prosecutor who practices criminal defense law in New York City. ``The man on the street doesn't care about individual rights but cares about, understandably, the horrors that drugs bring with it,'' he said. ``Clearly, attorney subpoenas will not solve the drug problem,'' Ross said. ``Clearly, ethics rules won't solve the drug problem. But the guy on the street feels this is a get-tough policy.''

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: FBI Seized Bomb Materials
DOC.TEXT: FBI agents seized items that could be used to make a pipe bomb such as those that killed a federal judge and civil rights lawyer during a search of property owned by a man convicted 18 years ago of possessing a similar bomb, a newspaper reported. The Atlanta Constitution quoted federal sources it did not identify in today's editions as saying laboratory tests are pending to establish whether the items found on the property of Walter Leroy Moody Jr. match the two bombs that exploded in December. Moody denied any connection with the bombs, his lawyer said. The bombs sent through the mail killed U.S. Circuit Court Judge Robert Vance in Alabama and lawyer Robert Robinson of Savannah, Ga. Two other bombs were safely intercepted. Investigators confiscated 2{-inch pipe, six-penny nails, rubber bands, alarm wire, flashlight bulbs, bolts, paper clips, gunpowder-packed bullets and welding machinery _ all similar to items used to make the mail bombs, the newspaper said. Also seized were adhesives, brown paper, labels, tape and ``old'' string, the paper reported. Similar materials _ particularly a unique string that has not been manufactured for about seven years _ were used on the packages in which the four bombs were mailed. The Constitution, in a story also copyrighted by The Atlanta Journal, reported that agents seized the following: _Seventeen 25-cent ``flag over Yosemite'' postage stamps in the pocketbook of Susan McBride, who lives with Moody. That stamp was used on all four package bombs. _A desktop copier. Photocopied, typewritten letters from a purported group calling itself ``Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System'' were sent after the bombings. _Highlighted newspaper clippings about the FBI's investigation of Robert Wayne O'Ferrell, an Enterprise, Ala., junk-store owner whose home and business were searched last month and who has been questioned repeatedly. O'Ferrell denies any knowledge of the bomb attacks. _Two typewriters that were examined on the scene and determined not to match the ones used by ``Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System.'' Moody, reached at his Clayton County home, referred inquiries to his attorney, Michael C. Ford. ``I don't see anything there that I see as significant,'' Ford said of the seized items. ``They found brown paper. Well, I hope they don't search my office. I probably have some of that, too.'' Ford said two motions were filed in federal court Monday seeking the return of Moody's property and attacking the searches as faulty. He said Moody has no connection to the bomb attacks. Moody, 55, a self-employed literary consultant, was convicted in 1972 of possessing a pipe bomb that the newspaper's sources said is very similar to the December package bombs. He was acquitted on a charge of building the bomb, which injured his then-wife, Hazel, in their Macon, Ga., home. In his appeals in that case, court records show Moody was extremely critical of the attorney, judges and government agents associated with his case. During an interview Friday with WSB-TV, Moody said, ``Criticizing the court is not an unhealthy practice, I don't think. I think it's unhealthy when you say, `If you don't rule my way, then I'm going to send you a bomb.' That's ridiculous.'' Moody served nearly three years in the Atlanta Federal Penitentiary on the bomb possession conviction but maintains his innocence. He is representing himself in asking the U.S. Supreme Court to throw out his conviction after an 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals panel denied his third appeal in June. Vance was not on that panel.

DOC.HEAD: Retail Sales Climb 1.6 Percent in Janaury
DOC.TEXT: Retail sales, driven by renewed automobile sales incentives, climbed 1.6 percent in January, the steepest increase in more than a year, the government reported today. The Commerce Department said sales increased to a seasonally adjusted $146.4 billion after declining a revised 0.2 percent in December during what analysts described as modest holiday shopping. The January gain was the sharpest since a 2.1 percent advance in October 1988. December sales originally had been reported to have gained 0.2 percent. A drop in estimated auto sales accounted for the decline. Overall sales in November rose 0.7 percent. Retailing usually slows in January because of the previous month's activity. Half or more of retail profits come from business between Thanksgiving and Christmas. Retail sales account for about one-third of the nation's economic activity and thus are a barometer of economic growth. The economy, particularly the construction and manufacturing sectors, has been squeezed by high interest rates as the Federal Reserve kept a tight rein on credit to cap inflation. The automobile industry, slowed by the high rates and rising prices on 1990 models, reinstituted rebates on many models last month to lure buyers to dealer showrooms. Commerce said auto sales gained 5.4 percent in January after falling 2.6 percent in December. It was the largest advance since a 6.6 percent increase in October 1988. Autos represent about 20 percent of retail sales. Excluding autos, retail sales for the month would have risen 0.6 percent. The overall durable goods category _ including cars and other big-ticket items expected to last more than three years _ gained 3.9 percent after declining 2.1 percent in December. Buildings materials advanced 2.3 percent, while furniture and other home furnishings rose 2 percent. Sales of non-durable goods such as food and clothing edged up 0.3 percent. Gains were posted by gasoline stations, up 2.5 percent; drug stores, up 2.3 percent; department stores, up 2.2 percent, and restaurants and bars, up 1.5 percent. Declines included grocery stores, down 0.4 percent, and apparel, down 0.7 percent. For the three months from November through January, overall retail sales were up 3.8 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Will Allow Last-Resort Use of Heart Devices
DOC.TEXT: A prominent surgeon who took exception to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration's disapproval of an artificial heart says a modified order allowing last-resort use may save lives. FDA officials ``are reasonable people; I think they came up with a reasonable decision,'' said Dr. Jack G. Copeland, who heads the heart transplant and artificial heart programs at University Medical Center. Last month, the FDA withdrew its approval for use of Symbion Inc.'s total artificial heart both as a permanent implant and as a temporary bridge to transplantation, saying there were ``serious deficiencies'' with its manufacture. The federal agency also withdrew its approval for use of the Tempe, Ariz., company's acute ventricular assist device. The artificial heart was developed by Dr. Robert Jarvik and initially was called the Jarvik-7. Jarvik no longer is associated with Symbion, which markets the artificial heart as the Symbion-7. The university said in a statement Monday that the FDA ``will not object to the use of the Symbion devices as a last resort after all alternative treatments with commercially available or approved investigational products have failed, or are determined to be inappropriate for the condition(s) to be treated, and when no other life-saving device is available to save the life of the patient.'' Richard Alder, president and chief executive officer of Symbion, confirmed Monday night that the FDA would permit last-resort, live-saving uses ``under certain, very prescribed conditions.'' The change was outlined in a letter the agency sent ``fairly recently'' to organizations that had been using the devices on an investigatory basis, he said. Alder said Symbion and FDA officials were setting up meetings to try to resolve remaining issues involved in last month's action. In response to the FDA's announcement last month, Copeland said that if the need arose he might defy the ban. Copeland said then the effect of withdrawing the Symbion devices would be ``to deprive potentially hundreds of critically ill patients of a chance for life.'' On Monday, Copeland said, ``We're pleased that the FDA and Symbion have opened a dialogue and we hope that there is a mutually agreeable solution soon.'' Copeland said he had called FDA officials ``as an individual physician'' after its initial letter and told them, ```Now we're in limbo again. Every time we put this device in somebody's gonna say that we're defying the FDA, and we know scientifically that they're good devices. ``I felt that it was an untenable position they were putting us into.'' Copeland said FDA officials told him ``they thought I had a point.''

DOC.HEAD: All-Party Coalition Dissolves, Service Government Remains
DOC.TEXT: Political party leaders pulled their ministers out of the governing coalition, but said they would continue to support a caretaker administration until national elections April 8. Party members who hold posts in Premier Xenophon Zolotas' Cabinet will be replaced today by other politicians who will lead Greece to its third national election in 10 months. ``We decided unanimously to withdraw our ministers from the government of Mr. Zolotas. The government will remain under his leadership and will continue to enjoy our confidence,'' said conservative leader Constantine Mitsotakis after a meeting with Zolotas and the socialist and Communist Party leaders. Mitsotakis leads the New Democracy Party, the largest political force in the country which narrowly missed winning a parliamentary majority in June and November elections. ``Many things separated us ... there were differences of opinion,'' he said, explaining the sudden end of the joint administration with the other two parties. He did not name the differences, but since the Zolotas government was given a mandate to tackle pressing economic and foreign policy issues in November, Mitsotakis has demanded that the administration be short-lived. He has claimed that the all-party government is hamstrung in taking decisions on tackling a $1.9 billion budget deficit, 14 percent annual inflation and problems with neighboring NATO ally Turkey. General elections are scheduled in April.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Putting Brakes on Alternative Fuel Cars Idea
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs pvs 5th graf, The Atlantic, with 2 grafs to elaborate on reformulated gasoline; note two grafs embargoed for release at 11:45 a.m. EST after 10th graf, bgng ``We have''
DOC.TEXT: Under pressure from the auto and petroleum industries, the Bush administration is backing away from a proposal that would require millions of alternative fuel cars to be sold in cities most plagued by smog. The phasing in of cars powered by fuels such as methanol or natural gas was a centerpiece of President Bush's clean air proposal last summer. The White House envisioned use of up to 1 million such vehicles annually by 1997 in an attempt to ``reconcile the automobile to the environment.'' But William Reilly, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, acknowledged Monday that the administration no longer considers mandatory production of alternative fuel cars as an essential part of clean air legislation. Instead, the administration is proposing in negotiations with Senate leaders that ``reformulated'' gasoline, which also cuts pollution, would be welcomed as an alternative to the alternative fuel vehicles. The Atlantic Richfield Co. is already starting to put reformulated gasoline into pumps in Southern California in an attempt to reduce smog-causing emissions. Unlike alternative fuel cars, vehicles using reformulated gasoline do not require any additional equipment or modifications because the pollutants are removed from the fuel itself in the refining process. ``There is no change in the goals or the performance objectives that we want to achieve, but we have tried to indicate more flexibility about methods of getting there,'' Reilly told a group of reporters. For example, he said, a city that has been unable to meet air quality requirements still would have to achieve certain annual reductions in smog-causing pollution. But that might be achieved by having all cars use reformulated gasoline, instead of having 30 percent of the cars powered on alternative fuels as was envisioned under the original proposal. Reilly conceded the proposal requiring automakers to build a specific number of alternative fuel cars ``has caused us considerable opposition'' and kept some senators from supporting the administration's clean air proposal. ``We have been willing for some months to redraft some language on the alternative fuels to try to reassure people that ... we do not prefer one fuel over another,'' said Reilly.
DOC.HEAD: Following for release at 11:45 a.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: But in a speech prepared for delivery to a trade conference in Scottsdale, Ariz., an EPA supporter of alternative fuels said they offer the only hope for severely polluted cities. ``If you don't have clean alternative fuels, forget about attainment,'' said Charles L. Gray, director of the EPA's emission control technology division in Ann Arbor, Mich.
DOC.HEAD: End embargoed material
DOC.TEXT: Neither the House nor Senate clean air bills include a requirement for alternative fuel cars. Instead, the Senate bill would impose a second round of automobile tailpipe emission controls, which the auto industry and the White House have vigorously opposed. In negotiations with Senate leaders, the Bush administration has sought to substitute its proposal _ including an option for using reformulated gasoline _ for the second round of tailpipe controls. Some Senate Democrats have expressed frustration in recent days over the changes in the administration's alternative fuels proposal, maintaining that although the White House opposes the second round of tailpipe controls it is now offering a substitute that is weaker than what Bush called for last summer. That original proposal envisioned phasing in a 30 percent use of alternative fueled cars in heavily polluted cities, or more than 1 million cars by 1997. At a White House ceremony June 12, Bush called the alternative fuels program a ``bold new initiative to reconcile the automobile to the environment.'' But automakers and the petroleum industry have waged strong lobbying campaigns against the alternative fuel proposal. The oil companies expedited introduction of the reformulated gasoline and have argued it is a better way to reduce smog than shifting to fuels such as methanol or natural gas. The car manufacturers said they were worried customers might not buy so many alternative fuel cars and have argued against the government mandating production and sale of such vehicles.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Said Proposing Big-Power Conference on German Unity
With PM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is proposing a big-power conference with the two Germanys to work out a framework for German reunification, government sources said today. She wants the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France _ the original occupiers of Germany after World War II _ to meet at foreign-minister level with representatives of East and West Germany, said the sources at her Downing Street headquarters. They spoke on condition they not be identified. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd drew up a detailed proposal and discussed it with Britain's allies at this week's East-West ``Open Skies'' conference in Canada of 23 nations, the sources said. The proposal is expected to be amplified when Mrs. Thatcher meets Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany in London on Wednesday. Genscher asked for the meeting, the sources said. They said no date was being set for the conference, but it was hoped it would take place soon after East Germany's March 18 elections. Any formulas agreed upon would then be presented to the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Mrs. Thatcher's proposal is seen as a response to critics who accuse her of seeking to slow the momentum toward reunification. The British leader has not disguised her concern that hasty moves could undermine European security. On Saturday, at a meeting of her Conservative Party, Mrs. Thatcher stressed that the 1975 Helsinki agreement stipulated that ``no boundaries would be changed except by agreement.'' ``So if any boundaries are to be changed, this requires massive consultation between us,'' she said. ``All this means the changes they are having now in Germany and moves towards unification must be done in accord with the other obligations to which we signed up.'' The Daily Mail, which first carried the report today, said the conference could produce an agreement ``tantamount to a German peace treaty.'' No peace treaty was signed after World War II, and although the United States, Britain and France renounced their status as occupiers in 1955, they retain authority in Berlin and maintain armies in West Germany. The Daily Mail said Mrs. Thatcher's proposal was a way of saying: ``Let's be practical and settle the complex problems at the conference table rather than through demonstrations in the streets.''

DOC.HEAD: Military Officers Demand Resignations of Ministers
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 300 military officers demanding the resignations of the defense and interior ministers protested silently today outside government headquarters on Victory Square. The uniformed officers from the army, navy and air force said they wanted to replace the incumbents with people untainted by December's revolution, or by long association with ousted Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Defense Minister Gen. Nicolae Militaru held a series of high army posts before being demoted and pensioned off by Ceausescu, who was ousted Dec. 22 and executed three days later along with his wife, Elena. Militaru came out of retirement during the revolution and was named minister of defense by interim President Ion Iliescu. Interior Minister Gen. Mihai Chitac is a former commander of chemical warfare troops. The officers cited unconfirmed rumors that Chitac shot demonstrators in the western city of Timisoara, where the revolution began. Some 700 regular soldiers from Valea Jiului in southwest Romania also demonstrated in the square, demanding that they be released from the army. Another group of 100 workers, shouting ``Where are our rights?,'' also demonstrated for changes in working conditions and higher salaries. The protests took place as Romania's new coalition government held its second meeting. The agenda included discussions on the government's precise role and a report from Prime Minister Petre Roman on the state of Romania's battered economy. In its first order of business, the national council, which counts more than 250 members, agreed to limit speeches to three minutes. Leaders of the major opposition parties threatened Monday to pull out of the council if the previously dominant National Salvation Front that took power in the December revolution does not stop what it called manipulation of the new body. One major charge against the front, which has said it will contest the free elections May 20 against the other, weaker opposition parties, has been its control of radio and television andits alleged refusal to allow other parties access to the media. An air force officer said today that as long as Iliescu ``chooses to have people next to him like ex-generals, we do not agree with him.'' He said the air force had good, untainted officers who could replace the old generals. A pilot said the officers were very angry that the pilot who flew the helicopter in which Ceausescu fled Bucharest on Dec. 22, identified in press reports only as Lt. Col. Malutan, was not dismissed and instead promoted to full colonel. Malutan was quoted in news reports as saying he deliberately flew low in order to be detected by radar and prevent Ceausescu from escaping.

DOC.HEAD: 45th Anniversary of Dresden Bombing Marked
DOC.TEXT: The people of Dresden today recalled the devastating Allied bombing raids 45 years ago that killed 35,000 and leveled one of Germany's most important cultural centers. The ceremonies were the first not rigidly directed by Communist leaders, who traditionally had used the observances as a forum for bitter attacks on the West. Public officials and citizens, led by city Mayor Wolfgang Berghofer, placed wreaths and flowers at a memorial cemetery where 29,000 victims of the attack _ many of them women, children and old people _ lay buried. The mourners stood before a simple memorial plaque engraved with the words of an unknown writer: ``How many died, who knows the number? In your wounds one sees the agony of the nameless that were burned to death here in a hellfire started by human hands.'' Many victims, burned beyond recognition or crushed in cellars of bombed buildings, were never identified. The Dresden bombings are described vividly in the popular novel ``Slaughterhouse Five,'' by Kurt Vonnegut Jr. While East Germany's official news agency ADN today said 35,000 had died in the bombings, other estimates put the number far higher. The actual figure is still a point of controversy. The bombing raids conducted by British and American forces remain controversial to this day. East Germans, along with others, argue that the intensity of the attack was not necessary militarily. Similar observances, some including readings of eyewitness accounts of the attack, took place at other cemeteries and sites associated with the bombing. Several of the city's historical buildings have been reconstructed. Several representatives from Dresden's partner cities throughout the world also joined in the observances. Dresden authorities were determined to avoid the Communist show and propaganda that characterized Dresden observances in the past, according to a Feb. 10 report in the Munich-based ``Sueddeutsche Zeitung.'' ``Participation of the people who live here is voluntary, there will be no ordered delegations,'' the newspaper quoted a Dresden city press spokesman as saying.

DOC.HEAD: US Says Rebel Activity in Laos Increasing
DOC.TEXT: Anti-communist insurgents in Laos have increased their activities lately and government forces have fought back with ground and air attacks, the State Department said today. In written responses to press questions, the State Department said some reports suggest the government counter-attacks have resulted in significant casualties among civilians of the Hmong hill tribe. ``Reports indicate that the government has used troops, artillery, armed helicopters and planes from its MiG-21 squadron against the resistance,'' the State Department said. ``We would view with strong concern both attacks by government forces which injure civilians as well as attacks by resistance groups on forces and officials of the Lao government,'' it said. The U.S. government has maintained diplomatic relations with Laos, which came under communist rule 15 years ago. It has no relations with the communist governments in neighboring Vietnam and Cambodia. The statement said the United States does not support Lao resistance activities either directly or indirectly. The U.S. government does not recognize a provisional government in western Lao proclaimed by the resistance in December.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Moves to Unify Party
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today moved to reconcile hard-line and moderate opponents in his Likud bloc after a party meeting ended in chaos and Trade Minister Ariel Sharon threatened to leave the Cabinet. There was confusion inside the right-wing party, and political observers were divided about whether Shamir or Sharon had emerged victorious from the stormy session Monday. There is a lot of time for maneuvering because by Israeli law, a resignation has to be formally announced by a minister at a Cabinet session. Then, a resignation letter is submitted to the premier, and it takes effect only 48 hours later. Party activists today tried to persuade Sharon, the former defense minister and architect of Israel's 1982 Lebanon invasion, to withdraw his letter of resignation. Sharon told Israel radio he had no plans to retract his threat, he also left a door open to compromise. He noted that he had quit on principle, and ``I would prefer certainly to stay in the government.'' The impact on Middle East peace efforts of Sharon's resignation and of the chaotic Likud Central Committee meeting also remained uncertain. Sharon's departure from the Cabinet could remove an obstacle to U.S.-sponsored efforts to start peace talks with Palestinians, since he is the ringleader of the hard-line camp. But Shamir, trying to hold the party together at the meeting, restated his opposition to at least some U.S.-backed compromises for starting peace talks. Labor Party chief Shimon Peres said of Shamir's speech, ``I don't think that this was a great contribution to the peace process.'' Labor is Likud's partner in the coaltion government and advocates compromise with the Arabs. Sharon had protested the government's failure to end the 26-month Palestinian uprising and ensure permanent Israeli rule in all of Jerusalem _ including the Arab eastern sector that was annexed after the 1967 Middle East war. The 90-minute session in Tel Aviv broke up about an hour later after Sharon interrupted an attempt by Shamir to win a show of support for his peace initiative. The plan calls for elections among Palestinians in the occupied lands. Hundreds of arms went up in Shamir's support, but Sharon shouted into a microphone: ``Who is for liquidating terror?'' His supporters responded with cries of ``Arik! Arik!'' Sharon's nickname. Both leaders claimed they won, and Shamir walked out. After a two-hour cooling-off period, Shamir held a reconciliation meeting with key Sharon backer and Deputy Premier David Levy, who is a leading contender for party leader after Shamir. Winning Levy's support, or neutralizing his backing for Sharon, could significantly enhance Shamir's image. The Moroccan-born Levy, a former construction worker, is a representative of the largely disadvantaged Sephardic community of Middle Eastern and African Jews, a major power base of Likud. Levy planned to meet today with Sharon and his supporters to persuade him to stay in the Cabinet, officials said. While the chaos seemed almost normal for Israeli politics, some politicians and editorial writers expressed worry over the disorder in Likud and the uncertainty over who rules the party. ``A body that cannot rule itself will find it hard to rule the state,'' said Mordechai Gur, a Labor member. The conservative Maariv daily wrote that Israel's image was ``hurt badly by what happened yesterday ... and Israel has enough problems already.''

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Told: No Quick Fix for Acid Rain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT name of program.
DOC.TEXT: A decade after embarking on a comprehensive study of acid rain, scientists say there's no quick fix for the pollution that can despoil mountain lakes and kill towering trees. But scientists from around the word who gathered here to review the research were told Monday their work has brought the problem into better focus. About 700 scientists from 35 nations are meeting this week at a conference sponsored by the National Acid Precipitation Assessment Program. The agency was established a decade ago by Congress and has spent $500 million investigating the problem. At that time, some people wanted to declare a national emergency because of acid rain, said John Knauss, undersecretary of commerce for oceans and atmosphere. Others wanted to do nothing. ``The former group _ those who feared the worst _ was convinced that a 10-year research program was simply an excuse for postponing immediate action,'' he said. ``The latter was convinced that spending so much on what they saw as a non-problem was a waste of precious research dollars. ``Today, there are few left who feel we need to declare a national emergency, just as there are few who consider acid deposition a non-problem,'' he said. Acid rain is a combination of sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide that mixes in the atmosphere and can fall as rain, snow, fog and dust particles. It can make lakes and streams acidic and can kill trees. The assessment program has compiled 28 reports comprising about 15,000 pages on the causes and extent of acid rain. The documents include no recommendations and scientists were told Monday there is no simple answer. ``The full story is seldom, if ever, known about the complex issues of environmental science,'' said William Rosenberg, an assistant administrator for the Environmental Protection Agency. ``Scientific investigation must continue _ including an evaluation of the control program put in place. In the meantime, we must take prudent actions to protect our health and our environment.'' Michael Deland, the chairman of the Council on Environmental Quality, told the group, ``You have changed the way the world thinks about acid rain.'' But he added, ``It is highly unlikely we'll reach scientific certainty on issues like acid rain.'' In his clean-air legislation, President Bush proposed a 10 million-ton reduction by the turn of the century in sulfur dioxide, one of the main ingredients in acid rain. Most of the reports that are the focus of the meeting have been released during the past two months. This week's meeting gives scientists from aboard a chance to review the material and critique their colleagues' work.

DOC.HEAD: `Rebel' English Tour Curtails Tour After Growing Opposition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 5th pvs, `Anti-apartheid...' to UPDATE with details, comments. Pick up 6th pvs, `English captain...'
DOC.TEXT: The protest-plagued tour of an English cricket team was sharply curtailed today under an agreement with anti-apartheid groups, organizers said. The South African Cricket Union agreed to cancel the team's match against the South African national team and cut the English side's remaining schedule from eight to four matches. The team has play four matches since arriving last month in defiance of an international sports ban. The anti-apartheid National Sports Congress say it had agreed to end protests in return. ``The National Sports Congress has agreed to withdraw protest action,'' said NSC General Secretary Krish Naidoo. Anti-apartheid activists have demonstrated at all of the team's matches, often leading to confrontations with police. Demonstrations have also been staged at hotels where the English team have stayed. Police said the decision to curtail the tour was ``totally unnecessary.'' A statement said authorities had been able to control protests against the tour. The South African Cricket Union, which arranged the tour, said it was cutting the schedule because of recent political developments. ``It is our duty as responsible sports administrators to be sensitive to wider interests,'' the union said. It apologized to ``cricket lovers'' and promised refunds to people who had purchased tickets for the canceled matches. English team captain Mike Gatting had no immediate comment. The English team defied an international ban on sports contacts with South Africa because of its apartheid policies. The English players are receiving $160,000 for the tour, with Gatting getting $320,000, according to local press reports. Naidoo said he hoped the compromise would help end apartheid in sport and promote mixed black and white teams. But the anti-apartheid group ``regrets that the tour was started in the first place and against all advice,'' Naidoo said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Drops Final Charge Against Panamanian Industrialist
DOC.TEXT: Federal prosecutors have dropped the final charge against a Panamanian industrialist whose drug arrest reportedly halted U.S. covert financial support of Panamanian opposition politicians. U.S. Attorney Edgar W. Ennis Jr. said Monday he asked U.S. District Judge Wilbur D. Owens to dismiss money laundering charges against Carlos Eleta Almaran because there was not enough evidence to convict him. Two cocaine conspiracy charges were dropped in January for the same reason, he said. Eleta, 71, initially was billed by drug agents as the head of a conspiracy to smuggle 1,320 pounds of cocaine a month into Macon and launder drug profits through dummy corporations. Eleta and two of his countrymen were arrested April 6, 1989, after a five-month investigation by the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration. Manuel Castillo Bourcy, 58, a former ambassador to Belize, and Juan Karamanites, 35, pleaded guilty last fall, but signed affidavits saying Eleta had no knowledge of the conspiracy. Eleta's arrest abruptly ended a U.S. covert operation to help political opponents of then-Panamanian leader Manuel Antonio Noriega, The New York Times has reported. The Times, quoting unidentified federal officials, said Eleta's arrest surprised the CIA, which it said had been relying on him to funnel money to Noriega's opponents. The charges against Eleta disturbed members of congressional intelligence committees, and caused the CIA to halt its program, the Times reported. Noriega was ousted in the U.S. invasion of Panama last month. Ennis issued a statement saying the charges were dropped when ``it became apparent that it would be in keeping with Castillo's character to attempt to ride upon the prominence of Carlos Eleta to serve his own ends, and that he could have done so without full knowledge on Eleta's part.'' Eleta's lawyer, Greg Craig of Washington, said his client was gratified by the decision. ``Carlos Eleta trusted a friend who didn't deserve his trust and helped a friend who didn't deserve his help,'' Craig said. Eleta has been free on $3 million bail and living in Miami awaiting his Feb. 20 trial.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Envoys Being Recalled by Solidarity Government
DOC.TEXT: The Solidarity-led government will replace 19 ambassadors appointed by previous Communist governments, a newspaper and sources said today. Among the ambassadors being recalled are the envoys to Czechoslovakia and East Germany, where leadership has changed from hard-line Communists to pro-reform democrats during the past four months, the pro-Solidarity daily Gazeta Wyborcza said. A source in the Foreign Ministry, who asked not to be identified by name, told The Associated Press that more than 19 ambassadors would be replaced. Prominent among them are those who ``came to this service from outside, from the so-called `nomenklatura' (party elite) who were not so well prepared to be ambassadors,'' he said. But he said that in an ordinary year, 25 to 30 ambassadors are replaced, so ``this is not so unusual.'' Ambassador Jerzy Kuberski, the envoy to the Vatican appointed in July when diplomatic relations between Poland and the Holy See were established for the first time in 50 years, is among those being changed, according to Gazeta Wyborcza. The newspaper also mentioned the ambassador to Prague, former Politburo member Wlodzimierz Mokrzyszczak, and the ambassador to East Berlin, former Deputy Prime Minister Janusz Obodowski, as being called back to Warsaw. Other prominent appointees from the previous power structure who are being called back include former Politburo members Tadeusz Porebski and Gen. Jozef Baryla, from Yugoslavia and Syria respectively, said Gazeta Wyborcza. In most cases, the recalled ambassadors are ordered to return to Poland by the end of March, Gazeta Wyborcza reported. Under previous Communist governments, ambassadorships were often given to senior party officials after they were retired from the Politburo, Central Committee or as party secretaries. Technically, President Wojciech Jaruzelski, the longtime Communist Party leader, is in charge of appointing and dismissing ambassadors. But Jaruzelski has been following the recommendations of the Solidarity-led government, which then must be approved by the Parliament foreign affairs committees. Solidarity activist Tadeusz Mazowiecki became prime minister in August and his foreign minister, Krzysztof Skubiszewski, was confirmed in September. Skubiszewski told the newspaper Rzeczpospolita last month that he wanted ``slow and gradual'' change in the diplomatic corps. ``I prefer to spend more time looking for candidates in order to find really good candidates,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Assesses $210,000 Against Reputed Wiretappers
DOC.TEXT: A judge has assessed $210,000 in punitive damages against two men who failed to convince a jury that their employer ordered them to perform hundreds of illegal wiretaps. Hamilton County Common Pleas Judge Fred J. Cartolano ordered the assessments Monday against former Cincinnati Bell Telephone Co. employees Leonard Gates and Robert Draise. ``You have to be punished,'' Cartolano said. ``I don't think you two have that much in assets, but I think you should be made an example for others.'' A jury found that Gates and Draise had defamed Cincinnati Bell, its parent company Cincinnati Bell Inc., and company supervisors with their wiretap claims. Jurors awarded $110,000 in compensatory damages, and said the judge should add punitive damages because Gates and Draise recklessly disregarded the truth in their accusations. After the jury announced its verdict on Jan. 23, Cartolano said he, too, had concluded that Gates and Draise lied. Cartolano said the law allows him to use punitive damages as both a punishment and as a deterrent. Although he acknowledged that the amount might not be collectible, he added, ``It is not my job to collect the damages.'' Gates and Draise testified Monday that they are out of work, deeply in debt, and have only a few hundred dollars in available cash. During their eight-week trial they represented themselves because they said they could not afford lawyers. The two men claimed they wiretapped more than 1,200 telephones between the early 1970s and 1984 on orders from Cincinnati police and Bell security supervisors James West and Peter Gabor. They claimed the taps were placed on the phones of various community leaders, reporters, criminal suspects, a federal judge and President Ford during a 1975 visit. Several past and present police officers admitted using the two men for about a dozen illegal taps in the early 1970s. But the police said Bell supervisors were not involved. Bell, West and Gabor denied any knowledge or participation in such activities. Phone company lawyers contended the two men were seeking revenge because Bell fired Draise in 1979 and Gates in 1986. Bell spokeswoman Cynthia Cantoni said the company was pleased with the judge's ruling, and that the fact that damages were assessed was more important than the dollar amounts. Gates and Draise stuck by their stories and said they are raising money to pay for an appeal. ``We are not surprised at anything. ... The public knows the wiretapping happened,'' Gates said. Several alleged victims of wiretapping are suing police and the city of Cincinnati. The case is scheduled to go to trial Feb. 20 in U.S. District Court.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Push for Expanded `Open Skies' Pact
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2 grafs for 3rd pvs, `In their...' to UPDATE with West German comment, session opening. Pick up 4th pvs, `In calling...'
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze urged the United States to expand its proposal on military surveillance flights to include sea and space, but the Bush adminstration rejected the idea. Shevardnadze pushed the proposal Monday at the outset of a meeting of the 23 members of NATO and the Warsaw Pact on allowing the alliances to make unarmed reconnaisance flights over member countries. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher opened today's session by hailing the ``Open Skies'' idea, saying: ``I am convinced that this openness and cooperation will increasingly become the natural form of relationship in Europe and North Amera.'' On Monday, Shevardnadze and Secretary of State James A. Baker III broke with the recent trend of soft-spoken reconciliation, leveling criticism at each other's stances on arms control. In calling for expanding ``open skies'' surveillance to the seas and space, Shevardnadze said sea-launched nuclear missiles are the ``darkest corner'' of arms control efforts. ``There can never be too much verification,'' he said. U.S. officials dismissed the idea, telling reporters in a separate briefing that Washington was not interested in a naval arms control agreement and that surveillance flights already are allowed over oceans and in space. Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Victor Karpov later reiterated the Soviet position and also said that the six Warsaw Pact countries would like to share information and planes in a common ``open skies'' fleet. The ``open skies'' plan, part of an idea first proposed in the 1950s, was revived by President Bush in May. The plan has been promoted as a confidence-building measure and both alliances have agreed to it in principle. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany told reporters Monday that he did not consider differing positions obstacles to a pact, and that both sides hope for final agreement by mid-year. The Open Skies plan is not linked to any other treaty negotiations. But the gathering in Ottawa has provided the first forum for face-to-face meetings since U.S. and Soviet leaders proposed deeper troop cuts in Europe. Hard-line Communist leaders have been thrown out of office in nearly every Warsaw Pact country since Bush made the Open Skies proposal. ``It potentially is the most ambitious measure to build confidence that we have ever taken,'' Baker said at Monday's opening session. ``We believe it can build confidence and predictability,'' Shevardnadze said in his opening statement. Both sides expressed hope that countries outside NATO and the Warsaw Pact eventually would become part of an Open Skies pact. NATO has said each alliance should make its surveillance flights separately and share data only within their blocs, although countries being surveyed would be allowed to inspect aircraft before flights. Karpov said Monday that the Warsaw Pact countries were aligned behind the Soviet position of shared data and shared flights, but he held out the possibility of compromise. The common fleet idea was not contained in the Warsaw Pact's working proposal for the conference, he said. ``Both sides are looking for a common ground,'' Karpov said. Most smaller countries welcome the Open Skies plan because they lack the satellite technology to conduct surveillance on their own and depend on their larger U.S. or Soviet partners for intelligence. Shevardnadze and Baker strayed from the main topic when they began criticizing elements of each other's positions on arms control. In pushing for greater monitoring of weapons at sea and potential weapons in space, Shevardnadze criticized the United States for excluding naval forces from disarmament talks and for seeking through development of ``Star Wars'' to put nuclear weapons in space that would block a missile attack. ``Let us face the truth,'' Shevardnadze said. ``Today, the easiest way to launch a surprise attack, a military invasion or an aggression is from the seas.'' Baker, meanwhile, said positions taken by Moscow on troops and aircraft still stand in the way of completing a treaty this year to limit non-nuclear forces. He criticized Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev for rejecting a proposal by Bush that would permit the United States to keep a total of 30,000 troops in Britain, Italy and Spain while both sides maintain 195,000 troops in Central Europe. Gorbachev had countered with ceilings of 225,000 Soviet troops to 195,000 U.S. soldiers on foreign soil throughout Europe. That would, in effect, prevent a U.S. numerical edge because the Soviets could offset in Central Europe any Americans stationed elsewhere on the continent. Bush said Monday that he stood by his plan but told reporters in Washington that he expected a ``major success'' on arms control at June's superpower summit in the United States. The first two days of the three-week Open Skies conference are dedicated to meetings of foreign ministers. Lower-level officials then will take over the talks with the aim of having a document ready to sign by mid-year at a second conference in Hungary.

DOC.HEAD: Oldest Member of Congress to Seek a Seventh Term
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-5, `In Indiana...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Coats announcement. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `In Maine....'
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Strom Thurmond, who at 87 says the secret to long life is good diet, exercise and optimism, has announced he'll run for re-election in November. He has no formal challengers. Thurmond became the oldest member of Congress when Rep. Claude Pepper, D-Fla., died last year at age 88. If Thurmond wins, he would be 94 when his new term _ his seventh _ ends. His announcement Monday came a day before planned announcements by candidates elseswhere. In Indiana, Republican Sen. Dan Coats announced his candidacy today for the Senate seat he was appointed to fill after Dan Quayle was elected vice president. Coats faces Baron Hill, a Democratic state representative. ``Our first challenge is to sustain and expand the remarkable economic growth of the last six years,'' Coats said. ``That means making `made in the USA' what the world wants to buy, no new taxes, and finally mustering the will to balance the budget.'' Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M., also was expected to announce his re-election bid today. He has no announced opposition. In Maine, Sen. William S. Cohen, was embarking on a bid for a third term. He will be challenged by state Rep. Neil Rolde, a Democrat from York. In Minneapolis, Democrat Ted Mondale, son of former Vice President Walter Mondale, today planned to announce his first bid for elected office as a state Senator a western suburban area of Minneapolis. His opponent would be Republican Phyllis McQuaid, who holds the seat. In Ohio on Monday, auto dealer Steve Tatone said he would seek the Democratic nomination for the state's 7th Congressional District. Tatone will face another Democratic, a retired Air Force officer, Jack Schira, and state Sen. David Hobson, a Republican. Michael DeWine, the GOP incumbent, is running for lieutenant governor. In his western South Carolina hometown, Thurmond told a small gathering he was proud to be a South Carolinan, working to make it the greatest state in the Union. ``I wouldn't elect a man just because of his seniority, but if he has all the other qualifications then it should be counted, and it is very helpful,'' said Thurmond, a Republican who has served in the Senate since 1955. ``In all my years of public service I have never felt a stronger obligation to continue my work for the future of our state and our nation,'' he told a small group of supporters. Thurmond has campaign funds of about $700,000 for the campaign, according to the Federal Elections Commission, and no formal opposition. Still, he did not seem overly confident he would be victorious in November. ``I've had opponents every time,'' said Thurmond, who wore a red-white-and-blue tie and an American flag pin in his lapel. ``The office belongs to the people. I'm a temporary occupant of the office.'' A former governor, state senator and judge who ran unsuccessfully for president as a Dixiecrat in 1948, Thurmond switched from the Democratic to the GOP in 1964. He served as president pro tempore of the Senate from 1981 through 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Three Suspected Communist Assassins Kill Town Mayor
DOC.TEXT: Three suspected members of a Communist death squad shot and killed the mayor of a town just outside Manila today, the military reported. Mayor Felino Maquinay of Carmona died on the spot with three bullet wounds in the head, said Capt. Romeo Gullas, provincial operations chief of the Philippine Constabulary. Three unidentified youths, believed to be members of the Communist New People's Army, approached Maquinay as he was having lunch and opened fire at close range with pistols, Gullas said. Maquinay's bodyguard and his driver, too surprised by the attack to protect him, were unharmed, Gullas added. The gunmen fled in a commandeered car. Carmona, largely a government resettlement area for squatters, is in Cavite province, just south of the capital.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 8-9, It's an unusual, with Scowcroft saying U.S. agencies are comfortable with security arrangements.
DOC.TEXT: George Bush is no stranger to danger in Colombia. Eight years ago, as vice president, he escaped an apparent assassination plot in which a load of dynamite was buried under the lone runway at the Bogota international airport. The explosives were found hours after Bush's plane took off. Only then did security officials discover the dynamite connected to wires running to an electrical generator 300 yards away. Defense Ministry officials theorized that leftist guerrillas rigged the dynamite in the days before Bush arrived but apparently were unable to sneak back into the area the day of the flight because the army had sealed off the airport. The 1982 incident provides a sharp reminder of the risks Bush faces as he prepares to fly to Colombia on Thursday for a six-hour drug summit with the presidents of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia. Colombian authorities say about 5,000 security agents will be deployed when the leaders meet at a heavily guarded naval base near the coastal resort of Cartagena. Aside from the ground forces, U.S. warplanes may be used to escort Air Force One and Bush's helicopter. In addition, U.S. warships likely will be stationed in the Caribbean. ``It's an unusual situation, because there are in Colombia these guerrilla bands, terrorist bands, with access to funds to purchase ... any kinds of arms, and so naturally there are unusual circumstances,'' Brent Scowcroft, the White House national security adviser said today. However, he said, ``We're comfortable about the president's security. All the agencies involved in presidential security are comfortable with the arrangements.'' ``It's a serious environment to deal with,'' said William A. Hawthorne, who retired from the Secret Service in 1987 as executive assistant to the director. ``The fact that they're going tells me the Secret Service believes they can provide security in that environment. I'm not particularly worried,'' Hawthorne said. Bush, expressing confidence about his security, says he wants to go to Colombia as an expression of support for its president, Virgilio Barco, who is waging war against the country's drug lords. Jerry Parr, head of President Reagan's protective detail, said that on a scale of 1 to 10, the danger to Bush is ``probably a seven or an eight.'' ``It's risky to be president,'' said Parr, who in 1981 shoved a wounded Reagan into a limousine and rushed him to a hospital after an assassination attempt. ``You can't reduce all the risks.'' Typically, he said, the Secret Service sets up three concentric rings of security for the president: an intensely guarded inner circle, a middle circle and an outer perimeter. ``The whole game will be to minimize the danger and reduce the killers' or the assassins' options,'' Parr said. Decoy limousines and helicopters have become standard fare in presidential security. Last week in San Francisco, a decoy motorcade of a half dozen cars fooled raucous demonstrators who were trying to haze the president. The Secret Service also can change travel routes and arrival areas and stage diversions and distractions, former agents say. ``There's going to be some razzle dazzle so people aren't quite clear about who to attack,'' said Chuck Vance, who helped guard President Ford and served on two vice presidential protective details. ``They'll have military personnel everywhere: frogmen, ships, aircraft,'' Vance said. ``I called in a whole (naval) fleet one time in a Moroccan visit for (Vice President Spiro) Agnew'' because of political uncertainties. The Secret Service won't discuss its security precautions or the threat potential to Bush. ``Do the Redskins send their playbook to Dallas the week before?'' asked Robert Snow, head of public affairs for the Secret Service. ``We feel we can do what we have to do,'' he said. ``We're still assessing it every day. It's not a done deal until we go. At this point, it's an hour by hour, day by day evaluation.'' Vance said he considered a direct attack against Bush unlikely. ``They (drug lords) could make a point for a moment but the retaliation would be so severe,'' he said. ``I think you may see some bombings (elsewhere) to show their displeasure and show they have the ability to do something.'' ``You prepare for the worst and hope for the best,'' Parr quoted Secret Service Director John Simpson as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Court Convicts Former Officer in 1987 Coup Attempt
DOC.TEXT: A military court today convicted a former lieutenant colonel of leading a 1987 coup attempt against President Corazon Aquino and sentenced him to 12 years at hard labor. Former Philippine Constabulary Lt. Col. Reynaldo Cabauatan was found guilty of mutiny on April 18, 1987, when rebellious troops stormed the army headquarters in suburban Fort Bonifacio. The mutineers seized some 50 hostages in a bid to free other rebels jailed for a failed coup the previous January. Troops loyal to the late President Ferdinand Marcos seized a TV station and raided at least two surburban military bases in the Jan. 27, 1987, rebellion, which ended after 61 hours when holdouts in the television station surrendered. The court cleared Cabauatan of involvement in the January revolt due to conflicting testimony by prosecution witnesses. The prosecution claimed Cabuatan led soldiers from a province north of Manila to reinforce the rebels in the station, but his troops were intercepted by loyal soldiers at a highway several miles away. Cabauatan, wearing a traditional Filipino formal shirt, appeared unmoved as the verdict was read. His wife cried loudly and his mother fainted as relatives and friends embraced him after the brief proceedings. His 43 co-conspirators in the April 1987 revolt were acquitted by the same court last year. Cabauatan's lawyers said they would appeal today's verdict. His conviction came two months after the Aquino government crushed the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt, the sixth and most serious bid by right-wing military officers to topple Mrs. Aquino.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Cites Complaints Against $20,000 Matchmaker
DOC.TEXT: The high cost of loving is under attack by the state attorney general, who is trying to run out of business a matchmaker who charges up to $20,000. A lawsuit being filed today contends among other things that the matchmaker has given some clients dates with ex-convicts or people ``not quite divorced,'' Attorney General Robert Abrams said Monday. ``Beautiful women do not go to singles bars,'' proclaim the widely published newspaper ads of Helena Amram _ known as just ``Helena'' to those in the dating game. Ms. Amram, 40, of Fairlawn, N.J., who runs three dating services in Manhattan and two in Great Neck, on Long Island, was accused in the lawsuit of overcharging customers and committing other fraudulent and illegal business practices. ``It can never be proved; I'm going to win this case,'' vowed Ms. Amram, who used the occasion to plug her coming book, ``Have I Got a Match for You,'' while fielding reporters' calls at her Madison Avenue office. ``I'm going to be so famous!'' Ms. Amram charged that Abrams is badgering her because she sued him Nov. 28, challenging a $250 restriction on dating services. A judge is to be appointed March 7 for that lawsuit. ``I never break the law,'' she said. ``If the law is no good, then I'm not breaking the law.'' Abrams said his office received about 50 complaints about exorbitant fees and Ms. Amram's alleged failure to live up to the terms of the contract _ such as adequate screening, a specified number of referrals per month and refunds to dissatisfied customers. Abrams said one woman complained to the service that her date had a criminal record. She was offered apologies and told a mistake had been made. Ms. Amram said it's not true her service gets dates for ex-offenders. ``He can never prove it,'' she said of Abrams. ``I check every one. We have an investigation company, a psychologist, a professional staff doing their jobs very, very carefully.'' One woman said she was set up with a free-lance computer programmer ``who was not quite divorced at the time we went out.'' Another also encountered a married man ``who was 100 pounds overweight, with dyed bright orange hair.'' One said her date revealed on the first date that he had a venereal disease. Another woman met a man who ``tried to physically assault me.'' Another woman complained: ``Of the two that called, one was presented to me as a doctor from New Jersey. He turned out to be a physical therapist who never called back after a brief and disturbing telephone conversation.'' Abrams said Ms. Amram also features image consultations _ a service ``generally limited to advising the consumer to lose weight and wear lipstick.'' The lawsuit said Ms. Amram charges $1,250 to $20,000 for social referral services. It wasn't clear how much was paid by the women who complained. Ms. Amram said $20,000 gets a client ``a spouse hunter, so you'll not be in competition. We have membership all over the world. These people are in a separate file, handled by me. Nobody would pay me $20,000 if I did not deserve it.'' She claimed her 22-year career has resulted in ``one wedding a day _ more than 8,000.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Fire Tear Gas to Quell Fighting Among Vietnamese Boat People
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with police correcting figure of demonstrators involved to 300 sted 3,000, seven people injured, more details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Police fired tear gas today to quell clashes among some 300 Vietnamese boat people at a detention center, and seven refugees were injured, officials reported. It was not immediately known what sparked the violence between Vietnamese from different regions of the country at the Whitehead detention center, which houses some 20,000 boat people. Police said an initial, erroneous figure of 3,000 Vietnamese involved in the clashes was based on the large groups who were milling around inside the camp. Some 150 policemen were rushed to the camp at the height of the brawl, which was brought under control about three hours later after 12 tear gas cartridges were fired, the police said. Seven Vietnamese injured in the fighting were taken to a hospital. Their condition was not immediately known. Five people died last year in factional violence that erupts frequently in the crowded and squalid Vietnamese camps in this British colony. The Vietnamese at Whitehead are among more than 40,000 people who have sailed into Hong Kong since mid-June 1988 and are considered illegal immigrants unless they can prove they fled persecution in Vietnam. Those who are denied refugee status and have their appeals rejected can volunteer to go home for face forced repatriation. last December, 51 Vietnamese were returned to Vietnam against their will. Meanwhile, 76 Vietnamese flew home today on a chartered flight, the 11th batch to be repatriated voluntarily from Hong Kong. The voluntary program, run by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, has repatriated 1,184 since early last year.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor Arrested On Federal Drug, Tax Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Doctor's name pronounced Ka-mah-chus.
DOC.TEXT: A diet doctor so well-known he was rated one of the city's top 10 attractions faces federal charges of unlawfully distributing drugs to patients and filing false tax returns. Dr. George Camatsos was in federal custody today in Jackson awaiting a hearing before a U.S. magistrate. He was arrested Monday by Mississippi Bureau of Narcotics agents in Natchez following a grand jury indictment last month. If convicted on all charges, he faces up to 97 years in prison and $5.75 million in fines. Known throughout the South for his unorthodox weight loss methods, Camatsos has patients regularly travel from as far away as Texas to visit him. He also sells his diet drugs from a pharmacy he owns in Natchez. A 1986 Natchez Democrat poll ranked him one of the city's top 10 attractions and local hotels offered discounts for his patients. His lawyer, Angelo Dorizas of Jackson, refused to comment today when reached at his office. Camatsos, a native of Greece in his early 50s, has long been under scrutiny by the Organized Crime Drug Enforcement Task Force, according to court documents. Camatsos is charged with filing false income tax statements in 1985 and 1986 and with one count of conspiracy to unlawfully dispense controlled substances. He also is charged with 20 counts of unlawfully distributing controlled substances. Agents raided Camatsos' office and home on Aug. 14, 1986 and seized several boxes of medical, insurance and financial records, according to an affidavit by narcotics agent Steve Campbell. The raid came a year after seven state and federal undercover agents went to Camatsos posing as patients. Campbell said in his affidavit that all the agents received brief or cursory examinations, attended a lecture by Camatsos on proper nutrition and were told to pick up their unlabeled medicine. State Crime Lab analysis showed the pills included three controlled substances _ two stimulants and the tranquilizer phenobarbital. ``(Agents) observed office employees automatically entering patient symptoms and diagnoses on patient records and insurance receipt forms without being advised of complaints by the patient or diagnosis by Dr. Camatsos,'' the affidavit said.

DOC.HEAD: Eggscellent Idea or Big Yoke?
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli company has hatched a plan for getting its clients' messages directly to the breakfast table _ ads printed on eggs. A company calling itself Golden Eggs introduced its first batch of egg-borne advertisements two weeks ago. ``You can't ignore it when you open the refrigerator,'' Golden Eggs President Rafi Orel said Tuesday. ``It's shouting at you, `here I am'.'' The American photography giant, Eastman Kodak, was the first to try the ads, ordering nine million eggs imprinted with the company's logo and the slogan ``Take a picture with Kodak.'' Orel said each batch of 1 million eggs reaches about 83,000 homes. He said he and an Israeli ad man got the idea several years ago, but before they shelled out money in the company they had to wait for a ruling from Israel's Rabbinate that the dye used in the process is kosher.

DOC.HEAD: Roman Ruins Emerge From River Bottom
DOC.TEXT: Columns and marble blocs from imperial Rome have been discovered by divers on the bottom of the Tiber River, Italian media reported Tuesday. Erosion uncovered the pieces buried underwater since the Roman Empire, according to the reports by state television and local newspapers. Some of the columns found near the suburb of Fiumara are as high as those at the Pantheon, a symbol of Rome's ancient glory. Several marble blocs are marked with the imperial seal. Archaelogoists said they believe the columns and marbles were being sent from a deposit in an imperial port to the capital when a landslide along the Tiber buried them in the river bed. They suspect other pieces could be found near Fiumara. One column was raised from the river bottom and will be displayed in Ostia Antica. It has not yet been decided whether the other objects will be raised or left underwater.

DOC.HEAD: Artist Montgomery, Who Helped Homeless, Dead at 78
DOC.TEXT: Claude Montgomery, who painted portraits of L.L. Bean, Edmund S. Muskie and others and who spent his last five years living in a shelter he founded for the homeless, has died. He was 78. Montgomery died Sunday in Maine Medical Center after a series of illnesses. In 1937, Montgomery made a drypoint etching of an old man on a waterfront, called ``Ol' Joe,'' that was called one of the best 100 prints of the year by the Society of American Etchers. The work was exhibited nationally. Two years later, the piece won a silver medal at the Paris International Exhibition. In addition to Secretary of State Muskie and Bean, Montgomery's subjects included Gov. Kenneth M. Curtis, philanthropist Charles Shipman Payson, publisher Guy Gannett and his daughter Jean Gannett Hawley, and U.S. District Judge Edward T. Gignoux. Portland gallery owner Thomas Crotty, who exhibited some of Montgomery's works, called him a fine painter of portraits and seascapes. ``But his work with the homeless ranks with equal importance to his career as an artist.'' Montgomery and his wife, Louise, used their life savings to buy a house and turn it into a private shelter for the homeless. They lived in the shelter, called Friendship House, and helped more than 600 homeless people in the last five years. Mrs. Montgomery said her husband suffered from alcoholism until 1969, so he felt a special empathy with many of the homeless who were recovering alcoholics. The shelter will ``go on the same as ever,'' Mrs. Montgomery said. ``I have a wonderful group of people here.'' Besides his wife, Montgomery is survived by a son, two daughters and two granddaughters. Services were set Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Great America Park Fires 28 Employees
DOC.TEXT: About 20 percent of the full-time workers at the Great America amusement park have been fired for allegedly stealing company property and using drugs or alcohol on company time. The dismissals of 28 workers, including some in management, occurred Friday. The theme park, closed now, opens for the spring season March 10. ``It is traumatic. In any business, anytime you find you're having drugs in the workplace, it's something you need to deal with. Can you imagine if Great America had this knowledge and didn't act?'' Lise Hurst, a spokeswoman for the park, said Monday. She said the property allegedly stolen was not money, and she described the alleged drug use as small-scale, although declining to say what drugs were involved. An investigation began several months ago, she said, after an anonymous tip. Those employees fired were not offered a chance of undergoing treatment as an alternative. Hurst also said the park won't press charges against dismissed employees.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Panel Reiterates Suspicion Lockerbie Bomb Originated in W. Germany
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. presidential panel today reiterated suspicions that the bomb that blew up Pan Am Flight 103 originated in West Germany, but said security has improved at Frankfurt Airport since the attack. President Bush created the commission on Aviation, Security and Terrorism last August as a direct result of the Dec. 21, 1988, bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland. The seven-member panel is examining options for improving airport security to prevent a similar attack. The bombing killed all 259 people aboard the jumbo jet and 11 on the ground. Commission members spoke to reporters at Frankfurt Airport, where they had looked into security measures. Rep. James Oberstar, D-Minn., said that in an official visit to Frankfurt Airport last June, he noticed there were still security deficiencies despite the Flight 103 bombing. The ill-fated flight originated in Frankfurt, although it changed planes in London. ``My impression then was security was diffuse, too decentralized, there were too many opportunities for intervention (terrorism),'' he said. But since then, better security measures have been put into place at Frankfurt Airport, Oberstar said. ``There's closer coordination among the levels of government. There seems to be better baggage control, there seems to be better baggage-passenger matching, and their technology has improved.'' There have been allegations that lax security allowed the bomb to be placed on board Flight 103 at Frankfurt Airport, but West German investigators have insisted there is no proof the bomb originated here. But the head of the presidential commission, former U.S. Labor Secretary Ann McLaughlin, insisted that theory remains a strong possibility. She said that ``as one looks at the variety of theories, that one certainly has merit. But it would not be up to me to suggest that's a final decision.'' Another commission member, Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., said one key reason the panel came to Frankfurt Airport was to ``see where the hitch was that permitted this (bombing) to happen.'' None of the commission members, however, said they had any final proof the bomb originated in Frankfurt. Ms. McLaughlin said the panel would likely present its recommendations to Bush in mid-May. She would not detail what any of these suggestions might be, but said they would include the areas of prior notification to the general public about terrorist threats, and improving airport and airline security.

DOC.HEAD: Paper Industry Sets Goals of 40 Percent Recycling
DOC.TEXT: The paper industry announced Tuesday that is setting a goal of 40 percent paper recycling by 1995. ``The U.S. paper industry is committed to being part of the solid waste solution,'' said Red Cavaney, president of the American Paper Institute. But, he added in a statement, ``it will require the cooperation of the public sector and the participation of tens of millions of citizens in order to expand collection systems.'' With total paper use expected to be just over 100 million tons by 1995, that would represent a recycling goal of 40 million tons, according to figures supplied by the Institute, the trade association for makers of pulp, paper and paperboard. That much recycling would represent an increase of more than 50 percent from the 26 million tons recycled in 1988, the Institute reported. Cavaney said the industry will establish a computerized system to help communities that undertake recycling programs to find markets for the paper they collect. The paper industry has begun an expansion program to provide more plants to handle the recycling, he said, and public service campaigns will be launched to encourage conservation. To reach the goal of recycling 40 percent of all paper, an industry study said that recycling would need to cover: _More than 50 percent of newspapers. One area where recycling is currently common, about 35 percent of newspapers are now recycled. _Recycling of about 66 percent of old cardboard boxes. _About 50 percent of printing plant scrap and sorted white office paper. _Some 20 percent of mixed papers. Mixed papers are collected unsorted from offices and contain a wide mariety of materials.

DOC.HEAD: Pullout of Invasion Force Completed, White House Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf to correct to Central sted South American
DOC.TEXT: The United States has completed withdrawal of its military force that invaded Panama on Dec. 20, the White House said today. The U.S. troop strength in Panama is at 13,504, below the 13,597 stationed in the Central American nation before the invasion, said presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. More than 14,000 troops had been rushed from bases in the United States for the invasion. While the troop levels have fluctuated by a few thousand over recent years, the 13,000 level is considered in the normal range, he said. That includes, however, the 2,000 extra personnel President Bush sent to Panama following an election last May 7 that was invalidated by now-deposed Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. ``The efforts of all the U.S. military personnel in Panama were key to helping put Panama on the road to democracy,'' Fitzwater told reporters. ``The president commends the efforts of these brave men and women. Their task is something of which all men and women should be proud.''
