The Panama invasion resulted in the combat deaths of 23 U.S. soldiers and the wounding of 324, with 314 Panamanian troops killed and 124 wounded, according to Pentagon figures. In addition, 202 civilians were killed in the fighting. The United States has no plans to withdraw its permanent force in Panama. However, the troops are shifting their emphasis from the traditional one of concentrating on the Panama Canal to help train a new national police force for Panama. Noriega's Panamanian Defense Force was effectively put out of business by the invasion and his ouster, but thousands of its members have signed up for the new police force. Fitzwater said the number of U.S. troops will likely continue to fluctuate in the years to come. Presence of the invasion force was a thorn in the side of Panama's Latin American neighbors who saw the invasion as an unwarranted use of U.S. muscle. President Alan Garcia of Peru initially said he would not attend this Thursday's drug summit in Colombia with President Bush as long as the invasion troops remained. Last week, however, as the U.S. troop withdrawal continued, he announced he would attend.

DOC.HEAD: East, West German Leaders Agree To Talk About Single Currency
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with Kohl, Modrow agreeing to begin talks on a single currency but not setting any target date. Pick up 16th pvs, `Kohl and Modrow...'
DOC.TEXT: East German and West German leaders today agreed to start talks on a common currency as early as next week, but set no target date for monetary union because of East Germany's resistance to capitalist reforms. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl said at a joint news conference with East German Premier Hans Modrow that the two had agreed to form a committee to examine how the West German mark can become the East German currency. But the talks will only consider economic union in principle because pro-democracy forces and rival political parties have effectively forbidden Modrow to commit East Germany to the currency union plan proposed by Kohl. Bonn again rejected an East German appeal for immediate financial aid of as much as $9 billion until an elected government is in power in East Berlin. East Germans go to the polls for their first free elections on March 18, and the absence of an elected leadership is stalling recovery efforts. Kohl's government does not want to loan huge sums to an East German leadership that is expected to be voted out of office in less than five weeks. The uncertainties, meanwhile, continue to fuel the exodus of East Germans to the West. Kohl disclosed that 85,000 East Germans have resettled in West Germany over the past six weeks. Modrow said before his one-on-one talks with Kohl that he was not authorized to approve measures toward monetary union during his two-day visit here. East German political leaders have rejected Bonn's call for making the powerful West German mark the official currency in their troubled nation, fearing that West Germany is pushing the reunification process too quickly. Monetary union would be contingent on a wholesale conversion of the East German economy to market principles. West German leaders consider a common currency the only means of giving East Germans immediate confidence in their future. The decision to form a joint committee will allow preliminary work toward monetary union to begin, despite East Germany's position on the issue. But some West Germans have predicted that the East German economy could collapse before the elections. In the East German city of Leipzig on Monday night, demonstrators demanded an immediate currency union or said they would leave for West Germany _ joining an estimated 2,000 daily who have left for the West. Modrow was accompanied by 17 Cabinet members and at least 10 other experts and advisers for the talks, aimed at determining how the two nations should eventually be reunified, and how East Germany can be kept financially afloat in the meantime. Kohl and Modrow agree that unification is the only means of rescuing the East German economy and providing higher living standards for those in the East. Washington and Moscow have given their blessing to eventual reunification. Kohl returned from weekend talks with Gorbachev saying a unification plan would likely be ready with the agreement of the four victorious World War II allies before the year was out. But the East Germans could slow the pace of reunification with their rejection of West Germany's idea of quickly setting up a monetary union. Another disagreement likely to arise during Modrow's visit was whether a united Germany should belong to any military bloc. Modrow says a united Germany should be neutral, but also has signaled he would be willing to talks about some other arrangement, which he has not disclosed. Kohl has said repeatedly that West Germany is firmly embedded in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and with the United States has rejected neutrality for a united Germany. His foreign minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, says the Soviets are studying ``several possibilities'' for the military posture of a united Germany, without specifying them. The Soviet Union has about 380,000 troops in East Germany. Kohl proposed the idea of monetary union as a means of trying to rescue the East German economy, hemorrhaging from an exodus of workers to West Germany. The exodus is also harming West Germany, seriously straining its housing and job markets and its social services.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Likely to Propose Using US Ships to Help Colombia Interdict Drugs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 5 grafs after 3rd graf, U.S. officials, to update with Bush comment and signing of U.N. compact; edits pvs 4th graf, Scowcroft, at, for transition
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is likely to propose at the upcoming drug summit that U.S. ships be used to provide an offshore ``radar net'' to help Colombia interdict drug traffickers, a top aide said today. National security adviser Brent Scowcroft said the proposal has been ``on the shelf'' since Colombian officials balked at news reports that the United States was considering a naval ``blockade'' of their ports. U.S. officials have denied they ever planned a blockade, calling use of the term unfortunate. Bush, meanwhile, signed a new United Nations compact to help curb international drug traffic and urged other nations to do the same, ``to join us in working together to rid the world of this menace, the menace of drugs.'' The U.N. Convention Against Illegal Traffic in Narcotic Drugs, adopted in Vienna in December 1988, calls upon all nations to make illegal the production, cultivation and transportation of narcotic and other danger drugs. It also calls for tighter controls of chemicals used in drug production, and sets up guidelines for extraditing drug offenders, seizing drug-tainted assets and curbing money-laundering. Bush, at a signing ceremony, said that ``on the eve of our Andean drug summit and the United Nations General Assembly special session on drugs, we call upon all nations to join us in ratifying this convention.'' The Senate ratified the agreement last November. The United States is the fifth of 76 signatories to the convention to ratify it. Meantime, Scowcroft told a White House briefing on Thursday's four-nation drug summit in Cartagena, Colombia, that the United States never planned a naval blockade, but wanted ``to provide a radar net and give the Colombians a better indication'' of air traffic that might be involved in drug trading. ``We would be interested in improved cooperation in that kind of interdiction,'' Scowcroft said. ``It's an idea we think has merit. I expect it might be discussed'' at the Cartagena meeting among Bush and the presidents of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia. ``We're not trying to push the use of U.S. military forces where they're not needed or wanted,'' Scowcroft said. He said the radar screen would be confined to equipment on U.S. naval ships cruising off the coasts of Colombia, and would not entail any land-based U.S.-manned radar installations. However, Scowcroft said the United States has provided Colombia and other Andean nations with radar equipment. Scowcroft said the communique that will be signed by the four presidents on Thursday will address the broad issues of U.S. economic assistance to the Andean nations and will also cover military interdiction assistance. It will call for reducing the demand for drugs in the United States, curbing U.S. export of chemicals such as ether used to manufacture cocaine from coa leaves, and will deal with the export of U.S. weapons to the region and with money laundering, he said. In additon, the United States will promise ``to broaden our reach into international financial institutions'' to gain additional economic aid for the Latin nations, Scowcroft said. U.S. allies ``have an enormous interest in the success of this operation,'' Scowcroft said, noting that the drug problem is an international one. Commenting on a dispute with Colombia over coffee and cut-flower trade, Scowcroft offered little hope that progress would be made on resolving the disagreements at the drug summit. Colombian President Virgilio Barco has complained to Bush that the U.S. Commerce Department is engaged in a trade procedure against Colombian flower growers that could result in big tariffs on Colombian-grown cut flowers. Scowcroft said there is nothing the administration can do about the matter, that the Commerce Department action was initiated after U.S. flower growers protested that Colombia was ``dumping'' flowers in this country at below-fair-market prices. Even though the United States would like to encourage Colombian farmers to grow crops other than coca leaves, ``we don't know exactly how this will work out,'' Scowcroft said. Colombia is also unhappy that U.S. withdrawal from an international coffee-pricing agreement last year sent Colombian coffee prices tumbling. The pricing agreement ``collapsed. Putting it back together again is not easy,'' Scowcroft said. He expressed some skepticism over plans to try to encourage crop substitutions for cocaine production, saying each of the Andean nations would have to work out such specific plans itself.

DOC.HEAD: One Marine Dead, One Injured After Ejecting From Planes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with IDs of pilots, value of plane, and to add that body and wreckage of last month's crash were never found.
DOC.TEXT: A Marine jet pilot died and a reconnaissance observer was hurt when they ejected almost simultaneously from separate aircraft during training missions, a Marine Corps spokesman said. Marine officials at the Air-Ground Combat Center said they were investigating whether the ejections were linked during the incident Monday. Capt. Thomas Kolb, 28, of San Diego, was the pilot killed, said 1st Lt. T.J. Skipton, a spokeswoman at Cherry Point, N.C., where Kolb was based. The single-seat AV-8B Harrier attack jet, valued at more than $20 million, crashed in a remote area. The aerial observer, Capt. Jeffrey P. Schade of Southhold, N.Y., ejected from a two-seat OV-10 Bronco observation and reconnaissance plane that landed safely, said Master Sgt. Sandra Riley at Cherry Point. Schade's age was not immediately available. He suffered minor injuries. The planes, both assigned to the 2nd Marine Aircraft Wing in Cherry Point, were training at the sprawling desert base 125 miles east of Los Angeles. The Harrier pilot ejected at about 10:15 a.m. Monday and was taken by helicopter to the Naval Hospital, where died nearly two hours later, said Capt. Kevin Murphy. An AV-8B Harrier attack jet based at Cherry Point crashed Jan. 25 in Okinawa, killing 1st Lt. Earl Anderson, 24, of Clemson, S.C. Neither his body nor the wreckage was found. Another crashed in South Carolina in May.

DOC.HEAD: Party Brews in Czechoslovakia
DOC.TEXT: Beer lovers in the famed brewery town of Pilsen have decided to mix party politics with the politics of partying. In one of the odder side effects of this country's move to democracy, a group of dedicated beer drinkers have formed their own party to run in Czechoslovakia's first free elections in more than 40 years. ``The main objective of the party is to decrease the price of beer while increasing its quality and consumption,'' the newspaper Mlada Fronta reported on Tuesday. The party also wants 1991 proclaimed the ``Year of Czechoslovak Beer.'' Czechoslovakia ranks second in Europe in per capita beer consumption, and the price of a pint of high-quality Pilsner Urquell is the equivalent of 18 cents. Mlada Fronta did not say how much the Pilsen party wants the price lowered. The party, known as the ``Friends of Beer,'' wants to run in the June 8 elections and hopes to win parliamentary seats, Mlada Fronta said. According to a ``draft'' of new election laws, a party has to have at least 10,000 supporters _ a condition the ``Friends of Beer'' may not find impossible to meet in a country of 15 million where beer is the national drink. ``We don't have to remind you that quite a few people are interested in membership in our party,'' Pavel Mader and Karel Sury, members of the party's preparatory committee, were quoted as saying by state news agency CTK. ``We ask all people who like Czech beer to support our demands by a manifestative gluttony on any day in any pub,'' Mlada Fronta quoted from the party's official declaration.

DOC.HEAD: North Koreans Fire on Guardpost on Eve of Cheney Visit
DOC.TEXT: Military officials said Korean soldiers fired on a South Korean guardpost in the demilitarized zone Tuesday, the eve of U.S. Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney's arrival. The U.N. Command, which is led by the United States, said the North Koreans fired 20 bullets at the guardpost near a border area Cheney plans to visit. U.S. officials said the shooting occurred at 6:11 a.m. about two miles southwest of the joint security area at Panmunjom, the truce village in the demilitarized zone between the Koreas. They said the South Koreans did not return fire and no injuries were reported. Cheney is to visit Panmunjom and nearby U.S. camps Friday, the third day of his visit to South Korea for security talks. Firing covered several seconds, but the type of weapons used was not clear, U.S. officials reported. ``Any shooting in the DMZ is a serious violation,'' one U.S. official said, on condition of anonymity. ``That it occurs on the eve of the visit of a U.S. Cabinet officer has to be considered in the investigation.'' U.S. Adm. Larry G. Vogt, senior U.N. Command delegate to the joint Military Armistice Commission, demanded an investigation by North Korea, but got no immediate response. The commission oversees the truce that ended the 1950-53 Korean war. The communist North and capitalist South remain technically at war because no peace treaty has been signed, and the DMZ is one of the world's most heavily guarded borders. Shooting incidents in the zone have been frequent, but military observers say the number has decreased in recent years, especially near the truce village where periodic talks are held. In 1988, a South Korean soldier was wounded in the last major incident. North Korean soldiers also opened fire in November, when a colleague defected to the South through the demilitarized zone. Cheney's arrival Wednesday will begin a two-week trip that also includes visits to Japan, Hong Kong and the Philippines. An official of South Korea's Defense Ministry said the agenda for his meetings with President Roh Tae-woo and other officials includes cutbacks of U.S. forces and an increase in South Korea's financial contribution. About 43,000 American soldiers are stationed in South Korea under a mutual defense agreement. On Jan. 30, Cheney announced the closure of three U.S. air bases in South Korea and withdrawal of 2,000 support personnel as cost-saving measures. The Defense Ministry official said topics to be raised in talks with Cheney include plans for the relocation of U.S. military headquarters from central Seoul to southern areas. Roh and other South Korean officials have expressed readiness to accept more U.S. cutbacks of support personnel, based on mutual agreement. U.S. troop reductions are a sensitive issue in South Korea. North Korea and some dissidents in the South demand the immediate withdrawal of U.S. forces, but polls indicate most South Koreans support the American presence.

DOC.HEAD: Rains Flood Southeastern Iran
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with casualties; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Rivers burst their banks on Tuesday after two days of unrelenting rain, flooding huge sections of southeastern Iran and killing at least 11 people, official Iranian news media said. Ten people were killed when a minibus fell into a river and another person drowned Tuesday following floods in large regions of Iran's Sistan-Baluchistan province, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, said the town of Chabahar on the southern tip of the province and more than 60 surrounding towns and villages were submerged. IRNA said rivers burst their banks after three days of non-stop rain that have submerged about 2,700 square miles of the region. Travelers caught in the flood were picked up by helicopters. A Boeing 747 jet and a C-130 transport plane loaded with food and supplies were sent to the region, said a Tehran radio report also monitored in Nicosia.

DOC.HEAD: Pa. House Approves Bill Requiring More Women's Restrooms
DOC.TEXT: Looking to flush long lines at women's restrooms down the drain, the House on Tuesday approved legislation that would require more bathrooms in new public buildings. The House voted unanimously for the bill, dubbed potty parity or restroom equity. It now goes to the Senate. The state Labor and Industry Department would determine how many more restrooms would have to be built in new buildings or in those that undergo 50 percent construction or renovation. Covered in the bill are stadiums, community and convention halls, public schools, sports and entertainment arenas and state buildings. Hotels and restaurants are exempt. Rep. Ruth Rudy, who sponsored the measure, said the bill would help older women and women with young children especially. Rep. Bruce Smith, a co-sponsor, said Pennsylvania would become the fourth state to have a restroom equity policy. ``I think that it's a women's issue, a fairness issue, a common-sense issue,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Finds Drug Use Down Among Young Adults
DOC.TEXT: Use of illegal drugs by high school seniors, college students and other young adults declined further in 1989 as anti-drug attitudes increasingly took hold, an annual survey found today. Frequent drug use has been sliding even faster, and today the likelihood that a high school senior or college student will use drugs routinely is about half what it was a decade ago, according to the study. ``This reduced demand is attributable largely to the important changes occurring in the attitudes, beliefs and social norms among our young people,'' said Lloyd Johnston, a University of Michigan social scientist who helped conduct the survey. Johnston said the decline has come about because anti-drug education has made illegal drug use unfashionable, and he noted the dropoff has been occurring despite students' belief that marijuana and cocaine are easy to get. Drug use among high school seniors peaked in 1981, when 65.6 percent of those surveyed said they had used marijuana, cocaine or some other illicit drug at least once during their lives. That figure dropped during the decade to 50.9 percent last year. The 1989 survey of college students found that 36.7 percent used an illicit drug at least once during the previous year, compared with 56.2 percent in 1980, when this survey began. Among young adults aged 19-28, use of an illegal drug within the previous year dropped to 32.8 percent in 1988 from 41.9 percent in 1986. In 1979, nearly 39 percent of high school seniors said they had used an illegal drug during the previous 30 days, and by 1989 that figure had dropped by nearly half to 19.7 percent, according to the survey. College students saw a similar decline _ from 38.4 percent in 1979 to 18.2 percent last year. Johnston said that although the survey missed high school dropouts, the data suggest the decline in drug use may also extend to this group as well. The survey found the dropoff in use was at least as great among high school seniors who were frequently truant and had poor grades as among those who were seldom truant and had good grades, he said. Use of crack, a highly addictive and smokable form of cocaine, also appears to be dropping, Johnston said, although not as much as use of powdered cocaine. The survey of high school seniors, which began in 1975, polled about 17,000 students in 135 public and private high schools nationwide. The other survey is a follow-up study of previously participating graduating classes. In this survey, about 1,200 college students and about 6,600 high school graduates who are one to 10 years past high school were questioned by mail.

DOC.HEAD: Group Seeks to Limit Service in House and Senate
DOC.TEXT: A bipartisan group announced today it will seek passage by state legislatures of resolutions calling for 12-year limits on service in each chamber of Congress. ``We propose to move towards a re-invigoration of our Congress by restoring the citizen legislature envisioned by our founders,'' said former one-term Republican Rep. James K. Coyne of Pennsylvania, co-chairman of Americans to Limit Congressional Terms. Members of the House serve two-year terms and senators serve six-year terms. Under provisions of the Constitution in effect since it was adopted 200 years ago, they may serve any number of terms. The group's proposal would limit a person to serving 12 years in the House and 12 years in the Senate in his or her lifetime. That would mean a limit of 24 years overall in Congress. The group is acting under a provision of the Constitution allowing the legislatures of two-thirds of the states to propose a constitutional amendment. Congress, on receiving such a proposal, would call a constitutional convention. Alternatively, Congress itself could propose an amendment. In either event, it must be ratified by three-fourths of the states. Coyne said South Dakota already has passed such a resolution and action is pending in Alaska, Arizona, Colorado, Connecticut, Idaho, Kansas, Missouri, New Hampshire, Utah, Vermont, Wyoming, Florida, Louisiana and Hawaii. ``We have a very, very real chance of doing it quickly,'' Coyne said. He said his organization is bipartisan and has 118 state legislators, 34 former members of Congress and two current members of Congress on its national advisory board. He said he did not know the party breakdown. Cleta Mitchell, a former Democratic state legislator from Oklahoma, joined Coyne in announcing the effort.

DOC.HEAD: Troopers Called in as Schools Reopen in Tense City
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with attendance figures, quotes on security. Picks up 9th graf, `More than....'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XSEL1
DOC.TEXT: Public schools reopened today amid heavy security after a week-long shutdown in a racial protest, but about 150 black students marched outside the high school and chanted ``Shut 'em down! No school!'' Hundreds of other black students filed inside Selma High School, although they waited about 10 minutes after the bell rang. White students walked inside well before the bell, with security provided by state troopers, National Guardsmen and military police as well as Selma police. School officials reported that 1,368 students, or 23 percent of the school system's 5,971 students, were absent this morning, compared with normal absenteeism of about 5 percent. Enrollment dropped from 6,049 last week. Selma High closed Feb. 6 and all 11 public schools in the city have been closed since Wednesday as tensions rose in a racial protest over the white school board members' vote to dismiss Norward Roussell, the first black school superintendent in this landmark city of the civil rights era. Student protesters voiced support of Roussell and of his efforts to limit a program known as leveling or tracking, which blacks say unfairly puts black students in slower-learning groups while whites mostly are in faster-paced classes. ``Down with tracking! Equal education!'' the protesting students shouted today as they marched around the high school's flagpole. The protesters earlier marched to the school while law officers stood guard, and at one point the marchers had a brief confrontation with state troopers. When several troopers told the marchers they needed to stay away from the school, the marchers stopped to pray, and the troopers took off their hats during the prayer. The students then moved through the troopers, who did not try to physically restrain them as they went to the flagpole. ``There is no reason for all this security, because they didn't come here to be violent,'' said Dallas County Commissioner Perry Varner, a black protest leader who was arrested in a melee in the mayor's office last week. ``This is the first time troops have been used to ensure that whites could go to school,'' said Jamie Wallace, executive vice president of the local chamber of commerce. More than 100 black students who staged a sit-in at the city's only public high school voted Monday night to continue their protest at the school today. ``The battle is on with the school until we get what we deserve,'' said state Sen. Hank Sanders, whose daughter Malika, an 11th-grader, is one of the protest leaders. Roussell, whose dismissal at the end of the school year sparked the protests, said his wife, a teacher, and daughter, a fifth-grader, would be back in school today despite anonymous threats he had received. ``I have some concerns about personal safety and their safety. This is an emotional issue tied to political and racial attitudes,'' he said. At the meeting Monday at First Baptist Church where black students voted to continue the protests, Roussell praised the students for their conduct during the sit-in, but told them and about 300 adults that he did not ``come here to be superintendent over empty classrooms and closed schools.'' Roussell took over the $80,000-a-year job 2{ years ago after serving as an associate superintendent in New Orleans. The racial turmoil began Feb. 2 when six white members of the city school board voted to dismiss Russell. Protests closed two schools Feb. 6 and all 11 of Selma's public schools Wednesday. Roussell was reinstated, but the board declined to extend his contract beyond its June expiration. Roussell and his supporters say the board opposes him because of his race, not his alleged lack of managerial skills cited in an evaluation. He said his white support started eroding when he proposed changing the system's tracking program to enable more blacks to get into predominantly white, higher-level classes. The enrollment is about 70 percent black. On Monday, about 150 black students sitting in at Selma High met with Roussell, then rolled up their sleeping bags and marched a mile to City Hall, where a sit-in of about 25 students and adults has continued non-stop since Thursday. ``He's our leader. He felt it was in our best interest to leave. Plus, the school board would fire him if we didn't leave,'' student protester Latima Salaam said. After the protesters left the school, some white parents stopped by to pick up their children's belongings so they could transfer to other schools. Sandra Knapp Sewell said she and her daughter, Melissa, were moving 35 miles east to Prattville. Those transfers, estimated by Selma's two all-white private schools to be as many as 35 in one day, included the sixth-grade son of white school board member Edie Jones, who enrolled Monday at all-white Morgan Academy in Selma. ``I'm leaving a place I've lived in 45 years to make sure she has a safe place to go to school,'' Mrs. Sewell said. Also Monday, U.S. District Judge Charles Butler of Mobile refused to a request by the city to grant a temporary restraining order against the sit-ins after getting assurances from the protesters' attorneys that they would not disrupt classes and would soon leave City Hall. City attorney Henry Pitts urged the judge to prohibit the protesters from ``totally paralyzing city government.'' He said the dispute now does not involve the human rights that were at stake in 1965 when the Selma-to-Montgomery voting rights march helped blacks gain access to ballot boxes across the South.

DOC.HEAD: Allies, Soviets `Close' on German Reunification: Hurd
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs; edits to tighten; note a0547 should have been slugged PM sted AM
DOC.TEXT: British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd announced today that the Western allies and the Soviet Union ``are quite close'' on a procedure for the unification of West and East Germany. ``This strikes me as an admirable and common-sense procedure,'' Hurd said. ``We are waiting for final approval from Moscow.'' The announcement referred to a U.S. plan to have East and West Germany work out legal, political and economic procedures for a merger immediately after East Germany holds national elections in mid-March. The ``Big Four'' allies of World War II _ the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union _ then will discuss security questions, including whether a reunified Germany would be a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The plan, known as ``2-plus-4,'' as the subject of a feverish an off-the-floor discussion today while NATO and Warsaw Pact foreign ministers held a closed session on a U.S. proposal for unarmed aerial surveillance to ally suspicions of surprise attacks. Secretary of State James A. Baker III met with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Shevardnadze then met with West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. Hurd said, meanwhile, he had been holding continuous discussion with Baker, Genscher and French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas. ``We are quite close to an agreement on a proposal for a meeting for the four powers,'' Hurd said. By the time the plan surfaced here Monday, State Department officials were privately describing Moscow as ``quite interested'' in the scheme. Baker held an unannounced meeting with Shevardnadze on Monday, their second of the day, and the two spoke for about 10 minutes today. Baker was returning to Washington later from a nine-day trip that also took him to the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and Romania. Three forces are at work in the no-longer-secret operation: _A conviction Moscow is beginning to share with Washington that unification is inevitable. _A Western desire to keep Germany in NATO. _Anxiety within the countries among people who suffered at Germany's hands in World War II. Bush administration policymakers are operating on an assumption those concerns can be allayed _ and any aggressive German tendencies diverted _ by keeping Germany within the 16-member NATO. The plan is called ``2-plus-4'' because East Germany and West Germany, joined by the Big Four allied powers, would work out the formula for the new and stronger state. As State Department officials outlined the strategy to reporters here, East Germany would become a sovereign power after national elections are held in mid-March. Almost immediately, the Warsaw Pact ally of the Soviet Union would begin working with West Germany to plan the legal, economic and political foundation of a merged country. Among the decisions that would be theirs to make would be the size of the Germany army. In a second stage, the Big Four would delve into security issues. The most important among them: a German role in NATO. But the State Department officials, speaking on condition their names not be used, stressed that no outside power would have the right to interfere in the Germans' sovereign decisions. Preparations for the evolving German reunification scenario have been under way quietly for several weeks even though the subject was not the stated reason for a number of meetings Baker has had with world leaders in and out of Washington. Baker talked about the matter separately with Hurd and Genscher separately in Washington; with Dumas during a refueling stop en route to Czechoslovakia, and finally, with Soviet leaders when he reached Moscow. Genscher outlined his vision for a new Germany in a speech to the ``Open Skies'' conference here today. There was no reference to NATO or Germany's association with the alliance in the future. ``We tell all our neighbors what we want to unite: the Federal Republic of Germany (West Germany), the German Democratic Republic (East Germany) and the whole of Berlin _ no less, and no more. We do not have territorial claims against any of our neighbors,'' Genscher said. He said the Germans seek unification ``out of responsibility for European peace, and we seek it as a contribution to stability in Europe.'' Referring obliquely to World War II, the foreign minister said, ``We Germans now follow the path of unity for which we waited for decades; we are aware of the historical dimension of this process.'' West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Genscher flew to Moscow last Saturday to lobby for unification with East Germany. ``The Soviets are quite interested in this,'' said a U.S. official who is a principal architect of the closely guarded U.S. policy. ``They have not adopted a dogmatic position.'' And yet, the official acknowledged, the Soviets also have not approved ``any mechanism'' for unification, including the U.S. formula. Britain and France have signed on, however, and the campaign is picking up steam. Gorbachev was quoted Monday by ADN, the East German news agency, as having told Kohl that it was unacceptable for Germany to stay in NATO. But Brent Scowcroft, the national security assistant to President Bush, said Monday in Washington that the Soviets had told Baker ``it was not really as positive as that.'' And Shevardnadze told a group of British reporters here that while neutrality ``is the best way'' for a reunited Germany, ``I am not saying neutrality is the only way.''

DOC.HEAD: Which House Will Mandela Live In? ^With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela returned on Tuesday to the four-room brick house he remembered as home for 27 years, but it has become a monument, surrounded day and night by people hoping for a glimpse of him. His wife, Winnie, built him a mansion on a hill three years ago, but suffered severe criticism for it. Mandela spent his first two nights of freedom in large homes in neighborhoods designated for whites. On Sunday night, the Mandelas, their youngest daughter and grandchildren stayed with Archbishop Desmond Tutu at the Bishopscourt mansion owned by the Anglican Church near Cape Town. Tutu, the nation's first black archbishop, has ignored apartheid laws that ban blacks from living in the area. On Monday evening, Mandela flew to Johannesburg and slept in a house owned by a white businessman, set in about four acres of garden and parkland. The press and some members of the public criticized Winnie Mandela when she had the 15-room, $200,000 home built on a hillside in 1987. She said Mandela deserved to live in such a house when he was freed, but he sent word from prison he did not want to enjoy such luxury amid the poverty of 2.5 million people in Soweto, the huge black township outside Johannesburg. Vandals did extensive damage to the empty mansion, known in Soweto as ``Winnie's Palace.'' It has been refurbished recently, but no one has said why. Close associates said Tuesday the black leader had wanted to go straight from prison Sunday to the small house on a corner built when the Orlando section of Soweto was being established in the early 1940s. Mandela worked for the municipal government then. He and his first wife, Evelyn, moved into the house when it was new and their four children spent their childhoods in it. They were divorced in 1957 and Mandela later brought his new wife, Winnie, to the house. An outbuilding in the yard contains several bedrooms where Winnie Mandela's notorious bodyguard stayed until it was disbanded last year. The house was nearly gutted in July 1988 when boys from a nearby high school set it afire during a battle with members of the bodyguard. The damage has been repaired and Mandela sent orders from prison that no one was to be charged or prosecuted for the arson. Anti-apartheid groups denounced Mrs. Mandela last year for allowing what they called a ``reign of terror'' by her bodyguards. Nine members of the group, known as the Mandela United soccer club, are charged in the death of a young activist who allegedly was one of four youths kidnapped and beaten at the Mandela home in December 1988. By the time of the fire, Mrs. Mandela already had bought a larger, ranch-style house in Diepkloof, another part of the township, where she spent at least half her time. She did not return to the Orlando house after it was burned. When one of Mandela's African National Congress colleagues, Wilton Mkwayi, was freed from life prison in October, he occupied the old house temporarily. On Tuesday, Mkwayi asked the people outside to disperse after Mandela arrived for a rest, but they simply stood silently, watching.

DOC.HEAD: Right-Wing Whites Condemn Government, Predict Violence
With AM-South Africa Bjt
DOC.TEXT: While blacks celebrated Nelson Mandela's release from prison, right-wing whites berated the government Tuesday and some predicted violence. The Conservative Party, which won 31 percent of the white vote in elections last year and supports the apartheid policy of race discrimination, expects thousands of supporters at a rally Thursday in Pretoria. ``We will give President (F.W.) de Klerk a friendly but firm message: Your days are numbered,'' party leader Andries Treurnicht said at a rally of about 3,000 supporters Monday night near Cape Town. The Conservatives filed treason charges Monday against Mandela and his African National Congress colleague Walter Sisulu based on support for an armed struggle against apartheid. Citizens can file private charges for police to investigate, but the governing National Party is unlikely to allow any official action. Mandela, the country's best-known black leader, was freed Sunday after more than 27 years in prison. Tens of thousands of blacks greeted him in Cape Town on Sunday and more than 100,000 welcomed him Tuesday in Soweto, his hometown outside Johannesburg. ``We are a simple people, but will not be oppressed and we refuse to accept Mandela,'' Treurnicht said. ``Who would think we live in a Christian country when F.W. de Klerk chose a Sunday to free Mandela?'' Conservatives say that, under a black government, the country's 28 million blacks will dominate the 5 million whites. They say the solution is to partition South Africa into several racially based states. Eugene TerreBlanche, leader of the neo-Nazi Afrikaner Resistance Movement, said Mandela's support for the armed struggle means ``conflict is unavoidable.'' TerreBlanche said his organization ``realizes the powerlessness of the government and is preparing itself to meet the ANC revolution.'' He said Mandela ``is now more free than Mr. de Klerk,'' and if the ANC ``ever get to the negotiation table, they would again threaten murder and death if they did not get their way.'' About 2,000 members and supporters of the Afrikaner Resistance Movement marched through Pretoria on Saturday, carrying swastika flags and alternately shouting, ``Hang Mandela!'' and ``Hang de Klerk!'' Most right-wing whites are Afrikaners, descended from Dutch settlers of South Africa. Afrikaners account for about 3 million of the 5 million whites and are traditionally more conservative than the whites of British descent.

DOC.HEAD: `Massive National Effort' Has Failed, Environmentalist Says
DOC.TEXT: Despite the expenditure of tens of billions of dollars to clean it, the environment is about as polluted as it was 20 years ago, says pioneering environmentalist Barry Commoner. ``There is inescapable evidence that the massive national effort to restore the quality of the environment has failed,'' Commoner writes in his ``Making Peace with the Planet,'' to be published in April. ``The Congress has mandated massive environmental improvement; the EPA has devised elaborate, detailed means of achieving this goal; most of the prescribed measures have been carried out, at least in part; and in nearly every case, the effort has failed to even approximate the goals.'' Commoner, 72, a biologist and an organizer of the first Earth Day in 1970, directs the Center for the Biology of Natural Systems at Queens College in New York. He earlier wrote ``The Closing Circle,'' an influential book on the environment. Ruth Caplan, executive director of Environmental Action, agreed in part with Commoner's assessment but says ``the environment would be much worse today if it weren't for the passage and implementation of the major environmental laws of the 1970s.'' She said in a telephone interview that the environment remains fouled because of a vast increase in polluting sources _ in both cars and miles driven, for example _ and because new problems such as global warming have arisen. They have been caused in part by sources, such as carbon dioxide, that in the 1970s weren't viewed as troublesome. ``Many of the pollutants that the earlier congressional actions were designed to control have been controlled,'' said Brooks Yeager, vice president of the National Audubon Society. ``(But) we've learned how to make thousands of new ones. ... It is not that the solutions to the old problems haven't worked, it's that the solutions to the new problems haven't been brought on fast enough.'' Commoner, in his new book, espouses a view that is becoming widespread in the environmental movement: Further progress will result only when pollutants are not allowed to be produced. While most environmental laws seek to control released pollutants, largely through devices ranging from automobile catalytic converters to smokestack scrubbers, Commoner argues that ``the destruction of our environment begins in our farms and factories _ and that's where we have to go to save it.'' Commoner cited a 92 percent decline between 1975 and 1987 in airborne concentrations of lead, which caused brain damage in children, and a 37 percent decrease in the lead levels in children's blood between 1976 and 1982. Those improvements, he says, came after leaded gasoline was banned. The incidence of DDT in humans' body fat fell by 79 percent between 1970 and 1983, Commoner says. The insecticide was banned in 1972. Environmental victories also have been won by banning cancer-causing PCBs, barring atmospheric nuclear tests and removing mercury from the chlorine-making process, he says. On the other hand, Commoner says, most pollutants that were to have been controlled by devices haven't been curbed much. ``A control device always allows some pollution to enter the environment, so that increased productive activity negates the device's intended effect,'' he says. ``In contrast, when a pollutant is simply eliminated or banned, its rate of entry into the environment falls permanently to zero. ``On the average, the emission of particulates, sulfur dioxide, carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides and volatile organic compounds decreased by only 18 percent between 1975 and 1987. Thus, since 1975 the overall improvement of most air pollutant emissions has been at best modest. The only exception is lead.'' The same pattern emerges with water pollution, he says. While some rivers and lakes have been cleaned there has been scant overall improvement. The incidence of toxic synthetic chemicals in water, air and food appears to be increasing, Commoner says, adding that the depletion of ozone, which results in global warming, ``has also continued to worsen.'' Commoner argues that society must shift to products that don't pollute or pollute less, such as lighter cars powered by low compression engines that don't throw off nitrogen oxides, an ingredient in acid rain; organic farming; emphasis on railroads and mass tansit; solar power and cogeneration; weatherizing homes; recycling; and the use of plastics only when they are really needed, such as for artificial hearts and videotape. ``We're not talking about putting people out of work,'' Commoner says. ``We're talking about corporations shifting their investments to technologies that are clean.''

DOC.HEAD: Telescopes on the Horizon: '90s Full of Major Projects
DOC.TEXT: Astronomy will experience a ``true golden age'' of large-telescope construction in this decade, astronomers and astronomical engineers say. Speakers at the Society of Photo-Optical Instrumentation Engineers' international symposium heard Monday about nine major projects in various stages of construction or planning. The projects, all intended to be operating before the end of the century, range from a 3.5-meter, or 138-inch, telescope on Kitt Peak southwest of Tucson to the European Southern Observatory's array of four 8-meter, or 316-inch, instruments called the Very Large Telescope. With the four telescopes working together, the VLT could be the equivalent of a single 16-meter, or 633-inch, scope. Telescope designs and materials are evolving so quickly that one of the projects is the rebuilding of the Multiple Mirror Telescope on Mount Hopkins south of Tucson. It's only been operating about 10 years, and is presently the third largest in the world, but the new telescopes will out-shine it if it isn't given a bigger mirror. ``The '90s will be the decade of a true golden age of construction of large telescopes,'' said Patrick Osmer, project scientist for the National Optical Astronomy Observatories' twin 8-meter telescopes project to be built in Hawaii and Chile. ``Basically, the need for big telescopes is to get more light,'' said retired NOAO official Larry D. Barr. ``Detectors are approaching almost theoretically perfect efficiency. So how do you detect more faint objects? The answer is you build bigger telescopes.'' Also in the works are: _The University of California's Keck Observatory, whose mirrow will be made up of 36 computer-controlled segments and will be equivalent to a 10-meter or 396-inch mirror, nearing completion on Hawaii's Mauna Kea. _The United Kingdom's Large Telescope Project, also an 8-meter telescope, to be built in partnership with Spain and Germany in the Canary Islands or with the United States and Canada on Mauna Kea. _The $43 million Magellan 8-meter Telescope Project involving the Carnegie Institute, Johns Hopkins University and the University of Arizona, at Las Campanas, Chile. _The Japanese National Large Telescope, a 7.5-meter instrument to stand next to the Keck. _The $60 million Columbus Telescope Project, two side-by-side 8-meter telescopes, resembling binoculars, to be built on Mount Graham in southeastern Arizona by Italy's Arcetri Observatory, the University of Arizona and Ohio State University. Peter Strittmatter, director of the University of Arizona's Steward Observatory, said the latter project, informally called the ``twin shooter,'' will have the equivalent viewing power of a telescope 11.3 meters, or 447 inches, in diameter and twice its image sharpness. The Multiple Mirror Telescope, whose six mirrors produce one image equivalent to that of a telescope 4.5 meters or 178 inches in diameter, will be converted to a single 6.5-meter or 257-inch mirror to keep it competitive with the big new telescopes, at a cost of about $15.5 million, said director Fred Chaffee. ``The price is very low,'' compared to the $45 million to $50 million for building an equivalent telescope from scratch, he told more than 200 astronomers. The MMT cost $12 million when it was dedicated in May 1979. While that observatory is giving up its multiple mirrors, the Keck, whose cost has been estimated at at least $90 million, is scheduled to have nine of its 36 hexagonal segments installed, computer-controlled and ready for ``first light'' or initial observation by August, said Jerry Nelson of the University of California-Berkeley. Additional segments will be added as their polishing is completed at the rate of two per month, he said. In the meantime, the Edwin P. Hubble Space Telescope is scheduled for placement in orbit by a space shuttle crew in April. From above the atmosphere, it is expected to allow astronomers to see seven times as far as the most powerful Earth-bound telescope.
SOWETO, South Africa (AP) _ Here are excerpts from Nelson Mandela's speech Tuesday in his hometown:

Today my return to Soweto fills my heart with joy. At the same time I also return with a deep sadness, with a deep sense of sadness. Sadness to learn that you are still suffering under an inhuman system. The housing shortage, the schools crisis, unemployment and the crime rate still remain. I am even more proud to be a member of this community because of the pioneering role it has played in the struggle for the democratization of local government.

As proud as I am to be part of the Soweto community, I have been greatly disturbed by the statistics of crime, what I have read in the newspapers. Although I understand the deprivations our people suffer, I must make it clear that the level of crime in our township is unhealthy and must be eliminated as a matter of urgency. It is through the creation of democratic and accountable structures that we can achieve this. I salute the anti-crime campaigns conducted by our organizations. The crisis in education that exists in South Africa demands special attention. The education crisis in black schools is a political crisis. It arises out of the fact that our people have no vote and therefore cannot make the government of the day responsive to their needs. Apartheid education is inferior and a crime against humanity. Education is an area that needs attention, that needs the attention of all our people _ students, parents, teachers, workers and all of the organized sectors of our community.

It has been the policy of the ANC that all the schools and the entire education system is a site of struggle. The outside process of learning must take place in the schools. I want to add my voice therefore to the call made at the beginning of the year: That all students must return to school and learn. We must continue our struggle for people's education within the school system and utilize its resources to achieve our goals. I call on the government to build more schools, to train and employ more teachers, and to abandon its policies of forcing our children out of the school system by use of various measures.

As I said when I stood on the dock at the Rivonia trial 27 years ago and as I said on the day of my release in Cape Town, the ANC will pursue the armed struggle against the government as long as the violence of apartheid continues. Our armed combatants act under the political leadership of the ANC, cadres of our people's army are engaged not only in military affairs but as the political commissars of our movement. We are therefore disturbed that there are certain elements amongst those who claim to support the liberation struggle who use violence against our people. The hijacking and setting alight of vehicles and the harassment of innocent people are criminal acts that have no place in our struggle. We condemn that.

DOC.TEXT: ti-apartheid groups) to take decisive steps to revive the peace initiative ... Let us act with political foresight and develop bold steps to end the mindless violence. Joint intitatives at local, regional and national levels within the party's concern must call for restraint. The security forces must be compelled to act with absolute impartiality and to arrest those offenders who continue with violence. We understand that attempts have been made to disrupt the unity of the oppressed by starting tensions between African and Indian communities in Natal. Let us build from the proud tradition of unity in action ...
I am also concerned by the ongoing violence perpetrated by certain sections of the security forces against our peaceful marches and demonstrations. We condemn this.

We call on the police to abandon apartheid, to serve the interests of the people. Join our march to a new South Africa where you also have a place. We note with appreciation that there are certain areas where policemen are acting with restraint and fulfilling the real role of protecting all our people irrespective of their race. Much debate has been spoken of the ANC policies on the economy relating to nationalization and the redistribution of wealth. We believe that apartheid has created a heinous system of exploitation in which a racist minority monopolizes economic wealth while the vast majority of the oppressed and black people are condemned to poverty. South Africa is a wealthy country. It is the labor of black workers that has built the cities, roads and factories we see. They cannot be excluded from sharing this wealth. The ANC is just as committed to economic growth and productivity as the present employer came to be. Yet we are also committed to ensure that a democratic government has the resources to address the inequalities caused by apartheid. Our people need proper houses, not ghettos like Soweto.

Workers need a living wage and the right to join unions of their own choice and to participate in determining policies that affect their lives. Our history has shown that apartheid has stifled growth, created mass unemployment, and led to spiraling inflation that has undermined the standard of living of the majority of our people, both black and white. Only a participatory democracy involving our people in the structures of decision-making at all levels of society can ensure that this is corrected. We will certainly introduce policies that address the economic problems that we face.

We call on employers to recognize the fundamental rights of workers in our country. We are marching to a new future based on strong foundations of respect for each other achieved through bona-fide negotiations. In particular, we call for genuine negotiations to achieve a Fair Labor Relations Act and mechanisms to resolve conflict. Employers can play their role in shaping the new South Africa by acknowledging these rights. We call on workers, black and white, to join industrial trade unions ...

We shall play an indispensable role in our struggle against apartheid. A number of obstacles to the creation of a non-racial democratic South Africa remain and need to be tackled. The fears of whites about their rights and place in a South Africa they do not control exclusively are an obstacle we must understand and address. I stated in 1964 that I and the ANC are as opposed to black domination as we are to white domination. We must accept that our statements and declarations alone will not be sufficient to allay the fears of white South Africans. We must clearly demonstrate our good will to our white compatriots and convince them by our conduct ... that a South Africa without apartheid will be a better home for all.

We call on those who out of ignorance have collaborated with apartheid in the past to join our liberation struggle. No men or women who have abandoned apartheid will be excluded from our movement towards a non-racial, united and democratic South Africa based on one-person, one-vote on a common voters roll.

Our primary task remains to unite our people across the length and breadth of our country. Our democratic organizations must be consolidated in all our sectors. Democratic political practice and accountable leadership must be strengthed on all fronts. Our struggle against apartheid, though seemingly uncertain, must be intensified on all fronts. Let each one of you and all of our people give the enemies of peace and liberty no space to take us back to the dark hell of apartheid.

Two days ago, in my address in Cape Town, I told the audience that I have read on numerous occasions that it is not the kings and generals that make history but the masses of the people. I have always believed in this. But much to the extent to which I now believe that basic principle because I have seen with my own eyes the masses of our people, the workers, the peasants, the doctors, the lawyers, the clergy, all our people I have seen them making history and that is why all of us are here today. In conclusion, I must repeat what Comrade Sisulu has said. It is proper that we should behave in a way worthy of disciplined freedom fighters ... DOC.HEAD: January Gain Biggest in More Than a Year
DOC.TEXT: Retail sales rose a strong 1.6 percent in January, their sharpest gain in more than a year, the government reported Tuesday. Analysts said the broad advance demonstrated enough consumer confidence to hold off any recession. ``Consumer spending is still alive,'' said John Silvia, an economist with Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. Most categories showed advances that ``suggest to me that the consumer is coming back in the first quarter, taking up his normal pace of spending.'' The Commerce Department said sales totaled a seasonally adjusted $146.4 billion and posted their steepest increase since a 2.1 percent gain in October 1988. ``This positive report confirms our forecast that consumer spending will increase this year, reversing the decline of late 1989,'' commented William K. MacReynolds, forecasting director of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. December sales, which originally were said to be up 0.2 percent, actually fell 0.2 percent, dragged down by a 2.6 percent decline in automobile sales, Tuesday's report said. Auto sales represent about 20 percent of retail sales. But car sales, prompted by a renewed round of incentives that continued into February, were up 5.4 percent in January. The gain in car sales was the largest since a 6.6 percent advance in October 1988. Excluding the often-volatile auto category, retail sales still rose 0.6 percent last month. ``The underlying strength is really quite remarkable,'' said David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a New York government securities dealer. ``You really had strength across the board.'' ``It hints that consumer confidence is not fading,'' Jones continued. ``As long as consumers stay positive, since they count for two-thirds of GNP, the economy is likely to stay out of a recession.'' Retail sales account for about one-third of consumer spending, which itself represents about two-thirds of the GNP, the nation's output of goods and services. The economy _ particularly the manufacturing and construction sectors _ slowed in the fourth quarter of 1989, squeezed by high interest rates as the Federal Reserve Board kept a tight rein on credit to cap inflation. Durable goods _ big-ticket items like cars expected to last more than three years _ felt the brunt of the sluggishness since many of these products are financed through loans. But durable goods sales rose 3.9 percent in January after falling 2.1 percent in December. Sales of building materials were up 2.3 percent and purchases of furniture and other home furnishings rose 2 percent. Purchases of non-durable goods, such as food and clothing, advanced 0.3 percent on top of a 0.9 percent gain in December. Gasoline stations led the advance with a 2.5 percent increase, but Jones said the gain probably reflected hikes in prices, not unit sales. Also posting gains were drug stores, up 2.3 percent; department stores, up 2.2 percent, and restaurants and bars, up 1.5 percent. Grocery store sales declined 0.4 percent while apparel purchases were off 0.7 percent. For the three months from November through January, overall retail sales were up 3.8 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Aspen Election Could Create Furrier-Free Zone
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with heavy turnout this morning, delete outdated material. Picks up 5th graf, `Aspen Mayor....'
DOC.TEXT: Heavy voter turnout caused 20-minute waits at polling places this morning in an election that could make this Rocky Mountain ski resort the first city in the nation to ban the sale of fur. ``Everyone is coming out. It's going slow,'' said deputy city clerk Kathy Strickland. ``We had three booths at the precincts last time, and now we have four, and they still are waiting in line.... So the turnout is going to be good.'' The town's 3,739 registered voters also will decide whether to stop construction of an $80 million luxury hotel, approving in its place a smaller one favored by the City Council. Celebrities including developer Donald Trump have jumped into the fray over the two issues. Aspen Mayor Bill Stirling, who proposed the ban on fur sales, said he has received hundreds of letters from around the world supporting the proposed ban. Stirling faces a recall election in March, prompted by citizens outraged over the fur issue. After all, noted the Aspen Times, Aspen is ``the capital of glitz, where furs are as common in 1990 as pickup trucks with dogs were in 1970.'' Stirling counted amoung his supporters cartoonist Berke Breathed and actress Kate Jackson. Television stars Rue McClanahan and Woody Harrelson joined a rally for the ban Sunday night. Arriving over the weekend to campaign for the fur sale ban was philosophy professor Peter Singer of Australia, considered the father of the international animal rights movement. ``The real issue is whether it is all right to kill animals to make fur coats,'' said the mayor's wife, Katharine Thalberg, co-founder of the Aspen Society for Animal Rights. The measure's backers claim sales taxes on furs sold in Aspen amount to profit from cruelty to animals. Opponents argue it's a matter of personal freedom and warn that if fur sales are prohibited, the wearing of furs and leather and even the sale of meat could be next. Aspen furrier Mark Kirkland, leading the fight against the ban, called it ``the biggest public relations disaster in Aspen's history. Aspen is losing tourist dollars left and right.'' Customers are calling and saying ``if I'm not welcome in Aspen, I won't come ... I can go anywhere in the world without getting into that hotbed of controversy,'' Kirkland said. Visitor numbers are down slightly this season, said Carol Pasternak of the Aspen Chamber Resort Association. She said publicity over the proposed fur ban ``may be having a negative effect,'' but late and light snowfall this year also has taken its toll on tourism. The hotel issue involves developer Mohamed Hadid's plans for a 292-room Ritz-Carlton at the foot of Aspen Mountain. Hadid, who has spent at least $13 million already, is being sued by Trump, who had sought the same property for a smaller hotel he says he could have completed by now.

DOC.HEAD: Gene Identified That May Cause Death Under Anesthesia
DOC.TEXT: The disorder that killed a 23-year-old volleyball player when she received general anesthesia last month is apparently caused by a defective gene that normally helps muscles work, a study says. If that suspicion is confirmed, further work might lead to a blood test to detect people at risk for the condition, experts said. The disorder is called malignant hyperthermia. It causes sustained muscle contraction, fever and muscle destruction in reaction to commonly used inhaled general anesthetics. While there are no good statistics on how often it occurs, estimates range from one in 10,000 administrations of anesthetics to one in 50,000, said Henry Rosenberg, chairman of the professional advisory council of the Malignant Hyperthermia Association of the United States. Pehaps one in 10 cases leads to death, said Rosenberg, who added that his organization learns of about eight to 10 deaths a year in the United States. Malignant hyperthermia is blamed in last month's death of Judy Bellomo, a member of the U.S. women's volleyball team. She died during surgery for thyroid cancer. Rosenberg said such young people appear to be particularly susceptible to the condition. If the new research leads to a reliable blood test to detect vulnerable people, it would be an important advance, he said Monday. The result would alert anesthesiologists not to use drugs that cause the reaction, he said. The current detection test is done for relatives of people with the condition. It involves removing a piece of muscle about the length of a middle finger, generally from the thigh, said study co-author David MacLennan. ``People are not very happy about having to do that,'' he said. The test, done in the operating room, is expensive and available only in certain medical centers, Rosenberg said. In the new study, scientists suggest that malignant hyperthermia comes from a defective version of a gene that normally tells muscle cells how to make a structure called the ryanodine receptor, which plays a key role in muscle contraction. Scientists at the University of Toronto and the Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario in Ottawa studied a series of families in which susceptibility to malignant hyperthermia was inherited. They found that the pattern in which the susceptibility ran in the families matched the inheritance pattern of the ryanodine receptor gene. That suggests the gene is either responsible for malignant hyperthermia, or that it lies very close to the reponsible gene on the threadlike structure called chromosome 19, MacLennan of the University of Toronto said in a telephone interview. Given the normal function of the gene, it makes ``excellent sense'' that a defective form could trigger malignant hyperthermia, he said. Researchers still must find the defect or defects within the gene that cause the disease, he said. Then a blood test could detect those defects in people, he said. The new study appears in the current issue of the British journal Nature.
