DOC.TEXT: A 47-year-old Paul McCartney couldn't quite reach a couple of high notes, but the moms and pops who brought their kids didn't seem to mind as the ex-Beatle reminded them of ``Yesterday'' with his old hit. ``This is nothing like the crowd we get for real rock concerts,'' security officer Evison Carter said. ``Those teen-agers run in here screaming and waving their arms.'' Maureen Schaefer, 15, and her sister Jeannie, 12, of suburban White Oak persuaded their parents to take them to the concert Monday night. ``They wanted to go so bad that we got two tickets from scalpers,'' said their mother, Dianne, a Beatles fan who last saw McCartney in 1966 performing at Cincinnati's old Crosley Field ball park. She said she paid scalpers $60 apiece for the two tickets. Jonathan Rosenberg, 3, of Cincinnati, was seeing his first concert. ``But he already knows `Yellow Submarine,''' said his mother, Miriam Rosenberg.

Geraldo Rivera says he's changing his ways to include more investigative stories on social issues for his television talk-show. ``It's not a kinder, gentler Geraldo. It's more like a leaner, meaner Geraldo,'' Rivera said in an interview Monday. ``On `Geraldo,' you're not going to get the freaks. The nuts and sluts will be on other people's programs,'' the 46-year-old talk-show host said. ``It's been published everywhere that my 10-year-old son had a dramatic influence on me, as he did. ``Last year, all his friends were saying that I had guts to stand up to those bad people (the skinheads), and this year they were all talking about transexual lesbian nuns,'' he said. ``I don't want people to associate me with the freak show. I want them to associate me with a program that does righteous, populace issues and _ once in a while _ has fun.''

She's been married to the mob and dabbled in a dangerous liaison. Now Michelle Pfeiffer will be roaming the back roads around Raleigh to shoot a new movie. The actress will begin filming ``Love Field'' in April. Her recent screen credits include ``The Fabulous Baker Boys,'' ``Dangerous Liaisons'' and ``Married to the Mob.'' The story involves the ``strong emotional relationship'' among Pfeiffer's character and a father and daughter she meets on a bus trip as she is traveling to Washington, D.C., for President Kennedy's funeral in 1963, said co-producer Midge Sanford. The movie takes its name from the Dallas airport where the president arrived on the morning of his assassination.

Faye Dunaway's overheated portrayal of a driven, abusive Joan Crawford in the movie ``Mommie Dearest'' was ``career suicide'' and a film she still is recovering from, the actress says. Dunaway, 49, has spent the last six years in a self-imposed exile, making only one movie, the critically acclaimed ``Barfly,'' which was not a big box-office success. In an interview published in the March issue of Ladies' Home Journal, Dunaway spoke of the problems she had with ``Mommie Dearest.'' ``That film was career suicide,'' she said. ``It turned into an exploitation movie that verged on camp, and I'm still recovering from it. ``Going in, the role seemed tricky and interesting,'' she said. ``I said `yes' because I listened to advice from someone in my private life _ the last time I'll ever do that. ``While making ``Mommie Dearest,'' I woke up with nightmares about her, and afterward I couldn't get out of bed for a month,'' Dunaway said. ``Sure, I overdid her.'' The Golden Raspberry Foundation on Monday nominated ``Mommie Dearest'' along with four other films as the worst of the 1980s. Dunaway said she spent most of her time away from Hollywood in England, with her now ex-husband, photographer Terry O' Neill, and their son, Liam. ``All those years in England, I wasn't paying much attention to my career,'' she said. ``I was just enjoying Liam's early years and working on myself, seeing my therapist every day. I still do. ``Terry verged on being a husband-manager, and it was a mistake we both made in our careers,'' she said.

Hollywood turned the spotlight on dwindling Amazon rain forests at an exclusive backyard benefit headlined by charity crooning from Sting, Bruce Springsteen, Paul Simon and Don Henley. Sting called it ``the most expensive garage band in history'' Monday night as the all-star music gathering entertained such celebrities as Don Johnson, Billy Crystal, Barbra Streisand and Goldie Hawn. The elaborate dinner party for 1,000 benefiting the Rainforest Foundation collected more than $1 million to save Amazon rain forests and the Indians who live there, organizers said. Tickets sold for $500 to $5,000. ``We're becoming more and more aware that we're destroying this precious Earth,'' Miss Hawn said. ``We have the power to influence others. We have the power to change minds.'' ``We must create a national ethic that insists on a clean environment,'' ``Cheers'' star Ted Danson told the crowd. Henley remarked during the performance that he and Sting had toured the coat room at the home of Ted and Susie Fields, hosts of the event. He said the room was filled with ``about a quarter of a million dollars' worth of dead animals,'' adding that he and Sting were tempted to torch the collection of fur coats. Following the benefit Sting, Springsteen and Henley gathered at the China Club in Hollywood for the club's twice-weekly Pro-Am Invitational Jam. The cover charge there was only $10.

DOC.HEAD: Funeral Held for Teen-Ager
DOC.TEXT: Mourners packed a high school gym for the funeral of an Arthur City teen-ager who received the first experimental lung-assist device. Melicia ``Mimi'' Harvey died Wednesday in Salt Lake City of complications from the respiratory disease that led doctors to insert the device. She was 16. Miss Harvey gave birth in January to a son. Her mother died Jan. 31 of complications from diabetes. ``Sometimes we ask, `Why?' but God's work must be done,'' the Rev. Aaron Jenkins, pastor of Oakl Hill Baptist Church, told schoolmates and friends of the family Monday. Miss Harvey received the IntraVascular Oxygenator at LDS Hospital in Salt Lake City on Feb. 2, after a severe respiratory illness worsened. The IVOX, a 20-inch bundle of hundreds of synthetic tubes as fine as human hair, was designed to give damaged lungs time to rest and recover. The hospital said the device functioned properly from the time it was implanted until Miss Harvey's death. They attributed her death to pulmonary failure.

DOC.HEAD: San Francisco Judge Named Head of Judicial Center
DOC.TEXT: U.S. District Judge William W. Schwarzer of San Francisco was appointed Tuesday as director of the Federal Judicial Center, the research, development and training arm of the federal court system. Schwarzer, 64, will succeed Judge John C. Godbold on March 24. Godbold is leaving the job after 2{ years upon reaching the mandatory retirement age of 70 for the position. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, in announcing the appointment, said Schwarzer has distinguished himself ``in the management of complex litigation'' in the 14 years he has been a federal judge. ``He has also pursued scholarly activities and published numerous articles and books on various aspects of procedure and judicial administration,'' Rehnquist said. Schwarzer's salary in the new post remains $96,600 a year and he is not giving up his judgeship. Schwarzer, who lives in Mill Valley, Calif., was appointed to the bench in 1976 by President Carter after 20 years in private law practice. The judicial center was created by Congress in 1967 to improve administration in the federal courts.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Defendant Gagged after Courtroom Outbursts
DOC.TEXT: A judge didn't issue a gag order but she ordered a gag for a murder defendant because of two outbursts. As Sabastian Frederick Morris, 28, sat calmly in a chair at the defense table, court bailiff Russell Adams and several Harris County sheriff's deputies applied gray duct tape to his mouth and neck. Deputies also taped Morris' hand to the armrests and shackled his feet to the legs of the chair. The tape was padded to prevent it from sticking to the defendant's mouth and neck. In his first outburst, Morris screamed that a deputy was lying when he testified that the defendant threatened a witness to the murder. About 15 minutes later, Morris leaned forward in his chair, pointed his finger at another witness and accused him of lying about the events on the night of the shooting. State District Judge Mary Bacon warned Morris to halt the outbursts, but when he refused she ordered him muffled. Morris is charged in the Aug. 16 shooting death of Kevin Young outside a Houston food store. Young, wounded in the leg, ran three blocks to his home after the shooting and collapsed on the porch. He died later at Ben Taub Hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Second Poll on Social Security Brings Different Results
DOC.TEXT: A poll says most Americans would rather cut Social Security taxes than use surplus funds to reduce the federal deficit, although a poll last month, phrasing the issue differently, found otherwise. In an ABC News-Washington Post poll released Tuesday, 60 percent of the 1,008 adults surveyed opposed using surplus Social Security funds to cut the deficit, and 63 percent supported lower Social Security taxes. However, in an NBC News-Wall Street Journal poll of registered voters in January, 53 percent favored increasing Social Security taxes in order to reduce the deficit and to keep the Social Security fund sound. The difference most likely was caused by the phrasing each poll used to frame its questions. Question wording can dramatically effect poll results, especially on sensitive or complex issues. One ABC-Post question noted that Social Security taxes have been rising, and asked: ``Which do you generally prefer: higher Social Security taxes and a bigger surplus, or lower Social Security taxes with the taxpayers keeping some of the surplus?'' Most preferred to pocket the surplus. The NBC-Journal poll, by contrast, said some people favored canceling an increase in the Social Security tax because the surplus made it unnecessary, while others favored the increase because the surplus is needed to hold down the deficit and to keep the Social Security fund ``sound for the future.'' Just over half, given that phrasing, favored the increase. Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan, D-N.Y., has proposed rolling back increases in the Social Security tax, saying it was improper to use the fund's surplus to reduce the federal budget deficit. The Bush administration opposes his plan. The ABC-Post poll, conducted by telephone among a random sample of adults Feb. 1-4, had a four-point margin of error. The NBC-Journal poll, done by telephone Jan. 13-16 among 1,510 registered voters, had a three-point error margin. Margin of error means, in the ABC-Post poll, that the results probably are within 4 percentage points of the results if all adults in the nation were asked precisely the same questions. Error margin does not take into account the possible effects of question wording.

DOC.HEAD: Third Mate Panicked Before Exxon Valdez Grounded, Witness Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Cousins testifying this morning on shipboard routine. Picks up 4th graf: `The Exxon Valdez . . .'
DOC.TEXT: The third mate deputized by Capt. Joseph Hazelwood to command the Exxon Valdez on its disastrous voyage panicked and grabbed the wheel in a futile attempt to avert a jagged reef, a seaman testified. ``I started making the turn and he grabbed the wheel and helped make it,'' Robert Kagan said of third mate Gregory Cousins. ``I think he was kind of panicking then.'' Kagan's appearance Monday at Hazelwood's trial set the stage for Cousins to give his version of the disaster today. Cousins, the third mate, explained to jurors the chores he routinely carried out before sailing. He depicted the day of the accident as routine in most ways. He said that unlike other members of the crew, he chose not to go into Valdez on a shore excursion during the day. Instead, Cousins said he stayed aboard, kept an eye on the loading of oil, and helped top off the tanks. The Exxon Valdez struck Bligh Reef on March 24, spilling more than 10 million gallons of oil and causing the nation's worst oil spill. The prosecution says Hazelwood was drunk and negligent in turning over control of the ship to Cousins, who was not certified to navigate in treacherous Prince William Sound. Cousins, of Tampa, Fla., took the stand briefly before court recessed Monday, saying he had crossed the sound between 26 and 30 times and was on the bridge for half of those trips. Cousins, who testified at hearings before the National Transportation Safety Board last year, has blamed the accident on a malfunction of the ship, which he says did not respond to his rudder changes after he took it off automatic pilot. Kagan, of Harahan, La., testified after a Coast Guard monitor conceded he didn't even look for the Exxon Valdez on a radar monitor before the accident because he was told it had disappeared from radar. ``I wasn't looking for him because he had been lost'' from radar, said Bruce Blandford, a civilian Coast Guard employee, who indicated he was stunned when Hazelwood called at about 12:25 a.m. to say the 987-foot tanker ``was hard around and leaking oil.'' ``I did a pretty hard swallow ... the adrenaline started pumping.'' He said he called the commanding officer of the Coast Guard station and told him ``this was the big one _ the Exxon Valdez was on the rocks leaking oil.'' Hazelwood's defense has suggested that the monitor could have averted the grounding by watching the radar more closely and warning Hazelwood he was off course. But Blandford said he had no authority to tell a captain to change course. Kagan told of making course changes repeatedly on orders from Cousins in the final, frantic moments before the crash. First, he said they grappled over the switch to remove the ship from automatic pilot and go back to manual steering. ``We both reached for it at the same time,'' he said. Then, Kagan said, he heard three separate commands to go right, left and then right again and saw Cousins get on the phone, presumably to Hazelwood, who was in his cabin. In the seconds before grounding, Kagan said, there was a command to turn hard left and Cousins grabbed the wheel with him in a panic. Then, he said, he heard ``a little rattle, bumping'' and the ship was aground. He said he had no idea of the extent of damage until daybreak when he looked in the water and saw ``there was a lot of oil around the ship. I was very surprised.'' Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is charged with one felony count of second-degree criminal mischief and misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil and operating a vessel while intoxicated. The maximum penalty for conviction on all counts is 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. Regarding Hazelwood's orders after the grounding, Kagan said he can't be sure whether the captain was trying to move the ship off the rocks or just stabilize it. ``I wasn't really sure what he was doing,'' said Kagan. But in the aftermath, he said Hazelwood commended him. ``He said I did a hell of a job.''

DOC.HEAD: Gag Gift Causes False Bomb Alarm
DOC.TEXT: One of Bill Roberts' friends gave him road flares as a Christmas gift, but the gift-giver's flair for creativity returned to haunt Roberts this week. To spice up a dull gift, the giver added a round, white clock with large numerals and wire, and packaged it with tape to look like an elaborate bomb. Roberts got a laugh, tossed the whole thing in his trunk and forgot about it. Until Monday. A mechanic noticed the package when Roberts left his car for an oil change. ``The mechanic saw it immediately when he opened the trunk,'' police Col. Tom Rutledge said. ``I tell you, you couldn't tell the difference from the real thing.'' Authorities evacuated the business, blocked roads and called in the Gwinnett County Hazardous Device Technicians. Experts disabled the device and put it through an X-ray only to find out the red sticks were flares. After a quick background check on Roberts, police decided the Snellville business executive was no desperado. Roberts had wanted flares because he had mechanical problems with the car and didn't want to get caught without them, Roberts said.

DOC.HEAD: Last of U.S. Invasion Troops Leave Panama
DOC.TEXT: The United States has withdrawn all of its invasion troops from Panama, leaving an American force of 13,504 in the country, the White House said Tuesday. In the face of resentment from many Latin nations, which objected to the continued presence of the invasion troops Panama, President Bush promised in his Jan. 31 State of the Union address to bring the invasion troops home by the end of February. The U.S. troop strength in Panama is now just under the 13,597 stationed there before the Dec. 20 invasion, said presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. ``All the troops are gone that went in after Dec. 20,'' said Fitzwater. The troops stationed in Panama are helping train a new police force, officials said. The invasion and toppling of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, now facing a drug-trafficking trial in Miami, resulted in disbandment of his Panamanian Defense Force. U.S. troop levels in Panama have fluctuated by a few thousand in recent years, depending on any exercises the military was conducting. Fitzwater said 13,000 is an average. Still in Panama are 2,000 troops Bush sent to Panama in a show-of-force to demonstrate his unhappiness over the May 7 election, which was invalidated by Noriega. The opposition candidate widely considered the winner of that election by independent observer groups, Guillermo Endara, was installed by the invasion troops as the country's president. Latin countries roundly denounced the invasion, which they considered an unwarranted display of U.S. muscle. The continued troop presence was seen as an additional affront. That military presence prompted Peruvian President Alan Garcia initially to back out of Thursday's drug summit in Colombia. He said he would meet with Bush as long as the invasion forces remained in Panama. With Bush's Jan. 31 announcement and the administration's gradual troop withdrawal, Garcia last week announced he would attend the four-nation summit after all.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Notes That Soviets Still a Pacific Power
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 10 grafs with Cheney speech; picks up at pvs 8th graf, In recently
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union remains a formidable military power in the Pacific despite its proposed troop cutbacks in Europe, and the United States must keep up its guard, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today. Cheney told the Pacific and Asian Affairs Council the Soviets maintain more than a half-million ground troops in Asia, dozens of air divisions and one of its largest naval fleets, numbering more than 260 surface ships and submarines. Despite publicity over a Soviet drawdown in Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam, he said, the Soviet Union continues to update and improve its navy in the region. ``What it may be losing in numbers, it is gaining back in terms of more modern, capable ships and advanced weaponry,'' Cheney said, referring to the Soviet military as a ``formidable'' force in the region. Reminding his listeners in Hawaii of the ``profound shock'' that overcame the United States with the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941, Cheney argued that the United States must maintain its military strength in order to remain a global power and to protect its interests in the Pacific. He noted that America's commerce in East Asia and the Pacific amounts to 35 percent of its world trade. Cheney spoke before flying to Seoul, South Korea, for a two-week Pacific tour to study U.S. troops commitments in light of congressional pressure for budget savings and increased support for U.S. forces from Asian nations hosting American troops. Some 120,000 U.S. troops are stationed in Hawaii and in South Korea, the Philippines and Japan. Speaking with reporters Monday, Cheney said he had no plans ``to dramatically alter our posture in the Pacific.'' But, he added, ``I don't rule out prospects for adjustments in our for deployments or in the overall size of our forces.'' In recently announcing base closings and realignments, Cheney ordered that U.S. military personnel be withdrawn from three airbases in South Korea, an act that concerned nations that have benefited by the U.S. military presence. Cheney said he hopes to consult with the allied nations in the Pacific ``and find ways for them to do more.'' Cheney was to be accompanied by a special State Department ambassador for ``burdensharing,'' the term for requesting more backup for the U.S. military stationed in nations whose economies are doing well. His trip has already sparked one controversy. Philippine President Corazon Aquino, angry that the Bush administration hasn't met payments on its bases in the Philippines, said she will not meet with Cheney. ``It's too bad Mrs. Aquino didn't want to host me. That's her choice. I've got plenty to do there to keep me busy,'' Cheney said. Talks on renewing the leases the huge U.S. bases in the Philippines are slated to begin next month. ``We want to be a good friend and ally, but we won't stay anywhere we aren't wanted,'' Cheney said. The defense secretary strongly disagreed with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's call to have U.S. and Soviet troops in Europe at equal levels. ``I don't believe there's any requirement on our part to go to the exact same level the Soviets are at,'' Cheney said. President Bush has proposed that Soviet troop levels in Europe go down to 195,000 in the central core of Europe, while U.S. levels could be 225,000, if forces in nations such as Britain, Greece and Turkey are included. ``I think it's a good position and I think we ought to stick to it,'' Cheney said. ``We are there as allies. They are there as occupational forces. ... It's important for us not to assume a moral equivalence between the Soviet occupation of Europe and our presence there as allies,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: What's Left of Soviet Communism? Mostly `Spirit,' `Methodology'
AP News Analysis
DOC.BYLINE: With AM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt ^By MARK J. PORUBCANSKY
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party of Lenin has endorsed elections, given up the right to control political life in the Soviet Union and says it favors private ownership. What's left of the Soviet Communist Party appears to be mainly vague concepts such as ``spirit'' and ``methodology.'' The new party platform to be considered by the Supreme Soviet legislature on Wednesday bears little resemblance in concept or phraseology to the ideas that have driven the Soviet Union for 72 years. Pushed by Mikhail S. Gorbachev through a meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee last week, the platform calls for a strong European-style presidency in a country where the Communist Party chief has been the most powerful person. Some other contradictions with the past: _In a system based on iron deductive logic claiming to predict the course of history, the platform decries ``ideological blinkers, dogmatism and intolerance towards different views and ideas.'' _From the Marxist prohibition on private ownership of factories, the party has come to the believe that ``the existence of individual property, including ownership of the means of production, does not contradict the modern stage in the country's economic development.'' _The new Soviet Communist Party now believes that instead of a dictatorship of the proletariat leading to communism, ``there is no room for dictatorship by any class.'' Democratic centralism, the theory that requires strict obedience to decisions made at the top is under review. _Competition from other political parties is now all right. The party recognizes that other countries using other systems have found a path to the general prosperity and social justice Communists thought could only be reached through Marxism. The large majority of Supreme Soviet deputies who gather in the Kremlin on Wednesday will be asked to put those new ideas into action by calling an emergency session of the Congress of People's Deputies to strengthen the presidency, and passing laws on ownership of land, property, and taxation. The new platform has phrases such as ``immunity of ... home and property, the secrecy of correspondence and telephone conversations,'' and ``freedom of speech, the press, meetings and demonstrations and the formation of public organizations.'' It also talks about ``free self-determination in the spiritual sphere, the freedom of conscience and religion.'' The platform sketches a pluralistic system of political liberties and varied forms of ownership that make the future Soviet Union sound much like a Western democracy with a mixed economy. What is left of Marxist theory and Soviet Communist practice? The platform at the beginning of its first section affirms its ``faithfulness to the creative spirit of the materialist world outlook and the dialectic methodology of Marx, Engels and Lenin.'' There is little to indicate how that will be implemented and if the Communists keep power, how it will distinguish the Soviet Union from other countries. The platform proclaims with pride the Soviet Union's commitment to pensions, free education and medical care and other social benefits pioneered by Soviet socialism. But they no longer can make the Soviet Union distinctive since the same benefits are offered elsewhere. Despite permitting private ownership of factories, the new Communist policy statement echoes classic Marxism by taking a stand against the alienation of man from the product of his work, and exploitation of one man by another. Both of those were thought to be the fruits of private ownership, which the party now says is permissible. One area where the party's intentions are not clear is on the question of private ownership of land. It cost millions of lives, but Stalin took all the land for the state and organized peasant farmers into large collectives. Legislation that will be presented to the Supreme Soviet says land belongs to the people and may not be bought or sold, holding true to Marxist restrictions. But one amendment calls for giving the Soviet republics the right to make exceptions to that rule, and the legislation also would permit farmers to pass the publicly owned land on to their children.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Mark J. Porubcansky has reported on Soviet affairs from Moscow since 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Group Wants to Limit Congressional Terms
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of a new organization called Tuesday for state legislatures to back a constitutional amendment limiting the tenure of members of Congress to 12 years in each house. ``America's outrage with its Congress has reached an all-time high, and it's no wonder,'' said former Rep. James K. Coyne of Pennsylvania, co-chairman of Americans to Limit Congressional Terms. ``Even as we struggle to free ourselves from budget deficits, Congress acts to give itself a 40 percent pay raise. By 1991, members of Congress will pay themselves nearly $121,000 a year, placing them in the top 1 percent of American wage earners.'' The organization wants two-thirds of the state legislatures to pass resolutions calling upon Congress to convene a constitutional convention to enact a constitutional amendment limiting a lawmaker to two six-year terms in the Senate and six two-year terms in the House. The proposed constitutional amendment would allow a person to serve maximum 12-year terms in both houses, for a total of 24 years in Congress. Any constitutional amendment must be ratified by three-fourths of the states. However, members of the group declined to suggest that Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., should step down. Thurmond, at 87 the oldest member of Congress, said Monday that he would seek his seventh term this year. Carter Hardwick of Charleston, S.C., a member of the steering committee of Americans to Limit Congressional Terms, said Thurmond had told him he favored the idea of limitations. ``I hope that nothing I say will be harmful to him,'' Hardwick said. ``Until the rules are changed for all the congressmen, I would think we would be better served for him to continue to serve.'' Thurmond said in a statement Tuesday that he did meet with Hardwick and told him the idea ``should be given careful consideration and study and, if the people deem it wise to amend the Constitution to this effect, they have the right to do so.'' ``However, unless this is done and everything being equal, a member's seniority greatly influences both his effectiveness and ability to meet the needs of the people of his state.'' Cleta Mitchell, a former Democratic state legislator from Oklahoma who joined Coyne in the announcement, conceded that ``you will find a lot of Republicans, perhaps more than Democrats,'' among the 188 state legislators the group says is backing its proposal. Democrats control both houses of Congress. Coyne said South Dakota has passed a resolution on the proposal, and that action was pending in Alaska, Arizona, Colorado, Connecticut, Idaho, Kansas, Missouri, New Hampshire, Utah, Vermont, Wyoming, Florida, Louisiana and Hawaii.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Against Tax Refunds to Federal Retirees
DOC.TEXT: A state judge ruled today that Virginia does not owe about $400 million in refunds to federal retirees who were taxed illegally until last year. Alexandria Circuit Judge Donald H. Kent's ruling makes Virginia the first state to win a lawsuit stemming from the U.S. Supreme Court's ruling last year that several states had taxed retirees improperly, the attorney general's office said in a statement. Virginia revised its income tax laws in response to the ruling. Before the ruling, the state had allowed state government retirees' pensions to be tax-free, but had taxed the pensions of federal government retirees. The high court said all retirees must be taxed the same. In a special session in April, the Legislature enacted a tax break for all pensioners. A revision of that tax break that would make it less costly is pending in the legislature this year. Dennis Harrington, a spokesman for the National Association of Retired Federal Employees in Washington, said the organization was prepared to appeal Kent's ruling on behalf of the approximately 200,000 retired federal workers who live in Virginia. Michael Kator, the lawyer who represented the retirees, said he would ask the Virginia Supreme Court to overturn Kent. Kator also said the U.S. Supreme Court has two pending cases, from Arkansas and Florida, that center on the question of unconstitutionally collected taxes. Meanwhile, the Virginia Senate voted 31-8 today for a bill that would reduce the pension tax break enacted last year by $111 million over the next two years. Legislators said the reform was needed because the bill passed last year was going to cost about $65 million more than they expected, and the state is facing a decline in revenue growth.

DOC.HEAD: Four-Masted Square-Rigger, Damaged by Fire, to Leave Philadelphia
DOC.TEXT: The four-masted square-rigger Moshulu, the last winner of the great grain race around Cape Horn and a fixture on the waterfront for years, is expected to be returned to sailing condition and leave the city. One possible new berth for the 394-foot barkentine, the largest of its kind still afloat, is San Francisco, its home port when it sailed under a U.S. flag, according to a spokesman for the owner. The 86-year-old tall ship has been a restaurant at Penn's Landing since 1976. Last July its plush interior was heavily damaged by a fire and the black, iron-hulled ship has been boarded up for months. A spokesman for the owner, Specialty Restaurants Inc. of Anaheim, Calif., said the plan is to refit the Moshulu in another city, possibly Wilmington, Del., as a working ship and sail it to a new home. ``At one time it was thought she'd never sail again. But that hull, built in 1904, is as sound as the day she was built,'' said Raymond E. Wallace, a marine architect in San Pedro, Calif., who is working on the Moshulu for the restaurant company. Specialty Restaurants, which owns 68 theme restaurants around the nation, has started soliciting sponsors among corporations and foundations, Wallace said. It would cost $4 million to $6 million to put it under sail again. Restaurant company President David Tallichet is committed to the idea, Wallace said. ``He wants something to happen here pretty soon. He loves the ship and so do I,'' Wallace said. The ship, originally named the Kurt, was built along Scotland's Clyde River in 1904 for a German company and started out carrying copper and nitrate from mines in Chile and Mexico. The United States seized the ship when it entered World War I. It was renamed Moshulu, believed to be an Indian word for ``fearless.'' The U.S. Shipping Board operated it until 1921, when the government sold it to a company that used it to haul lumber. In 1935, it was sold to a Finnish shipper and put into the grain trade from Australia to Europe. Giant sailing ships raced around Cape Horn in what came to be called the Great Grain Races of the 1920s and 30s. The Moshulu, carrying 45,000 square feet of canvas, won the last race, sailing from Melbourne, Australia, to Cardiff, Wales, in 91 days in 1939. The record was 83 days set by the bark Parma in 1933. The Moshulu lost its masts during World War II and was used as a storage barge. Wallace and Tallichet found the hulk in Finland and brought it to the United States. The present set of masts and yards were put on only for show and could not carry sails, Wallace said. Restaurant company executive Jeff Mills said the tall ship could end up in a number of seaports, either as a restaurant or a museum, but Philadelphia is not one of them. ``Our lease is up,'' he said. Possible new locations include Jersey City, N.J., Wilmington, San Francisco and San Diego, he said. The fire that damaged the Moshulu started when a bare light bulb ignited paper products in a storage area, city fire officials said. It burned the ship's hold and sent smoke throughout the upper decks. Six people were injured and 200 restaurant patrons had to flee.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Kidnap 2 Americans to Protest Bush Visit
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas kidnapped two Americans to protest President Bush's visit here next week and said they would put their captives on trial, police said today. The Americans, snatched in the drug capital of Medellin, were identified as David Kent and James Archer Donelly, a police spokesman told The Associated Press. The Colombian radio network Caracol said its Medellin station received a telephone call from an anonymous man claiming to be a spokesman for leftist guerrillas who claimed responsibility for the abductions. The man said the two men would be put on trial and would be released in five days, Caracol said. The caller did not explain why there would be a trial and why the captives would be released. The Colombian radio network RCN said Kent was from Indianapolis. The police said he had lived in Medellin for several years and was a teacher at the bilingual, private Colombo school. Donelly runs a company that manufactures hydraulic equipment, the police spokesman said, speaking on condition he not be named. The spokesman said he could not reveal any further details on the kidnappings. The police spokesman said the kidnappers were from the National Liberation Army, a leftist guerrilla group, known by its initials in Spanish as the ELN. There was no way to confirm if the kidnapppers really are leftist guerrillas. Drug traffickers have been found in the past posing as leftist insurgents. The public affairs office of the U.S. Embassy in Bogota said it was trying to confirm the information on the kidnappings. The ELN has become the most active of Colombia's six leftist guerrilla groups with a total of about 10,000 armed insurgents. Organized about 15 years ago, it has consistently patterned its ideological dialogue on the teachings of Cuba's Fidel Castro. The ELN has kidnapped dozens of people in the last four years, many of them small town mayors who were held several days while they were warned to do more for Colombia's poor.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Invades Shore As Weather Stops Cooperating
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 9-12, `The Coast...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with American Trader moved to Arco dock. Picks up 13th graf, `The oily....'
DOC.TEXT: Wind and the tide turned from allies to enemies today, sending waves of gooey brown foam and sludge ashore and spurring calls for more workers to clean up an oil spill. Winds reversing toward shore combined with high tides to push new bands of thick crude oil onto state beaches, producing the worst shoreline contamination yet from Wednesday's tanker spill. An earlier offshore wind pattern and calm seas that helped keep much of the 400,000-gallon oil slick from hitting the beach through the weekend gave way to onshore winds reaching speeds of 30 mph and 6-foot seas, the National Weather Service said. ``We have a very serious situation down here,'' said Mayor Tom Mays, who called on Gov. George Deukmejian to declare an emergency. A spokesman said the governor would consider the move today. Two skimmers worked to keep a finger of the slick 200 yards from the Newport Beach shore. About 300 people were dispatched for overnight cleanup and British Petroleum said it would increase the number of workers throughout the day, the Coast Guard said. By Wednesday, police Sgt. Andy Gonis said 100 people would be dispatched to work a vacuum truck and absorbent booms. ``We're very concerned about the weather,'' Gonis said. On Monday, waves of grimy crude oil spilled by the tanker American Trader rolled into Bolsa Chica State Beach, leaving on the beach bands of oil with a consistency of tar that were 2 inches thick in some spots. About 15 miles of beaches were ordered closed to the public, and ship traffic was barred at Newport Harbor, Anaheim Bay, Huntington Harbour and the San Gabriel River. Meanwhile, the patched-up, 811-foot American Trader moved from a Long Beach Harbor anchorage and tied up at an Arco dock this morning to unload its remaining cargo of crude oil and to begin repairs of hull punctures. An estimated 400,000 gallons of oil leaked from the vessel last Wednesday afternoon after it apparently collided twice with its own anchor while mooring in shallow water at an offshore oil pipeline. Divers applied temporary patches to two holes in the punctured hull Sunday, and authorities said the vessel passed ``watertight integrity'' tests. The oily onslaught spared the nearby inland Bolsa Chica Wetlands, an ecological reserve that's home for the endangered California brown pelican and a stop for thousands of migratory birds and marine life. ``There is no oil in the estuary,'' said Patrick Moore of the state Department of Fish and Game. ``But birds are leaving the wetlands and going to the ocean and bringing the oil back to the estuary.'' In addition to the 30-foot-wide slick on Bolsa Chica State Beach, the Coast Guard said smaller ribbons of oil 4-feet-wide were reported near the Huntington Beach Pier. Seventy-one dead birds _ grebes, gulls, loons and pelicans _ have been found in the area and more than 200 oil-soaked birds were rescued and taken to a treatment center, Moore said. The beach pollution was so serious that British Petroleum, which chartered the American Trader, put out the call for more applicants to add to the current work force of about 400 cleanup employees. ``We are looking for people who want to volunteer to be employed,'' said BP spokesman Fred Garibaldi. The Coast Guard said one-third of the Alaskan crude still menaced the coast, staining sand as far north as Long Beach. Skimmers picked up 23 percent of the spill and 43 percent evaporated or naturally dissipated. On the beach, meanwhile, politicians, environmentalists and celebrities gathered on the sand to demand legislation at the federal and state levels to prevent another spill. Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., viewed the beaches from a helicopter, then criticized President Bush for telling reporters Monday that the spill should not sound the death knell for offshore oil drilling. ``The president should read the environmental impact statements by his own Department of the Interior, which point out that the more drilling platforms that you have the more tankers you will need,'' said Cranston. In searching for the accident's cause, the Coast Guard said drug and alcohol tests on the ship's officers, including Capt. Robert Laware, were negative.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys Say Keating Victim of Government Vendetta
DOC.TEXT: Over the objections of government attorneys, a federal judge on Tuesday allowed lawyers for Phoenix millionaire Charles H. Keating Jr. to portray him as a victim of a vendetta by federal savings and loan regulators. U.S. District Court Judge Stanley Sporkin, a former top regulator himself at the Securities and Exchange Commission, repeatedly overruled objections to testimony alleging leaks of confidential information from the Federal Home Loan Bank Board about Keating's Lincoln and Savings and Loan Association. Attorneys for the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision, which last year replaced the bank board as the thrift industry's chief regulator, argued that the leaks were irrelevant to Keating's suit challenging the federal takeover of the $5.5 billion thrift last April. Sporkin, however, said he wanted to learn the ``broad backdrop'' to a case that, because of Keating's $1.3 million in political gifts to five U.S. senators who interceded on Lincoln's behalf, has become the focal point of a congressional ethics probe. ``Lincoln has the right to tell their side of the story and they're telling it,'' he said. ``They're saying we are not looters as we are accused. They're just playing their cards.'' The hearing, going into its 10th day, technically is on a government motion to dismiss Keating's suit alleging that the seizing of Lincoln last year by regulators was ``capricious and arbitrary.'' Judith Wischer, who headed the day-to-day operation of Keating's real estate and thrift empire as president of American Continental _ Lincoln's parent company _ testified Tuesday that confidential information about Lincoln and its loans was repeatedly leaked by the bank board to journalists. Results of a 1986 exam of the bank were published in The Wall Street Journal and the Mesa (Arizona) Tribune four months before Lincoln was officials notified of them, she said. ``You read about them in the newspaper, that's the way you were advised of the exam?'' Sporkin asked, incredulously. ``That's the way we were advised of the exam,'' Mrs. Wischer replied. It was only through press reports, she said, that American Continental learned much later that the examiners in May 1987 also had recommended to bank board officials in Washington that the government take over Lincoln then. That recommendation fell on deaf ears for nearly two years. During that time, officials now contend, the cost to taxpayers of covering Lincoln's loss of federally insured deposits to soured real estate loans doubled to nearly $2 billion. Just a month before the May 1987 recommendation, the San Francisco regulatory officials in charge of Lincoln's audit were summoned to Washington to meet with the five senators. The five _ Sens. Alan Cranston, D-Calif.; Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; John McCain, R-Ariz.; John Glenn, D-Ohio, and Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich. _ have all denied trying to influence the regulators improperly. All are now under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Civil Rights Activist Dies
DOC.TEXT: Moses LeRoy, who filed a landmark 1973 lawsuit for minority representation on the City Council to force adoption of single-member districts, has died of kidney failure. He was 92. Prior to the lawsuit against the city, only one black had been elected to the council in Houston's history. Now there are five black members and one Hispanic on the 14-member council. ``I'm on City Council because of the lawsuit and because of Mr. LeRoy,'' said Councilman Ernest McGowen, a black retired postal worker elected in 1979. As recently as last week, LeRoy worked in the county's voter registration office, said Carl Smith, Harris County's tax assessor-collector. He died over the weekend. LeRoy came to Houston in 1914, working for 15 to 20 cents an hour digging sewer ditches. He later worked for Southern Pacific Railroad for 47 years, where as president of the Brotherhood of Railway and Airline Clerks, he fought both the railroad management and its union over discriminatory work rules. LeRoy was an executive board member of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People local chapter and was its president for 30 years. LeRoy is survived by his wife, Erma, a daughter, two grandchildren and a great-grandson. Funeral services were scheduled Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Jack Kerouac's Widow Dies
DOC.TEXT: Stella Kerouac, widow of beat generation author Jack Kerouac, has died. She was 71. Mrs. Kerouac died Saturday in St. Joseph's Hospital. She lived with a sister in Dracut and in St. Petersburg, Fla., where her husband died in 1969. Kerouac was best known for his novel ``On The Road.'' Mrs. Kerouac spoke briefly at the dedication of a memorial to her husband at Eastern Canal Park on June 25, 1988, but when asked to be interviewed about their life together, would say, ``If you want to know about Jack, read his books.'' They were married in 1966 and had no children. Both were natives of Lowell, where she worked for a dress manufacturer before their marriage. Kerouac was a boyhood friend of her late brother, Sebastian. She is survived by two sisters and four brothers. A funeral was scheduled Wednesday in Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Still a Major Power in Asia, Cheney Says
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, preparing to ask the United States' Pacific allies to contribute more toward their own defense, said Tuesday that the Soviet Union remains a formidable power in the area. ``What it may be losing in numbers it is gaining back in terms of more modern, capable ships and advanced weaponry,'' Cheney told the Pacific and Asian Affairs Council. The Soviet Foreign Ministry announced last month that it was withdrawing some of the MiG-23 fighters and Tu-16 bombers stationed at Cam Ranh Bay, described by U.S. military sources as the Soviets' largest foreign base. Reminding his listeners of the ``profound shock'' felt when the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbor, Cheney argued that the United States must maintain its military strength to remain a global power and to protect its interests in the Pacific. He said that 35 percent of America's world trade is with east Asian and Pacific nations. From Hawaii, Cheney was heading for South Korea and discussions with officials about increasing their support for the 43,000 U.S. troops stationed there. In all, Cheney is spending two weeks in the Pacific, meeting with representatives of Hong Kong, the Philippines and Japan in light of congressional pressure for paring the defense budget and for larger allied contributions to the costs of keeping U.S. forces in Asia. Cheney said South Korea contributes $300 million a year to maintaining the U.S. force there. The Seoul government, on the other had,n has estimated its share of the U.S. expenses at more than $2 billion. Cheney arranged for a special State Department representative to accompany him as he asks allies with booming economies to kick in more toward the cost of maintaining U.S. forces in Asia. The defense secretary noted that the Soviets maintain more than a half-million ground troops in Asia, dozens of air divisions and one of its largest naval fleets, numbering more than 260 ships and submarines. Overall, there are 120,000 U.S. troops in Asia and Hawaii, a force some members of Congress say is too large. On Tuesday, Cheney said that while he had no plans to ``dramatically alter our posture in the Pacific,'' he could not rule out prospects for adjustments in our deployments or in the overall size of our forces.''

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Choice Union Forces Worried Over AFL-CIO's Delay on Abortion
DOC.TEXT: A decision by AFL-CIO officials to skip a vote on abortion at next week's annual meeting may mean the federation's hierarchy ultimately will remain neutral on the issue, pro-choice union leaders say. Others, such as Duke McVey, president of the Missouri State Labor Council AFL-CIO, say the abortion issue ``has nothing to do with 40 hours a week or 20 bucks an hour.'' ``We have enough to say grace over without taking on the abortion issue. It splits our members and it doesn't address wages, hours or conditions of employment,'' McVey said. Jay Foreman, executive vice president of the United Food and Commerical Workers International Union, said the question is whether the union hierarchy wants ``to take any risks.'' ``The majority of them are male,'' he said. ``They're not children; they're getting up there in years and are kind of fixed in their attitudes. They may not want to bite on this.'' AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland has told the federation's 33-member Executive Council, which meets next week in Bal Harbour, Fla., that he wants a committee to determine whether the federation should take a pro-choice stand or stay neutral. There is no organized move to condemn abortion. Three of the council's 33 members are women. Some pro-choice union forces say that if the council chooses to stay on the sidelines _ as the AFL-CIO has been urged in a national Right to Life letter-writing campaign _ organized labor's efforts to attract women will be damaged. ``If they're going to keep the women and minorities active, they're going to have to come out of the Dark Ages,'' Arlene Collins, first vice president of the Oregon AFL-CIO, said Tuesday. Many union officials, regardless of their position on abortion, agree that organizing women and minorities are key if labor is to reverse the loss in stature it suffered in the 1980s. Collins said she is concerned that if the council continues to delay taking a stand, as it has done for more than a decade, the issue won't have as much impact on the 1990 politial races. But others say abortion won't serve as a litmus test for candidates. ``It's not critical to the election cycle. We're not a single issues group,'' Foreman said. Still, he and other pro-choice labor leaders think the AFL-CIO should commit on the issue because they say abortion has workplace ramifications, such as affecting the economic well-being of working women and raising questions of health-care coverage and the ability of health-care workers to do their job. McVey said a number of rank-and-file union members ``feel very strongly about the issue. They don't support their union doing that kind of activity and they don't want to pay dues to a union that does.'' Yet several pro-choice union leaders noted the AFL-CIO historically has gotten involved in issues not directly related to collective bargaining, such as civil rights, gay rights and school busing. Delegates from all 90 AFL-CIO unions declined last fall to adopt any of the half dozen pro-choice resolutions submitted, referring them to the Executive Council. Adoption of such a resolution would put the federation in line with the stance taken by many of its political allies, such as the Democratic Party and various women's and civil rights groups. William Wynn, president of the UFCW and a pro-choice member of the council, will chair the committee that will determine whether the federation should take a position. Kirkland has not given the committee a deadline, but Wynn predicted it ``will be able to come to a definitive conclusion that will be responsive to everybody's feelings, everybody's emotions.''

DOC.HEAD: Dominican Republic President Checks into Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Dominican Republic President Joaquin Balaguer, who is considering bid for a sixth term in May, was undergoing tests Tuesday at The Methodist Hospital. If Balaguer gets a clean bill of health, he has said he would be a candidate for the May 16 election. Balaguer arrived in Houston on Monday, hospital spokeswoman Brenda Koch said. ``He is a patient here, but he has asked that we not release anything about him,'' she said. Results of his checkup by heart surgeon Michael DeBakey may be released Tuesday, she said. Balaguer, 83, suffers from glaucoma and is nearly blind. Still, he is considered energetic, alert and politically astute. He has published more than 20 books. The May election is the most important in the Caribbean this year and would pit Balaguer against 80-year-old nemesis Juan Bosch, a leftist man of letters whose election in 1963 led to the U.S. invasion of the county in 1965. Bosch has been ahead in recent polls. Balaguer was first elected in 1965, four years after dictator Gen. Rafael Trujillo was assassinated. Balaguer served under Trujillo in a variety of posts for nearly 30 years, but never was implicated in corruption associated with the Trujillo regime.
