Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Women-only Chatham College is considering admitting men for the first time _ at least partly to attract women. Trustee Louis B. Barnes said one factor behind Monday's proposal was apprehension that young women would look elsewhere for their education. He called the process of getting 18-year-old women to apply to a female-only college a ``tough sell.'' ``There's a so-called stigma attached to a single-sex college,'' Barnes said. ``Many modern young women choose to go to coed colleges. They are at least as interested in their social existence as their academic existence.'' Chatham's Board of Trustees approved a resolution, backed by President Rebecca Stafford, which would open the doors of the school to men next year for the first time. The proposal came from the board's long-range planning committee, which includes faculty and alumnae. A final decision will be made at the board's spring meeting in April. ``We've increased enrollment. We want to increase it even more, especially traditional-aged students,'' Ms. Stafford said. ``We want to increase the student body so we can offer more courses.'' Chatham College was founded in 1869. It has about 650 women enrolled.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: And now, with the latest in sports, here's ... Senate Majority Leader George J. Mitchell. The Maine Democrat, known in the nation's capital for his scholarly, measured political arguments, tried his hand at television sportscasting Tuesday, going on the air live with stories about heavyweight boxing, tennis and other sports on WCSH-TV. ``That was fun,'' Mitchell said after stepping off the set. He appeared on the noon news as a ``celebrity sportscaster'' with his brother, John, the assistant men's basketball coach at Colby College in their home town of Waterville. George Mitchell led the sports segment with a story on the controversy surrounding the Douglas-Tyson fight in Tokyo this weekend. ``The president of the World Boxing Council says there never was any doubt that James `Buster' Douglas beat Mike Tyson, fair and square,'' the Senate majority leader said, reading from a script prepared by WCSH's regular writers. Mitchell then reported on tennis player Steffi Graf's recovery from a thumb injury before cutting to his brother for a report on professional basketball. He's been interested in sports for years, Mitchell said, and is scheduled to be grand marshal in next week's Daytona 500 national stock car race. How does sportscasting compare with Senate debate? ``They're both fun, but in different ways,'' said Mitchell, who has no plans to dump politics for sportscasting full-time.

DOC.HEAD: All But One Vehicle Test Show Possible Injuries
DOC.TEXT: Six of seven 1990-model autos so far tested appear unlikely to protect drivers from head injuries in a 35-mile-per-hour crash, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said Tuesday. Only the Acura Integra four-door sedan appears able to protect from driver head injuries, the agency said. The Toyota 4-Runner four-door truck ranked worst among models tested. Besides the Acura and Toyota models, tests have been conducted on the Chevrolet Lumina, the Mazda Miata, the Nissan Stanza, the Lexus ES250 and the Mitsubishi Eclipse. Some carmakers have criticized the government's testing, which uses instrument-equipped dummies. The manufacturers contend the tests to not accurately reflect highway crash conditions. The safety agency continues testing throughout the year until all models are covered. Dummies in the tests are secured by seat belts and, if available, air bags. Instruments are designed to measure potential head, chest and upper leg injuries to an average-sized adult male. Each car is given a head-injury rating. Scores below 750 indicate that head injury is unlikely, between 750 and 1,250 that it is possible and above 1,250 that it is likely. Here are the models tested so far and their head injury scores: Toyota 4-Runner four-door, 1,306; Chevrolet Lumina four-door, 1,200; Nissan Stanza four-door, 1,105; Lexus ES250 four-door, 992; Mazda Miata two-door convertible, 920; Mitsubishi Eclipse two-door hatchback, 772; Acura Integra four-door, 585.

DOC.HEAD: Senator Criticizes ``Pension Raiding'' By Corporations
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Howard Metzenbaum on Tuesday criticized ``pension raiding'' by corporations that terminate employee retirement plans to gain surplus assets and turn over the pensions to companies holding junk bonds. ``Pension raids leave workers and retirees with frozen pension checks while their employers lugh their way to the bank with millions of dollars,'' said Metzenbaum, an Ohio Democrat. Metzenbaum's comments came as his Senate labor subcommittee held a hearing on pension terminations and the potential risks from companies establishing replacement retirement programs with annuities bought from insurance companies heavily invested in high-risk ``junk bonds.'' Annuities are contracts that pay fixed monthly benefits to retirees. Surplus pension assets have become a popular target for corporate raiders who acquire a company and use its retirement programs as a source of cash. Metzenbaum focused on a proposal by the Kansas-based Coleman Co. to terminate employee pension funds valued at $83 million and a scrapped deal to buy annuities from First Executive Corp., a California insurance holding company hit by financial downturns from turmoil in the junk-bond market. He also cited the takeover of California-based Pacific Lumber Co. in 1986 by Maxxam Group Inc., which replaced an employee pension fund with an annuity bought from First Executive and took control of about $50 million in surplus pension assets. ``We are very worried about our pension and feel we didn't get a fair deal,'' Pacific Lumber worker Lester Reynolds, of Fortuna, Calif., told the panel. Metzenbaum said the subcommittee would consider legislation to impose tighter standards on pension terminations and provide greater protection for retirement benefits. ``Too often, sound pension plans are wrung dry of their cash and replaced with annuities offering fixed benefits and no chance of cost-of-living adjustments,'' Metzenbaum said. ``These annuities are backed by an under-regulated insurance industry that plays fast and loose with everything from accounting methods to capital standards.'' Metzenbaum suggested that Coleman's corporate parent, MacAndrews & Forbes Holding Inc., had a potential conflict of interest in doing business with First Executive and may have violated federal standards in failing to adequately safeguard the interests of retirees. First Executive, Metzenbaum said, had $310 million in bonds of Revlon Inc., a subsidiary of MacAndrews & Forbes. Coleman officials said they had acted properly. ``It is my belief ... that the company has acted in every step in good faith and with full appreciation of applicable fiduciary obligations,'' said Coleman president Larry Jones. Coleman was acquired in April by MacAndrews & Forbes, controlled by takeover specialist Ronald O. Perelman. Wichita-based Coleman is one of the world's largest makers of outdoor recreation equipment. Because Coleman's pension plans are overfunded, MacAndrews & Forbes will be able to take up to $32 million in surplus money for its own use by terminating the pensions and setting up an annuity program. A MacAndrews & Forbes official said the surplus would be closer to $20 million after taxes, and that all of the money would be reinvested to expand and modernize Coleman, finance a new employee retirement savings program and develop new products and markets. ``Our retirees will not suffer one penny's loss as a result of this transaction,'' said Howard Gittis, vice chairman of New York-based MacAndrews & Forbes. Coleman has scuttled its deal with First Executive and officials told the subcommittee that it had secured the return of a $45 million ``premium deposit.'' Coleman officials said they would proceed with their termination plan but would buy annuities from an insurance company carrying the highest rating of claims-paying ability.

DOC.HEAD: Cambridge Candy Company Churns Out Conversation Hearts
DOC.TEXT: Only the messages have changed on those familiar Valentine's Day staples: conversation hearts. ``Skidoo'' and ``Oh You Kid'' have given way to ``Luv ya'' and ``Let's Rock.'' The medium _ small, colored candy hearts _ remains the same. The New England Confectionery Company, better known as Necco, originated ``conversation hearts'' at the turn of the century. It ceased production in 1920 but revived them six years ago when company officials decided they had become popular again. Today, it's Valentine's Day year-round at the company's huge, nondescript building. Necco churns out 1.7 billion conversation hearts a year and is believed to be the leader among several companies that make them. ``I think people today, in spite of what they say about them, are more interested in talking about their thoughts and feelings than we ever were,'' said Charles Welsford, systems manager of the Necco company. ``Candy has long been a way of expression between people. People love conversation hearts,'' he said Tuesday. Necco makes the hearts on the same machines that produced them in the early 1900s. On one floor of the sprawling plant, dozens of white uniformed employees scurry around a maze of huge vats of sugar, rollers and conveyor belts. Necco, which also makes chocolates and a series of candy bars, makes conversation hearts from the same ingredients as its famous Necco wafers _ a mixture of sugar, corn syrup and dextrose. It's a simple process. The conversation hearts are almost 100 percent sugar, which is blended into a paste in large troughs. The mixture is then rolled onto a conveyor belt like a blanket, where a printing mechanism engraves the sayings onto the paste. A cutter mold, which operates at 145 strokes a minute, cuts out 37 hearts per stroke during each eight-hour shift. The tiny hearts are the most popular but Necco also makes a slightly larger version as well. ``I know they're popular because it's not even Valentine's Day and we're already out of them,'' Jean Philippe Simonet, manager of the Fanny Farmer candy shop in Boston, said Tuesday. Necco employee Anthony Staropoli says he never tires of them, and he's been working at the plant for 43 years. ``People are crazy for them,'' said Staropoli. ``When they hear I work here, I have to give bags to everyone.'' Welsford said Necco's approximately 700 employees are asked to contribute ideas for the messages printed on the hearts. A total of 25 phrases are chosen _ none of which will win awards for ingenuity or cleverness. A sampling: ``Dig Me,'' ``Stay Loose,'' ``Buzz Off'' ``Cool'' or ``Far Out.'' But Welsford defends them, pointing out that ``any of them can be given to any youngster without explanation.'' And yes, some of the hearts contain that one message that hasn't changed over the years and never needs an explanation: ``I Love You.''

DOC.HEAD: Trump vs. Trump: The War
DOC.TEXT: The big question Tuesday in the society soap opera of Trump vs. Trump was a legal one: How solid is a prenuptial agreement between Donald and Ivana? Under it, Mrs. Trump would be limited to custody of their three children, their Greenwich, Conn., mansion and $25 million. But Donald Trump is worth $1.7 billion, by Fortune magazine's estimate, and New York Post gossip columnist Cindy Adams reported that Ivana Trump wants $150 million, the Plaza Hotel and her husband's 727 jetliner. The real estate magnate and his wife signed an agreement before their marriage 13 years ago limiting Ivana's share in case of a divorce. The agreement was updated at least twice, the last time two years ago. Last summer Ivana asked the prominent divorce lawyer Raoul Felder whether the agreement could be broken. He told her to forget it. ``The law doesn't protect you from making a bad deal,'' Felder said this week, adding that the Trumps' agreement ``isn't even prenuptial; it's postnuptial.'' New York courts are known for their respect for prenuptial agreements, in the absence of evidence that there was not a full and fair disclosure of the assets at stake. But Mrs. Trump's lawyer, Michael Kennedy, said, ``We do not consider the so-called prenuptial agreement to be serious. It will have no relevance to a court because it is unconscionable and fraudulent.'' And Adams, who says she has known Trump ``when he was straight out of school and in his early dating days,'' asked, ``Who of us knows what properties could have been undervalued or overvalued for varying purposes, right?'' Her conclusion: ``Donald knows he's about to get hit.'' Trump's spokesman was adamant: ``The prenuptial agreement signed by Donald and Ivana Trump is a long and detailed document which covers all aspects and is 100 percent enforceable in courts of law.'' Trump, in Wilmington, Del., on Tuesday to promote the second Tour de Trump bicycle race, repeatedly said ``no questions'' when asked to comment on the breakup. Asked later if he planned to rename the helicopter that bears his wife's name, the developer laughed heartily but refused to comment. Although published reports had linked Trump romantically to a number of women, actress Marla Maples moved ahead Tuesday as the New York tabloid newspapers' favorite candidate for the role of the other woman. In an Aspen, Colo., restaurant over the holidays, Mrs. Trump reportedly warned Maples to stay away from her husband. Maples reportedly told her: ``I love him and if you don't, why don't you let him go?'' A source who had heard a firsthand account of the meeting told the Post that Mrs. Trump cursed at the actress and mispronounced her name as ``Moolah.'' Trump told his wife afterward, ``You're overreacting.'' Other Trump allegations, reports and rumors filled the tabloids: _Donald had Ivana locked out of her office Monday at the Plaza Hotel, but then let her in. _Donald and Ivana had an hour-long meeting alone at the hotel. _Some of Ivana's jewelry was missing and she suspected Donald took it from their vault. The headline writers did their bit, with ``Ivana Be Alone'' (Newsday), ``Ivana Better Deal'' (Daily News) and ``Gimme the Plaza'' (Post). The News used the overline ``Trump: the War'' over its three pages of Trump coverage. Even Leona Helmsley, the self-described hotel queen, got into the act. ``He's obsessed with me, isn't he?'' Mrs. Helmsley said to a reporter. ``Then why would he push her (Ivana) to be just like me _ to run his hotels? Really!'' Donald had been quoted as telling a source that Ivana's ``level of arrogance has grown steadily worse in recent years. The bottom line is I don't want to create another Leona Helmsley.'' Mrs. Helmsley, who was recently convicted of tax evasion, was described at her trial as ill-tempered and demanding. ``I have told Ivana, `Whatever Leona would do, do the opposite. Be nice to everybody.' And she is nice, anyway,'' Trump said in an interview published in the March issue of Playboy magazine.

DOC.HEAD: Dry Soil, Lack of Snow Cover Still Threaten Winter Wheat
DOC.TEXT: Dry soil conditions and lack of snow cover in parts of the Great Plains continue to threaten winter wheat, the government's Joint Agricultural Weather Facility said Tuesday. ``Portions of the southern Great Plains received some moisture but more was needed,'' the facility said in its report for the week of Feb. 4-10. ``Most of the central and northern Great Plains remained dry, but above-normal temperatures helped to maintain crop condition.'' The facility is operated by the department's of Agriculture and Commerce. The weekly reports cover soil and crop conditions but do not project yields. Looking at some other crops, the report said the sugarcane harvest continued in Florida, but that ``unseasonably hot, dry weather forced citrus producers to continue irrigating.'' The warm weather also continued over the major Florida vegetable areas where spring plantings were under way. In Georgia, tobacco plant beds were reported in ``good to excellent'' condition and that North Carolina farmers continued to seed their beds. ``Rain and wet field conditions again limited field work in the Delta,'' the report said. ``Land preparation for the 1990 cotton crop continued in Arizona and California.'' Livestock pastures were helped by rain and mild temperatures in the Delta and Southeast, the report said. ``In the Great Plains and Corn Belt, mild temperatures and the lack of snow cover reduced the amount of supplemental feeding necessary (for livestock),'' the report said. ``Mild weather provided ideal conditions for calving, which was under way in many areas.''

DOC.HEAD: Survey: Most Germans Want Neutral State with Berlin as Capital
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A survey has shown that 58 percent of West Germans and 92 percent of East Germans questioned want military neutrality for a unified Germany, a magazine said Tuesday. The survey also showed overwhelming support for Berlin as the capital of a single Germany, the Munich-based weekly magazine Quick said. The survey, which questioned 3,599 Germans _ 2,170 in West Germany and 1,429 in East Germany _ was conducted for the magazine by the Tuebingen-based Wickert Institute. Seven percent of the East Germans and 42 percent of the West Germans questioned would want a unified Germany to be a NATO member, the survey said. Only 1 percent of East Germans questioned would favor continued membership in the Warsaw Pact, according to the survey. Support for Berlin as the capital was overwhelming. The survey said that 91 percent of East Germans questioned want Berlin as the government seat of a unified Germany. East Berlin already is the capital of East Germany, although the United States, France and Britain say that status violates post-war agreements. Sixty-seven percent of West Germans questioned favor moving the capital from Bonn to Berlin, in the event of unification, according to the survey. No margin of error was given and the magazine did not say how the poll was conducted last week.

DOC.HEAD: At Summit, Bush May Bring Up Military `Radar Net' Over Columbia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 15th graf, The United, to fix spacing
DOC.TEXT: President Bush may use the four-nation drug summit to revive the idea _ shunned in Latin America _ of using U.S. military forces to cast a ``radar net'' over Colombia to track cocaine-carrying aircraft, a senior adviser said Tuesday. Brent Scowcroft, Bush's national security adviser, said the idea was ``on the shelf for the moment'' because Colombian officials balked last year at news reports that the United States was considering a naval ``blockade'' of their ports. Scowcroft said the plan probably would not win approval ``in the next several days'' _ the summit is Thursday _ but he added that ``it's an idea we think has merit.'' He said, ``I expect it might be discussed'' at the summit. Another administration official, speaking anonymously, played down the sensitive subject, calling it ``not a significant agenda item.'' Bush, after a pre-dawn flight from Washington on Thursday, will join the leaders of Colombia, Bolivia and Peru in the coastal resort of Cartagena for six hours of drug-fighting talks. The summit site, at a heavily guarded naval base isolated on a peninsula, was selected to provide maximum protection in a nation torn by drug-related violence. Underscoring the hazards, police reported Tuesday that leftist guerrillas had kidnapped two Americans in the drug capital of Medellin, Colombia, to protest Bush's visit. They were identified as David Kent, a teacher from Indianapolis, and James Donnelly, employed by a company that manufactures hydraulic equipment. Colombian authorities say about 5,000 security agents will be on hand for the presidents' protection at the summit. To bolster security, two American warships have been deployed in the Caribbean, along with a Colombian escort ship. The U.S. vessels are the USS Nassau, an 820-foot amphibious assault ship which carries helicopters and a Marine landing team, and the USS Sampson, a 437-foot destroyer armed with missiles and two five-inch guns. Acknowledging risks involved in the trip, Scowcroft said, ``It's an unusual situation because there are in Colombia these guerrilla bands, terrorist bands with access to funds to purchase ... any kinds of arms, and so naturally there are unusual circumstances.'' However, he said, ``All the agencies involved in presidential security are comfortable with the arrangements.'' In preparation for the summit, Bush called in senior advisers in the drug war, including Attorney General Dick Thornburgh; drug policy director William Bennett; CIA Director William Webster; Drug Enforcement Administration Director John Lawn; Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; Trade Representative Carla Hills and Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan. Bush also signed a new United Nations compact aimed at helping curb international drug traffic and urged other nations to do the same, ``to join us in working together to rid the world of this menace, the menace from drugs.'' The United States is the fifth nation to ratify the agreement tentatively approved by 76 countries. The U.N. Convention Against Illegal Traffic in Narcotic Drugs calls upon all nations to make illegal the production, cultivation and transportation of narcotics and other dangerous drugs. It also calls for tighter controls on chemicals used in drug production and sets up guidelines for extraditing drug offenders, seizing drug-tainted assets and curbing money laundering. Scowcroft, at a briefing on the summit, said the United States never planned a naval blockade of Colombia. Instead, he said the plan envisioned using offshore facilities to erect a radar screen ``that will give the Colombians the ability to target where the loaded plans are coming from, going up to North America and where the empty planes are coming back in, and so forth.'' Scowcroft said, ``We would be interested in improved cooperation in that kind of interdiction.'' A day earlier, Bush said, ``What I'd like to convince them is we can be extraordinarily helpful, particularly, to Colombia in their courageous fight against narco-traffickers by a sophisticated interdiction effort.'' Scowcroft said the four leaders will sign a communique covering U.S. economic assistance to the Andean nations, as well as aid from international financial institutions. It also will call for reducing the demand for drugs in the United States, curbing U.S. export of chemicals such as ether used to manufacture cocaine from coca leaves, and will deal with the export of U.S. weapons to the region and with money laundering, he said. Commenting on a dispute with Colombia concerning coffee and cut-flower trade, Scowcroft offered little hope that progress would be made on resolving such disagreements at the drug summit. Later, however, Bennett said the subjects were open to discussion. Colombian President Virgilio Barco has complained to Bush that the U.S. Commerce Department is engaged in a trade procedure against Colombian flower growers that could result in big tariffs on Colombian-grown cut flowers. Scowcroft said there is nothing the administration can do about the matter, which he described as a regulatory procedure taken after U.S. flower growers protested that Colombia was ``dumping'' flowers in this country at below-fair-market prices.

DOC.HEAD: Civilians Flee Main Militia Stronghold, Fearing Attack
DOC.TEXT: Civilians fled on foot through deep snow Tuesday to escape a ski resort area they fear will be the next battleground of the rival armies fighting for control of Lebanon's Christian territory. Kesrouan province in the mountains north of Beirut is noted for both summer and winter resorts, but also is the main stronghold of Samir Geagea and his Lebanese Forces, the largest Christian militia. Michel Aoun, the rebel general whose 19,000 soldiers been trying to destroy Geagea for more than two weeks, described the militia as ``an unacceptable tumor in our body'' and called up reserves and volunteers. Police said Aoun was massing troops along Kesrouan's eastern flank and its southern coastal area near Jounieh, a port 12 miles north of Beirut, for an apparent two-pronged thrust. His troopers and Geagea's militiamen fought intermittent artillery and mortar duels Tuesday in Christian east Beirut and in Kesrouan. Aoun's command reported 15 soldiers in combat in two days and police said 18 corpses were taken from the streets of east Beirut, where snipers are active. At least 513 people have been killed and 1,724 wounded since the battle began Jan. 30, according to police figures. Snow was 20 inches deep in the mountains Tuesday and more was falling. Police said dozens of exhausted civilians slogged to villages away from the potential field of battle. ``Many civilians have reached central Kesrouan, with cases of exhaustion after crossing the deep valleys on foot,'' said a police spokesman, whose name cannot be used under standing regulations. ``Unfortunately, there is nothing we can do to help. We can't send patrols to evacuate them because bridges have been blown up and other narrow roads have been either mined or blocked by snow.'' In an attempt to limit Aoun's ability to maneuver, militiamen have blown up all bridges linking the mountains he controls in the east to central and western Kesrouan, the spokesman said. Geagea's men also have planted antitank mines along most narrow mountain roads in the province to block any advance. Aoun, who commands about 19,000 men, said he was willing to give Geagea a political role in the 310-square-mile Christian enclave north and east of Beirut, but also indicated he was ready for a showdown. He said army would be the only armed group permitted to operate in the enclave, where 1 million Christians live. ``They are welcome if they want political responsibility,'' Aoun told a news conference at his headquarters bunker beneath the shattered presidential palace in Baabda, a Christian suburb east of Beirut. ``They should be integrated into an official apparatus,'' he said. ``They are an unacceptable tumor in our body,'' Aoun said, but added: ``We are ready to give them a chance. In times of major crisis, one should be ready to take valiant decisions to avoid more victims and more tragedies.'' Aoun has retained his command in defiance of President Elias Hrawi, who dismissed him as army chief after being elected in November with a mandate to implement a peace plan designed to end the 15-year-old civil war. The general rejects the peace plan and refuses to leave the presidential palace. His remarks Tuesday about the Lebanese Forces amounted to a restatement of conditions he outlined when the battle began, that the militia be disbanded transformed into a political party. Geagea has rejected the offer as ``an effort to eliminate us.'' He noted that his militia, which has about 6,000 regulars and thousands of reservists, has fought Lebanese Moslems, Palestinians and Syrians during the long civil war. Aoun accused the Lebanese Forces of ``stabbing the army in the back'' and said his forces had ``achieved the minimum we are capable of doing.'' His reference was to the battle for the strategic Dbaye Hills north of Beirut, which his men captured early last week.

DOC.HEAD: Selma Schools Reopen Amid Heavy Security, Absenteeism; Protest Continues
LaserPhoto XSEL2
DOC.TEXT: Schools closed for a week by a racial protest reopened Tuesday amid heavy security, including 200 National Guardsmen sent by Gov. Guy Hunt. Absenteeism was high but officials reported no classroom problems. About 150 black student protesters boycotted Selma High School and marched around a flagpole chanting ``Shut 'em down! No school!'' before the opening bell. Another two dozen protesters continued a sit-in at City Hall for a seventh day. Outside some carried signs saying ``Equality! Education!'' ``This is the first time troopers have been used to ensure that whites could go to school,'' said Jamie Wallace, executive director of the Selma chamber of commerce. The protest, prompted by the dismissal of the city's first black school superintendent by white school board members, was less strident than in recent days when throngs of black demonstrators rekindled images of historic Selma marches in the 1960s. The superintendent, Norward Roussell, who was reinstated last week, called for racial unity Tuesday. But he said he doubted the conflict will end ``until there is some movement on my contract,'' which expires in June. His supporters contend he is being dismissed because of his race and action he took on behalf of black students, not because of an alleged lack of managerial skills cited in an evaluation. He has held the $80,000 post for 2{ years. Protesters also want the school board, with six whites and five blacks, to be elected rather than appointed by the City Council, which has five whites and four blacks. The city is 52 percent black. ``It saddens me that children have to be pulled into a political and racial conflict that should have been solved years ago, after the Edmund Pettus Bridge,'' said Roussell. He referred to the Selma bridge where marchers were clubbed by state troopers in 1965 in what became known as ``Bloody Sunday,'' a milestone in the drive for equal rights. Hunt agreed to dispatch 200 military police from National Guard reserve ranks to join an undisclosed number of state troopers and local police in guarding Selma's 11 public schools, which closed Feb. 7 amid rising racial tensions. The system, with 5,971 students, is about 70 percent black, and some white parents have moved their children to private schools or other systems during the past week. ``There is no reason for all this security, because they didn't come here to be violent,'' said Dallas County Commissioner Perry Varner, a black protest leader who was arrested in a melee in the mayor's office last week. Roussell said about 23 percent of the students were absent Tuesday. He said he had predicted 30 percent would stay home because of uncertainty over the school environment. ``Both black and white parents seriously want their chidren back in schools,'' said Roussell, who has opposed student boycotts even when they were conducted in support of him. ``I want to commend parents, both black and white, for sending their children back to school. We don't need a superintendent over empty schools and classrooms.'' He said the situation in the schools was ``reasonably calm,'' with two boys, both black, in a shoving match at a middle school. He said 54 students were withdrawn from schools Tuesday, but he believes most will return ``once they see we're open and things are going smoothly.'' ``I want to emphasize that we're not having a mass exodus of whites from our schools,'' he said. The protesting students marched about a mile to the high school Tuesday morning, and at one point the marchers had a brief confrontation with state troopers. Several troopers told the marchers they needed to stay away from the school, prompting the marchers to stop and pray, with troopers taking off their hats during the prayer. The students then moved through the troopers, who did not try to physically restrain them as the students went to the flagpole.

DOC.HEAD: Secret Police Say More than 750,000 People Shot from 1930-53
DOC.TEXT: More than 750,000 people were shot to death as enemies of the state during Stalin's 1930-53 reign of terror, the KGB secret police said in a report Tuesday. The figure does not include the millions who died in labor camps and prisons or in the famines during Stalin's collectivization of agriculture, but it represented the first time the KGB has given a figure for any of Stalin's victims. Many Western sources say that altogether more than 10 million people were killed. Under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms, government commissions and the KGB have been ordered to find the truth about Stalin's terror and rehabilitate the victims. Gorbachev's KGB director, Vladimir A. Kryuchkov, has pledged to never again permit the secret police to be involved in such repression. The official Tass news agency quoted a KGB committee as saying a review of its archives determined that 3,778,234 people had been sentenced for counterrevolutionary activities or crimes against the state from 1930 to 1953, when Stalin died. It said 786,098 of them, including many top state and party leaders, scientists, military leaders and cultural figures, had been shot to death. Most leading figures such as Bolshevik leader Nikolai I. Bukharin, who was shot at the height of the terror in 1938, have since been cleared of any crimes. The Tass report said the cases of more than 850,000 people had been reconsidered by the KGB and the Soviet prosecutor's office the past two years, and that all but about 12,000 had been cleared. The KGB said it was continuing to look for the mass graves where Stalin's victims were buried to place memorials there. Such graves have been uncovered in many regions of the country in recent years. But it charged that many local KGB offices were not helping uncover the truth about innocent victims in their areas. The KGB has been trying to improve its public image and in recent months it has gone on a publicity offensive, presenting some of its top officers for a television call-in program and allowing a film to be made about its operations. During the 1970s, the KGB harassed Soviet dissidents and now say they were only carrying out the policies required of them at the time. As the agency's role has changed in society, Kryuchkov has called for closer cooperation between the KGB and intelligence agencies in the West to fight drug trafficking and terrorism.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Against Bowie Thrown Out by Federal Judge
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has dismissed a 2-year-old lawsuit against rock star David Bowie filed by a woman who claimed he sexually assaulted her. U.S. District Judge Sam Cummings on Monday threw out the lawsuit filed by Wanda Lee Nichols, who accused Bowie of assaulting her in his hotel room on Oct. 9, 1987, during a four-day concert stopover in Dallas. Bowie conceded he had spent the night with Ms. Nichols, but denied accusations he sexually assaulted her. A grand jury declined to indict Bowie on Nov. 18, 1987. Ms. Nichols asked a judge to have Bowie tested to see if he carried the AIDS virus, although her attorney had said she already had tested negative for exposure to the virus herself. Bowie subsequently tested negative for AIDS in Switzerland and mailed the results to Dallas. Dallas lawyer Daniel P. Callahan, who represented Bowie in the suit, said the judge's decision to dismiss the lawsuit on Monday was ``the appropriate result.'' ``As far as I can tell, it was just a nuisance suit,'' Callahan said. Ms. Nichols, a resident of suburban University Park, said she would continue to press for monetary damages despite the judge's decision. ``I'm not going to give up totally,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Artist Una Hanbury Dies
DOC.TEXT: Sculptor Una Hanbury, whose work is found at the National Portrait Gallery and other museums and galleries around the world, has died. She was 86. Hanbury died Friday at her Santa Fe home following a brief illness. Hanbury's works, in bronze, cast aluminum, stone, terra cotta and marble, are found in more than 500 private and public collections worldwide, including those of the Portrait Gallery, the Smithsonian Institution, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, all in Washington, D.C., and the Royal Academy in London. Her monumental bronze sculptures and portraits include those of scientist Robert Oppenheimer and artist Georgia O'Keeffe. She became a fixture in the Santa Fe arts community after moving here 25 years ago. A memorial service is scheduled Feb. 24 at the Museum of Fine Arts.

DOC.HEAD: Hispanics Left Out Of Job Training Program
DOC.TEXT: Federal job training programs fail to serve enough Hispanics because of income and documentation barriers, a government report said Tuesday. The National Commission for Employment Policy, an independent agency that reports to Congress and the president, said the federal Job Training Partnership Act needs to be amended so more Hispanics will participate. The report, based on a 12-month study, called on Congress to ease income requirements. It also asked the Labor Department to urge states to loosen documentation requirements needed to get into job training programs. While Hispanics account for between 13 percent and 14 percent of those eligible for job training programs, they make up only between 10 percent and 11 percent of those who take part, the report said. The commission blamed part of the discrepancy on federal requirements that mandate candidates for the program be receiving food stamps. Many Hispanics refuse to accept public assistance and therefore miss out on job training oppurtunities, the report said. ``Because of their cultural heritage of self-sufficiency and attendant distaste for government assistance programs, many Hispanics would rather forego JTPA training than accept food stamp assistance just to qualify for the program,'' the agency said. The report recommended that Congress change the law so that candidates merely be ``eligible'' for food stamps rather than actually accepting the assistance. Under current law, receiving food stamps is one way to be eligible for JTPA. There are also job training income cut-off levels, which are higher, in some areas, than the food stamp qualification. That means some working poor Hispanics have income levels that fall between the two levels, which keeps them from meeting the JTPA cut-off but qualifys them for food stamps. Congress needs to make the two income levels compatible, so that Hispanics falling between the two income levels who choose not to take food stamps can still receive job training, the report said. In addition, the commission said requirements on documents such as birth certificates are overly restrictive in some areas, such as Miami where there are a large number of political refugees. ``Maybe some of us still have our birth certificate sitting in a drawer some place, but for these people, in order to get a birth certificate, they have to get it from the very government they fled,'' said Carol Romero, the staff economist who oversaw the report. The Labor Department should urge states to consider ways to ease documentation requirements, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Militants Kill TV Journalist; Intelligence Officer Hanged
DOC.TEXT: Moslem militants fighting for the secession of Kashmir from India shot and killed the senior television journalist in Srinagar on Tuesday as he returned home from work, witnesses and officials said. Lassa Kaul, a Hindu and top executive in the Srinagar bureau of the state-owned Doordarshan TV network, was shot three times when he stepped from his jeep outside his home, said witnesses. Witnesses also said the body of Inspector Yashpal Sharma, an intelligence officer, was found hanging from an almond tree Tuesday near the town of Wahabpura, about nine miles west of Srinagar. They said Sharma, also a Hindu, was kidnapped from nearby Chadura on Sunday night. Gov. Jagmohan of Jammu-Kashmir state told reporters, ``We have no such report.'' The witnesses spoke on condition of anonymity. The deaths would raise to 87 the number of people killed since Jan. 20, when the government began a crackdown on the militants. Sixty-four percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 6 million people are Moslem, making it the only Moslem-dominated state among the 25 states in overwhelmingly Hindu India. Nationwide, Moslems make up 12 percent of the 880 million population. Jagmohan, a Hindu who uses only one name, was named governor on Jan. 18 and ordered the crackdown two days later. He said Tuesday that police and soldiers raided at least 15 houses believed to be militant hideouts in downtown Srinagar, but said nothing of arrests. Police said two bomb explosions hit Srinagar on Tuesday during a curfew relaxation, but no casualties were reported. A senior state administration official said intelligence reports showed the militants had acquired rocket-launchers and missiles, and military sources said they suspected plans for large-scale sabotage were in the making. The official and sources spoke on condition of not being identified. Kashmir was divided into Pakistan-held and India-controlled districts by a cease-fire line after a war in 1948-49. A campaign for secession for India began shortly after and turned violent in recent years. A 1965 India-Pakistan war did not change the position, although the cease-fire line was overwritten by a so-called line of actual control. The latest round of violence flared Jan. 20 following the government crackdown and the arrest of 250 suspected militants, most of whom were later released. India says neighboring Pakistan trains and arms the militants with a view to annexing the state. Pakistan denies it, but says it upholds the Kashmiri people's right to self-determination. Border incidents killed up to six Pakistani demonstrators last Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: James Earl Ray Files for Divorce
DOC.TEXT: James Earl Ray, serving a 99-year prison sentence for killing civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr., has filed for divorce from his wife of 12 years. In a petition filed Feb. 5 in Morgan County, Ray, 62, said only that irreconcilable differences had developed between him and his wife, Anna Sandhu Ray, 45. But relatives said Ray is upset because his wife has not visited him in Brushy Mountain State Prison, west of Knoxville, for several years. The Rays married in 1978. They met while she worked as an artist for a Knoxville television station during Ray's trial for escaping from Brushy Mountain. In October 1988, Mrs. Ray threatened to file for divorce, saying Ray had cut her out of profits from a book he's writing about his life, but she did not follow through. In an interview last month with the Nashville Banner, Mrs. Ray said she still believed her husband was innocent of the King slaying. Ray has contended he was framed to cover up an FBI assassination plot to kill the civil rights leader, who was shot to death April 4, 1968, in Memphis.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Shouts Mrs. Thatcher Down on South African Sanctions
With AM-South Africa Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Opposition legislators shouted Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher down Tuesday when she defended easing sanctions against South Africa, and the Labor Party leader called her ``absurd and arrogant.'' More uproar came during question time in the House of Commons, when a legislator said, referring to Mrs. Thatcher, ``If she'd just spent 27 years in jail ...'' ``And so she should!'' interjected Gerald Kaufman, Labor's spokesman on foreign affairs. Neil Kinnock, the Labor Party leader, said Mrs. Thatcher was ``absurd and arrogant'' for seeking to ease sanctions that had to support of Nelson Mandela, the black leader freed Sunday after serving more than 27 years in prison. When Kinnock referred to Mandela's support for sanctions, Mrs. Thatcher accused Labor of taking ``its instructions'' from the African National Congress guerrilla organization. After loud protests, Mrs. Thatcher withdrew the remark. ``Mr. Mandela also said he approved of armed struggle,'' she said. ``I disagree with him on that and I disagree with him on the present sanctions.'' She remained standing for question time, sometimes trying to shout above the noise and sometimes silent, as opposition legislators yelled and jeered. Her own Conservative Party members shouted back at Labor across the green leather benches of the Commons. Speaker Bernard Weatherill called repeatedly for order. ``This sounds awful!'' he protested. ``I've never heard the House behave in this way at question time.'' Mrs. Thatcher said both the Labor Party and ANC believed in comprehensive economic sanctions against South Africa's white government, in the armed struggle against it and in widespread nationalization of industry. ``Mr. Mandela naturally said he supports all three, in what I would call his ritual speech,'' she said, referring to Mandela's remarks Sunday to huge crowd in Cape Town. ``I believe he is making very much better and more peaceful speeches during his (subsequent) press conferences.'' On Sunday, Mandela said the armed struggle and international sanctions should continue until the white-led South African government finally abolished apartheid. This month, Mrs. Thatcher will seek to get the 12-nation European Community to drop a ban on new investment and on promoting tourism to South Africa, both voluntary measures. She has hinted she will go ahead alone if necessary. The prime minister says President F.W. de Klerk should be rewarded for freeing Mandela and legalizing the ANC as a prelude to negotiating a new constitution enfranchising blacks, who outnumber South Africa's whites by more than 5 to 1. Her officials say de Klerk risks being ousted in a white backlash unless he can show anxious South African whites some response from the outside world. There is little support for Mrs. Thatcher's stance in the European Community and President Bush is prevented by law from lifting sanctions until specific reforms are adopted. In the Commons, she said: ``President Bush has made clear that he does not think that sanctions are necessarily right answer in this situation. He is bound by a law passed by Congress. In so far as we are bound by laws, we will be.'' The European Community has banned member states from importing iron, steel or gold coins to South Africa and from exporting oil to it. The United States, European Community and Japan are South Africa's major trading partners.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. And Korea Sign Pact To Study Expansion Of Trade
DOC.TEXT: Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher and Korea's trade minister signed an agreement Tuesday to create a joint commmittee on commercial cooperation designed to expand trade and reduce friction. The committee will develop opportunities for cooperationin trade and investment, exchange information on mutually beneificial development proejcts and exchange technical information. ``Our ability to address areas of potential cooperation will lead not only to expanded trade, but reduced friction,'' Mosbacher said after the signing with Korean Minister of Trade and Industry Han Seung-Soo. ``South Korea's announcement yesterday of a $100 million award to General Electrict to provide equipment to the Ildo Power Prodject demonstrates the long-term commitment that U.S. firms ar e making to the Korean market,'' Mosbacher said. ``It's another brick in the strong foundation that exists for trade expandion between our two coutnries.''

DOC.HEAD: Woman Jailed for Refusing to Testify in Barry Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 10th graf, bgng: The attorney xxx to UPDATE with lawyer's statement.
DOC.TEXT: A woman was jailed for civil contempt of court Tuesday after refusing to testify before a federal grand jury investigating Mayor Marion Barry. U.S. District Judge John Garrett Penn granted immunity from prosecution to Maria McCarthy, of Greensboro, N.C., after she initially refused to discuss Barry with the grand jury, said her attorney, Leslie Scherr. When she still declined to testify, she was ordered jailed, said Scherr. The grand jury is investigating Barry's ties to former city employee Charles Lewis, who has cooperated with the panel after pleading guilty to two cocaine conspiracy charges. Lewis testified in open court that he supplied Barry with crack cocaine. The federal investigation began in December 1988 after city police aborted an undercover drug purchase from Lewis when they discovered that Barry was in his downtown Washington hotel room. Barry, who is enrolled in a Florida substance abuse treatment center after being arrested Jan. 18 on a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge, has denied using drugs with Lewis. In another development Tuesday, U.S. Magistrate Deborah Robinson ruled that Barry does not have to undergo a urinalysis while he is at the Florida clinic. However, the magistrate said that Barry must be tested within 12 hours of his departure from the clinic in West Palm Beach. Weekly tests were a condition of Barry's original release from custody on Jan. 19. The U.S. Attorney's Office submitted a motion on Monday asking that Barry leave the clinic to be tested weekly at a court-approved facility. Authorities said that Barry had not been tested at the clinic since his arrival on Jan. 22. Scherr said McCarthy explained her decision not to testify by telling him, ``I have to live with myself, whether he was a friend or enemy, we had a relationship that doesn't need public scrutiny.'' The attorney declined to say whether McCarthy had been referring to Barry, but two city government sources said that Barry and McCarthy had had a personal relationship. Scherr said McCarthy had authorized him to reveal that she knows Rasheeda Moore, the woman who cooperated with the FBI sting operation that resulted in Barry's arrest. Scherr declined to provide further details about McCarthy's connection to Moore or the mayor. McCarthy is the second woman jailed for civil contempt for refusing to discuss her relationship with Barry. Karen Johnson served eight months in jail in 1984. Under law, McCarthy can be hel in jail as long as the grand jury hearing evidence in the case remains in session. Grand juries are normally empaneled for 18 months at a time, but can be extended if the case continues.

DOC.HEAD: Snow On Northern Plains And Rockies
DOC.TEXT: Cold air from the Arctic forced its way southward across the nation Tuesday, generating high wind and stirring up snow from the Pacific Northwest to the northern Plains. A wind chill advisory was posted for Missoula County in west-central Montana, where strong easterly wind produced dangerous wind chills. Livingston, Mont., reported a wind chill reading of 44 degrees below zero in the afternoon, and Duluth, Minn., had a wind chill reading of 43 below zero. Temperatures were below freezing at midday from the northern and central high Plains to Upper Michigan and northern Lower Michigan, and below zero across parts of Montana, North Dakota and Minnesota. But temperatures remained mild east of the cold air mass, and Mansfield, Ohio, had a record 56 degrees, while Green Bay, Wis., tied its record of 43. Strong, gusty wind also ushered cold air into the Southwest. Heavy snow fell across Wyoming late Monday and early Tuesday, including 15 inches at Big Horn, 11 inches at Rawlins, and 10 inches at Casper and Dayton. Heavy snow also fell across parts of western South Dakota, with up to 9 inches reported in the Black Hills area. Snow advisories were posted for parts of Utah and Colorado. Snow also fell across parts of the Northwest, with snow reported at elevations near sea level as far south as northern California, where snow was reported at Arcata and Redding during the morning. Newport, on the central coast of Oregon, got 2 inches of snow overnight. Redding tied its record low for the date of 26 degrees. Snow was expected in northern Arizona by Wednesday and a winter storm watch was issued for Wednesday at higher elevations. Strong southerly winds prevailed ahead of the arctic cold front from the southern Plains and the lower Mississippi Valley to the Northeast. Winds gusted to 54 mph during the morning at Burlington, Vt., and to 52 mph at Erie, Pa. Strong westerly winds blew through the high mountain passes of extreme southwestern Texas. Guadalupe Pass reported winds at 56 mph during the afternoon, with gusts to 69 mph. Wind warnings and advisories also were posted for parts of Idaho, Nevada and Southern California Elsewhere, light snow fell ahead of a warm front over parts of northern New England and upstate New York. Tuesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 14 degrees below zero at Caribou, Maine.

DOC.HEAD: Celine's Fashions Updated for Nineties
DOC.TEXT: Short skirts, skittish decolletes and beautiful fabrics gave a modern update to Celine styles for next winter in a Tuesday show. If you thought Celine meant the carriage trade, specializing in beautiful handbags and moccasins, you're right. But the house aims to stay in the money with the rich country-club set since its acquisition by the Agache group, run by Bernard Arnault, whose stable also includes Dior and Christian Lacroix. ``We're still a classic house but with new flair in styles that really go out on the street or to parties,'' said Celine's president, Nan Legeai. Dressed in a siren-red suit with panther-spotted blouse, Legeai said she was thrilled with the peppy new-look clothes, designed by Peggy Huynh-Kinh. ``We also planned the event as a special one,'' she said of the show that came before all the other ready-to-wear houses, which plan to present their winter styles during the ready-to-wear week next March. Models paraded Celine's fashions by tables in the covered flowered garden at the Ritz Hotel. Many found the clothes beautiful, if not overly trendy _ outfits that look very much at home at the Ritz. From the lush cable-knit ivory or beige cashmere and suede pants outfits to a smashing evening suit of ruby satin with slashed black lapels over a transparent tulle blouse, the clothes were sexy but very ``BCBG.'' The acronym stands for ``bon chic, bon genre,'' meaning French upper-middle class, a couple of notches above preppy or yuppie. ``I wanted to create practical ensembles for daytime, more romantic styles for late day,'' said Ms. Huynh-Kinh, who designed luxury ready-to-wear for Gres and Balmain before coming to Celine a couple years ago. Celine was founded by Richard Vipiana and his wife in 1946, with a line of leather goods, including the signature mocassins with metal bits. The house was taken over by Aarnault's Financiere Agache consortium in 1987. Celine's luxury ready-to-wear operation looks attractively viable, with prices in the $1,000 range for a suit, less for a draped velvet cocktail dress. And faithful clients will find fun new items to tempt them in the superb and colorful argyle patterns on suede handbags, belts and shoes.

DOC.HEAD: United Nations Announces Withdrawal Plans from Namibia
DOC.TEXT: With Namibia's independence set for March 21, the United Nations announced plans Tuesday to withdraw its more than 6,000 personnel from its largest and most expensive peacekeeping operation. U.N. spokesman Fred Eckhard also said U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar likely would attend the ceremonies marking Namibia's independence after 75 years of South African rule. The South-West Africa People's Organization (SWAPO), which will form the first government, has said it will invite both South African President F.W. de Klerk and recently released black leader Nelson Mandela to attend. Eckhard said 4,000 troops will start pulling out immediately after independence and all are expected to depart by April 8. Most of the civilian staff and the police monitors should be gone by the end of March or early April, Eckhard added. The operation has cost more than $400 million. Shortly after U.N. personnel began arriving last March, their mission appeared in jeopardy when fighting broke out in April between SWAPO guerrillas and the South African-led security forces. However, the fighting was stopped after three weeks and the transition to independence has proceeded remarkably smoothly. Elections, universally regarded as free and fair, were held in November and seven parties captured seats in the 72-member Constituent Assembly. SWAPO, which waged a 23-year bush war against South African, won 41 seats and its long-time leader Sam Nujoma is expected to be named the first president. There have been sporadic instances of violence but no sustained conflicts since the fighting in April last year.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: OTTAWA (AP) = The United States and the Soviet Union reached agreement Tuesday on a ceiling for troops they can station on foreign soil in Europe, Canadian External Affairs Minister Joseph Clark announced. Essentially, the accord worked out during an ``open skies'' conference represents Soviet acceptance of the initiative President Bush unveiled in his State of the Union address Jan. 31.

DOC.HEAD: White House Scuttles USIA Chief's Firing of VOA Director
DOC.TEXT: The head of the U.S. Information Agency tried to fire the director of the Voice of America last week, but the White House said VOA's Richard Carlson still enjoyed President Bush's confidence, officials said Tuesday. One government source close to the situation, speaking only on condition of anonymity, described a confrontation between USIA Director Bruce Gelb and Carlson over a decision last month to eliminate six of VOA's 43 language services in an effort to save $3 million. White House personnel director Chase Untermeyer, while declining to go into the question of any dispute between Gelb and Carlson, said Tuesday that he had met in recent days with the two _ both presidential appointees whose nominations had been approved by the Senate. Gelb is a personal friend of Bush and a campaign fund raiser, and Untermeyer said Carlson was held over from the Reagan administration, ``proof that he has our support.'' While declining to discuss what he had told the two men, Untermeyer did say that now ``all is calm at USIA.'' Fifty-seven people would lose their jobs if the Uzbek, Swahili, Lao, Slovenian, Greek and Turkish services go off the air as announced this spring and summer. The cuts were approved by Gelb, spokesman Frank Johnson said, before Carlson announced the decision to employees two weeks ago. Gelb ``approved the plan, but he wasn't comfortable with it,'' Johnson said. The USIA director was out of town when Carlson met with the VOA employees, Johnson said. When Gelb returned and read news accounts of the decision, he was extremely upset, said one participant at a meeting of senior agency officials convened by Gelb. The USIA director ``claimed he knew nothing about it (the decision). He was almost hysterical. He claimed we tricked him,'' said the source. Johnson, Gelb's spokesman, said the USIA director proposed that funds be transferred from VOA's construction account to keep the six services operating in what Johnson called ``one last attempt to solve the problem.'' Carlson and Gelb's senior aides objected, saying that the construction budget was already squeezed and that any transfer of funds could jeopardize transmitter projects around the world, said the source. Carlson also said that transferring funds from one account to another would require the approval of Congress, which had rejected such a solution in preliminary discussions of VOA's budgetary dilemma, the source said. But Gelb pressed his solution, berated Carlson for failing to support him and told the VOA chief last Thursday that he was fired, the source said. Gelb also told aides to cancel Carlson's Sunday departure for Israel and talks with Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir about a $300 million transmitter the VOA wants to build in Israel to improve its transmissions to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. At that point, the White House weighed in. One source said that ``it was agreed they would try to work out their differences.'' Johnson said simply that Gelb and Carlson ``enjoy a professional and worklike relationship.'' VOA spokeswoman Beth Knisely said Carlson ``has not resigned and he has not been fired.'' On Tuesday, shortly before he left for Israel, Carlson met with VOA employees to deny rumors that he'd been fired and, said one participant, to tell them the White House was pleased with the job VOA was doing. As for the announced cutbacks, VOA officials are now exploring whether Congress will approve the transfer of funds to keep the six foreign language services operating.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says Mandela's Support of Armed Struggle `Not Helpful'
With AM-South Africa Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela's support for guerrilla violence has ``not been helpful,'' but white leaders agree with the need for black voting rights, a government minister said Tuesday. Gerrit Viljoen, the constitutional development minister, said Mandela's organization, the African National Congress, appears confused over how to respond to the reforms of President F.W. de Klerk. Mandela, the country's best known black leader, was freed Sunday after more than 27 years in prison. He has said negotiations with the white government could begin soon, but he still supports the ANC sabotage campaign he helped launch in 1961. Viljoen, whose job is to negotiate a new constitution that will enfranchise the 28 million blacks, said the government agrees with Mandela on several major issues. ``The government accepts the principle of universal franchise and an end to apartheid,'' he told a news conference, but ``Mandela's remarks on the armed struggle have not been helpful.'' ``The government is not prepared to accede to the handing over of power. If that is the goal of the armed struggle, then there is no meaningful way ahead.'' He said the government's ``power to maintain law and order is quite considerable.'' ``ANC policy ... dates back several decades'' and the organization remains wedded to such ``failed'' policies as a socialist-oriented economy, he said. On Feb. 2, de Klerk legalized the ANC and more than 60 other opposition groups. The ANC says it still is considering a formal response to the speech. ``It seems at the moment that there is some confusion and contradiction in the responses of the ANC,'' Viljoen said, and urged it to ``cooperate in the process of negotiations and not just set new conditions.'' De Klerk's government says it wants to bring blacks into the national government within five years, but says a one-man, one-vote democracy would result in black domination of the 5 million whites.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
OTTAWA: Communist governments.
DOC.TEXT: Announcing the settlement, Clark said, ``It overcomes one of the most difficult obstacles'' to a treaty NATO and the Warsaw Pact are negotiating in Vienna on limits to conventional forces in Europe. Other key elements in the projected treaty would cover limits on tanks and other non-nuclear weapons. However, only Monday, Secretary of State James A. Baker III stressed in a speech to the conference that the United States and the Soviet Union were in disagreement on limits for combat aircraft. Without such agreement, a treaty would be more difficult to reach.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Black Factional Violence Increases in Natal
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Black factional violence in Natal province has increased and 50 people have been killed since Nelson Mandela was freed from prison, according to estimates Tuesday by police and monitoring groups. Also, people of Indian descent are being attacked more frequently in the area around the port city of Durban, which has the largest Indian population. Growing violence in an area that has suffered four years of black factional fighting ``has been linked to the raised political temperature created by Mr. Mandela's release and his statement that the ... armed struggle would continue,'' said The Star of Johannesburg, South Africa's largest daily. A police statement Tuesday afternoon said: ``Although the situation was somewhat quieter today, a number of deaths were reported from Natal and the eastern (Cape) province.'' Police headquarters in Pretoria said an officer who tried to stop three men from robbing a bus driver in a black township near Pietermaritzburg, the capital of Natal, was shot in the back and hacked to death. An officer was shot in the stomach and two black men were killed when police fired at two clashing groups in Nxamalala, a Natal township, police reported. They said houses were burned and three black women were injured. Police said two black men were stabbed to death and burned when houses were set ablaze in a factional fight in Kwanobuhle township near Uitenhage in the eastern Cape province. Brig. Jac Buchner, police commissioner for the Zulu homeland in Natal, said guns were used to kill 13 people in Mpumalanga township Monday, the day after Mandela's release. He called it ``a worrying escalation'' in an area where firebombs, knives and sharpened sticks are the usual weapons. More than 2,500 people have been killed in the factional violence since 1986. Most of the Natal fighting was between supporters of the African National Congress and members of the Inkatha political organization of Mangosuthu Buthelezi, the Zulu chief minister, but criminal elements were taking advantage of the chaos, police reported. The newspaper Natal Witness reported concern about increasing anti-Indian sentiment in the townships around Durban. Black crowds have attacked Indians four times in a week, two Indian men were stabbed to death in Durban on Sunday and other blacks rescued Indians from a mob, it reported. Black marchers celebrating Mandela's release Sunday burned three Indian stores and a gas station, witnesses said Tuesday. They said police had fired on the marchers. Thulebana Phewa, 16, limping from police buckshot wounds, said the attacks by 3,000 blacks on Indian stores were not racial. He said people were angered when officers from a nearby police station opened fire on a peaceful crowd in a squatter area outside Durban called Amahula. Phewa said looters took 12 cows from the I.J. Hafferjee general store and slaughtered two before police fired shotguns and recovered the remaining cattle. Groups monitoring the unrest said a pamphlet was distributed in black townships saying Indians controlled the Congress of South African Trade Unions and had called strikes so black people would lose their jobs. The pamphlet urged Zulus to unite against the labor federation, which is affiliated with Mandela's African National Congress. Buthelezi said Tuesday the pamphlets had nothing to do with his organization or government. ``I totally condemn any racist behavior and utterances directed against the Indian community and ask that a halt be called to all rumor mongering ... that may result in death and destruction,'' he said in a statement distributed by the independent South African Press Association.

DOC.HEAD: Peru, Bolivia Will Ask for U.S. Aid to Switch from Growing Coca
With AM-Colombia-Summit
DOC.TEXT: The presidents of Peru and Bolivia say they will ask the United States at the drug summit Thursday for money to help farmers switch from coca, the raw material of cocaine, to growing other crops. Presidents Alan Garcia of Peru, Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia and Virgilio Barco of Colombia are to meet President Bush in Cartagena, Colombia, on Thursday to discuss the drug-trafficking problem. Garcia said Tuesday he will request help for Peruvian farmers to stop growing coca and produce coffee, cocoa or other crops. Paz Zamora told a meeting of farmers Monday north of La Paz, the capital of Bolivia: ``We are not going to allow the peasants of Bolivia to become poorer after substituting'' other crops for coca. Andina, the Peruvian government news agency, quoted Garcia on Tuesday as saying peasants of the Huallaga Valley, a major coca-growing region, were willing to switch crops if they were assured transportation for what they produced and an international market for it. With those conditions, ``In a year or two we'll switch over all the land now under coca, but ... massive economic resources are needed,'' Garcia was quoted as saying. He said Peru exports about $3 billion worth of fish meal, oil, coffee, silver and other products, plus about $750 million to $1 billion worth of coca and cocaine paste. Coca ``is enormously important to our economy,'' the agency quoted him as saying. The Bolivian president, Paz Zamora, told the farmers he would pursue a policy of eradicating coca plantations in exchange for economic and social development programs. He said Barco and Garcia agree with that position and he was confident Bush also will agree. About 1,500 farmers attended the meeting Monday at Coroico, in a coca-producing area about 60 miles north of La Paz. Substituting other crops for coca is the centerpiece of Bolivian policy against drug trafficking but it has made little progress. Bolivia adopted an ambitious plan in 1988 to eradicate coca cultivation in seven years, but as of Jan. 31 only 7,750 acres had been withdrawn from coca cultivation, about 5 percent of the officially recognized 150,250 acres devoted to coca. Plans had called for the elimination of 12,500 acres in 1989 alone. Part of the plan to substitute other crops for coca was the payment of $2,000 to peasants for every hectare (2.5 acres) of coca planting eliminated voluntarily. Peasants also demanded better prices for the new crops, guaranteed markets and better roads and transportation. On Monday, Paz Zamora said coca production ``allows us to keep our balance of payments even, and for this reason we should study carefully the problem of substituting other crops.'' In eight to 10 years, when the substitution program has been completed, farmers should have incomes at least equivalent to what they now make from coca, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Romanian Council Says It Will Serve as Quasi-Parliament
DOC.TEXT: Romania's new, ruling Council of National Unity endorsed Ion Iliescu as interim president on Tuesday and said it would serve as a quasi-parliament. Despite its powers, including the right to initiate legislation, Iliescu stressed the council is not quite a parliament. ``We were never elected and should try to concentrate as much as possible on our main task of paving the way for elections,'' he said. ``In the future parliament of Romania, everyone will have the right of legislative initiative.'' The second meeting of the 253-member council was held in a markedly improved atmosphere over its inaugural session Friday, when opposition parties accused Iliescu of packing the hall with rowdy supporters of his National Salvation Front. ``We have shown constructive debate and even consensus are possible,'' Iliescu said after the meeting. ``We now have chances ... to assure the continuation of life in this country until the elections.'' Radu Campeanu, head of the influential National Liberal Party, lauded the achievement of an ``equilibrium, albeit fragile.'' He had criticized the Front on Monday and accused it of packing the council. Also Tuesday, military officers demonstrated to demand that the ministers of defense and interior resign as part of an overall purge of military officials who backed Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu in December's revolution. The Defense Ministry dismissed the demands Tuesday night as ignorant and ``an affront'' to military values. Nearly 300 uniformed officers protested silently in pouring rain outside government headquarters in Victory Square while 49 representatives waited inside to see Iliescu and present a list of demands. It was the military's first serious challenge to the government, which consolidated power only after the army decided to back the popular uprising against Ceausescu, who was deposed and later executed. Iliescu was president of the 11-member National Salvation Front council that ruled until the Council of National Unity took over Friday. On Tuesday he was confirmed as president of the new council. At one point during the debate, Iliescu asked: ``Is anyone opposed to my continuing as president?'' A near-unanimous chorus of ``No!'' was his answer. Elected as Vice Presidents were Campeanu, Ion Minzatu of the Republican Party, independents Cazimir Ionescu and Ion Caramitru, and Karol Kiraly, representing minorities. The council decided to hold regular biweekly meetings on Fridays and other meetings ``as circumstances dictate;'' two-thirds of the membership constitutes a quorum; decisions will be made by simple majority in either open or secret ballot, and attendance will be mandatory for government members. Tuesday's council meeting was open to reporters and broadcast on TV. The council elected a 21-member Executive Bureau to coordinate activities _ 10 representatives of political parties, 10 independent Council members, plus Iliescu. One major point of contention within the Council will likely be opposition demands that the elections be postponed until at least September. More than 35 parties are expected to compete in Romania's first multiparty elections since World War II, now set for May 20. The council also set up 16 commissions to deal with specific issues, including one to investigate ``abuses'' committed under Ceausescu's leadership and another on constitutional and human rights. The transport minister late Tuesday resolved merchant seamen's complaints over pay and food that led to strikes that closed Romania's main port of Constanza on the Black Sea and several smaller ports Monday and Tuesday, idling dozens of ships. ``Our conditions of working and living have made us the laughingstock of the world. We have become the paupers of the sea,'' said Petricia Munteanu, president of the Union of Merchant Seamen.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Spokesman Accuses Communists Of Stalling Talks
DOC.TEXT: A spokesman for Bulgaria's opposition alliance accused the Communist Party on Tuesday of trying to hinder progress in negotiations, the official Bulgarian news agency BTA reported. Georgi Spassov of the Union of Democratic Forces, appearing on national television, also repeated its demands that party cells in factories and other places of work be abolished before free elections scheduled for May, the agency said. At the weekly negotiating session Monday, the opposition said it would not continue talks with the Communists until that issue was resolved. The Union of Democratic Forces has been negotiating for more power sharing, but has refused Communist appeals to join the government because the party still dominates Parliament. Last week the Agrarian Party, once a docile ally of the Communists, said it was abandoning its subservient role and no longer would participate in the government, which left Premier Andrei Lukanov no alternative to forming an all-Communist Cabinet. BTA quoted Spassov of comparing the national negotiations to ``a boat with oars on one side only that's ... going round and round in a vicious circle.'' He accused the Communists of ``torpedoing'' the talks by delaying agreement on several questions. Spassov claimed the Communists were ``in complete isolation,'' BTA reported. That appeared to be a reference to the Agrarian Party and reformists who split from the Communist Party and formed the Alternative Socialist Party on Sunday. Although neither has joined the opposition, both parties supported the demands the alliance made at Monday's talks. Communist Party structures were like ``cancerous growths,'' Spassov said, and should be demolished because they were ``a means for the nomenclatura (bureaucracy) to keep in subjection and exploit all working people, Communists included.'' He repeated the threat to withdraw from the talks. In apparent response, Georgi Pirinski, head of the Communist delegation to the talks, said in a separate television statement any ``dictatorial approach'' was unacceptable and served only to question the work of the negotiations. One opposition demand has been for greater access to the media, especially television and radio, to carry its platforms to the entire country. They have been allowed to start a newspaper, which is called Democracy and began publishing Monday. State television and other official media are reporting on the oppposition more openly, but it has been a slow process. BTA reported that, on Tuesday, the Communist Party daily Rabotnichesko Delo appeared for the first time without the party motto ``Workers of the World Unite.'' Stefan Prodev, the new, reform-minded editor in chief, said in an editorial it must ``turn from a paper of one large party into a paper of the nation.''

DOC.HEAD: 37 Reported Dead, Refugees Flee Violence in Tadzhikistan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 6 `Later, local' to CORRECT spelling of province. Picks up 7th pvs, `Television showed...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOS32
DOC.TEXT: A crowd stormed Communist Party headquarters in the Tadzhikistan capital of Dushanbe Tuesday in ethnic rioting that has killed at least 37 people and injured 108, news reports said. Armenians fled the city by the hundreds to escape the violence, which began Monday. The situation worsened Tuesday, with at least 200 new attacks and other incidents despite a curfew and state of emergency, late-night television news said. Soldiers in tanks and armored personnel carriers were reportedly in control of the central Asian city 1,600 miles from Moscow, but violence was spreading to the suburbs, said Anatoly Larenok, a correspondent for the national newspaper Vozdushny Transport. ``There are tanks guarding key buildings in the center of the city,'' he said. People began to flock into Dushanbe, a city with about 400,000 residents, early Tuesday to gather in front of Communist Party headquarters. But officials failed to persuade them to disperse and the crowd attacked the building, the television report said. Later, local authorities appealed to the population on Tadzhikistan television to repel the ``hooligans.'' They also said local forces were insufficient to control the situation and urged the national leadership to help them. Television showed footage of clashes between rioters and police, smashed vehicles and shattered storefronts. In one scene, a smiling old man stepped out of a broken store window with his arms full of cartons of milk. Violence broke out in Dushanbe on Monday after rumors spread that thousands of Armenian refugees _ already fleeing ethnic clashes with Azerbaijanis in the Caucasus _ were being given preference for scarce new housing. There is a chronic housing shortage in Dushanbe for Tadzhik families, which traditionally are large. Larenok said at least 300 Armenians had fled the city aboard special flights to Yerevan, the Armenian capital, and many others had left on regular flights. About 30 people were arrested for taking part in the violence, the television said. Ethnic tensions also were reported high in Frunze, capital of the neighboring republic of Kirgizia on the border with China, following rumors that Armenian refugees were to receive apartments in the city, the Komsomolskaya Pravda said. No violence was reported there. Zaniddin Nasreddinov, an editor at the Tajiktass news agency, reported another rally in the center of Dushanbe Tuesday morning, but said there was no violence. Communist Party leaders spoke to the crowd and assured them that all Armenian refugees had left the city, he said. The demonstrators elected a committee of 12 to represent the public in negotiations with authorities on issues such as the current ethnic strife, housing and unemployment, Nasreddinov said. Interfax, a publication of official Radio Moscow, said the crowd demanded the deportation of all Armenians from Tadzhikistan, the closure of an ecologically dangerous aluminum plant, the return to the republic of all proceeds from cotton production, and the resignations of the Communist Party and government leadership. The official Tass news agency, contradicting the TV report of continuing attacks, said Dushanbe was calm Tuesday but ``still very tense.'' An official with the Interior Ministry who declined to give his name said the situation remained ``serious'' Tuesday night. A state of emergency was declared Monday and a 10 p.m.-6 a.m. curfew was imposed, Tass said. The curfew remained in effect Tuesday night.
