Tass said precise casualty figures were unavailable, but preliminary reports showed that at least seven people had died in the rioting and 108 were injured when young Tadzhiks stormed the Communist Party headquarters and went on a rampage in the city. The news agency said a small crowd that had gathered in front of the building Monday morning swelled to a rally of at least 4,000 later in the day. Communist Party First Secretary Kakhar Makhkamov and other members of the government told the crowd that only about 40 refugees were in Dushanbe, and they were living with relatives, Tass said. ``No one believed them, and several members from the rally attempted to enter the building,'' Tass said. ``Interior Ministry troops blocked entrances to the building and soldiers fired into the air, but this did not stop the extremists.'' Shots were fired at the troops from the crowd and stones were thrown at them, Tass said. Rampaging youths broke the ground floor windows and set fire to the building, it said. Larenok reported that the rioters then attacked apartments belonging to Armenians across the city. ``A jewelry store, shops, a railway station and several kiosks were broken into and smashed,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``The rampage continued in the street. Several trolleybuses and cars were set on fire,'' Larenok said. ``Passersby, including women and children, were attacked and beaten.'' More than 200 people have been killed in the southern Caucasus republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan since Jan. 13. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev sent thousands of soldiers into the area to end a nationalist revolt in the Azerbaijani capital of Baku and end attacks on Armenians, many of whom have been evacuated from Azerbaijan. Until Monday, there had been no reports that the trouble had spread to the predominantly Moslem republics of Soviet Central Asia such as Tadzhikistan. Families in Tadzhikistan, a small mountainous republic bordering China and Afghanistan, traditionally are large. In addition to the housing shortage, some of the mainly Moslem Tadzhiks also remain homeless after an earthquake in the republic in January 1989 that killed scores of people.

DOC.HEAD: 25 People Die in Scattered Guerrilla Violence in Peru
DOC.TEXT: Scattered clashes and assassinations by leftist guerrillas have left 25 people dead across the country in the past three days, authorities said Tuesday. Also Tuesday, the Interior Ministry announced the capture of four Shining Path rebels who were accused of producing counterfeit tickets to soccer matches and bullfights and selling them for money for the group's armed insurgency. Officials said the illegal operation went on for five years. In the bloodiest incident in three days, police said 100 Shining Path guerrillas with automatic weapons attacked the mountain village of Sol Naciente Sunday night, and captured and killed eight peasants. The rebels also wounded nine others who tried to flee, police said. Police said the attack probably was in response to the village's recent formation of a civil defense group intended to repel guerrilla incursions. The military has organized dozens of the groups in isolated villages to fight the rebels, but many are armed only with homemade shotguns, lances and machetes. Witnesses to Sunday's attack said villagers tried to hold off the rebels with two shotguns, then had to flee when they used up their ammunition. Sol Naciente is 245 miles southeast of Lima in a remote area of the Andes. Police said some of the wounded were being hospitalized in Ayacucho. Another report said members of a civil defense group in the village of Andamarca, 165 miles east of Lima, ambushed 15 guerrillas Sunday night and killed seven. Police said a gun battle Monday between Shining Path rebels and a police patrol near San Martin de Pangoa, 175 miles east of Lima in the jungle, left five guerrillas dead and one policeman wounded. Also Monday, police said, guerrillas fatally shot two policemen in Piura, two others in Huacho, and one in Chiclayo. Huacho and Chiclayo are on the Pacific coast northwest of Lima, and Piura is in the northern coastal desert. The Interior Ministry said police Tuesday captured four men with printing equipment and thousands of counterfeit tickets to soccer games at the national stadium and bullfights at Lima's historic Acho bull ring. They identified the four as working for the Shining Path and said the tickets were sold to raise money for guerrilla operations. Police said the four also produced thousands of falsified identification cards for providing aliases to Shining Path members to escape police detection. The Mao-inspired Shining Path launched its armed insurgency in 1980 near Ayacucho, 235 miles southeast of Lima in the Andean highlands. The group now operates through much of the highlands and the coca-producing jungles of the northeast, where drug traffickers pay them to provide protection from police, authorities say. The government says more than 17,500 people have died in the decade of violence, including police, soldiers, rebels, government officials and civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Israel's Peres Demands Quick Vote on Peace Talks Compromise
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf with 4 grafs to UPDATE with suspected collaborator killed.
DOC.TEXT: Labor Party leader Shimon Peres on Tuesday demanded a quick Cabinet vote on a Palestinian-approved compromise to launch peace talks, and senior party officials said Labor should pull out of the government if the proposal is rejected. ``We will certainly act so that the Cabinet will make an unequivocal decision regarding the makeup of the Palestinian delegation. There is no point in any delay or avoidance tactics,'' the leader of the center-left party told Israel army radio. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir moved to reconcile with hard-liners in his right-wing Likud bloc who want to block the compromise, which outlines the makeup of a Palestinian delegation to peace talks with Israel in Cairo. The compromise plan has U.S. backing. A Likud meeting broke up in confusion Monday after the hawks tried to force a vote on specific compromise proposals, while Shamir insisted on a general show of support for his peace initiative calling for elections in the occupied lands. Peres, who has accused Shamir of endangering peace efforts through stalling tactics, suggested that the chaos in Likud heightened the need for a quick decision. He did not say when he would seek a vote on the compromise plan, or whether a Likud rejection would prompt him to break up the Labor-Likud coalition. The so-called Forum of Four _ comprised of Shamir, Peres, Likud's Foreign Minister Moshe Arens and Labor's Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin _ is scheduled to meet Wednesday. The next regularly scheduled Cabinet session is on Sunday. Haim Ramon, the chief Labor parliamentarian, demanded on Israel TV that Labor quit the government if the Cabinet rejects the compromise plan. ``If Shamir says no, and blocks this opening, there is proof that there is no point to continue the peace process with the prime minister,'' he said. The compromise plan says the 10-member Palestinian delegation should include two Arabs deported by Israel from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, and at least one resident of Israeli-annexed Arab east Jerusalem who also has an address in the occupied lands. Such a delegation would meet Palestinian demands for diaspora representation, while technically complying with Israel's insistence that it will only negotiate with residents of the occupied territories. Likud hard-liners, including Trade Minister Ariel Sharon and Housing Minister David Levy, say the compromise allows the PLO to enter negotiations through the back door and cast doubts on Israel's sovereignty over Jerusalem. In a speech before the Likud Central Committee on Monday, Shamir ruled out participation of east Jerusalem Arabs but did not address the issue of deportees, suggesting he was ready to compromise. On Tuesday, Likud activists, including Levy, were trying to persuade Sharon to withdraw his letter of resignation, which he read at the opening of the Likud meeting. Sharon said on Israel radio he had no plans to retract the letter, but left a door open to compromise. He said that if he had not quit on principle, ``I would prefer certainly to stay in the government.'' By law, the resignation does not take effect until 48 hours after the premier receives the letter. Also Tuesday, Arab reporters said Israeli border police entered a Bethlehem high school near Manger Square and beat two dozen students with truncheons, metal bars and rifle butts. The army said a border police patrol entered the Bethlehem High School for Boys Tuesday after students threw stones at them, but that all injuries occurred when the youths escaped over a terrace. The Arab reports did not say what provoked the incident. Hospital officials in Bethlehem said they treated 20 students and that at least five of them suffered serious head injuries. The body of Abdu Salam Hamoud, 24, was found in a cave near the West Bank village of Beituniya, where he lived, and Arab reports said he was suspected of collaborting with Israeli authorities. The army confirmed the death and said police were investigating. Hamoud's death would bring to 182 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel's security service. At least 656 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the 26-month-old revolt against Israeli rule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Forty-three Israelis have also died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: President Says Greater Development Needed to Combat Coca Leaf Farming
DOC.TEXT: President Jaime Paz Zamora said Tuesday on the eve of his departure for the drug summit in Colombia that greater economic development is the key to stopping coca leaf farming. He also said consuming nations must do more to combat drug use. ``Coca reduction in exchange for development _ that is our premise,'' Paz Zamora told foreign reporters. ``We are proposing investments in the Bolivian economy. It is not just a question of substituting one hectare of coca for oranges or coffee but the development of the country because coca is an integral part of the economy.'' Now, the government says, cocaine brings in $500 million to $600 million a year in illegal export earnings. The country's legal export earnings for 1989 were $600 million dollars. Paz Zamora praised President Bush ``because he is showing unlike any other U.S. president that the cocaine problem is a global one.'' Bolivia's president called on the establishment of an emergency fund to handle the problem of unemployment and poverty that would be created as coca plants are eradicated. He said, however, that he was not going to the drug summit in Cartagena, Colombia, to ask for specific amounts of U.S. aid but to present Bolivia's views. ``We do not want subsidies for alternative products since that is a short- term solution,'' Paz Zamora said. ``We rather require help in private and public investment and export policies that would strengthen our economy. We have to compete with alternative crops.'' Bolivia, an impoverished country of 6.9 million in the heart of South America, produces an estimated one-third of the coca leaf that is processed into cocaine paste and cocaine. Bolivia's coca leaf eradication program began to take off in December and January when farmers destroyed 3,127 acres of coca plants. Farmers destroyed fewer than 7,410 acres in 1989, far short of the 12,350 goal under an agreement with the U.S. government that promised aid in return for meeting the eradication quota. The United States was supposed to cut off $12 million in economic aid but has decided not to because of the eradication efforts of the past two months, the U.S. Embassy in La Paz said. At least 250,000 farmers depend on coca leaf cultivation and cocaine production for their livelihood, U.S. Embassy figures indicate. But tens of thousands of coca leaf farmers have been leaving the tropical jungles in interior Bolivia in recent weeks because the price of coca has plummeted below the cost of production. The drop in coca leaf prices is attributed to the Colombian drug crackdown and increased anti-drug activities in Bolivia's drug-producing jungles. Bolivian police and U.S. drug agents said Tuesday that two major cocaine processing labs had been destroyed and 8,800 pounds of cocaine paste confiscated the past several days. The labs, found the past four days, were hidden in tropical forests in the north, where most of the coca leaf is processed into cocaine paste and cocaine. They are the biggest labs and the largest quantity of cocaine paste ever found in the region, the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration said. ``We are now aiming at big-time traffickers and leaving farmers alone,'' said Don Ferrarone, the DEA station chief for Bolivia. He said the labs were in full operation and were capable of producing 1,100 to 13,000 pounds of cocaine base a day.

DOC.HEAD: World War II Victors Still Oversee Division of Germany
With AM-Germany-Superpowers
DOC.TEXT: The four Allied powers that defeated Nazi Germany in World War II have maintained their rights as victors, and 45 years later still have the final say on the reunification of the divided nation. The disclosure in Ottawa that the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France had agreed to a two-stage plan for reunification provides the international framework to close the long final chapter of the war. A peace treaty has never been signed between the four powers and Germany, even though all four ended their state of war with the country during the 1950s. Differences between the Western powers and the Soviet Union over Germany led to some of the tensest episodes of the post-war era, such as the Western airlift in 1948-49 that broke the Soviet attempt to isolate West Berlin. In 1961, East Germany built the Berlin Wall, which only began to be dismantled last year, around West Berlin to stop the flow of East Germans to the West. That exodus was threatening to deprive the Communist state of some of its most skilled workers. At the end of World War II, Britain, the Soviet Union and the United States agreed pending a peace settlement that some former German territories in the east would be taken over by Poland and the Soviet Union. Many Germans living there fled to the West. East and West Germany joined in the 35-nation Helsinki accords of 1975 that specified European borders could be changed only peacefully, and West Germany has signed separate treaties with the Soviet Union and Poland that addressed the border issues. But not all German political parties have renounced claims to the eastern territories, and any peace agreement would be expected to put the issue to rest. The zones occupied by the victors after the war became the modern states of East and West Germany _ the Germany Democratic Republic in the eastern, Soviet zone and the Federal Republic of Germany in the western zones. Over the years the four powers have forsaken most of their occupying rights in East and West Germany, but a number of anomalies remain, and the victors continue to oversee Berlin. Berlin, deep inside East Germany, is divided into four sectors, each controlled by one of the powers. The British, French and U.S. sectors make up West Berlin and the Soviet sector is East Berlin, which East Germany claims as its capital. Armed forces of the four powers retain and exercise their rights to patrol in the other sectors. The Western powers refuse to recognize East German authority in East Berlin and officially insist on resolving any disputes with Soviet officers. The four powers' military units also have rights to patrol in East and West Germany. The Western powers require East and West Germany to run ``troop trains'' to ferry any of their military between West Germany and Berlin. East Germany must allow access through three corridors across its territory to Berlin. The military forces of Britain, France and the United States remain concentrated in the zones once occupied by the victors, now allied with West Germany through the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The Western powers also have maintained exclusive rights to fly commercial planes into Berlin from the West, although West Germany has recently obtained some rights for joint flights. Reluctance of the Western powers to recognize the East German state created under the auspices of the Soviets was one of the obstacles to German membership in the United Nations. East and West Germany didn't join the United Nations until 1973. One of the last joint enterprises of the four powers was imprisoning Rudolf Hess, a deputy to Hitler, whom they took turns guarding in Spandau prison in Berlin until he died in 1987 at age 93.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Members Urge Separating Warring Parties
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council's five permanent members said Cambodia's warring factions must withdraw to separate areas as a prelude to peace, but talks ended Tuesday without agreement on disarming the groups. Representatives of the United States, the Soviet Union, France, China and Britain focused their discussions on proposals to get all parties in the civil war to lay down their arms and sought to define the shape of an interim government to rule until elections. However, diplomats said the three days of talks stalled over proposals to dismantle the Communist government of Premier Hun Sen and its army, which are supported by Vietnam. U.N. diplomatic sources speaking on condition of anonymity said the Soviet Union, allied with Vietnam, opposed moves led by China to urge disarming the Cambodian military and three guerrilla factions. Beijing supports the Khmer Rouge and Washington provides backing for the two non-Communist factions. The Security Council members issued a statement saying ``the regrouping and cantonment of the armed forces of the factions into designated areas'' is essential to the peace process. It did not elaborate. The statement also said the Council members discussed possible U.N. administration of Cambodia and how to structure the interim government. ``They look forward to making further progress on this key issue in subsequent discussions,'' the statement said. The five countries agreed to resume consultations in Paris during the first half of March following a conference on Cambodia set for Feb. 26-28 in Indonesia. The full 15-member Security Council would have to approve a major U.N. role in Cambodia peace efforts. The Khmer Rouge ruled Cambodia from April 1975 to late 1978, when Vietnam invaded to oust it. During the Khmer Rouge's reign, nearly 1 million Cambodians died of starvation and disease or were executed. Vietnam says the last of its troops left Cambodia last year.

DOC.HEAD: Humorists Say Comedy Trends Changing
DOC.TEXT: More young Americans today love humor if it is gruesome, targets women or is low-key, according to a psychologist who studied what made college students laugh. James Carroll, a psychology professor at Central Michigan University, said Tuesday that students 25 years ago disapproved of the gruesome humor that is now widely accepted. ``Gary Larson's cartoon `The Far Side,' which occasionally portrays animals eating humans, is an example of gruesome humor, so are Helen Keller jokes and dead baby jokes,'' Carroll said. ``College students 25 years ago did not endorse that kind of humor, but it seems more acceptable today.'' Mel Helitzer, a journalism professor who teaches a course in humor at Ohio University in Athens, Ohio, said societal attitudes have changed more than have individual tastes. ``It's more of a public acceptance,'' Helitzer said. ``Humor is criticism and we tend to make jokes about things that bother us, like Dan Quayle.'' Carroll administered the Institute for Personality and Ability Testing Humor Test of Personality to 79 college students in fall 1988. The original test was administered in 1963 to 200 students by Raymond Cattell at the University of Illinois. Results of Carroll's study were published in the December 1989 issue of Psychological Reports. The test asks subjects to respond to 150 jokes and cartoons as either funny or dull. He correlated the results with 12 dimensions of humor and compared the findings to the 1963 results of the same test. ``What we once called blue humor or hard core is being accepted today,'' said Helitzer, who had not reviewed the study. Carroll said his study found college students of both sexes have changed in their appreciation of humor. For instance, the 1963 study indicated that 40 percent to 45 percent of all students appreciated humor directed at women. That figure rose to about 70 percent of all students in the 1988 study. ``It may be that the society is more open,'' Carroll said. His study also found that women are finding jokes about themselves funny, and people like low-key, controlled humor like that of comedians David Letterman and Arsenio Hall.

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Got $52.5 million for Quake Relief, Spending Half
DOC.TEXT: The American Red Cross received $52.5 million in donations designated for earthquake relief after the Oct. 17 quake, but the group only plans to spend half that amount on the disaster, a spokeswoman said. Mayor Art Agnos has criticized the disaster relielf organization for failing to disclose donation and spending information, as well as its spending plans. So far, the Red Cross has spent $12.1 million, according to spokeswoman Barbara Lohman, who said the total emergency spending will reach between $13 million and $16 million. An additional $10 million was allocated in December for ``extraordinary''' needs, she said, after elected officials and community leaders appealed to the Red Cross for additional aid. An Agnos spokesman said the figures disclosed Monday confirm the mayor's position. ``This seems to confirm what we've been saying, and even more,'' said spokesman Scott Shafer. ``That $52.5 million figure is just for those who designated earthquake relief. A lot of people probably just donated without specifying where it was to go so even that figure is probably conservative.'' Lohman defended the spending plans. ``We don't give service based on how much money has been raised,'' she said. ``We give service based on needs.'' Donors who earmark their checks for quake relief have no guarantee that the money will be spent that way, she confirmed. A committee charged with allocating the special $10 million fund has set a deadline for Friday for accepting spending proposals from cities, counties and private groups, Lohman said. The group will begin making decisions next month, she said, adding that more money may be allocated if the needs are there. The northern California quake on Oct. 17 measured 7.1 on the Richter scale, killing 67 people, injuring about 3,000 and causing an estimated $7 billion in damage.

DOC.HEAD: World War II Victors Still Oversee Division of Germany
DOC.TEXT: The four nations that defeated Nazi Germany in World War II have maintained their rights as victors and legally have the final say 45 years later on the reunification of the divided nation. The disclosure in Ottawa that the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France had agreed to a two-stage plan aimed at reunifying Germany provides the international framework to close the final chapter of the war. The four principal victors _ the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union _ all ended their state of war with Germany country during the 1950s. The three western powers made agreements with West Germany, the Soviet Union with East Germany. Further agreements followed in the 1970s. No peace treaty was ever signed, and it is not clear there will be a formal treaty like the Versailles Treaty that ended World War I. Germany was never supposed to be divided, and the allies agreed to administer the country as a unit. But to avoid confusion, zones of occupation were established for the country, and separately for the capital, Berlin, even before the allied armies entered the country from East and West. Despite pressure from British Prime Minister Winston Churchill to hold what he had, the western commander, Gen. Dwight Eisenhower, insisted on adhering to the occupation zones, even pulling back U.S. troops that had driven much further to the East in many places. Differences arose almost before the shooting stopped. The Soviet Union dismantled whole factories in its occupation zone, carting them home over the objections of the western allies. The introduction of a new currency in the western zones over Soviet objections in 1948 led the Soviets to stop all rail, road and water access to Berlin, which lay 110 miles inside their occupation zone. An airlift by the western powers that flew coal and food into Berlin 'round the clock eventually led to the lifting of the blockade, one of the most tense episodes of the Cold War. In 1961 East Germany built the Berlin Wall, that only began to be removed last year, around West Berlin to stop the flow of East Germans to West Berlin which was threatening to deprive the communist state of some of its best-trained people. At the Potsdam Conference in July 1945, Britain, the Soviet Union and the United States agreed that pending a peace settlement, some former German territories in the east would be taken over by Poland and the Soviet Union. Many Germans living there fled to the West. East and West Germany joined in the 35-nation Helsinki accords of 1975 that specified European borders could be changed only peacefully, and West Germany has signed separate treaties with the Soviet Union and Poland that addressed the border issues. But not all German political parties have renounced claims to the eastern territories, and any peace agreement would be expected to put the issue to rest. The zones occupied by the powers after the war became the modern states of East and West Germany _ the Germany Democratic Republic in the eastern, Soviet zone and the Federal Republic of Germany in the three western zones. Over the years the four powers have forsaken most of their occupying rights in East and West Germany, but a number of anomalies remain, and the victors continue to be the legal overseers of Berlin. The city is divided into four sectors, each controlled by one of the powers. The British, French and U.S. sectors make up West Berlin and the Soviet sector is East Berlin, which East Germany claims as its capital. Armed forces of the four powers retain and exercise their rights to patrol in the other sectors. The Western powers refuse to recognize East German authority in East Berlin and officially insist on resolving any disputes with Soviet officers. The four powers military units also have rights to patrol in East and West Germany. The Western powers require East and West Germany to run ``troop trains'' to ferry their military units between West Germany and Berlin. East Germany must allow access through three corridors across its territory to Berlin. The military forces of Britain, France and the United States remain concentrated in the zones once occupied by the victors, now allied with West Germany through the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The Western powers also have maintained exclusive rights to fly commercial planes into Berlin from the West, although West Germany has recently obtained some rights for joint flights. Reluctance of the powers to recognize the state created under the auspices of the other side was one of the obstacles to German membership in the United Nations. East and West Germany didn't join until 1973. One of the last joint enterprises of the four powers was imprisoning Rudolf Hess, a deputy to Hitler until his mysterious flight to Britain in 1941. They took turns guarding Hess in Spandau prison in Berlin until he died in 1987 at 93.

DOC.HEAD: Drexel Woes Lend Undercurrent of Fear to NYSE Trading Floor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Frederic is cq in 2nd graf
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Drexel
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert's announcement that it was seeking bankruptcy court protection deepened the gloom for many stock market traders, whose jobs already are at risk amid an industrywide business recession. ``The atmosphere of the market is as bad as I've ever seen it,'' said Frederic J. Bostrom, who has spent 22 years as a New York Stock Exchange floor trader, the last five with Minneapolis-based brokerage Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc. Drexel brokers and clerks milled about on the exchange floor Tuesday, openly looking for job prospects. Skittishness and gallows humor prevailed among nearly all the traders as they elbowed past each other or stepped outside for cigarettes. ``Did you hear _ Drexel's paying debts with Monopoly money,'' a passing trader said to Bostrom. In a telephone interview after the close of trading, Bostrom said he had received calls from large institutional clients of Drexel, asking him if he knew of any openings for brokers. There were none. ``If one out of 10 that are unemployed by Drexel Burnham find a job, that's good given the state of the business these days,'' he said. One floor specialist, who asked not to be identified, played down the effects of Drexel's problems on the mood of the exchange, noting that the Dow Jones Industrial Average closed up nearly 5 points after initially falling when Drexel said it would default on $100 million in loans. But others said the market's performance was no indicator of the depth of personal fears on the trading floor. ``This stuff is very, very worrisome, as it bears on the whole stock market community and the feeling that you ain't seen it all yet,'' said Robert Seijas, a specialist with the firm Lasker, Stone & Stern. ``It's generally an atmosphere of malaise, of uncertainty and depression.'' The securities industry's business has slowed since the October 1987 stock market crash, resulting in thousands of layoffs as firms attempt to cut costs. ``You've got an already depressed industry with people losing their jobs, and then you superimpose this on top of it,'' said an independent trader. ``There isn't a positive sign here right now.'' Further deepening the gloom were fears that Drexel's troubles would create a ripple effect among companies with business or pending deals with Drexel. Those fears were fueled early in the day when exchange officials temporarily stopped the execution of trades by Pforzheimer & Co., a company that uses Drexel's back office to complete its trades. Later, satisfied that no Drexel capital was involved, execution of Pforzheimer trades was allowed to continue. But a message had been sent that Drexel's troubles might also be woes for the rest of Wall Street. ``It's everybody's problem in the market because everybody has done business with Drexel and is still doing so,'' Bostrom said. ``I do know it's got this place in a very negative mood ... and the market at this juncture doesn't need much of anything to have the stilts knocked out from under it.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Makes Triumphant Return Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT 3 grafs after 12th graf, ``The government ...'' UPDATING with de Klerk comment. Picks up 13th graf, `Mandela, speaking ...' EDITING 32nd graf, `The ANC ... ' to CONFORM
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos JOH8,10,11,12
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela came home a hero Tuesday, welcomed after nearly three decades by an ecstatic throng of blacks who delighted in his freedom but also heard him mourn the oppression of apartheid. More than 120,000 people crammed into the country's largest stadium to greet the man revered by most South African blacks as their leader. Many were getting their first glimpse of him. ``The march toward freedom and justice is irreversible,'' Mandela told the roaring crowd in the township that has become one of the bleakest symbols of apartheid. At what the independent South African Press Association called the largest political rally ever in southern Africa, Mandela exhorted blacks to end their factional disputes, take control of a crisis-ridden school system, and work with discipline to end white-minority rule. Whites, he said, must be reassured that ``a South Africa without apartheid will be a better place for all.'' Some spectators came six hours early to get seats, and the 80,000-seat stadium was overflowing by the time Mandela arrived. Youths perched precariously on wall tops, others scaled 120-foot-high light towers, and more than 30 people were injured as crowds shoved and pushed to get a view of the podium. An explosion of joy shook the stadium when Mandela, 71, emerged from an underground walkway, saluting with a raised fist. ``Mandela! Mandela!'' the crowd roared as he slowly walked around the field, flanked by top leaders of his African National Congress and other anti-apartheid groups. People thrust fists into the air and danced as Mandela passed them. ``Today, my return to Soweto fills my heart with joy,'' Mandela said. ``At the same time, I have returned with a deep sense of sadness that you are still suffering under an unjust system.'' In Cape Town, the government issued its first formal response to Mandela's statements since his release Sunday after more than 27 years in prison. Constitutional Development Minister Gerrit Viljoen said the government agreed with Mandela that apartheid must be eliminated and voting rights extended to blacks. But he criticized Mandela's support for continued guerrilla violence and economic sanctions. ``The government is not prepared to accede to the handing over of power,'' Viljoen said. ``If that is the goal of the armed struggle, then there is no meaningful way ahead.'' President F.W. de Klerk, who ordered Mandela's unconditional release, replied when ABC newsman Ted Koppel asked him in an interview Tuesday why after 27 years he decided now was the time to free Mandela: ``In South Africa, life sentences usually come to an end at 25 years. But there is also the political side. First the officials, ministers of the state and finally my predecessor started to talk to Mr. Mandela. And the commitment to peace came through. Also in the two discussions that I have had with him the commitment to peaceful solutions came through.'' The interview was broadcast in part on ``ABC News.'' Mandela, speaking from a podium on the playing field, said the thought of returning to Soweto helped him endure his years in prison, serving a life term for starting the ANC's guerrilla war. ``God bless Africa,'' the crowd sang in rolling cadences after Mandela ended his speech, raised his fist again and joined in the anthem of the anti-apartheid movement. Two helicopters then descended onto the field and took him, his family and top aides to a smaller stadium in Soweto. From there he drove in a motorcade _ escorted by Soweto police with ANC flags on their motorcyles _ to the modest, four-roomed brick house he lived in before his arrest. Mandela waved to about 2,000 people waiting outside, then walked into his home. In his nearly 30-minute speech, Mandela deplored the poverty and suffering endured by many in Soweto, a sprawling township of 2.5 million people that has been a home base for the anti-apartheid movement. ``Our people need proper housing, not ghettos like Soweto,'' he said. ``Our people need a living wage.'' Dressed in a gray suit and wearing reading glasses, he echoed the major themes he has addressed since his release. He said the ANC would ``continue the armed struggle as long as the violence of apartheid continues.'' He also condemned black-against-black violence, saying it had weakened the fight against apartheid. ``We must take bold steps ... to end the mindless violence'' in Natal Province, he said. More than 50 blacks have been killed in fighting there this week, and more than 2,500 since 1986. He also addressed the white-run security forces, which he said many blacks view as instruments of repression. ``I call on the police to abandon apartheid,'' he said. ``Join in the march to new South Africa, where you also have a place.'' In remarks aimed at quelling white fears, he said: ``I and the ANC are as opposed to black domination as we are to white domination. I must accept that our statements ... are not enough to allay the fears of the white population.'' ``A new South Africa has to eliminate hatred and suspicion caused by apartheid, and (substitute) it with peace.'' ``Go back to your schools, churches, mines and communities and build on the massive energy of recent events in our country,'' Mandela said. Soweto schools were virtually deserted because pupils were taking part in the celebrations. Tens of thousands of adults stayed away from work. ``I am so happy,'' said spectator Tebello Pooe in broken English. ``I am proud because how long have we been waiting for Nelson Mandela. We are near to get what we are hoping for _ freedom.'' Huge columns of people blocked every street leading to the stadium even after the facility was full. Overloaded buses with youths perched on their roofs inched along the streets. The crowd was orderly, heeding a call from Mandela to behave with dignity. Also Tuesday the white, right-wing Conservative Party filed treason charges with police against Mandela and fellow black leaders Walter Sisulu and Zeph Mothopeng. The pro-apartheid party claimed Mandela's remarks since Sunday were a call to overthrow the government. Citizens can file private charges that police investigate to determine if any action should be taken. It is unlikely the governing National Party would allow any official action. The ANC seeks a one-person, one-vote system, which would be dominated by South Africa's 28 million blacks. De Klerk seeks to negotiate a new constitution that would establish some political rights for blacks, but provide the 5 million whites with some sort of veto over major decisions. On Feb. 2, de Klerk lifted a 30-year ban on the ANC and other opposition groups, suspended executions and announced other reforms aimed at clearing the way for black-white negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Germans Get News of Accord on Reunification
With AM-Germany-Superpowers
DOC.TEXT: West Germany's ARD television network went live on Tuesday to its correspondent in Ottawa, who gave the news of the accord there on German reunification shortly after 11 p.m. ARD said in its account that the way seemed clear for most of the points, but that the foreign ministers had ``set to one side'' temporarily the tricky question of the military posture of a united Germany. In East Berlin, the official news agency ADN distributed the news at 10:43 p.m. ``The discussions will also include the questions of security of neighboring states,'' said the brief report. According to a statement obtained by The Associated Press in Ottawa, the United States, Britain and France on Tuesday worked out an agreement with the Soviet Union and both Germanys on a two-stage formula to reunite the two Germanys after 45 years of division. In the first stage, East Germany and West Germany would meet on legal, economic and political issues, according to the statement. The talks would begin soon after East Germany holds its March 18 national elections. In the second stage, the foreign ministers of the two Germanys would meet with the foreign ministers of the United States, France, Britain and the Soviet Union ``to discuss external aspects of the establishment of German unity, including the issues of security of the neighboring states.''

DOC.HEAD: Text of Statement on German Unity
With AM-Germany-Superpowers
DOC.TEXT: Following is the full text of a statement on German reunification released Tuesday by foreign ministers of the four World War II allies and both Germanys: ``The foreign ministers of the Federal Republic of Germany, the German Democratic Republic, France, the United Kingdom, the Soviet Union and the United States had talks in Ottawa. They agreed that the foreign ministers of the Federal Republic of Germany and the German Democratic Republic would meet with the foreign minsters of France, the United Kingdom, the Soviet Union and the United States to discuss external aspects of the establishment of German unity, including the issues of security of the neighboring states. Preliminary discussions at the official level will begin shortly.''

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Valdez Mate Called Skipper to Warn of Trouble
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 19 grafs to UPDATE with more Cousins testimony, call to Hazelwood; picks up 9th graf, `Cousins described...'.
DOC.TEXT: Seconds before the Exxon Valdez went aground, the third mate in control of the tanker testified Tuesday that he called skipper Joseph Hazelwood to tell him the tanker was ``getting into serious trouble.'' The message was interrupted by a crash, Gregory Cousins testified at Hazelwood's trial. Cousins and a helmsman, Robert Kagan, were at the wheel when the 987-foot tanker ran aground on Bligh Reef, spilling more than 10 million gallons of North Slope crude in the nation's worst oil spill. Cousins said he had begun to realize that Kagan was not properly following his orders to make hard turns in the ship's course. ``I could tell we hadn't turned,'' he said. And after giving another order to Kagan to turn harder, Counsins said he phoned the captain. ``I told him that we were getting into serious trouble,'' he recalled. ``He asked, `Where's the rudder?...' That was when we suffered the first shock and we were hard aground.'' Asked what further was said during the conversation, Cousins said, ``There was nothing else to say. There was a mutual hangup of the telephones.'' Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is charged with one felony count of second-degree criminal mischief and misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil and operating a vessel while intoxicated. The maximum penalty for conviction on all counts is seven years, three months in prison and $61,000 in fines. Cousins testified Tuesday that after the ship ran aground, the tanker was still moving. ``The vessel was swinging rapidly to the right ... I knew we were hard aground. My fear was that we were sliding down the reef. The aft end of the vessel was sliding into the rocks and we had people down in the engine room,'' said Cousins. He said he gave an urgent order to Kagan to turn hard left. ``I think Mr. Kagan didn't really understand the command,'' he said. ``He hesitated and I spun the wheel.'' He said he had never worked with Kagan before and had heard rumors the seaman had problems with steering on another voyage. He said Hazelwood had left the bridge only about 10 minutes before the accident, leaving specific orders for rerouting the ship. ``He asked if I felt comfortable with what we were going to do and I said, `Yes,''' Cousins testified. ``He said, `Do you feel comfortable enough that I can go below and get rid of some paperwork?' I said I felt very comfortable.'' Cousins said Hazelwood told him would be gone ``just a few minutes'' and to call him in his cabin when the ship started to make a turn. Cousins, who was described Monday as being frantic in the moments before the ship ran aground, told of fairly smooth sailing until the hour before disaster struck. In a slow, painstaking delivery, the third mate explained to jurors how tankers operate, how radar works and the difference between magnetic and true north. He told of many conversations with Hazelwood about the course the Exxon Valdez would follow into Prince William Sound. The prosecution is seeking to show that Hazelwood abdicated his responsibility for command of the ship when he went below and left Cousins in charge. Cousins described the night of the accident as extremely dark and misty. He said that about an hour before the grounding he spotted ice on the ship's radar screen. It was too dark to actually see the ice from the deck, Cousins said, but he reported it to Hazelwood, who decided to divert the tanker from normal shipping lanes to avoid the ice. At the point where the evasive maneuver was beginning, Cousins said the shift changed and a new helmsman, Kagan, arrived. At some point, he said, the tanker was placed on automatic pilot but he did not know when or for how long. Hazelwood contends that he left clear orders with Cousins for the ship's direction and that if his orders had been obeyed the disaster never would have occurred. Cousins testified that he has been on the crew of various ships for as many as 26 trips through the Valdez Narrows into Prince William Sound. But prosecutors have stressed that he did not have a special license to pilot a ship in that area. Kagan testified Monday that Cousins panicked and grabbed the wheel in a futile attempt to avert the jagged reef. ``I started making the turn and he grabbed the wheel and helped make it,'' Kagan said. ``I think he was kind of panicking then. ... He was kind of excited.''

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Asks Closed Deposition
EEds: INSERTS grafs 11-12: ``Arguing for,'' with Poindexter view
DOC.TEXT: Ronald Reagan's lawyers asked a judge Tuesday to bar reporters and the public from the courtroom when the former president gives videotaped testimony Friday in the Iran-Contra case of his former national security adviser, John Poindexter. Iran-Contra prosecutors and the Justice Department joined Reagan's lawyers in saying that news organizations have no constitutional right to attend the pre-trial deposition. ``Even if there were a constitutional interest in the press' attendance at the deposition ... that interest is outweighed by the significant risk of disclosure of confidential information,'' Reagan's lawyers said in a filing in U.S. District Court. The Justice Department said in a court brief that a closed deposition was the only way to prevent inadvertent disclosure of sensitive information. ``There is no other means to prevent the disclosure of national security matters unless they are edited out before the videotaped deposition is made public,'' the department said. Reagan's lawyers urged that the videotape and any transcripts of it be sealed until the videotape is played back to the jury at Poindexter's trial. Iran-Contra prosecutors, however, said the court should consider the news organizations' alternate request for access to the edited videotape and censored transcripts of the deposition after it is completed. The prosecutors said the protection of sensitive national security information is a compelling governmental interest ``sufficient to justify precluding the media from attending this proceeding.'' Twelve news organizations have asked U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene, who is presiding in the Poindexter case, for admission to Reagan's deposition at the federal courthouse in Los Angeles. If necessary, the news organizations said, Greene could order closing of the deposition during lines of questioning that may elicit sensitive information. Arguing for an open deposition, Poindexter's lawyers said Reagan's testimony presents no special problems of classified information that distinguish it from the testimony of several other key witnesses in the case. In the unlikely event that classified information does seep out inadvertently, the court might be able to strike the information from the public record and preclude publication of that information, they argued. The proposal by the 12 organizations ``defies common sense,'' said Reagan's lawyers. ``There is no possible way to predict which questions posed to the former President would elicit confidential or national security information.'' They said such an approach would lead to ``disruptive'' restrictions on the sequence of questions or ``significant interruptions'' occasioned by repeated press entry and exit to the deposition. Reagan's testimony is to be edited and played back at the trial of Poindexter, who last week was given permission by Greene to ask Reagan 154 questions plus follow-ups. Iran-Contra prosecutors will cross-examine Reagan at the same session. The former president agreed last Friday to submit to the questioning, while reserving the option of invoking executive privilege on specific questions. The Justice Department will send representatives to the testimony so that the Bush administration may block responses that may impinge on national security. Executive privilege is the doctrine that certain deliberations of a president and his advisers in fulfilling their constitutional duties may be kept secret. The Supreme Court has ruled that the need for evidence in a criminal trial may in certain circumstances require breaching that secrecy. The former national security adviser faces trial March 5 on charges of conspiracy, obstruction and making false statements in the Iran-Contra scandal. The news organizations applying to have Reagan's testimony given in public are Cable News Network Inc., Capital Cities-ABC Inc., CBS Inc., National Broadcasting Co. Inc., The New York Times Co., The Times Mirror Co. of Los Angeles, The Washington Post, The Associated Press, Dow Jones & Co. Inc., National Public Radio, USA Today and Gannett News Services Inc.

DOC.HEAD: NATO, Warsaw Pact Reach Tentative Pact On Surveillance Overflights
DOC.TEXT: NATO and Warsaw Pact negotiators agreed Tuesday on the basic elements of a plan to open their skies to surveillance overflights. After two days of talks, the 23 members of both military blocs took a break from high-powered meetings on German unification and European troop-cut treaties to issue a statement accepting the basic principles of ``Open Skies.'' The plan, first proposed in the 1950s and resurrected by President Bush last May, calls for members of both alliances to let surveillance aircraft fly over their territory. The aim is to enhance trust and openness, in addition to monitoring compliance with disarmament treaties. The communique made no mention of a Warsaw Pact proposal to share planes, surveillance equipment and information, the most controversial element still to be worked out in the plan. The Soviet Union and United States had accepted the broad outline of the plan before the Ottawa meeting. ``The `Open Skies' regime is neither an arms control nor a verification measure per se,'' the communique said. ``Its successful implementation would encourage reciprocal openness on the part of participating states. It would strengthen confidence among them, reduce the risk of conflict, and enhance the predictability of military activities.'' The negotiators agreed to four points: _The North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact will implement the plan ``on a reciprocal and equitable basis,'' and the ``Open Skies regime ... will ensure the maximum possible openness and minimum restrictions for observation flights.'' _Each country will have an annual quota of flights, the quotas to be decided at future negotiations. The original plan called for larger countries to allow several flights a month over their territory and smaller countries to have at least one every three months. Both alliances were to have roughly the same number of flights. _Countries will use unarmed aircraft and certain types of surveillance equipment to be decided during negotiations. _Other countries, notably the non-aligned nations of Europe, will be encouraged eventually to participate in ``Open Skies.'' All NATO and Warsaw Pact foreign ministers will meet in Budapest, Hungary, on May 12 to sign a final agreement, said Foreign Minister Gyula Horn of Hungary. Lower-level officials will continue meeting for two weeks in Ottawa to work out the remaining issues. Although NATO had rejected the Soviet idea of shared aircraft and information, both sides have expressed willingness to compromise. Foreign ministers from most of the 16 NATO and seven Warsaw Pact contries have praised the ``Open Skies'' plan and said any remaining disputes are not likely to block a final agreeement. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III opened the conference Monday by calling the plan ``potentially the most ambitious measure to build confidence that we have ever taken.'' West Germany's foreign minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, said Tuesday he was convinced ``this openness and cooperation will increasingly become the natural form of relationship in Europe and North America.'' Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze on Monday proposed expanding the surveillance concept to sea and space, but U.S. officials quickly rejected the idea and it appeared to go no further. The ``Open Skies'' plan is not linked formally to any other treaty negotiations. But officials hoped early agreement could ease verification questions in the Vienna talks on cutting conventional forces. Most smaller countries welcome the ``Open Skies'' plan because they lack the satellite technology to conduct surveillance on their own. East bloc countries, all of whose hard-line Communist leaders have lost power in the past year, face critical economic conditions and some expressed reluctance to take on the expense of overflights. Czechoslovak Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier said Monday that, ``At a time when we are embarking on the very complicated period of transition to a market-based economy, we could only with difficulty assume excessive financial commitments.''

DOC.HEAD: French Mineral Water Pulled from Shelves for Contamination Check
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with testing under way in Australia, SUB 3rd graf pvs with 2 grafs; pickup 4th pvs, `The water...'
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese subsidiary of the French bottler of Perrier mineral water said Tuesday it will withdraw its product from stores after the discovery of a tiny amount of contamination in Perrier water in the United States. Mika Iiyoshi, an official of Perrier Japon K.K., said the company will voluntarily withdraw about 10,000 cases from store shelves immediately until the Japanese Health and Welfare Ministry confirms the mineral water's safety. The Australian importers of Perrier said in Sydney Wednesday that the government and independent laboratories were testing random samples on supplies of Perrier. A spokesman for Coca-Cola Amatil said no contamination had been discovered so far, and Perrier had not been withdrawn from sale in Australia. Ms. Iiyoshi said the French government inspected the source of the mineral water, a spring in Vergeze, southern France, after the U.S. Food and Drug Administration discovered benzene in some bottles in North Carolina. The water since has been taken out of stores, restaurants and bars in the United States and Canada. Perrier said it believes an employee mistakenly used a product containing benzene, a cancer-causing chemical, to clean grease from one bottling line. A spokesman for the French Health Ministry said there was no contamination at the spring from which the sparkling water flows. Although the benzene levels were relatively low _ about two to four times the five parts per billion level allowed under FDA standards _ Perrier said it requested the recall Friday to protect consumer confidence. Ms. Iiyoshi said it will take several days for the Japanese Health and Welfare Ministry's investigation. An official of the ministry, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the agency is collecting information from the United States while checking whether the mineral water in the Japanese market is contaminated. Ms. Iiyoshi said Perrier Japon markets 150,000 cases of Perrier water a year.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Says Rebels Trying to Block Election Process
DOC.TEXT: President Daniel Ortega said Tuesday that about 2,000 Contras have infiltrated Nicaragua in an attempt to sabotage the campaign leading up to national elections Feb. 25. Ortega said the Contras plan to ``contest electoral results, since two North American opinion polls clearly indicate a Sandinista victory.'' Two surveys conducted in January by the U.S.-based pollsters Greenberg Lake and Bendixen Schroth gave Ortega's Sandinista Front a strong lead over his major rival, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of the United National Opposition, known as UNO. Ortega said he met with Roman Catholic Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo to discuss his claims that 2,000 Contras plan to ``block the electoral process with attacks, ambushes, etc., and create a climate of terror in the war zones so that people won't vote.'' The allegations could not be corroborated by non-government sources. ``I expressed to the cardinal my worry about the verbal and other kinds of violence ... of recent days,'' Ortega said. Obando y Bravo said he told Ortega, ``We believe that the country can only move ahead through authentic reconciliation.'' ``Hopefully the people of Nicaragua will be able to express themselves on Feb. 25 without fear,'' he said. The church has conducted orientation sessions on the electoral process. Ortega called on ``those who have plans to subvert the electoral process to renounce their plans and accept this battle on civic grounds.'' In the poll by Greenberg Lake, 51 percent of those surveyed supported Ortega, 24 Mrs. Chamorro and the rest were undecided or backing minor candidates. Interviewers questioned 901 people around the country for the poll, commissioned by Hemisphere Inititatives, a Boston-based group that has been invited to observe the elections. The Bendixen Schroth poll, commissioned by the Spanish-language network Univision in the United States, gave Ortega 53 percent of the vote, Mrs. Chamorro 35 percent and said the rest either were undecided or supported minor candidates. Neither of the pollsters disclosed the method of interviewing or the margin of error in the surveys. The Contras began fighting the government with U.S. backing in 1981, claiming the Sandinistas had betrayed the goals of the 1979 revolution that toppled the family dynasty of Anastasio Somoza. Many Contras have given up the struggle and returned to civilian life in Nicaragua, but others remain hostile to the Sandinistas. Some Contras still live in camps along the Honduran border. The United States has stopped arming them but Congress is expected to discuss continuing non-lethal aid, which runs out at the end of the month. The Bush administration has indicated it wants the Contra force to remain in existence until after the elections as pressure for free and fair balloting.

DOC.HEAD: Researcher Links Fat To Body Rhythms, Sees Weight Loss Without A Diet
DOC.TEXT: A new study linking natural body rhythms to fat and cholesterol has raised the possibility that patients could lose weight without special exercise or diet, researchers said Tuesday. ``All you need to do is take a pill, but you have to do it at the right time of day for the individual,'' said Albert Meier, professor of zoology at Louisiana State University, who initiated the research. The results of the study were announced by LSU, which has patented the procedure and licensed it to a Boston diabetes clinic for further clinical tests and application for U.S. Food and Drug Administration approval. The procedure, in which small amounts of the drug bromocryptine were given at specific times, was tested on 70 patients by Baton Rouge physician C. William Lovell, and the results are being prepared for scientific publication, the university said. The first 33 patients in the study lost 25 percent or more of their fat within six weeks, although they were allowed to eat anything and did no special exercise. Meier said people don't get fat because they eat too much or are lazy, but because their body produces fat in a rhythmic kind of biology similar to that experienced by animals during migration or hibernation. He said the discovery grew out of 25 years of research that started with white-throated sparrows, which build up body fat before their long migrations without eating any extra food or cutting down their activity. Meier, who has published extensive research on birds and fish, said he expanded his focus to include mammals when he saw the possibilities for humans. Other researchers in obesity called the concept interesting and said it would be the first bridge between human weight loss and studies of fat in hibernation and migration. ``I hope he's right,'' said Elliot Danforth Jr., director of the clinical research center at the University of Vermont. ``We need a breakthrough in this area.'' However, he said he could not assess the study without seeing how the researchers monitored what people ate _ or didn't eat, since the nausea from bromocryptine could possibly reduce appetite. And he said it would be tricky finding the exact time of day in which the pill would work. ``The proof will be in the clinical effect,'' said Dr. George Bray, an authority on obesity who directs the Pennington Biomedical Research Center in Baton Rouge. But applying the medication in rhythmic doses ``may be enough to make it work,'' Bray said. Meier said the bromocryptine works by inhibiting secretion of the hormone prolactin. Prolactin is linked to the body's use of insulin, which scientists have known for years has caused fat production, he said. ``Prolactin's major function is to maintain receptors in the liver that respond to insulin. The higher the level of prolactin at a specific time of day, the more abundant the receptors and consequently the greater the fat production by the liver,'' he said. ``Inhibiting prolactin cuts down on the number of receptors and thus the amount of fat produced.'' Bromocryptine is already FDA-approved and in weight loss is used in tiny doses, as small as one-hundredth of the normal dosage. Meier said actual weight loss per person averaged about 5 percent. ``Only fat was removed _ no water, proteins or carbohydrates,'' he said. Lovell said he took the drug and lost 11 pounds in six weeks. The only side effect was some nausea, he said. Meier and LSU adjunct professor Anthony Cincotta, now associated with Wellman Laboratory, part of Massachusetts General Hospital and Harvard Medical School in Boston, reported the results of their study with animals in December in the journal Life Sciences. In the article, they said that within 10 to 15 days, body fat was reduced 15 to 50 percent and cholesterol 15 to 40 percent in several animal models, including pigs. LSU has signed an agreement with ERGO Inc., a biotechnology company in Newport, R.I., to market the research.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Prime Minister Says Political Reforms Will Continue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Ryzhkov becoming ill, postponing signing of agreements; EDITS to CONFORM. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov came down with a fever and cold Wednesday and postponed the signing of several bilateral fishing and trade agreements, a spokesman said. The Soviet spokesman said the signings would be held Thursday. Ryzhkov, the highest-ranking Kremlin official ever to visit Australia, is on the second day of a three-day trip as part of a Pacific tour aimed at forging closer economic ties. He arrived Tuesday in Melbourne from Bangkok, Thailand, and was greeted by Prime Minister Bob Hawke and Foreign Minister Gareth Evans. He flew to Canberra on Wednesday morning. Ryzhkov, the main architect of Soviet economic reform, is scheduled to sign agreements on matters including port access for Soviet fishing trawlers and consular guarantees and commodities deals. He spent Tuesday inspecting the distribution center for the Australian-owned Safeway supermarket chain and later officially opened a Center for Soviet and East European Studies at the University of Melbourne. Vadim P. Perfiliev, deputy chief of the Soviet Foreign Ministry Information Department, said the computerized distribution and management at the 47-acre supermarket complex could be useful in the Soviet Union. Shortages of food and inefficient distribution are two of the Soviet government's most pressing problems. At a dinner given by Premier John Cain of Victoria state, Ryzhkov said the Communist Party's historic decision to give up its monopoly on power is only one of many political reforms and economic changes to come in his nation. ``Despite the difficulties, we are determined to continue along the road we have mapped out,'' he said. He said reforms now under way were the most radical ever carried out to ``democratize the whole of our society and develop a new federalism in my country.'' Ryzhkov also said the Soviets want ``to find a radical solution to the disarmament problem, to remove the threat of a nuclear war and resolve grave regional conflicts.'' Ryzhkov and his party are to visit Sydney, Australia's largest city and a major Pacific financial center, on Thursday and travel to Singapore, his last stop, on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: United States and Soviet Union Agree on European Troop Ceilings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 18th graf: ``In Washington,'' with White House statement
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union agreed Tuesday on a sharp reduction in troop deployments in Central Europe to 195,000 for each superpower, Canadian External Affairs Minister Joseph Clark announced. The United States could keep up to 30,000 troops elsewhere in Europe under the agreement, Clark said. The accord worked out during an ``open skies'' conference represents Soviet acceptance of the initiative President Bush unveiled in his State of the Union address Jan. 31. Clark made the announcement in a conference hall with Secretary of State James A. Baker III, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and other foreign ministers looking on. Baker and Shevardnadze did not speak. The United States now has about 305,000 troops in Europe, of which about 275,000 are on the central front _ mostly West Germany _ and 30,000, generally in Navy and Air Force units, in Greece, Turkey, Italy, Spain and Britain. The Soviet Union has about 565,000 in East Germany, Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia _ four nations that have shed their hardline communist governments. Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia are negotiating troop reductions with the Soviet Union. Announcing the settlement, Clark said, ``It overcomes one of the most difficult obstacles'' to a treaty NATO and the Warsaw Pact have been negotiating since the 1970s in Vienna on limits to conventional forces in Europe. Other key limits in the projected treaty would cover tanks and other non-nuclear weapons. However, only Monday, Baker stressed in a speech to the conference that the United States and the Soviet Union were in disagreement on limits for combat aircraft. Without such agreement, a treaty would be more difficult to reach. The agreement on troop ceilings, the first of its kind, was one of three at the NATO-Warsaw pact conference capping an extraordinary nine days of diplomacy that saw Baker confer with allies and others in Ireland, Czechoslovakia, the Soviet Union, Romania, Bulgaria and finally in Ottawa. The second agreement establishes a two-stage process aimed at German reunification in which the two Germanies confer, followed by talks of their foreign ministers and those of the four powers that defeated Nazi Germany in World War II, the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union. In the third agreement, NATO and the Warsaw Pact agreed in principle on ``open skies'' surveillance methods by which reconnaissance aircraft of one side will fly over the territory of the other. Details are to be worked out for a May 12 signing ceremony in Budapest. During Baker's talks in Moscow last week, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev proposed a somewhat different troop arrangement _ equal levels for the United States and the Soviet Union on European soil of either 195,000 or 225,000 each, with no sub-ceiling for Central Europe. Baker took that proposal to the foreign ministers of the 15 U.S. allies in NATO, who were assembled in Ottawa for a two-week conference with the seven members of the Warsaw Pact on aerial surveillance as a means of allaying suspicions of surprise attack. Shevardnadze said the accord was close to Gorbachev's proposals. Referring to Bush's initiative, Shevardnadze told reporters: ``He did not say he would not agree to that.'' The foreign minister, with a twinkle, quipped: ``Are you disappointed?'' In Washington, the White House said in a statement, ``The president is pleased that this agreement on manpower removes the major obstacle to an early conclusion of a CFE (Conventional Forces in Europe) treaty.'' The accord on troop limitations capped a series of breakthroughs during Baker's nine days in Europe and Canada In Moscow, he and Soviet officials broke the back of several key issues that stood in the way of a treaty to reduce long-range missiles, bombers and submarines by 30 to 50 percent. Sea-launched cruises missiles were separated from the emerging treaty that Bush and Gorbachev intend to sign at their summit meeting in Washington in June. Also, an agreement was worked out for destruction of chemical weapons stock, also to be signed in June, provided other nations capable of producing gas agree to an international treaty. After a farewell chat with Shevardnadze, Baker headed home for Washington after a nine-day trip.

DOC.HEAD: Glance at Soviet Ethnic Hotspots
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES casualties in Tadzhikistan.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief look at current ethnic hotspots in the Soviet Union's republics:

TADZHIKISTAN: At least 37 people were killed Monday and more than 108 injured in rioting that began after rumors spread that Armenian refugees from violence in the Caucasus Mountains would receive priority for new housing in the capital, Dushanbe. Hundreds of Armenians fled the city.

KIRGHIZIA: Large crowds gathered in the capital Frunze of the Kirghizian republic, located on the Chinese border next to Tadzhikistan. They were drawn by similar rumors of Armenian refugees taking scarce housing and jobs away from local people. No violence was reported.

ARMENIA-AZERBAIJAN: Soldiers remained in both republics to control a flare-up in January of the ethnic violence that has wracked the Caucasus region for the past two years. More than 200 people have been killed since Jan. 13 in ethnic attacks and fighting between heavily armed groups of Armenians and Azerbaijanis.

MOLDAVIA: Tens of thousands of Moldavians rallied Sunday in the capital Kishinev to press for independence from the Soviet Union. The small republic once was part of Romania, and that Eastern European country's revolution in December has increased the passion for independence or a return to Romania.

DOC.HEAD: Superpowers Agree on Formula for Reuniting Germany
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 7th graf: ``President Bush,'' with Bush-Kohl call; SUBS grafs 11-12: ``The agreement,'' with three grafs to note third agreement in Ottawa; SUBS 21st graf: ``In Bonn,'' to delete now-redundant first name and identification of Kohl
DOC.TEXT: The United tates and its major European allies forged agreement with the Soviet Union and East Germany Tuesday on a two-stage formula to reunite Germany 45 years after the World War II victors divided it. The nations' foreign ministers released a terse statement on the agreement, and U.S. officials added detail. In the first stage, East Germany and West Germany would meet on legal, economic and political issues, according to the statement. The talks would begin soon after East Germany holds its March 18 national elections. In the second stage the foreign ministers of the two Germanys would meet with the foreign ministers of the United States, France, Britain and the Soviet Union ``to discuss external aspects of the establishment of German unity, including the issues of security of the neighboring states.'' The statement, hammered out at an East-West ``open skies'' conference, added that ``preliminary discussions at the official level will begin shortly.'' Although the statement was not specific, among the ``external aspects'' to be considered by the Big Four allies of World War II _ who defeated Nazi Germany and its allies in the most devastating war in history _ will be whether the new Germany is a member of the main Western military alliance, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. President Bush telephoned Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany during the day to discuss final details of the agreement, according to a White House statement Tuesday night. The news came late in the evening in Germany, too late for most citizens to react immediately. The West German television network broadcast a live report from its correspondent in Ottawa shortly after 11 p.m. German time. ARD pointed out that the way seemed clear for most of the points, but that the foreign ministers had ``set to one side'' temporarily the tricky question of the military posture of a united Germany. In East Berlin, the official news agency ADN distributed the news at 10:43 p.m. in a brief report that noted, ``The discussions will also include the questions of security of neighboring states.'' The agreement on German unification was one of three at the NATO-Warsaw pact conference capping an extraordinary eight days of diplomacy that saw U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III confer with allies and others in Ireland, Czechoslovakia, the Soviet Union, Romania, Bulgaria and finally in Ottawa. In the second agreement, announced by Canadian External Affairs Minister Joe Clark, the United States and the Soviet Union agreed on troop ceilings of 195,000 for each superpower in Central Europe and an additional 30,000 for the United States elsewhere in Europe. In the third agreement, NATO and the Warsaw Pact agreed in principle on ``open skies'' surveillance methods by which reconnaissance aircraft of one side will fly over the territory of the other. Details are to be worked out for a May 12 signing ceremony in Budapest. The United States wants a united Germany to remain in the NATO alliance, while the Soviet Union wants a neutral Germany. East Germany now is a member of the Warsaw Pact. U.S. officials bill the plan as ``Two plus Four,'' a reference to the four World War II allies and the two Germanys. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze met earlier Tuesday with his West German counterpart, Hans-Dietrich Genscher and with Baker. Genscher on Tuesday affirmed that East and West Germany would reunite and sought to reassure the world that the new country would not pose any threat to peace. ``We tell all our neighbors what we want to unite: The Federal Republic of Germany, the German Democratic Republic and the whole of Berlin _ no less, and no more. We do not have territorial claims against any of our neighbors.'' ``We seek a European Germany, not a German Europe,'' he said. Genscher made the comments to open the second day of a 23-nation ``Open Skies'' conference, the main topic of which has been eclipsed by the German unity issue. In Bonn, Kohl and Communist Premier Hans Modrow met to discuss monetary union. They agreed to set up a commission to study ways of making the West German mark the official currency of East Germany. Three forces had been at work in the world powers' discussion: _A conviction Moscow grew to share with Washington that unification was inevitable. _A Western desire to keep Germany in NATO. _Anxiety among people who suffered at Germany's hands in World War II. Bush administration policymakers were operating on an assumption those concerns could be allayed _ and any aggressive German tendencies diverted _ by keeping Germany within the 16-member NATO. But State Department officials, speaking on condition their names not be used, stressed that no outside power would have the right to interfere in the Germans' sovereign decisions. Work toward the German reunification plan had been under way quietly for several weeks, though the subject was not the stated reason for a number of meetings Baker had with world leaders in and out of Washington. Baker talked about the matter separately with British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd and Genscher separately in Washington; with French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas during a refueling stop en route to Czechoslovakia, and finally, with Soviet leaders when he reached Moscow last week. West Germany's Kohl and Genscher flew to Moscow last Saturday to lobby for unification with East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Expresses Concern over German Reunification
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Ottawa agreement. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who is seeking a big-power conference with both Germanys prior to reunification, said Tuesday night that some European developments ``may stir deeply felt anxieties.'' Britain on Tuesday joined in an agreement in Ottawa on a two-stage formula to reunite the two states after 45 years of division. The United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France _ allies in World War II _ and the two Germanys agreed that talks between East Germany and West Germany would begin soon after East German's March 18 elections. The six foreign ministers would meet later to discuss security considerations. Speaking at a dinner in honor of visiting Polish Premier Tadeusz Mazowiecki, Mrs. Thatcher said both Poland and Britain have had experiences this century ``which we are determined should not happen again'' _ an evident reference to Nazi Germany and World War II. ``That is why we believe it is so important to work out very carefully the implications of Germany's unification for existing alliances, for the Helsinki accords and for the European Community.'' ``We understand and support your view that the present border of Poland should be guaranteed,'' she told Mazowiecki, Poland's first non-Communist prime minister since the war. West Germany has promised to respect Poland's border with East Germany, saying it will not try to reclaim Polish territory inhabited by ethnic Germans. Mrs. Thatcher said she accepted the Germans' right ``to determine their own future in freedom.'' ``But it is vital that Germany's unification should uphold, not weaken, Europe's stability and security. That is why these matters must be very carefully worked out in full consultation with Germany's allies and neighbors.'' In his reply, Mazowiecki also referred anxiously to German unification. ``How will the Germans settle the problem of their constitutional unity to which, as any other nation, they are unquestionably entitled?'' he asked. Thatcher aides, speaking on condition of anonymity, had said earlier she wants any formulas that emerge from talks to be presented to an East-West summit meeting of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe due this year. Mrs. Thatcher is to discuss the proposal in London Wednesday with West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. Mrs. Thatcher's plan is seen as a response to critics who accuse her of seeking to slow the momentum toward reunification. She has not disguised her concern that hasty moves could undermine European security. Jacques Delors, president of the European Community executive commission, suggested Tuesday that the 12-nation bloc hold a special summit on German unification after the East German elections. No German peace treaty was signed after World War II. Although the United States, Britain and France renounced their status as occupiers in 1955, they retain authority in Berlin and maintain armies in West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Big Investment Firm's Crisis Has Profound Implications
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 2 and 4 to UPDATE with announcement that Drexel would file Tuesday night. A version moved on the financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: The impact of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s stunning decline reaches like an octopus beyond Wall Street and junk bonds, potentially threatening many businesses that depend on financial markets to raise money.
