The Drexel bankruptcy filing could inject more sellers into the already depressed junk bond market which the firm dominates, creating a confidence crisis that might spread into stocks, higher-grade corporate debt and other securities, investment experts and business executives said Tuesday. Such turmoil would affect the broader economy, possibly by pushing interest rates and the dollar higher in opposition to government attempts to sustain economic growth. Drexel said its parent company was filing Tuesday night for federal bankruptcy court protection from creditors, due to problems stemming from the deterioration of the junk market and the impact on its financial holdings. Many expressed surprise at the frightening speed with which Drexel, formerly one of the most powerful investment banks, hurtled toward collapse because of the junk bond market it was largely responsible for creating. ``It took a long time to string together this enterprise, and not much time at all for it to crack up,'' said James Grant, author of a prominent financial newsletter that frequently has warned against the perils of junk-bond debt. Others likened Drexel's demise to a disaster that will further erode the tarnished credibility of the depressed securities industry overall and persuade investors to shun investments that have no relation to junk bonds. This could force companies that historically have relied on selling stocks and bonds for new capital to curtail spending plans, lay off workers or even seek bankruptcy protection themselves. ``Does Three Mile Island ring a bell with you?'' said Paul E. Berg, president of Berg Fiduciary Consultants, an investment advisory firm in Port Chester, N.Y. ``When we had the explosion and problems at Three Mile Island, it impacted the entire utilities industry,'' Berg said, referring to the 1979 nuclear accident. ``You've got pretty much the same situation here.'' Drexel vaulted to prominence in the 1980s by aggressively peddling high-interest securities with low credit ratings as a way to raise money for businesses seeking to expand. The securities became known as junk bonds because of their relatively higher risk of default compared with investment-grade corporate bonds. Even before Drexel's latest problems, a number of prominent deals that depended on junk-bond financing had begun unraveling or faced serious obstacles. Drexel played a role in many of them. On Tuesday, for example, Drexel client Integrated Resources Inc., a diversified financial services company that has been struggling for months, sought federal bankruptcy protection. Earlier this month federal regulators seized Florida's biggest thrift, CenTrust Bank, blaming its failure partly on risky investments in Drexel junk bonds. CenTrust is one of Integrated's leading creditors. Banks, insurers, pension funds, mutual funds and other investors who bought junk bonds because they promised such high rates of interest could wind up owning nearly worthless pieces of paper, some financial strategists said. ``Now the reality is beginning to sink in, it's coming home to roost, that when people originally called them `junk bonds,' that's exactly what they were,'' said Jack Barbanel, managing director of First Global Asset Management, an investment company in Princeton, N.J. Others emphasized, however, that the overall number of junk bonds held by most investors remains only a tiny percentage of their portfolios. The total value of assets held by pension funds, for example, is more than $2.5 trillion, while the entire junk bond market once amounted to about $200 billion. ``If everybody owned a piece of a junk bond it would be pretty small,'' said William Overgard, director of investment consulting at Buck Pension Fund Services in New York. Drexel's destiny changed dramatically after the 1987 stock market crash and its involvement in the Ivan Boesky insider trading scandal, for which the company paid record penalties and agreed to unprecedented government scrutiny. Drexel has since shrunken to half its former size, forced to sell some operations because of the agreement with the government. Still, Drexel has remained the pre-eminent marketer of junk bonds, which have plunged in price during recent months because of rising concern that the debts won't be repaid. Throughout its rise and fall, Drexel has enjoyed strong client loyalty because of what supporters call the company's culture of hard work and dedication.Many expressed sorrow at the company's latest crisis. ``I think the whole thing is a terrible tragedy,'' said Bernard Salick, chairman and chief executive officer of Salick Healthcare Inc., a chain of outpatient health care centers that Drexel helped finance. ``It's going to have reverberations through so many industries, like one after the other.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Official Says Some Members May Leave Warsaw Pact
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 5 grafs SUB for grafs 5-8, President Bush ... to UPDATE with Ottawa agreements. Picks up 9th, `Speaking through ... ADDS one graf to UPDATE with German unification accord
DOC.TEXT: An adviser to Mikhail S. Gorbachev acknowledged on Tuesday that some East European nations may eventually may leave the Warsaw Pact, the Soviet military alliance. Marshal Sergei Akhromeyev, former Soviet chief of staff, was asked in an interview whether he thought one or two of the seven Warsaw Pact members might withdraw, and replied: ``Probably.'' He would not say which ones. Hungary and Czechoslovakia are negotiating for removal of Soviet military forces from their territory. Akhromeyev said the Kremlin was willing to discuss troop withdrawals with Poland, but had not received a formal request. He also repeated the Soviet position, expressed by the Soviet president last week, that the maximum number of U.S. and Soviet soldiers allowed in Europe must be identical in an agreement to reduce conventional forces. President Bush had said Monday the Gorbachev proposal was unacceptable. But on Tuesday, the United States and the Soviet Union agreed in Ottawa on a deep cut in troop deployments in Central Europe to 195,000 each, with the United States allowed to keep up to 30,000 troops elsewhere in Europe, Canadian External Affairs Minister Joseph Clark announced. The agreement, worked out during an ``open skies'' conference, represents Soviet acceptance of an initiative Bush unveiled on Jan. 31. An estimated 565,000 Red Army soldiers are stationed in Europe outside Soviet territory. The United States has 305,000, most of them in West Germany. NATO and the Warsaw Pact also agreed in principle in Ottawa on Tuesday on ``open skies'' surveillance methods by which reconnaissance aircraft of one side will fly over the territory of the other. Details are to be worked out for a May 12 signing ceremony in Budapest. Speaking through an interpreter, Akhromeyev said he thought most nations ``will continue to stick to their organizations, united by some common nature of interests, so I believe the Warsaw Pact will continue to exist.'' ``If one or two states would pull out of the Warsaw Treaty, part of the military contingents will withdraw from the combined armed forces,'' Akhromeyev said. ``This is going to be for those states to decide.'' The statement, once unthinkable, reflect the great changes in the Soviet bloc, where virtually all nations have renounced the Communist Party's dominant role in society and have embraced democratic changes. Akhromeyev is on the defense committee of the Soviet legislature and is in Brussels for meetings sponsored by the North Atlantic Assembly, which consists of legislators from the 16 nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Some of the Soviet legislators are to confer on Wednesday with Manfred Woerner, a West German who is secretary-general of the Western alliance. Akhromeyev said he thought negotiators for NATO and the Warsaw Pact could complete an agreement in Vienna this year on reducing the number of tanks, artillery and other non-nuclear arms in Europe. The toughest issue, he said, was a formula for combat aircraft. Negotiators ``will have to undertake really great efforts in order to find a solution to this problem,'' but leaving it out of the accord was ``out of the question,'' Akhromeyev said. A sticking point has been Soviet insistence on excluding thousands of defensive aircraft the West wants included in the count. Akhromeyev said the timing for withdrawal of soldiers from Hungary and Czechoslovakia would be fixed in the talks, but ``I don't believe it is going to be a lengthy process.'' As for Poland, he said, once a request for negotiations was received, ``we are going to engage in the talks and have our forces removed from there.'' He said the 380,000 soldiers stationed in East Germany were there because of agreements reached after World War II. ``The legal basis for stationing our forces there is the same as the legal basis for the American troops, British troops and French troops'' in West Germany, Akhromeyev said. He would not discuss what security arrangements the Soviets would want for a unified German state, but said Moscow would ``not say anything against'' the reunification process or oppose efforts ``to have a reunited Germany a neutral nation.'' West Germany is part of NATO and East Germany belongs to the Warsaw Pact. Western officials insist a united Germany remain in NATO. Another agreement at Ottawa Tuesday establishes a two-stage process aimed at German reunification in which the two Germanys confer, followed by talks of their foreign ministers and those of the four powers that defeated Nazi Germany in World War II, the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union.

George Bush is no stranger to danger in Colombia. Eight years ago, as vice president, he escaped an apparent assassination plot in which a load of dynamite was buried under the lone runway at the Bogota international airport. The explosives were found hours after Bush's plane took off. Only then did security officials discover the dynamite connected to wires running to an electrical generator 300 yards away. The 1982 incident provides a sharp reminder of the risks Bush faces as he prepares to fly to Colombia on Thursday for a six-hour drug summit with the presidents of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia. Colombian authorities say about 5,000 security agents will be deployed when the leaders meet at a heavily guarded naval base near the coastal resort of Cartagena.

Drexel Burnham, which became a Wall Street powerhouse through its pioneering use of high-risk junk bonds to help finance the 1980s takeover boom, is looking for outside help because of its deteriorating holdings. Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s announcement Monday that it is seeking a major investor or merger partner followed three days of talks with federal regulators, who worried that a collapse of the firm would shake confidence in the nation's financial markets, The New York Times reported today. Securities industry analysts and former Drexel executives echoed those concerns. They said its difficulties with the declining junk-bond market it helped create and its 1989 guilty plea to federal securities fraud could deter potential investors. ``At this point I think the biggest problem is the loss of confidence in them,'' said Chris Mahoney, analyst with Moody's Investors Service. ``Who would want to do business with them if they were a risk not to make it?''

Under pressure from the auto and petroleum industries, the Bush administration is backing away from a proposal that would require millions of alternative fuel cars to be sold in cities most plagued by smog. The phasing in of cars powered by fuels such as methanol or natural gas was a centerpiece of President Bush's clean air proposal last summer. The White House envisioned use of up to 1 million such vehicles annually by 1997 in an attempt to ``reconcile the automobile to the environment.'' But William Reilly, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, acknowledged Monday that the administration no longer considers mandatory production of alternative fuel cars as an essential part of clean air legislation. Instead, the administration is proposing in negotiations with Senate leaders that ``reformulated'' gasoline, which also cuts pollution, would be welcomed as an alternative to the alternative fuel vehicles.

This just in for Valentine's Day: nine of 10 people in a survey claimed they had never been unfaithful, and four of five said they would marry the same person again, given the chance. The Gallup survey, commissioned by Psychology Today and two television shows, King World's Inside Edition and ABC's Home Show, was released Monday. Three of four respondents said their spouse is their best friend, and 64 percent said their marriage was ``very happy.'' Pollsters contacted 657 randomly selected, married men and women nationwide shortly before Christmas. The margin of error was plus or minus 4 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Cancer Comes to Nancy on ``thirtysomething''
DOC.TEXT: Nancy, a character in ``thirtysomething,'' the ABC chronicle of the lives of ordinary people of a certain age, is encountering one of life's biggest crises: Nancy has cancer. She had found her own empowerment as a successful illustrator of children's books and had reconciled with her self-absorbed husband, Elliot. They were contemplating having another child, so she went for a physical examination. The physical prompted ``a high suspicion that something might be abnormal,'' said Dr. Maurie Markman, a medical oncologist specializing in ovarian cancer at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center here. He is a frequent watcher of ABC's series, which airs on Tuesday nights. Tonight's episode, an ABC spokesman says, continues the story of Nancy, and the problems another character, Melissa, is having with her father and her lover. In earlier episodes that led to Nancy's far greater problem, doctors ``initially did a laparascopy _ a small incision in the abdominal cavity,'' Markman said. They found the abnormal cells that indicated ovarian cancer. She then underwent removal of her uterus, ovaries, and fallopian tubes. Nancy was lucky, Markman said, because ovarian cancer has no specific, early symptons. ``Examination won't help in this disease at all,'' he said. Even though the disease was discovered at any early stage, Nancy still faces a grueling regimen of chemotherapy. ``She certainly needs chemotherapy and I think they're going to give it to her,'' Markman said. ``It's usually between five and eight to 10 months of treatment with fairly standard drugs, associated with a fair amount of acute side effects,'' Markman said. He said the severity of those side effects ary from patient, but they include nausea, vomiting, fatigue, loss of appetite, hair loss, potential risk of infection, bleeding, anemia and sometimes more serious problems like kidney damage and neurological damage, including numbness and tingling of the feet. Seventy to 80 percent of ovarian cancer patients are cured with therapy, he said. In the more advanced cases, probably only 20 to 30 percent survive. And in very advanced cases, probably 10 percent survive. ``Most of the time, you survive,'' Markman said. ``She doesn't appreciate that at this point. ``What she's focusing on is that she has got a 20 to 30 percent chance of dying, and I think that's very accurate. That's not television.'' Elliot, played by Tim Busfield, also is creating a true-to-life, if not particularly likeable, character. ``He's sort of dealing with this by being incredibly busy and almost not willing to hear what she's saying,'' Markman said. ``That's exactly how I would expect a loved one to respond. With time and with thinking about it, with discussions, you will find out what your loved one needs. Not by ignoring the complaints and then being reassuring,'' he said. Marshall Herskovitz, executive producer and co-creator with Edward Zwick of ``thirtysomething,'' said the show's writers have consulted with cancer specialists about the disease. He said Nancy has stage I(c) ovarian cancer and the side-effects of her chemotherapy aren't expected to involve hair loss or extreme nausea. ``Which is not to say that there aren't side effects,'' he added. ``That is the reality.'' ``It was always our intention to illustrate what we've seen to be the truth of life with cancer, which is that life goes on,'' Herskovitz said. ``Nancy is not defined by the fact that she has cancer now, and that's something we've not seen on television, and that seems so much the heart of life with cancer,'' he said. ``Chemotherapy will become a factor in her life, a nuisance, a burden in her life, but it will not define her life,'' he said. Markman is impressed with the show's handling of the cancer theme as well as actress Patricia Wettig's portrayal of Nancy. ``This is not a soap opera,'' the doctor said. ``The character herself is very good and I think she (Wettig) has done a very good job of portraying the real feelings. She's focused on her death.'' What Markman wants to emphasize is that there is real hope Nancy will be cured of her cancer and live a normal life for many years. ``Right now, she can't think about that,'' he said. ``I'm just hopeful that that aspect of the life of a cancer patient does not get lost in the story line.''

ELSEWHERE IN TELEVISION: ANOTHER REASON TO CONSULT YOUR LOCAL LISTINGS: Ex-wives of Dustin Hoffman, Vidal Sassoon, Robert Goulet, Mark Gastineau, and Joe Montanta appear on Tuesday's ``Geraldo,'' to talk about breaking up with the rich and famous. Goulet's ex-wife, Broadway star Carol Lawrence, says her marriage was breaking up while her husband ``was in the throes of alcoholism. He was violent and it got dangerous at times.'' Miss Lawrence describes how Goulet would lock their two young sons in the trunk of his two-seat car and forget they were there. Lawrence said when she admonished him, ``He would say, `I will do what I want, they are my kids.''' She says she has forgiven him and wishes him only the best.

DOC.HEAD: The Economy Needs a Pusher and a Driver
DOC.TEXT: While the economic fraternity was looking for economic clues from retail sales during the Christmas season, the manufacturing economy was eroding right under their noses. Productivity was falling, layoffs growing, profits falling, inventories accumulating, labor costs rising and production declining. In some respects, the situation was the worst since the last recession. None of this was new, however. All these indicators were weakening throughout the year. The rate of profit growth, for example, fell in every quarter of 1989, and it probably will fall again in this quarter. Understandably, such a situation has instilled fear in manufacturers, and they have expressed it by production slowdowns, campaigns to reduce inventories, and a re-evaluation of plans to expand factories. How could all these signs have drawn so little attention? Because, say some analysts, consumers are the key, and everyone was watching them. They account for 66 percent of gross national product; they have kept the expansion going. The consumer, they said, is our leader. That might have been so, observed economists at DRI McGraw-Hill, a statistics unit of Standard & Poor's Corp., ``but now the consumer has become a follower, not a leader of the economy.'' In short, manufacturing slowed down to wait for the consumer and the consumer slowed down to see what manufacturers were up to. The economy stalled out. Economic silence breeds fear. Somehow, interest rates began rising, even though everyone but Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, seemed to believe they should be going the other way. As you might expect, the weather didn't cooperate. December was one of the coldest on record in much of the northern United States and even deep into the South. Utility and food bills rose. Producer prices jumped sharply. Recession talk grew more ominous, and there was a good basis for it. If prices are rising and production is slowing you have a recipe for no growth. And no growth is just a statistical fraction from shrinkage. ``Unfortunately, the fear of inflation is feeding the fear of recession,'' the DRI McGraw-Hill analysts pointed out. And now, nobody seems to believe in the future strongly enough to get things moving again. The engine has stalled, and producers and consumers stand by wondering what to do. Somebody has to get in the vehicle and steer, but somebody has to push. Who will do what? Not I, say the consumers. We haven't the strength to push and, frankly, we don't think it's fair for us to have to steer the engine. We've had our splurge. We have kept the economy moving for years and now we need a rest. Moreover, we have piled up too many bills; everyone tells us that and we believe them, and now we're going to save instead. Interest rates are rising, so it will pay to have money in savings. Producers, however, view their big inventories and rebel against being in the driver's seat. And, they add, they aren't strong enough to push. Profits of late are real poor; they say they might even have to cut capital spending. Help!
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Tuesday, Feb. 13.

DOC.HEAD: Exercise Shows Show Why It's Best to Simply Watch
DOC.TEXT: Dawn can be horrible if you've fallen asleep with the TV on. You're apt to wake up hearing odd chants and sayings that chill the soul. You will hear things like this: ``And it's one and two and three and four.'' Or, ``Four, three, two, and hold it.'' Or, ``This workout's gonna be an outer-body experience.'' All that is from ESPN's ``Bodies in Motion,'' one of nine exercise shows for adults available on cable and over-the-air TV here from 5:25 a.m., when ``Morning Stretch'' begins, to noon, when ESPN emits ``Bodyshaping.'' There is also a 6:30 a.m. show for tykes called ``Mousercise.'' Most of the grown-up shows are in the early morning, which is when everyone should be thinking of calling in sick. They feature something called low-impact aerobics, a form of exercise in which hearty men in tights and lovely women in leotards stomp in place, wave their arms and smile, smile, smile. It is not good to see all this at dawn. But you can watch exercise tapes _ those of Jane Fonda are the best-known _ at a decent hour. A decent hour is 3 p.m. on a Saturday when you just can't back get to sleep. What goes in these tapes always had been a mystery to us. But we recently received one called ``Fitness Now,'' by Judi Sheppard Missett, founder of a 20-year-old exercise business in Los Angeles called ``Jazzercise.'' Missett previously made two other tapes and in 1982 had the first exercise album to sell more than 500,000 copies, according to a note with the tape. Moving right along, now, her new tape starts with an explanation of a ``perceived exertion method.'' It uses a chart divided into three parts _ yellow, green and red. Red means you may be about to go blooie and should slow down. Yellow is for warmup, says Missett, with the green zone for aerobic time. When in the green, she says, ``to maximize your fat-burning potential, you'll need to exercise between fairly light, to somewhat hard, and hard.'' She introduces six fellow instructors, all as healthy-looking as she, and the main event begins. We normally don't exercise, lest we croak. But we have a go at following follow Missett's instructions, which include exhortations to ``keep your body lined up'' and how to warm up the feet for ``fat-burning dancing.'' The tempo of the soft-rock music increases. Arms are waved amid her cries of encouragement, to wit: ``Yeah! And again. Hah! And again.'' Then individual parts of the body get a workout, including the head, which is to be rolled around. That is the easy part. We start fading when she moves us into the green zone part of the tape. ``So, put on your dancing shoes, tap your toes ... we're going to burn some fat and we're going to have fun, right, guys?'' Her colleagues say yes. But as the tempo goes to a brisk disco beat, we say no. We hop up and down. We hear a wild scream. It is Max the cat on whom we accidentally have hopped. Max flees. We bend about, rock back and forth, do a ``pelvic tilt,'' raise and lower the old knees, roll the old arms around. ``What are we burning, gang?'' cries Missett. ``Fat!'' her colleagues shout. We get down and boogie. We find it very hard to get back up. After only three minutes of brisk hopping, bending and waving, we hear sounds of things breaking _ a hamstring, an Achilles tendon, a truss, all of it ours. This means we are in the red zone. We sit down. Then we lie down, and realize there is a large untapped market out there. It is for a tape that shows you how to lie down and stay there.

Elsewhere in television ... ABC WINS AGAIN: ABC's ``World News Tonight'' last week won its sixth consecutive week in the ratings by a hefty margin, averaging an 11.0 rating to the 9.9 of Dan Rather's ``CBS Evening News'' and the 9.6 of Tom Brokaw's ``NBC Nightly News.'' Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. MORE FROM SOUTH AFRICA: With Nelson Mandela now free after 27 years in a South African prison, CBS' ``48 Hours,'' as might be expected, will devote Thursday's show to that nation and its apartheid policy. A spokewoman for the show said it will contrast the way whites and blacks there live.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wed PMs, Feb. 14

DOC.TEXT: For all that's happening in Eastern Europe, the Communist Party remains in firm control in Vietnam. But a visit to the capital city of Hanoi reveals that even here capitalism has obtained a toehold, some stringent controls have been loosened, and Westerners are no longer looked on as ogres.

A pedicab works its way through Hanoi's tree-lined streets, dodging a jumble of motor scooters and bicycles, delivering a Japanese color TV to its new owner. It rolls past a park dominated by a bronze statue of Karl Marx, then under a large poster depicting a heroic laborer, peasant, soldier and scientist fighting to build socialism. But elsewhere along the pedicab's route, there are indications that fledgling capitalism is taking hold in this communist capital of Southeast Asia. There are the dozens of privately run cafes decorated with colorful lights where people gather at night to chat or watch television over a drink that may be a $1 can of Heineken beer or a 50-cent bottle of Vietnamese-brand Lua Moi vodka. There are shops stocked with imported tape decks and videocassette recorders to be snatched up by the city's nouveau riche. By all accounts, the Vietnamese capital has become a more relaxed place to live as the government introduces dramatic market-style economic reforms and eases stringent political controls. Westerners who live in Hanoi or frequently visit the city say they are amazed at how fast the changes have occurred. They note the Vietnamese are even becoming more colorful in their dress, with reds and pinks replacing the drab clothing of a few years ago. Everywhere one turns, Western influences are clearly mingling with the traditional and socialist. At a recent Hanoi wedding reception, for example, a pop combo complete with sax was on stage playing an overly audible version of Cat Stevens' ``Wild World'' as traditional cookies and tea were served to about 200 guests, including elderly communist officials. State-run television also reflects the Western influence. On a recent early evening program, the camera lovingly panned along a counter of carefully arranged lean cuts of meat, the type of propaganda programming long found in poor Marxist states. But just a few hours later, the people of Hanoi tuned in to a flashy Whitney Houston music video. Socialist author Nguyen Dinh Thi insists the party also is giving the country's intellectuals more freedom. He said writers now ``have the right to speak the truth,'' even though private newspapers and magazines still are not allowed in this one-party state. And while a foreigner can now visit a Hanoi friend without causing a panic over possible repercussions, such visits are best made at night under the cover of darkness so as not to attract too much attention. But for all the changes, the party still rejects any challenge to its monopoly on power and the economy still has a long way to go, as Vietnam remains one of the world's poorest nations. Beggars accost foreigners on Hanoi's streets and inside department stores, while families live in cramped apartments housing up to a dozen or more people. On virtually every Hanoi street, dozens of young men play billiards on roughly hewn pool tables, a sign of the serious unemployment. Meanwhile, the colonial-era infrastructure of Hanoi continues to crumble from neglect after escaping largely unscathed from the war with the United States. Power outages are common and the buildings need not only a fresh coat of paint but substantial renovation work. Among the structures still standing is the infamous ``Hanoi Hilton,'' a prison that once housed American prisoners of war but is now, officials say, home to only common criminals. Public transportation is limited, with only a few buses and wheezing trolleys of ancient vintage on the potholed roads. The major mode of transportation remains the bicycle. In the countryside, the rice paddies that line the main road to the northern port of Haiphong are irrigated by hand. Bridges over major rivers are only one lane wide but handle two-way vehicle and rail traffic. On a recent weekday morning, scores of cars and trucks waited for nearly an hour as two steam locomotives belching black smoke laboriously chugged across one bridge. Vietnam is counting on the West to help in its modernization efforts, particularly now that Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union are preoccupied with fixing their own sputtering economies. Fifteen years after the end of the Vietnam War, the United States still refuses to establish diplomatic ties with Hanoi and is blocking Vietnamese efforts to obtain assistance from international financial organizations. Despite the U.S. bombing of the north during the war, and the continued political snubs from Washington, the people of Hanoi appear to hold few grudges against Americans. That spirit was exemplified by Nguyen Thi Quy, a 66-year-old woman who lives near Kham Thien, a Hanoi street devastated by a 1972 U.S. bombing raid. Quy lost her 14-year-old daughter in the attack. Every day she lights incense at a memorial to the victims that was erected on the site of a kindergarten destroyed in the bombing. The open-air memorial consists of a concrete statue of a woman with a dead child resting on her knee. It bears the inscription: ``Deeply bear in mind hatred for the U.S. aggressors. 26-12-1972.'' Two small bunches of flowers flank the entrance. Quy, her long hair streaked gray and black, began to cry when she recounted the loss of her daughter, whom she said was making plans to travel abroad to study when the bombs fell. How does she feel about Americans? ``I hate that American plane that killed my daughter,'' she says, ``but I don't hate the American people.''

DOC.TEXT: It was an ``All-American'' city of the 1950s, a prospering factory town on the Hudson River 50 miles north of New York City. Today Newburgh, N.Y., like so many other cities, has fallen victim to drugs, crime and decay. The citizens of Newburgh, however, are starting to fight back.

Cops in hiding on Newburgh's East End watch three men selling crack cocaine make a couple of quick deals. ``There's no business like drug business,'' sings out one of the dealers, to the tune of the Irving Berlin show biz anthem. The cops move in and bust all three. That's Newburgh, 1990, a city of 25,000 on the Hudson River just 50 miles north of New York City, but with a worse reputation in relation to its size. The Newburgh of Donald Presutti's youth was so safe, so prosperous, so clean that in 1952 Look magazine called it the ``All-American'' city. The Newburgh of Donald Presutti's adulthood, the one he administers as mayor, is an urban battleground where citizens are trying to reclaim their streets from the drug pushers and addicts and criminals who've made the city a dirty word in the Northeast. ``The fight for freedom on the American soil is being fought in Newburgh and on the streets of cities like Newburgh,'' Presutti says. ``If we lose this war, society as we know it today will no longer exist. What you'll end up with is possibly what old Rome was like, with all the villas and cities walled, and armed guards everywhere.'' Presutti doesn't think he is overstating the danger, and neither do other city and civic leaders. What has happened to their city is happening all over America, just not to such an extraordinary degree, they say. ``Our commitment to the war on drugs is so great that we have unarmed John Q. Citizens out on the street trying to intimidate drug users and drug dealers,'' Presutti says. ``This is the first war other than the Revolution and the Civil War that's being fought on the street.'' Just over 9,000 crimes were reported to police in Newburgh in 1988, the last full year for which statistics are available. The city's crime rate of 139.5 per 1,000 in population was more than double the statewide average and a total approaching those of cities atop the FBI's national high-crime list. For a community in New York state, however, the crime index that's always mattered most is how a city compares with New York City. Newburgh has a higher murder rate than New York City, and a higher rate of rapes and burglaries and robberies and aggravated assaults and larcenies, according to data from the New York state Division of Criminal Justice Services. A special anti-crime unit formed within the Newburgh police department in 1985 was supposed to deal with burglary, robbery and prostitution cases. Now, 90 percent of its work concerns drug-related crime. The task force makes eight to 10 felony drug arrests each week. People old enough to remember agree that Newburgh's slide began in the 1960s, when manufacturing companies began to scale back local operations in the face of foreign competition and aging factories. Newburgh was once the biggest maker of pocketbooks in the nation, once a thriving fabrics and garment center, once a busy bottler of beverages and maker of furniture. The bottom fell out in the 1970s. ``I would say that Newburgh in a lot of ways epitomized the problems that the entire Northeast experienced,'' says Chris Dunleavy, executive director of the Orange County Chamber of Commerce. ``The manufacturing base moved off, to the South and offshore. Many workers who had moved in from the South, from Puerto Rico and Latin America _ people who were basically unskilled _ remained.'' The city's medium household income is $10,923, far less than the $18,012 average for Orange County as a whole. Unemployment in the city runs at about 8 percent, compared to the statewide average of about 5 percent. Newburgh's location on the Hudson River was once an ideal place for a manufacturing center to distribute its goods. Later, the city benefited from being at the intersection of two major interstate highways, the north-south New York State Thruway and the east-west Interstate 84. Now, police say the city has become a crossroads for drug traffic between New York City, upstate New York and New England. Authorities say local dealers have ties to cocaine distribution networks based as far away as Miami. Many dealers have set up business in Newburgh to escape the cutthroat drug trade in New York City. Police say the drug buyers range from Newburgh's own poor to affluent businessmen and college students. Buyers also come from as far away as Albany, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, according to Newburgh Police Capt. Santo Centamore. State Social Services Commissioner Cesar Perales said after a recent tour of Newburgh that the most blighted parts of the city are comparable to the notorious South Bronx in New York City. A citizens' group called the Newburgh Drug and Alcohol Task Force has tried for a year to mount a grass-roots campaign against drugs. The group has staged rallies on Lander Street and other notorious drug haunts, where members marched with signs and chanted anti-drug slogans in demonstrations they dubbed ``One Block At A Time.'' It has organized rallies in local schools and lobbied with state officials for special anti-drug aid. Among the most visibile anti-drug activists are Joan Shapiro, a former mayor of Newburgh, and her husband, Jerry. While in office, during the mid-1980s, she regularly cruised the streets at night in search of her son, a cocaine addict who eventually was sent to a drug treatment center and has been ``clean and serene'' for more than three years. In late September, Gov. Mario Cuomo declared that Newburgh would be the only area outside New York City to be included in an experimental state program to fight drugs through a combination of stepped-up enforcement, better treatment programs and improved education. As Cuomo was announcing Newburgh's designation at a local school, a woman was arrested on nearby Lander Street for crack possession. She was wearing a ``Stop Crack'' button.

DOC.TEXT: A Scottish disc jockey has found a wide audience playing her own brand of down-home music on public radio in, of all places, North Carolina. But why not? Most of this area's original settlers were Scotch-Irish immigrants who brought their fiddles and tin whistles to harken back to the music of their homeland.

``I obviously sound like where this music comes from,'' she says in her lilting, rich Scottish brogue. And listening to Fiona Ritchie from her forum, ``Thistle & Shamrock'' on public radio, it sounds like she is surrounded by musicians from Scotland, Ireland, Wales and Brittany. She's a Scottish disc jockey with a weekly hour-long show originating in North Carolina. Unlikely? Why not? Some of this area's original settlers were Scotch-Irish immigrants who sought to imitate the music of their homeland with fiddles and tin whistles. Fiona's radio show has attracted a wide and faithful audience from Maine to California. Even she had to chuckle when she found her name in The Boston Globe's crossword puzzle. The clue was, ``Public radio's Ritchie.'' Ritchie, a youthful 29-year-old with thick auburn hair, says she has had no formal training in music or radio. Yet over the last six years, she has evolved into one of American Public Radio's biggest draws. It is now picked up by 165 public radio stations across the country. ``It's still popular and growing,'' she said in an interview at her studio at WFAE-FM, just before leaving for a working vacation at her parent's home in Greenock, Scotland. ``If it weren't, I might graciously bow out.'' That's the last thing her fans, many of whom write her letters and subscribe to her newsletter, want Ritchie to do. ```Thistle & Shamrock' is the reason God invented ears,'' wrote one fan from Laramie, Wyo. ``I work as a ranger deep in the woods of northern Maine for half the year, and every Saturday night at 8 p.m. finds me glued to the radio for `The Thistle & Shamrock,''' wrote another fan. ``Your show has opened a whole new world of music and musical instruments to me.'' Ritchie launched the Celtic music show in 1981 as a local radio show in Charlotte, where she had spent a year in college as an exchange student from Stirling University in Scotland. Two years later, APR syndicated it nationally. The name of the show came out of her imagination. ``It's my own concoction,'' says Ritchie, her face breaking into a big smile. ``I wanted a name that would evoke a place where this music would be performed _ a pub-like setting.'' There's a style she brings to her weekly show that's all Fiona Ritchie. One week the theme could be songs of the sea. The next, songs about the working class. Later, music from a particular region of Ireland or England could be featured. Ritchie gives her listeners a brief preview before each set. ``The appeal of the show lies directly with Fiona,'' says APR spokeswoman Deborah Wolfer in a telephone interview from St. Paul, Minn. ``Her personality is engaging and her fans sense her enthusiasm for the subject. People listen for her, not just the music.'' To Ritchie, the real attraction is the music, some of it hundreds of years old. While she started off as an amateur, her small office is now crammed with tapes, Celtic records and music reference books. ``I'm always looking for new music,'' she says. ``I'll be bringing some recordings and CDs back with me from Scotland. But I even find some of it here in Charlotte.'' Ritchie's playlist ranges from the traditional Scottish ballads of Jean Redpath, including ``The Songs of Robert Burns,'' to the Irish traditional music of De Danann and, of course, The Chieftains (``In Ireland''). Another Ritchie favorite is the Battlefield Band, which plays music based on traditional Scottish tunes. Dougie MacLean, who toured with Ritchie last year, also is a popular attraction. He's a Scottish songwriter who writes new music in traditional arrangements. You also could hear the contemporary offerings of Nightnoise, including cuts from ``Something of Time'' and ``At the End of the Evening.'' ``When I first moved here I had no idea there was such a connection between the area and Scotland,'' Ritchie says. ``I didn't expect the people to take such an interest in the music.'' To Ritchie, the music's appeal transcends most of life's differences _ including age, national origin and economic class. ``People enjoy music that's emotional,'' she says. ``This music is loaded with emotions.'' Her fans come from all ethnic backgrounds, not just those with an Irish or Scottish heritage. ``This music ... has something everyone can enjoy.'' Her own tastes run from traditional Celtic music to jazz and classical and on to contemporary artists like U2, Van Morrison and Nancy Griffith. Ritchie can be spotted at concerts across the country taping live shows for later play on the ``Thistle & Shamrock.'' Last March, Ritchie took the ``Thistle & Shamrock'' on the road. Six Scottish musicians, headed by fiddler Dougie MacLean, played sellout concerts in 10 U.S. cities. The second annual tour will begin in September.

DOC.TEXT: Actress Valerie Harper, who plays a city manager in her new CBS comedy series, knows how to fight city hall. After she was fired in August 1987 from NBC's ``Valerie,'' since retitled ``The Hogan Family,'' she took the producers, Lorimar Studios and the network to court. She not only fought, she won, getting a settlement of $1.4 million for lost wages. Her husband and the co-executive producer, Tony Cacciotti, also received a substantial settlement. In the series ``City,'' Harper plays City Manager Liz Gianni, who copes with hectic conditions at work and with a nubile teen-age daughter demanding more freedom at home. Harper, probably best remembered as the irrepressible Rhoda Morgenstern of ``The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' and ``Rhoda,'' also will be seen Tuesday in the CBS movie ``Stolen: One Husband.'' She stars as a wife who loses her husband of 25 years, played by Elliott Gould, and sets out to get him back. While still in court over ``Valerie,'' Harper became actively involved in developing ``City.'' In January, Jeff Sagansky, the new president of CBS Entertainment and former subordinate of NBC's Brandon Tartikoff, pulled the faltering ``The Famous Teddy Z'' and rushed ``City'' into its Monday time slot. That puts ``City'' directly opposite ``The Hogan Family.'' In the ratings for the premiere episode Harper knocked the socks off her former family. Which, in a sense, is biting the hand that feeds her. The court awarded her a profit participation in her old show that could yield $15 million. ``I don't think placing it against my former show was deliberate,'' she says. ``It was deliberate to put me in that Monday comedy block. I think Jeff Sagansky was looking for something fresh and singular and honest to replace `Teddy Z.' But going against `The Hogan Family' was happenstance. ``I certainly didn't want to go against `The Cosby Show' on Thursday at 8 o'clock. I didn't want to go head-to-head against `Roseanne.' Roseanne Barr sent me two dozen roses the day after I started work. We're both at the MTM Studios. ``We'd met at the `Comedy Awards Show' when I was still in court. She said someone had told her not to get pushy, to remember the lesson of Valerie Harper. She said to me, `I hope you teach them a lesson.''' Harper believes her court victory has indeed sent a clear message to Hollywood. It showed, she says, that she had not walked off the show in a display of temper or behaved erratically, as Lorimar had alleged, but had been wrongfully discharged. After ``Valerie,'' Harper was first involved in a show called ``Desperate Women.'' The comedy, created by Paul Haggis, was about a family of Italian women in Brooklyn. ``CBS said, `We liked the show before but we don't like it now,' '' says Harper. ``I don't know what they didn't like about it. Probably that I was in a domestic situation the way I was in `Valerie.' I had a deal with CBS for a show and we started over again. There was no way I was going to go ahead without Paul Haggis. I wasn't sure he'd want to start over again from scratch. ``Tony knew that Paul had a treatment for an hour show called `City' that was like `L.A. Law.' Tony suggested making it a half-hour. Paul said it was too heavy, but he came back after a weekend and said OK. The original show was intended for a woman.'' The city in ``City'' is never identified. It's a large city, about the size of Cleveland or Pittsburgh, and is in the snow belt. A broken sign in the show that says ``City of--'' expresses conditions and attitudes at city hall that Liz is trying to correct. Harper's character is Italian. She calls herself Italian by association. ``My stepmother Angela is n Italian from New York City,'' she says. ``I based Rhoda on her and a Jewish friend named Penny Ann Green. People often said that Rhoda seemed to be Italian. That was the Angela seeping through. ``Liz is a person who has to handle a budget and deliver what the politicians promise. She has to see that the police and fire departments run and that the garbage is collected. She has a passion that sometimes gets her into trouble. Her daughter, Penny, is the apple of her eye, but their temperaments are entirely different. There's a lot of give and take between us.'' Harper says she sees no resemblance between Liz and Rhoda. Liz is a woman with a lot of ability who knows how to get things done. She sees Liz as closer to the role she played in ``Farrell for the People,'' a 1982 movie pilot in which she played a prosecuting attorney.

DOC.TEXT: When you're an aspiring musical comedy performer and can't get jobs because you look as if you're 12 but sing like Alfred Drake, where do you go? The precarious world of cabaret offers opportunity, if not steady employment. The latter might be a possibility now for Jeff Harnar, a 30-year-old, baby-faced baritone who has gathered rave reviews since the debut last July of ``Carried Away,'' his show celebrating the lyrics of Betty Comden and Adolph Green. New York critics tossed superlatives, comparing him to cabaret performer-turned-superstar Michael Feinstein. They called Harnar's innovative evening of songs _ done at two different nightspots around town _ one of the best of the year. The object of their admiration is an unassuming young man who has struggled for more than a decade to make a name for himself in music. It has been an effort. Harnar arrived in New York in 1979 from various points west. He grew up in a lot of cities where his father worked for Ford Motor Co. It was in Dearborn, Mich., at age 5, that Harnar discovered musicals. A neighbor was doing a community theater production of ``How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying'' and took him to see it. ``The whole thing _ the music, seeing someone I knew on stage, the sets, the costumes and knowing, even at that age, that the show had a part in it I would like to do _ just came together,'' Harnar says. He was hooked on theater. Harnar nurtured that ambition in high school in Winnetka, Ill., at a school where musicals, he says, were treated with respect. When he finally got to New York in 1979, it was a different story. Musicals weren't the same. Brash Broadway musical comedy had given way to big British spectacle. `I was typed as a juvenile in auditions,'' he says, ``and then I'd sing with a baritone voice. Most of the roles were for tenors, juvenile tenors. I was never cast, and I took that very much to heart.'' In 1983, as his last hurrah in show biz, Harnar put together an act for a one-night run at a small club. Out of it came a two-week booking. ``But I had such a miserable time that I figured, `That's it. I don't know what I'm going to do with this career,''' he recalls. What he did was put it on hold. He went to work as a houseboy for Phyllis McGuire of the McGuire Sisters. For three years, he didn't sing or go to the theater. ``I was very depressed,'' he says. But the job proved to be an opportunity to observe his employer in a similar situation. ``She was launching a comeback, and I was watching her go through the exact same things that I was going through as a newcomer. The scope of it was a lot grander, but she had to prove herself again to get back in the door in Las Vegas. It inspired me, probably even more than I realized. ``It was through the course of that job that I realized that it's not so much the talent. There comes a point where your talent is the given. It's more happenstance _ the opportunities, the persistence, the perseverance.'' By 1987, Harnar was ready to try again. He eventually found a home at Eighty-Eight's, a Greenwich Village nightclub. He was able to change and hone his act there, finding out what was viable in front of an audience. To support himself between engagements, he took a job as a singing waiter at a West Side restaurant. The evening of Comden and Green songs was born last April. But the songwriting team, responsible for the lyrics for such shows as ``On the Town,'' ``Bells Are Ringing,'' ``Wonderful Town,'' ``Do Re Mi'' and others, was not easy to persuade at first. Harnar, his pianist, Alex Rybeck, and his director, Sara Louise Lazarus, researched material from all the Comden and Green stage and film musicals. But when the singer called them to get approval, he found the team wanting to discourage the project. Harnar kept talking, turning the tide when he told them he was thinking of singing ``Never Never Land'' from ``Peter Pan'' as a doo-wop number. That got a laugh out of Green as well as the team's OK. The title of the show, ``Carried Away,'' a song from ``On the Town,'' also is its theme. In it, Harnar sings Comden and Green patter songs as examples of getting excessive about life and love. For his next cabaret effort, Harnar and friends plan to salute a theatrical year. He picked 1959 because that's the year he was born and because he's hooked on the '50s. There's plenty of material. Among the shows that opened on Broadway in 1959 were ``Gypsy,'' ``The Sound of Music,'' ``Fiorello,'' ``Take Me Along,'' ``Redhead'' and ``Destry Rides Again,'' as well as such interesting flops as ``Juno'' and ``Saratoga.'' The list of composers includes Richard Rodgers, Jule Styne, Jerry Bock, Marc Blitzstein, Harold Rome and Harold Arlen. ``When you put together a club act, it's entirely your favorite songs. It's exactly what I want to be singing. When that gets received well, that's the most rewarding experience I can imagine,'' he says. ``Now my peers come up to me and say, `When are you going to get over this cabaret thing and get back to pounding the boards auditioning?' I am auditioning. When auditions come along that I'm right for, I go to them. But the fact of the matter is, I'm so happy doing what I'm doing.''

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Europe's Upheaval Rattles Mideast Rulers
DOC.TEXT: Small but potentially significant moves toward more representative government are touching much of the Arab world, where monarchs, emirs, presidents or ruling parties have long held overwhelming power. The overall balance has hardly shifted toward popular rule, however. Parliamentary democracy as it is known in the West, with government answerable to an elected legislature, has never taken firm root in the Arab world despite a number of experiments. While some nations now are experimenting with secular parliaments and national assemblies, it is possible that new regimes in some countries could ultimately be shaped as much by Islamic traditions as by Western democratic principles. And developments in Eastern Europe, where centralized political and economic systems are being painfully rebuilt, could also have their effect. Liberalizations have been touching individual Arab nations for at least a year, with rulers in many cases being careful to strictly limit the new openings. Some Arab commentators, however, say leaders need to move faster with concessions to popular representation before increasingly educated citizens, disgruntled by economic problems and strict political control, launch revolutions of their own. The fall of Eastern Europe's dictators, like Romania's Nicolae Ceausescu, touched off additional comment in the Arab world. ``There's an Arab saying: When your neighbor shaves, you should wet your beard,'' publisher Ahmed Jarallah wrote in Kuwait's Al-Seyassah daily. ``After what happened in Romania, many should prepare their beards for shaving as the people will not forgive them. There are regimes in the Middle East which destroyed their peoples and their economic resources.'' But while there are comparisons between some Arab nations and Eastern Europe _ powerful elites, pervasive security networks and burgeoning economic problems _ there also are significant differences. The Arab drive toward reform, pre-dating the upheaval in Eastern Europe, stemmed in large part from the spread of Islamic fundamentalism that is anathema to all Arab governments. The demand for political systems based on Islamic principles has considerable support, particularly in countries like Egypt, Jordan and Tunisia. Arab leaders have largely tolerated this but have sought to defuse it with limited reforms. Some analysts believe the most dramatic changes could occur in two of the most repressive regimes in the Arab world, Syria and Iraq, which are ruled by minority elites. Both have been heavily dependent on the Soviets, and reforms in Eastern Europe will, many believe, force them to change their policies. One nation to experiment with substantial liberalization has been Jordan. Bloody price riots last April highlighted widespread popular frustration and prodded King Hussein into restoring Parliament and overseeing the first elections since 1967. They were among the freest in the region in years. Hussein's government also announced it would lift martial law, free political prisoners, legalize political parties, denationalize the press and fight corruption. Yet as in other countries, the reforms do not go all the way toward putting power in the people's hands. Hussein still can invoke emergency powers and dissolve Parliament. Other Arab leaders, such as Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, also retain sweeping powers and are not elected by popular vote. In prosperous Kuwait, citizens are demanding the restoration of Parliament, which was dissolved in 1986 at the height of the Iran-Iraq war after deputies harshly criticized authorities. Kuwait's ruling family has announced it is considering lifting censorship and introducing unspecified democratic changes. But the emir has refused to receive a petition signed by 25,000 citizens demanding the convening of Parliament. Salem al-Marzouk, a former member of Parliament who is agitating for its return, said that since it was dissolved, corruption and economic abuses in the emirate have been ``rampant.'' ``One cannot say that Parliament could solve the problems, but it could raise the issue and pressure the government to do something about it,'' he said. In Algeria, once a bastion of autocratic Third World radicalism, President Chadli Bendjedid has allowed the creation of poplitical parties, freed the press and introduced private enterprise corporations. Following riots that left 176 people dead by official count, he brought in a new constitution for ``more democracy, to assure public and individual liberties and establish the sovereignty of law.'' Local elections are due this spring, with the ruling National Liberation Front competing as one of many parties. In neighboring Tunisia, President Zine el Abidine ben Ali promised to bring ``true democracy'' to his North African country when he ousted aging Habib Bourguiba in 1987. But in the first elections, held in April last year, the ruling Democratic Constitutional Rally won all 141 seats in the National Assembly, leading the opposition to cry foul. South Yemen is opening the doors to a multiparty system, easing travel restrictions and improving its relations with Western countries. The leadership there is a coalition of the ruling Yemeni Socialist Party and various tribal factions, reflecting the uneasy duality of Western and traditional concepts found in many Arab countries. As the Arab world's only avowedly Marxist state and a close ally of Moscow, South Yemen has felt the repercussions of Soviet perestroika more acutely than other countries in the region. Elsewhere, Sultan Qaboos of the Persian Gulf nation of Oman reportedly is considering reforms that include elected local councils in line with the traditions of the ruling Ibadi sect, which has highly developed principles of elected leadership and representative government. Saudi Arabia's ruling family has considered setting up a consultative council and even built an ornate building to house it, but it has shelved the project amid conservative opposition in the theocratic kingdom. There are few signs of any democratic opening in Syria, dominated by President Hafez Assad, who seized power in 1970, and his pervasive military apparatus. But there are no signs of upheaval either, despite severe economic problems. Nor is there sign of sweeping change in neighboring Iraq, ruled by strongman Saddam Hussein, despite experiments such as allowing elections and waging periodic anti-corruption drives. Saddam recently announced that a new constitution, to be approved by referendum, would provide for a free press and the formation of new political parties but no details were given.

DOC.HEAD: Alien Smuggling in Asia: `The Crime of the '90s'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: an accompanying story is BC-Alien Smuggling-China, b0567.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Selling travel documents and smuggling aliens have become gold mines in Asia, with government officials and middlemen making fortunes creating new identities for thousands of people. Paying up to $30,000 apiece, thousands of Asians are leaving their continent and hoping for a better life. Most want to go to North America. Some enter a life of crime along the way. ``Alien smuggling is the crime of the '90s,'' said Mark D. Riordan, a Hong Kong-based special agent of the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service. ``It's almost as lucrative as drugs but the penalties and dangers are minimal.'' The latest rage involves a complex paper trail where legitimate travel agents in Hong Kong pay large fees for real passports and visas and then sell them to their clients. But it's also done traditionally by faking visas and smuggling travellers across borders at night. Diplomats and travel agents say officials from Latin American countries have sold thousands of genuine travel documents to Chinese fleeing the communist regime. Bolivia recently removed several China-based diplomats after allegations of trading travel documents for sex and money. In December, the consul general for Panama in Hong Kong submitted his resignation after allegations that his consulate sold up to 7,000 visas to Chinese. On the traditional end, counterfeit rings are pumping out thousands of bogus travel documents to people from Thailand, Malaya, Pakistan, the Philippines, Taiwan and Hong Kong. Currently, the biggest market for travel documents is China, where businessmen and the children of important officials are fleeing the increasingly hardline state. Another is Hong Kong, which comes under Communist Chinese sovereignty in 1997. A 1989 U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service report identified ``an elaborate and intricate smuggling pipeline'' used by people from China, Hong Kong and Taiwan to get into the United States. ``This illegal traffic is noticeably on the increase,'' it said. Most of the travellers want to go to North America, businessmen and immigration officials say. But immigrating there legally is difficult. Without a relative in the United States, most people have little chance of becoming Americans. Canada has strict residency requirements. One way people leave Asia is to first obtain Latin American travel documents and then head to South America by way of the United States or Canada, entering North America under a category called ``transit without visa.'' Arriving in North America, the immigrants attempt to sneak out of airports. Failing that, they continue to Latin America where they try to enter North America from the south. Prices for a genuine visa or passport from Latin America range between $6,000 and $30,000, U.S. businessmen say. The large fees often mean people borrow huge sums of money from crime syndicates in exchange for years of service, diplomats say. In New York City, Chinese criminal organizations have been paying an average of $30,000 for men from Fujian province in southern China to be smuggled into the United States as ``indentured servants'' in the gangs, the INS report said. ``They have to commit crimes to pay back their sponsor,'' said one Western law enforcement source. ``The more violent the crime, the more money it's worth.'' Law enforcement agents say there is little they can do to stop the trade. First time smugglers in the United States and Canada are rarely jailed and profits appear immense. A Chinese woman, Cheng Chui-peng, who faces alien smuggling charges in Buffalo, N.Y., made tens of millions of dollars in the trade, the INS alleges. Hong Kong travel agent John Choi estimates the industry has made roughly $140 million in the past year moving people out of China. ``The Chinese are desperate,'' said Jean Chong, another travel agent who claims he has sold scores of genuine Ecuadorian passports to Chinese nationals. ``All they want to do is leave.'' To get Chinese out of China, businessmen in Hong Kong say they buy visas and passports from Argentina, Bolivia, Ecuador, Paraguay and Thailand. Panama, which once topped the list for document sales, saw its popularity plummet after the U.S. invasion in December. As the Chinese government does not routinely issue passports to its people, the travel agents often buy those from corrupt police or local officials. The going price is about $2,500. Diplomats from Latin American countries generally deny that their countries sell travel documents. Carlos Pimentel, the consul general of Brazil in Hong Kong, said Brazilian officials in Asia do not sell travel documents. He said any such documents were forgeries. A spokesman for the Argentine Embassy in Beijing said he was ``fairly sure that every visa'' granted by the embassy was legal. But Western diplomats, who have seen examples from several Latin American countries, said many of the documents appear genuine. One country, Bolivia, has acknowledged the sales. Bolivian diplomats were improperly issuing thousands of visas in China until the middle of last year, said Oscar Siles, Bolivia's new consul general in Hong Kong. Some were being exchanged for sex and others for money, diplomats said. The illegal practice was halted after several diplomats were fired, Siles said. Businessmen claim the biggest single outlet for visas for Chinese nationals was the Panamanian Consulate in Hong Kong, which, according to Hong Kong immigration records obtained by The Associated Press, issued about 7,000 last year. The consulate was run by Ciro Noriega, the cousin of deposed Panamanian leader Manuel A. Noriega, but he has submitted his resignation. A Panamanian trade official, Martin Palacios, said that any illegal activity occurred in Panama and not in Hong Kong. South Korea has been a recent popular destination for Chinese and other Asians, even though Beijing has no official relations with the South Korean government. Hong Kong immigration records show that more than 700 Chinese a month for the past six months have passed through Hong Kong to Seoul, South Korea's capital. Many Chinese and other Asians stay in Seoul only long enough to change flights, travel agents in the field say. In the airport's transit lounge, the travellers meet couriers who supply them with plane tickets and new travel documents, they say. Bogus documents are generally less expensive than genuine, but immigration authorities worry that that may change as counterfeiting techniques improve. The Hong Kong government recently cracked a counterfeiting ring for visas to the U.S. Trust Territory of Saipan, along with U.S. ``green cards.'' Immigration officials say many of the counterfeit passports are produced by forgers in the Philippines. Taiwan also possesses an active industry. Said one agent about the quality of recently seized fakes: ``If this is the type of stuff they're coming up with, we're sunk.''

DOC.HEAD: China Is Asia's Biggest Market for Aliens
With BC-Alien Smuggling, b0566
DOC.TEXT: With a little patience and a lot of cash, Mr. Zhang escaped China. A $2,500 bribe bought him a Chinese passport. An additional $6,000 bought him what he said was a genuine Brazilian visa and a plane ticket to South America. With some luck and $8,000 more, he says, he'll have a real Brazilian passport in a month. He arrived in Hong Kong on Feb. 3. As he paced his Hong Kong hotel room shortly before he left for Brazil, Zhang said he was glad to be out of China. A suitcase of U.S. dollars stood by his bed. ``I'm a businessman,'' said Zhang, who spoke on condition that his whole name not be used. ``My nationality got in the way of my work.'' Zhang said he hopes to go to the United States and also return to China as a ``foreigner.'' Holders of foreign passports in China have access to better hotels and other facilities usually off limits to average Chinese. With access to large amounts of foreign exchange through his work as a top official in an import-export company, Zhang said, he ``borrowed'' the necessary funds from his company. Hong Kong-based businesses say corrupt agents of the Chinese Public Security Bureau sell Chinese passports for $2,500 each. Mr. Zhang said that is how he got his passport. Agents representing a Hong Kong-based travel agency supplied a Chinese police officer with two of Zhang's photographs, his birth date and $2,500, he said. ``In 20 days I had my document,'' said Zhang, slapping his red Chinese passport. Zhang explained he couldn't get a passport on his own because authorities had been investigating his company for tax evasion. ``We were too successful,'' he said with a laugh. Zhang, however, may have to change his plans to return to China as a priveleged ``foreigner.'' A recent issue of the overseas edition of official Chinese newspaper People's Daily reported that Chinese were buying passports for high prices in Hong Kong and Macao. It announced that holders of such second passports could face prosecution.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Feb. 18

For Release Sunday, Feb. 18, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: At the End of the Cold War: Not Necessarily a Rainbow
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: For almost half a century, being prepared for World War III has been the military's mission and a piston driving the American economy. Moscow and Washington, East and West, stood toe-to-toe along the Iron Curtain. It took a million soldiers, 12,000 strategic nuclear warheads and a growing defense budget to keep the peace in Europe. Inside a year, the world changed. ``For eons we've been saying, `The Russians are coming, the Russians are coming,''' says Rep. Ronald Dellums, D-Calif. ``Well they haven't come, and they aren't coming.'' Defense Secretary Richard Cheney told Congress: ``We are now on the verge of winning one of the greatest victories in the history of the world without a shot ever being fired.'' Three arms treaties are being negotiated for the signatures of Presidents Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Once they are settled _ reducing the stockpiles of chemical weapons, conventional forces in Europe and long-range nuclear missiles _ the American military will be transformed in size and purpose. Yet with the outbreak of peace, as Gov. Richard Celeste of Ohio notes, ``there can be a dark side.'' Peace is not a completely comforting prospect for everyone: _Not for the 1,600 people who work in St. Louis at the Army Troop Support Command, distributor of uniforms, tents and other military supplies. The Pentagon wants to close it. _Not for the 101,000 who work for General Dynamics Corp., maker of tanks, submarines, jets and missiles in plants from Florida to California. The No. 2 defense contractor has become a symbol of the end-of-the-Cold War malady. Public relations executive Chris Schildz discourages reporters seeking interviews on how the company is going to handle it. _Not for thousands upon thousands of GIs who now must confront something that American soldiers don't usually worry about _ job security. Today's troops aren't draftees like those let go after World War II or the Korean War or Vietnam. They are volunteers. Many chose the service as a career. Demobilization, for them, is as rude a slap as a layoff for a factory worker. ``We are very well aware of the fact that this is the first time the United States of America has ever taken apart an army made up of all volunteers,'' says Lt. Gen. Gordon R. Sullivan, the Army's deputy chief of staff for operations and plans. He says it's too early to estimate how many soldiers will be let go. _Not for the 13,000 people in and around Lima, Ohio, who owe their jobs to the Army Tank Plant. It makes the M-1 Abrams tank, a 60-ton monster deemed too muscular for the lighter, more mobile Army the Pentagon envisions for the 1990s. The plant is scheduled to close in 1993. Don Downhour, a Lima resident who doesn't work at the plant, says he's sympathetic to the plight of the tank builders, but he sees another side. ``We don't need tanks if we're going to have peace,'' he muses. ``And that's what we've been praying for.'' Harry O'Brien, shop steward at the Saco Defense plant in Saco, Maine, whose mainstay is the Mk-19 grenade launcher, says his co-workers are worried by the defense cutbacks. ``Everybody is saying, `Gee, what happens if we get closed down?','' he says The diminishing of the 45-year-old threat of global war between the two superpowers is worrisome in other places, too: _In President Bush's White House. No sooner had Bush submitted his budget to Congress, calling for a slight drop in Pentagon spending next year, than he took to the road to sell Americans on a single idea: Cutting back too fast, too far is dangerous folly. _At the Pentagon, where Cheney has been carrying the Bush message to Capitol Hill. He is a man in the middle _ knowing reductions will be forced by Congress, but needing to protect Bush's cautious approach and the strategic concerns of the armed forces. _In Congress, where claimants for the ``peace dividend'' _ those who want to retire some national debt; or cut Social Security taxes; or address the problems of the homeless and ill-housed, hungry and poor; or repair decaying bridges, roads and sewage systems; or fix America's education system; or ease the medical-cost burden of the elderly _ are lining up for a piece of the pie. A pie that Bush says doesn't exist. _And again in Congress, where some foresee severe economic upheavals if defense plants and bases close suddenly and thousands of workers are left in the cold. The trouble, then, is figuring out just how much defense to drop, and where. If the Cold War is over, what is the justification for spending 25 cents of every federal dollar on defense _ half of which goes to deterring a Soviet invasion of Europe now deemed less likely than a blue moon? From the fall of the Berlin Wall in November to the Soviet Communist Party's historic decision Feb. 7 to give up its power monopoly, events in the East bloc have eroded the very underpinnings of Western strategic thinking. Indeed, the East European states no longer are a ``bloc'' in the traditional sense. In this new world order, what will the United States do with its military might? Fight terrorists? Play ``policeman'' in Third World hot spots? Revert to the isolationism so dreaded by U.S. allies in Europe and Asia? One answer may be in joining the Bush administration's war on drugs, and the president is pressing for more money to use Marines and other military resources to help keep drugs out of the country. For years the Pentagon fought the idea, arguing it would sap readiness to fight conventional wars and involve soldiers in police work, customarily a civilian concern. Those misgivings seem to have diminished. The exact features of the military transformation are not yet clear, but some signs are visible. U.S. troop strength is being cut, bases closed, weapon programs illed and security threats reassessed. Less clear is what these changes will mean for individual soldiers and their families, for communities and companies that depend on a thriving military-industrial complex, and for a NATO alliance facing possible disintegration. Bush says he hopes attrition will reduce the ranks of the military so that relatively few soldiers will have to be discharged. ``I would like to think that a kid that went in to make a career out of this would not be unceremoniously dumped from the armed services,'' he told reporters recently. As Pentagon planners redefine the military's mission, politicians are rushing to reset the nation's spending priorities. They see a new hope for social programs that took second place to the 1980s military buildup. Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., has proposed carving out a $169 billion ``peace dividend'' over the next five years _ more than quadruple the savings proposed by Bush in the same period. Rep. Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., accuses Bush of ``beating plowshares into swords.''
