DOC.HEAD: WASHN: into swords.''
DOC.TEXT: The focus on defense savings also has opened an opportunity for supporters of ``conversion'' legislation intended to ease the economy's transition from military to civilian endeavors. A bill sponsored by Rep. Ted Weiss, D-N.Y., would require defense contractors to set aside 1.25 percent of revenues to pay for economic adjustment. Laid-off workers might get 90 percent of their wages while being retrained to make civilian products. ``Maybe it's about time to redirect some of that money that has been used for national security to the security of people who live in cities across our country,'' Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn said recently. The Bush administration cautions against hopes for a peace payout. It says big savings on defense should not come until new arms controls deals are struck, the pro-democracy movements in Eastern Europe take firmer root and more doubts are erased about the future of Gorbachev. Cheney told the Senate Armed Services Committee on Feb. 1 that hasty moves to disarm could jeopardize a peaceful conclusion to the Cold War. He also cautioned that while Gorbachev has shown a will to reduce Soviet conventional forces in Europe, Moscow is modernizing its nuclear missiles capable of reaching U.S. soil. In his proposed 1991 budget presented to Congress Jan. 29, Bush set Pentagon spending at $292 billion for the fiscal year that starts Oct. 1. That's a nominal increase from the $287 billion to be spent in the current budget year, but is a 2 percent decline after the effect of inflation. Bush foresees similar cuts in each of the next several years, but critics say the pace is far too slow in light of the extraordinary political turnabout in Eastern Europe, where the Warsaw Pact has fractured and at least two Pact members _ Hungary and Czechoslovakia _ are demanding Soviet troop withdrawals. William Kaufmann, a defense analyst at the Brookings Institution think tank and a frequent consultant to the Pentagon, says the defense budget could be halved over the next nine years without risk to national security. Others counsel more caution. ``We shouldn't be so euphoric about the prospects for peace,'' says James Blackwell, a defense specialist at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. Of the Soviet threat, he says: ``It's different, but it's not gone.'' Much of the heat on Bush's defense spending priorities comes from critics who say the president is putting money in the wrong places. For example his budget proposal seeks more than $18 billion for weapons targeting Warsaw Pact forces, according to Congress' bipartisan Arms Control and Foreign Policy Caucus. That is an increase of more than $1 billion from the current budget. ``We shouldn't pour billions into new weapons systems designed to counter Warsaw Pact forces that no longer exist,'' said Rep. Howard L. Berman, D-Calif., chairman of the caucus. The percentage of Americans who want defense cuts is growing, although it's still a minority. A New York Times-CBS News poll conducted in mid-January said 36 percent of those surveyed favored a decrease in military spending, 48 percent said it should stay the same and 13 percent said it should be raised. A year earlier, 24 percent said it should be cut, 58 percent wanted it the same and 13 percent wanted an increase. Of Bush's ``big-ticket'' weapons projects, the chief candidates for congressional slashing are the Strategic Defense Initiative, or Star Wars project, to develop a space-based shield against ballistic missiles, and two new long-range missiles, the mobile MX and the smaller Midgetman. Bush requested an increase of $900 million, to $4.8 billion, for Star Wars research in the 1991 budget. Congress last year cut $1 billion from the program, which many see as a fat target for reductions given the low risk of a Soviet nuclear attack. The administration says a growing number of smaller nations are acquiring ballistic missiles, even while the superpowers are negotiating big cuts in their arsenals. So, they say, Star Wars could be used to knock down a missile fired from Iran or another hostile nation. The president also faces a tough fight in Congress over his request for billions of dollars to begin modernizing _ and, in some cases, expanding _ the network of production plants and laboratories that make U.S. nuclear weapons. Some lawmakers say they'll oppose Bush's plan to spend up to $600 million to extend the life of the Rocky Flats plutonium processing plant near Denver that cost $225 million to build but has never worked properly. The plan runs against the grain of a Democrat-led move in Congress to seek a superpower ban on production of nuclear arms materials. ``We are not exactly living at the height of the Cold War. What is the rush to build a new facility at Rocky Flats?'' asks Sen. Timothy Wirth, D-Colo. While the size and scope of defense spending cuts are debated, the military is pondering its future in a fast-changing world. Sullivan, the Army deputy chief of staff, says his service already is implementing a ``new vision'' of a smaller Army, one with more mobility and fewer foreign bases, but also one that could be easily expanded. One question on the minds of recruiters as well as soldiers who survive manpower cuts is: How's the job going to change? Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, says one new chore will be fighting the drug war. Bush's 1991 budget calls for Pentagon spending of $1.2 billion to combat illegal drugs. That's less than one-half of 1 percent of the total Defense Department budget request, but it would mean a big increase in military resources to help in drug patrols along the border with Mexico and in deployment of National Guardsmen to stop drug trafficking. Marines have been assisting Border Patrol agents in drug surveillance since last fall. Also, last summer Bush sent about $65 million worth of helicopters, weapons and other military supplies to Colombia to try to stem the flow of illegal drugs to America and to help Colombia battle its drug cartel. ``We are in this one for the long haul,'' Powell said of the Pentagon's anti-drug mission.

DOC.HEAD: Change in South African TV Brings Political Shifts to Livingrooms
DOC.TEXT: In a significant policy shift, the state-run television news is giving South Africans a chance to see for themselves the dramatic political changes taking place across the country. The extensive live broadcast of Nelson Mandela's release after 27 years in prison Feb. 11 was unprecedented for a spot news development. The South African Broadcasting Corp. scrapped much of its Sunday programming to show Mandela's walk to freedom. For South African television reporters it was a new experience; they rarely had been called upon to do live commentary. But SABC's chief political reporter, Clarence Keyter, got caught up in the excitement, repeatedly telling viewers they were about to watch history in the making. He did not have the backup that Western television correspondents have in such situations. When the Mandela story dragged _ his release was 75 minutes behind schedule _ the studio provided no pre-taped biographies of Mandela or other short features that could fill the intervals. Thus Keyter was left to think of new things to say when nothing was going on. At one point the commentator described Victor Verster prison as probably the most beautiful jail in the world. A more lively, open-minded approach to news coverage began when President F.W. de Klerk took over from P.W. Botha six months ago. Botha had kept a close watch on the domestic television service and on at least one occasion called the newsroom in mid-broadcast to order changes. The nightly television news shows had the trappings of propaganda programs, carefully filtering out disturbing scenes and opposition accusations while emphasizing the government's line on every issue. But on the night of Feb. 2, after de Klerk legalized 60 banned organizations and lifted restrictions on hundreds of government opponents, white viewers listened to televised comments from a string of black activists they had been taught were among South Africa's worst enemies. In recent months, viewers have seen throngs of blacks, chanting, singing with fists and banners raised, marching in protests that would have been mentioned _ if at all _ in a sentence or two without pictures a year ago. Much of the change is due to Carel van der Merwe, a journalist with 25 years' experience in broadcasting and newspapers, who returned to SABC as director of news last August, when de Klerk came to power. Van der Merwe's view that television journalism should be ``gripping, understandable and fair,'' has made a striking difference in what people now see on the evening news. The televising of Mandela's speech at a Cape Town rally on the day of his release, and his news conference the following day, in which he endorsed the organization's guerrilla actions, would have been illegal just a few weeks ago. U.S. television networks carried live material on Mandela's release and his address to the rally. SABC delayed its start of Mandela's address, which began while the regularly scheduled evening news was on, but switched live after the news and all that was missed were tributes at the beginning, said Rob Stevenson, SABC's evening news editor. SABC is run by a board appointed by the nation's president and, by law, has a monopoly on news broadcasting, although two independent radio stations in self-governing black homelands can be heard in some cities. During the height of political unrest in 1984-86, most South Africans never saw pictures of black protests, stonings, arson and police violence that the rest of the world saw. Government officials told them night after night that the unseen violence in their country was caused by leaders of the African National Congress and the Communist Party, who were never shown and were quoted only selectively and rarely. Sometimes the faces of people like Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu were shown speaking, while the television announcer paraphrased their words. Tutu's first voluntary appearance on SABC was last October, in a debate on religion in politics, in which he was allowed 15 unedited minutes to make his points. The experience encouraged Tutu, who had once refused to answer questions from SABC reporters, to give more interviews. ``He's still rather cautious about it, but people in the SABC have told us privately there are changes and it certainly appears to be getting out of the tight government control,'' said Tutu's spokesman, John Allen. ``The people working there appear to be conservative, but the journalists are exercising more discretion.'' Cabinet ministers who were accustomed to giving uninterrupted and unchallenged speeches in response to soft queries from TV interviewers are now being questioned on national television by black reporters and editors from newspapers the government once tried to suppress. One of the most dramatic changes in the approach to news was illustrated by a transportation strike in January, when more than 30 people were killed and millions of dollars of damage done to government-owned railroad equipment. Amid the reports of clashes and violence, the black leader of the South African Railway and Harbor Workers Union was on television, giving his side of the story. In contrast, during a mine strike in 1987, one of the costliest and longest in South African history, the leader of the black miners union was never heard from until the strike ended. ``For years they've had a kind of doctrine where the official view always takes precedence,'' said Gus Silber, a television news analyst and freelance writer. ``In any story about unrest or political controversy, they always led with the official response, the opposite way that other journalists do things.'' But Gavin Stewart, a journalism professor at Rhodes University, says: ``The new approach does not mean the SABC is independent of the government. It just happens that government policy is now more reasonable.'' ``The SABC is only changing because the official line is changing,'' agreed Silber. ``Until a couple of months ago, the official line was the ANC was a terrorist organization that was never to be spoken to. Now the ANC gets the same treatment as other organizations.'' Anti-apartheid activists are changing their attitudes, too, answering news conference questions from SABC reporters and agreeing to appear on broadcasts they once dismissed as government propaganda. ``I think people realize it makes sense to put their point of view to viewers of the SABC who haven't heard and don't usually hear it,'' said Moegsien Williams, editor of South, a newspaper the government suspended in 1988. Williams recently was part of a panel questioning Foreign Minister Pik Botha on national television. When Walter Sisulu and six other ANC leaders celebrated their release from prison in October, rally organizers refused the SABC permission to set microphones near the stage. Television showed pictures of the meeting, but could not broadcast the black leaders' words. Now Sisulu appears on television and radio regularly. Van der Merwe said the overwhelmingly positive viewer response has encouraged SABC ``to carry on trying to be a good news medium.'' To those shocked at seeing Communists and former guerrilla leaders speaking on their television screens, van der Merwe said, ``They will have to accept that their own viewpoint in life is not the only viewpoint.''

DOC.HEAD: STOCKHOLM

DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which rose to prominence by pioneering the market for high-risk junk bonds and using them to fuel the 1980s takeover boom, now finds itself looking for outside help because of its deteriorating junk bond holdings. The firm's announcement Monday that it was seeking a major investor or merger partner followed three days of marathon talks with federal regulators, who worried that a collapse of Drexel would shake public confidence in the nation's financial markets, The New York Times reported. Securities industry analysts and former Drexel executives echoed those concerns. They said the firm's difficulties with the declining junk-bond market it helped create and its 1989 guilty plea to federal securities fraud crimes could deter potential investors.

Nelson Mandela's declaration of support for nationalization of gold mines and other key assets sent shockwaves through South Africa's business world. Mandela's statement Monday on his first full day of freedom sent gold shares down 4 percent on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange. The financial rand, a special currency used to encourage foreign investment, plummeted 10 percent. Mandela told a news conference he fully supports the economic plan of his African National Congress for a state-run economy, including nationalization of mines and other major pillars of the economy.

Typical first-time buyers remained unable to enter the starter-home market in the fourth quarter of 1989 despite rising incomes and declining prices and interest rates, a real estate trade group said. The National Association of Realtors said Monday its index measuring the purchasing ability of first-time home buyers was 74.4, meaning the typical entry-level buyer had only 74.4 percent of the income needed to buy a typical starter home. The index stood at 71 in both the second and the third quarters of 1989.

Bottling of Perrier mineral water resumed and human error was regarded as the likely cause of contamination of U.S. stocks of the product with the hazardous solvent benzene, a spokesman for the company said. The spokesman said Monday that officials believed only 13 bottles had been contaminated, adding that exports to the United States and Canada would quickly resume. Source Perrier SA halted production of its mineral water over the weekend and withdrew an estimated 72 million bottles from store shelves in United States after the contamination report. The recall later was extended to Canada.

Safeway Stores, one of the nation's largest privately held companies, has announced it will sell stock to the public for the first time since a management-led buyout three years ago. The sale, announced Monday, was a show of confidence by the nation's third-largest supermarket chain that has aggressively reduced a staggering $5.7 billion debt from the 1986 leveraged deal by selling nearly half its assets.

The first trial has begun in the ``Guinness Affair'' stock manipulation case, the unprecedented white-collar scandal that rocked British business after the multibillion-dollar takeover of Distillers Co. by brewing giant Guinness PLC. Eight men, including Guinness' former chairman Ernest Saunders, went on trial Monday for alleged involvement in a scheme to purchase Guinness shares during the 1986 takeover fight for Distillers, a Scotch whisky and gin maker, in an attempt to boost Guinness' stock price. The defendants allegedly aimed to make Guinness' $4.3 billion cash and stock bid more attractive than a rival offer from supermarket operator Argyll Group PLC.

A jury has ruled that Monsanto Co. was not liable for alleged damages to residents whose homes were built near a toxic waste dump. The verdict Monday came in a case in which 222 homeowners had sought $335 million from the chemical company, the chief user of the dump. Past and present residents of the subdivision in southeast Houston sued Monsanto after learning much of the toxic waste in the dump came from the chemical company.

Top U.S. and Soviet trade officials have begun negotiations aimed at wiping away nearly a half-century of trade frictions between the two superpowers by the time of the Bush-Gorbachev summit in June. Both sides expressed optimism Monday that a new trade treaty could be completed by then even though the complexity of the talks was highlighted by the size of the delegations and the length of the negotiating agenda.

Time Warner Inc. said it lost $317 million in the fourth quarter and $987 million for all of 1989 because of costs related to its $14 billion acquisition of Warner Communications Inc. Despite the loss, reported Monday, securities analysts said they were satisfied with the results because Time Warner's cash flow _ which is crucial for paying off its $10.6 billion in debt _ was strong. Time Warner, formerly Time Inc., completed its acquisition of Warner Communications on Jan. 10 after having acquired more than half of Warner's shares in a tender offer last July.

The stock market, beset by renewed interest-rate and recession worries, declined broadly Monday in the quietest session so far this year. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 45.50 points last week, fell 29.06 to 2,619.14. The dollar ended narrowly higher against most key currencies. Bond prices fell sharply. Platinum futures prices jumped after Nelson Mandela endorsed anti-apartheid violence and nationalization of South Africa's mining operations; oil futures fell; coffee futures rose; grains and soybeans were mostly higher; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Wells-Gardner Returns to Making TV's the American Way
DOC.TEXT: Wells-Gardner Electronics Corp. manufactured televisions before the Japanese were even a blip on the industry screen. Now, they're hoping to stage a comeback with a new line of U.S.-made sets. The accent is decidedly American in the company's deal with Majestic Industries Inc., a year-old Maryland-based independent distributor managed by a team of former RCA executives. Stamped ``Made in America,'' the new televisions will be built at Wells-Gardner's plant on Chicago's northwest side and marketed to middle America _ rural residents and suburbanites who prefer old-fashioned console-model TV sets. Some parts will be made in places like Taiwan, Mexico and Malaysia, but the full assembly process will take place at the 275,000 square-foot plant, Richard Conquest, the company's chief financial officer, said in a telephone interview Monday. The company doesn't have any intention of trying to compete head-on against Japanese giants like Sony and Mitsubishi, Conquest said. Instead, he said Wells-Gardner simply wants to get back into a business where it once played a leading role _ supplying private-label televisions. ``That's our cup of tea,'' Conquest said. ``We're really excited about it.'' The three-year Wells-Gardner contract is designed to fill an industry void, said James Schwab, president of Majestic. ``What we saw was that with the basic marketing, most television manufacturing was aimed at the top 200-300 retailers, so their sales, planning, and product offerings were aimed at the top retailers,'' he said. ``This left a void with the independent retailer, who needs local support from an independent distributor,'' Schwab said. Seventy percent of the sets Wells-Gardner plans to make will be traditional console models. They will be sold under the Majestic name through independent dealers rather than mass retailers like Sears, Roebuck and Co. and J.C. Penney Co. Production starts this week, with 24,000 to 30,000 sets scheduled to be built in the first year, Conquest said. The sets should become available to consumers within a month. ``It will add approximately $10 million to our 1990 sales,'' Conquest said. That would represent about 30 percent of 1989's estimated sales of $35 million. For now, Wells-Gardner doesn't have any plans to build TVs for other distributors, officials said, but the company might consider similar deals in the future with retailers like Highland, Silo and Fretters. Wells-Gardner was founded in 1924 as a radio manufacturer. The company diversified in the television age and was one of the first makers of black-and-white sets. It was a major manufacturer of sets sold in stores like Sears and Penney's, Conquest said. ``Then in the 1970s, the Japanese came in and we got out of the TV business,'' he said, explaining that the company couldn't compete with cheaper overseas labor costs. At the end of the 1970s, the company decided to try again and began assembling sets for Fujitsu's Teknika division. But the Japanese company, deterred by high import duties and U.S. labor costs, decided not to renew the contract in 1988, Conquest said. In the meantime, Wells-Gardner has focused its energies on making monitors for coin-operated video games, which account for about 60 percent of its sales. It hopes the new deal will bring stability and help reduce its dependence on the cyclical video game industry, said President Frank J. Myers. The company rejoins an industry now dominated by foreign-owned firms like RCA and Sony, and Glenview, Ill.-based Zenith Electronics Corp. Zenith is the only remaining American-owned manufacturer of color TVs that also makes most of its parts, said Bob Violino, associate editor at Television Digest, a weekly newsletter that tracks the consumer electronics industry. Only a handful of smaller firms, like Wells-Gardner, also assemble their own sets in this country, he said. Wells-Gardner's re-entry won't ``cut into any of these other companies' shares,'' Violino said. Zenith does not expect the move to affect its business, company spokesman John Taylor said.

DOC.HEAD: Perrier Recall Could Leave French Company Dry
DOC.TEXT: Source Perrier SA's lion's share of the U.S. bottled water market could begin to evaporate if its recall of the popular Perrier brand because of benzene contamination lasts for two months, marketing experts say. The bubbly water is being kept out of stores, restaurants and bars in the United States and Canada after North Carolina officials found some bottles tainted with small amounts of benzene. Perrier said it believes an employee mistakenly used a product containing the cancer-causing chemical to clean grease from one bottling line, whose production was destined only for North America. A spokesman for the French Health Ministry said there was no contamination at the spring from which the sparkling water flows. Although the benzene levels were relatively low _ about two to four times the five parts per billion level allowable under Food and Drug Administration standards _ Perrier said it requested the recall late Friday to restore consumer confidence. The company's U.S. subsidiary, Perrier Group of America Inc., said Monday it expects to keep the product out of U.S. and Canadian markets for up to two or three months. However, a spokesman for the parent company in Paris said the green bottles could be back on North American store shelves in a week or two. ``The timing is more of a problem than the benzene,'' said Al Ries, chairman of Trout & Ries Inc., a Greenwich, Conn., marketing strategy firm. He said the absence of Perrier for any extended time will severely test the loyalty of many consumers, who may be used to drinking the sparking water several times a week. Perrier, which turned bottled water into a status symbol several years ago, accounts for nearly a quarter of the estimated $2.2 billion in annual bottled water sales in the United States, according to the New York-based Beverage Marketing Corp. ``Brands are badges,'' said Ries. ``By that I mean when you sit at a restaurant table and order a brand by name it says something about you personally. Not being available will force the consumer to ask for another brand name. And the smart competitior is going to move in.'' Gary M. Stibel, principal of New England Consulting Group of Westport, Conn., agreed: ``It's a godsend trial opportunity for its competitors ... if they're smart enough to take advantage of it.'' But experts questioned whether the numerous other smaller bottled water companies were strong enough to fill the temporary void left by Perrier. ``No one in the marketplace has seen fit to build a strong No. 2 brand in America if Perrier goes flat,'' said Ries.``Distribution is the key. The product has to be out there, and the product has to be widely available.'' There are about 450 water bottling plants in the United States, producing more than 600 different brand labels of drinking water, natural water and spring water, according to Bevmark Inc., a Los Angeles-based consulting firm. In addition, there are more than 50 brands of imported waters, Bevmark said. Perrier also markets Poland Spring, Calistoga and Arrowhead bottled waters. Key brand competitors include Evian and Saratoga, both owned by BSN of France, and San Pellegrino of Italy. David S. Daniel, chief executive officer of Evian Waters of France Inc., said his company had no intention of capitalizing on Perrier's problems, although it plans to launch a major new advertising campaign in the next two weeks. He said it was coincidence the campaign was starting right after the Perrier recall. ``Right now we don't see any real need to change our strategy or adjust our spending,'' Daniel said. ``It's pretty much business as usual.'' Many marketing experts likened Perrier's problem to that of Johnson & Johnson, which recalled its Tylenol pain killer in 1982 after some capsules were tainted with cyanide, resulting in several deaths. Some of the marketers criticized Perrier's relatively low-key public relations approach to the problem, which seemed to contrast with Johnson & Johnson's full-scale public information campaign. That campaign was credited with helping the company regain market share following the Tylenol scare. But others said Perrier's total recall _ even though only a dozen bottles were believed to be contaminated _ was more than enough to reassure consumers.

DOC.HEAD: Drexel Seeking Major Investor or Merger Partner
With PM-Drexel-Glance
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which rose to prominence by pioneering the market for high-risk junk bonds and using them to fuel the 1980s takeover boom, now finds itself looking for outside help because of its deteriorating junk bond holdings. The firm's announcement Monday that it was seeking a major investor or merger partner followed three days of marathon talks with federal regulators, who worried that a collapse of Drexel would shake public confidence in the nation's financial markets, The New York Times reported. Securities industry analysts and former Drexel executives echoed those concerns. They said the firm's difficulties with the declining junk-bond market it helped create and its 1989 guilty plea to federal securities fraud crimes could deter potential investors. ``At this point I think the biggest problem is the loss of confidence in them,'' said Chris Mahoney, a securities industry analyst with Moody's Investors Service. ``Who would want to do business with them if they were a risk not to make it?'' Drexel announcement was another sign of decline at the firm once so sure of itself that it made commitments to raise hundreds of millions of dollars by merely saying it was ``highly confident'' in its abilities. Analysts said Drexel's capital base been reduced to ``a minimum level'' and that without an infusion the firm could fail to meet federal capital requirements. Individuals familiar with Drexel's internal problems said confidence was at an all-time low and several key executives had left in recent months. Pending litigation from its fraud woes also still plague the firm, which has shrunk to 5,300 employees from a peak of 10,700. ``Financial service companies are confidence and people,'' one former Drexel executive said. ``There's obviously no confidence and the best people have left.'' Led by junk-bond chief Michael Milken, who pioneered use of the low-grade debt securities for multibillion-dollar takeovers but left after his indictment last year on fraud and racketeering charges, Drexel was a symbol of the high-flying, takeover-driven 1980s. But the departure of Milken and other top performers combined with the big slump in the nation's $210 billion junk bond market has hit Drexel hard. Its large positions in corporate junk bonds have nosedived, weakening the firm's capital base. ``There's no other line of business to keep them strong in order to make up the difference,'' said analyst Lawrence Eckenfelder of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. The firm's total capitalization _ the money it relies on to back its commitments and meet any losses _ shrank to $1.7 billion at the end of 1989 from $1.96 billion in 1988, leading to rumors on Wall Street that Drexel was on the verge of being sold or collapsing. Drexel is the biggest player in the junk bond market, so if its financial straits forced it to sell its holdings, prices could drop sharply in a junk market already weakened by months of bad news. In Monday's statement, Drexel said its senior members had concluded it should seek outside assistance because ``unsettled markets, particularly in the high-yield area, have adversely affected the liquidity'' of its parent, Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. Drexel said its securities subsidiary ``continues to have good liquidity and has satisfactory excess regulatory capital.'' The firm last week began to shift cash to the strapped parent from its securities subsidiary, but the move alarmed officials at the Federal Reserve and the Securities and Exchange Commission, who feared it might weaken the subsidiary, the Times reported. On Monday, Drexel agreed with the government to sell assets and raise bank loans to keep the firm afloat, the Times said. The Fed requested that Citibank, Drexel's chief bank for years, and Morgan Guaranty provide financing while Drexel gets its house in order, the newspaper said. Fed and SEC officials remain directly involved in efforts to rescue Drexel, the newspaper said. A Drexel spokesman said the firm was acting on its own initiative to raise capital. ``We've been in touch with the regulators all along,'' spokesman Steven Anreder said. ``I don't think they're dictating what we do as a business entity.'' Federal Reserve spokesman Joseph Coyne said he was unaware of any such role by the Fed. Mary McCue, a spokeswoman for the Securities and Exchange Commission, declined to comment. The Times also reported that the New York Stock Exchange had set up a crisis center on Drexel and that exchange chairman John Phelan had assured the exchange's board of governors that the firm's problems were being tackled. Exchange spokeswoman Sharon Gamsin declined to comment on the report, saying only that ``Drexel Burnham is currently a member in good standing.'' Jeffrey Bowman, a vice president at Standard & Poor's Corp., said the firm's capital is ``at a minimum level.'' After Drexel's announcement, S&P downgraded its rating on $200 million of the firm's commercial paper to ``single B'' from ``A-3.'' Securities firms rely on the issuance of commercial paper to finance their business, and the rating downgrade would force Drexel to pay higher interest on its borrowings. ``Repayment of outstanding commercial paper will depend on the firm's ability to negotiate a capital infusion or alternative sources of liquidity,'' S&P said. Drexel reported a loss of $40 million on $4.1 billion in revenue for last year, when it paid $650 million to settle the fraud charges, slashed its work force by nearly one half, sold its retail brokerage business and overhauled its internal operations under a civil settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The firm had made a net profit of $523 million _ $951 million before taxes _on revenue of $5.3 billion in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Judge Approves Federated Plan
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Bankruptcy Court judge has given Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allies Stores Corp. permission to obtain $2.4 billion in financing to help them carry out Chapter 11 reorganization. Orders approving the loan petitions were entered by the court clerk's office Monday. U.S Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. had signed them after the office's closing time Friday. The filing allowed Federated and Allied to beat the Wednesday deadline banks had imposed for proceeding with the loans. Citibank of New York heads a 90-bank group providing $2.1 billion. Chemical Bank of New York is providing the other $300 million. Separately, Nieman Marcus Group sued the two retailing chains, claiming they hired their new chairman by luring him away from Nieman Marcus in violation of his contract. Neiman Marcus, part of General Cinema Corp. of Newton, Mass., said it filed the suit in state court in Dallas, Texas, where the department store group is based. Named as defendants along with Federated and Allied was Olympia & York Developments Ltd., the Canadian property developing company that provided a $250 million cash infusion last year to Campeau Corp., the Toronto-based owner of Allied and Federated. Neiman Marcus accused the defendants of ``tortious interference'' in enticing Allen Questrom to become the chairman and chief executive officer of Federated and Allied. The suit said Questrom's contract with Nieman Marcus ran until September 1991. Federated, which operates five department store chains, received permission to obtain $400 million in cash and letters of credit for working capital and $1 billion for a credit subsidiary that buys receivables. Allied, which operates four department store chains, received approval to obtain $300 million in cash and letters of credit and $700 million for its receivables facilities. Federated and Allied employ about 100,000 people and operate 260 stores. They listed debts totaling $7.7 billion in their Jan. 15 Chapter 11 filing. Officials of the two sister companies, which make up the U.S. retail division of Toronto-based Campeau Corp., spent two days last week telling Aug the financing packages were the best they could obtain. Aug heard more than 10 hours of testimony over two days before granting approval. He said he thought the retailers had met minimum standards in their arguments, and praised both sides for agreeing to ``a productive compromise.'' The stores comprising Federated are Abraham and Straus and Bloomingdale's of New York, Burdine's of Miami, Lazarus of Cincinnati, and Rich's of Atlanta. The Bon Marche of Seattle, Jordan Marsh of Boston, Maas Brothers of Tampa, and Stern's of Paramus, N.J., are in the Allied group.

DOC.HEAD: Company Going Public Once Again
DOC.TEXT: Safeway Stores' plans to issue a modest amount of stock to the public marks the beginning of the final chapter in one of the nation's most successful leveraged buyouts. ``I don't know of any leveraged buyouts that have numbers like they have,'' said Brian Suher, an analyst with the brokerage Black & Co. in Portland, Ore. Suher was referring to Safeway's reduction of a staggering $5.7 billion buyout debt to $3.1 billion and its surging operating profits in the past year. The Oakland-based chain achieved the turnaround largely by eliminating its least profitable stores in reducing the size of the chain from 2,326 stores to 1,117. Analysts for the past year have praised the buyout for forcing Safeway to accelerate a restructuring and trim itself quickly to its most profitable core. Chairman and Chief Executive Peter Magowan recently boasted that although sales last year were $14.3 billion, Safeway's operating income was greater than when it posted annual sales of $20 billion. Those numbers are the stuff of dreams that fueled the buyout craze of the 1980s. In a leveraged buyout, a small group of investors acquires a company in a transaction financed largely by borrowing. The debt, often nearly crippling, is repaid with money generated by the acquired company's operations or the sale of its assets. The LBO, as its commonly known, is often used by management to retain control of a company threatened by a hostile suitor. The idea is for the company to re-emerge later as a public one, stronger and more profitable and thereby less subject to takeovers. The ability of a company to re-enter the public market also is crucial to managers' hopes of eventually cashing in their stakes and reaping big profits from the turnaround. The stock sale, announced Monday and the first since the Nov. 30, 1986 buyout, was a show of confidence by the nation's third-largest supermarket chain. The offering of 10 million shares of new common stock will sell for between $13 and $16 a share. After the offering, the company will have 100 million shares outstanding. Company officials and those at Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Co., the New York investment firm that managed the buyout, said Monday they could not comment publicly on the offering because of restraints by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The remaking of Safeway began in July 1986 with a hostile tender offer from the Dart Group Corp., led by Herbert and Robert Haft. That attempt forced Safeway to agree to be acquired by Kohlberg Kravis that fall for $69 a share. The deal left Safeway management in command and offered certain officers the right to buy 10 percent of the now closely held concern. The deal also left Safeway burdened with debt: a staggering $45 in debt for each dollar in equity, one of the highest such ratios ever in a large deal. To restore profitability, Safeway has been building larger stores, called ``super'' stores, that offer specialty departments such as bakeries, delicatessens, pharmacies, seafood counters and floral and wine shops. To offer more services and longer hours, Safeway employees' hours have gone up 23 percent per store in the past two years. Safeway was able to win significant contract concessions from its unions, and wages are now only slightly higher than in 1986. The buyout has been lauded as mutually beneficial by both Safeway and Kohlberg Krravis, which also acquired RJR Nabisco in the nation's biggest leveraged buyout after a fierce bidding contest. In most cases, Safeway sold operations that were underperforming. Exceptions were Safeway stores in Britain, which garnered a strong price, and 172 Southern California stores sold to the Von Cos. in a $408 million deal. That transaction also made Safeway the largest shareholder in Vons, the biggest supermarket chain in the Los Angeles area. ``The performance improvement is nothing short of sensational, but more importantly the public has endorsed their operating formats,'' Suher said. ``They're having marvelous increases because they have changed from a behemoth that was insensitive to a corporation very, very sensitive to consumers and communities.'' Safeway finished the year with a $3 million profit on $14.3 billion in sales, its first profitable year since the buyout. Operating profits jumped 42 percent for the year to $463 million, and 80.5 percent in the fourth quarter to $139 million.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Stocks Fall in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against the yen for the second consecutive trading day today, and the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index declined moderately. The dollar closed at 144.48 yen, down 0.24 yen from Friday's close of 144.72 yen. After opening at 144.53 yen, the dollar was traded in a narrow range of 144.35 to 144.63 yen. It now has lost 1.02 yen in two trading days. Markets were closed Monday for a national holiday. Currency dealers said the yen's relative strength against the dollar reflects the market's confidence that the governing Liberal Democratic Party is likely to retain a parliamentary majority in Sunday's elections. They also said investors bought the Japanese currency to correct their long-mark, short-yen positions, accumulated in a recent mark-buying boom. Akihiko Hori, a dealer with Mitsui Bank, said he expected no major movements in dollar-yen rates until after the election. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which shed 228.10 points last Friday, fell another 181.11 points, or 0.48 percent, closing at 37,107.03 yen. Dealers said share prices generally remained weak as many investors retreated to the sidelines with the lower house elections only five days away. Investors also were discouraged by a 29.06-point decline in the Dow Jones Industrial Average on Wall Street overnight, said a dealer with a major Japanese securities firm on condition of anonymity. ``No one wants to take part in trading today,'' said a dealer with Nikko Securities Co., also requesting anonymity. ``With the national election in sight, we do not expect any increase at least until it is over.'' Volume traded on the exchange's first section was estimated at 300 million shares, compared with Friday's 364.37 million shares. It was the lowest volume since Aug. 28, when 313.60 million shares changed hands.

DOC.HEAD: Paper Merger Heats Up on Several Fronts
DOC.TEXT: Georgia-Pacific Corp. and Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. intensified their merger fight, accusing each other of wrongdoing shortly after Georgia-Pacific sold off assets in three states to eliminate a potential antitrust problem. Great Northern said Georgia-Pacific and three of its key executives have lied during the $3.8 billion takeover attempt. Georgia-Pacific then accused Great Northern's directors of breaching their fiduciary duty by resisting the offer. Most of the developments on Monday were in federal court in Portland, where Great Northern told U.S. District Judge Gene Carter that Georgia-Pacific's tender offer should be blocked because the hostile suitor has lied about an alleged plan to sell Great Northern's mills in Millinocket and East Millinocket as well as 2.1 million acres of Maine. ``G-P is lying. They're not telling you their true plans,'' said Great Northern attorney Bernard Nussbaum, of New York. Nussbaum asked Carter for a preliminary injunction halting the merger attempt as well as Georgia-Pacific's efforts to oust the Great Northern board at a special shareholders meeting on March 2 in Portland. Georgia-Pacific attorney Stuart J. Baskin accused Great Northern of ``pandering to the poor people in Maine'' through an unfair motion that has no basis in law. Baskin, also of New York, said Georgia-Pacific has produced depositions and affidavits from 14 people, including Georgia-Pacific executives, consultants and bankers, who dispute Great Northern's contentions about a planned sale of the Maine properties. Great Northern said Georgia-Pacific has violated federal securities laws by trying to cover up its alleged plans. Nussbaum, citing documents dating to at least 1984, said false statements have come from three Georgia-Pacific officials, Chairman T. Marshall Hahn Jr. and executive vice presidents A.D. ``Pete'' Correll Jr. and James C. Van Meter. Georgia-Pacific spokeswoman Gail Smith said the company stands by all of its sworn statements. The judge said he would rule as quickly as possible. After Monday's contentious hearing, lawyers met in chambers with the judge and agreed to unseal a motion for a preliminary injunction filed last month by Georgia-Pacific. It alleges Great Northern's directors have breached their fiduciary duty by resisting the tender offer. Great Northern has called the $63-a-share offer inadequate. But Georgia-Pacific said that Great Northern's investment banker, Goldman Sachs & Co., conducted a study last spring that put the value of Great Northern's stock at somewhere between $46.39 per share and $68.75 per share. The motion asks the judge to force Great Northern to rule out the use of its ``poison pill'' bylaws that are designed to thwart a hostile takeover and to strike down ``golden parachute'' payments that will be given to Great Northern's executives if they lose their jobs in the battle. Georgia-Pacific also asked the judge to force Great Northern's directors to refrain from using Maine's anti-takeover act to block the merger and to correct alleged misleading statements about its plans to invest money that would rebuild its aging mill in Millinocket. Georgia-Pacific has called Great Northern's previously announced plans for Maine ``a pipe dream.'' Great Northern issued a statement that said the Goldman Sachs study was ``stale'' and ``originally prepared for a different purpose than evaluating a bid for the company.'' Georgia-Pacific acknowledged that it did not know what methodology was used in computing the stock value. Also Monday, Great Northern filed papers saying it wanted to pursue a speedy appeal of an order last week from Carter, who ruled it will take just a two-thirds vote by Great Northern's shareholders to oust the Great Northern board. Great Northern's bylaws called for a three-fourths vote, but the judge agreed with Georgia-Pacific that two-thirds was the most allowed under Maine corporate law. The judge also ruled that shareholders and not the outgoing board members, can immediately replace the directors, if they are ousted, as he struck down other aspects of Great Northern's bylaws. Before the court battle on Monday, Georgia-Pacific announced it had agreed to sell safety-paper operations in Vermont, Iowa and New York to remove an antitrust question in the takeover attempt. The company said it was selling facilities in Gilman, Vt., and Burlington, Iowa, to Seattle-based Simpson Paper Co., for a price that would not be disclosed unless lawyers are forced to do so in a separate lawsuit in federal court in Bridgeport, Conn. The deal also calls for the sale of two wet process machines and a precision sheeter in Warwick, N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: Dealers Appear Cool to Opening Quick Oil Change
DOC.TEXT: The nation's auto dealers are approaching the Big Three's quick oil-change operation offers cautiously, wondering if the investment is worth the return. General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. are offering packages to dealers who want to offer oil changes that would take about a half hour and cost around $20. Typically, quick oil changes involve a new oil filter, oil, spot lubrication on doors and some suspension joints, filling brake and windshield washer reservoirs and checking tire pressure. Dozens of companies have sprung up nationwide offering the service in drive-through bays, and the idea is a topic among members of the National Automobile Dealers Association, which is holding its annual convention here. The idea is to get consumers into the dealership's service area on a routine, non-warranty basis. That can result in increased service or parts business and quickly become the bread and butter for the dealers. Many of the nation's 20,000-plus auto dealers, about half of whom are not making money, rely on profits generated by their parts and service departments to keep them financially afloat. The setup also would profit the automakers' in-house parts operations. But money stands in the way for Tony Fuentes, general manager of Don Thornton Ford of Tulsa, Okla. He said the Ford program, which includes a lift, close-at-hand tools and parts, would cost him $24,000. ``In the past,'' he said, ``people would not think of a dealership for this stuff. You went to dealerships for warranty work. ``Once the warranty expires, bang, they go off to an independent'' mechanic. Wayne Phillips, a consultant for the NADA, said he's found that dealers are interested in the operations, but cautious about them. ``In some areas, it can be a very profitable thing,'' he said, especially if the dealership is on a busy street. Ford was the first to offer quick oil changes nationwide. Five dealer in Chicago had it in June 1988. That number grew to 25 by October 1988. General Motors Corp. started a pilot program at about 100 dealerships in and around four manor cities in 1989 and Chrysler Corp. also has some dealers offering the service. Dealers are approaching the offers in a variety of methods. Colonial Dodge in Rockville, Md., offers an oil change and quick lubrication for $9.95. ``We want more traffic in the back'' of the service department, where more expensive work is performed, said Al Briggs, general manager of the dealership. George Hornbeck III, owner of Hornbeck Chevrolet-Cadillac in Carbondale, Pa., isn't interested in the operations. ``I kind of think I'm not going to go that way,'' he said. ``I'm not ready to put that money out for something I already do.''

DOC.HEAD: Big Financial Firm, Drexel Client, Seeks Bankruptcy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with quotes, details from filing papers, financial background, list of top creditors; No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Drexel
DOC.TEXT: Integrated Resources Inc., once the nation's biggest seller of tax-sheltered investments, sought federal bankruptcy protection today after talks with creditors collapsed on restructuring more than $1 billion in debt, much of it in high-yield junk bonds. The troubled financial firm's filing came a day after Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the Wall Street junk bond giant that has foundered because of scandal and financial problems, said it was seeking financial help. Integrated was an important Drexel client. Integrated's filing under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy laws protects the real estate and financial services company from creditors while it continues to operate and attempts to reorganize its finances. The company said none of its subsidiaries and affiliates is included in the filing, made in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. ``We came to the conclusion probably a couple months ago that we'd have to file eventually in order to deal with issues unrelated to a consensual restructuring of the debt,'' Integrated Chairman Stephen D. Weinroth said in an interview. Weinroth said the company was forced into the filing because several creditors who refused to negotiate a restructuring had filed or planned to file legal complaints seeking more than $40 million owed by the firm. Trading in Integrated was halted today on the New York Stock Exchange. Integrated closed at 25 cents a share on Monday. Integrated originally was a real estate company and expanded rapidly several years ago by selling tax-sheltered investments, but that business was scuttled by 1986 tax-law revisions. The company then moved aggressively into insurance and mutual funds, financed largely through junk bonds arranged by Drexel. Integrated said negotiations for restructuring $1.008 billion in debt had been progressing but a few creditors refused to participate in the talks. The company said those creditors had the ability to seize Integrated's assets to satisfy their individual claims. About $800 million of the debt was in junk bonds, the bulk of it sold by Drexel, whose parent company said today it too is considering filing for Chapter 11 protection. ``We were spending too much time and too much money trying to stave off actions where the ultimate outcome was not in doubt,'' Weinroth said. ``Sooner or later they were going to get a judgment. Working out a consensual out-of- court reorganization depends on the good faith of substantially all the creditors.'' According to court papers filed this morning, Integrated also has $610 million in subordinated debt outstanding. Weinroth said the firm's assets currently are about $1 billion less than liabilities. According to its balance sheet for June 1989, the most recent filed, Integrated had total assets of $1.4 billion and a negative net worth of $558 million. Its total debt was $1.62 billion. The firm has estimated it lost about $1 billion in the second quarter and the company is estimating a large loss _ believed to be around $200 million _ for the 1989 third quarter. According to the bankruptcy court papers, Integrated said its top 10 creditors included large banks and savings and loans, which bought much of the junk-bond debt issued by Drexel under its indicted former bond leader Michael Milken. Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. led all creditors with a total owed of $55.84 million, followed by Chemical Bank with $51.57 million. The rest of the top 10 were: Executive Life Insurance Co., $48.8 million in long-term public debt; Hong Kong Shanghai Banking Corp., $45 million in public and private debt; Drexel, $41.105 million in total debt exposure; Imperial Savings and Loan, $39.98 million in public debt; Centrust Savings and Loan, $39 million in public debt; Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, $33.195 million total; USX Portfolio Inc., $24.09 million in commercial paper; and Mellon Bank, $22.596 million total. Earlier this year, Integrated sold its key financial services businesses to Broad Inc., a Los Angeles financial services concern, for $95 million. The company had hoped to receive about $450 million for the units. Other units were either liquidated or sold to other parties and Weinroth said the firm has sold about $175 million in assets so far. Integrated said it expects to resume talks with creditors soon.

DOC.HEAD: Digital Announces Venture in Hungary
DOC.TEXT: Digital Equipment Corp., plagued recently by slow U.S. sales, today formally announced formation of a joint venture company to sell and service its computer systems in Hungary. Digital, the world's second largest computer company behind International Business Machines Corp., said in a news release from Budapest that the new venture called Digital Equipment (Hungary) Ltd. will begin operations April 2. ``History has shown that information technology can often be a lubricant of change,'' said Alberto Fresco, vice president and country group manager of Digital in Europe. ``As Hungary moves forward with its plans to restructure its economy, computers will play an important role ...'' The opening of new markets in Eastern Europe would be a welcome development for U.S. computer makers, which have been mired in a slump. Digital reported last month that its profit for the October-December quarter fell 44 percent from a year earlier because of the slow U.S. computer market. ``Eastern Europe represents one of the few untapped markets that have long-term potential,'' said Terry Shannon, an analyst with International Data Corp., a computer market researcher in Framingham. ``Given the changes in the geopolitical climate, this is laudatory on Digital's part,'' Shannon said. Digital will control the Hungarian venture, owning 51 percent. It has the option of acquiring 100 percent of the joint venture company and forming a wholly owned subsidiary in the future. The remaining 49 percent will be split equally between KFKI, a research institute of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences, and Szamalk, a software company. Digital, based in the Boston suburb of Maynard, explored the possibility of doing business in Eastern Europe about a year ago by sending representatives to Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary. The group found that Hungary was furthest along in political and economic reforms and had relatively strong development in technology. Digital's activity in Eastern Europe has been severely limited since the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan in 1979 prompted tighter U.S. trade restrictions with the Eastern bloc. Before then, however, Digital had ``significant business'' in that region, said Robert Krause, senior trade representative for Digital. The company now hopes restrictions will be eased by the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, an agency with representatives from most NATO countries, Japan and Australia, that regulates what technology can be exported to Eastern Europe. Although Digital has been unable to sell much of its equipment in Eastern Europe, its machinery has been imported through illicit channels, and computer makers there have tried to duplicate Digital products. Fredrickson, the Digital spokesman, said the company has not decided whether to service those machines. Shannon, the analyst, said, ``I wouldn't recognize the existence of a pirated machine.'' But Shannon added that even if Digital does not service the equipment, it will have an advantage in marketing its products because ``the illicit base creates a familiarity with Digital hardware and operating systems.''

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Selling Gulfstream Aerospace for $825 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with Paulson saying that he and Forstmann have made a $60 million bid to buy Lear Jet, inserts 1 new graf after 9th graf pvs, `The capital ...' Picks up 10th graf pvs, `Chrysler said ...
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. today said it has agreed to sell Gulfstream Aerospace Corp. for $825 million to a partnership of Gulfstream Chairman Allen E. Paulson and the New York investment firm Forstmann, Little & Co. ``Allen Paulson certainly knows Gulfstream and its strengths,'' Chrysler Chairman Lee A. Iacocca said in announcing the deal. Iacocca said proceeds of the all cash transaction would go to general operations of the company. ``We're happy with the price,'' he said. Chrysler purchased the Savannah, Ga. maker of corporate jets in 1985 for $637 million. The deal is not subject to any financing conditions nor will it be financed with any junk bonds, Forstmann Little and Paulson said in a news release. The partners jointly will provide all of the equity while Forstmann will supply the subordinated debt, bringing its total investment in Gulfstream to about half of the purchase price. The balance of the financing has been promised by Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. Paulson, commenting on the deal, said: ``Aviation is my life. I've been at it since I was 18. Many well known organizations offered to be my partner in buying Gulfstream, but I chose to team up with Forstmann Little. ``The capital structure of our company, which will have no junk financing whatsoever, will allow us to invest in the continued growth of the G-IV program, as well as new technologically advanced products,'' said Paulson who founded Gulfstream. In a related development, Paulson said that he and Forstmann have made a bid to buy Lear Jet for $60 million. He said at a news conference in Savannah that Gulfstream and the Wichita, Kansas-based Lear could share engineering and marketing technology. Chrysler said Dec. 6 it was considering selling its Chrysler Technologies Corp. subsidiary, of which Gulfstream is a part, to raise cash. Gulfstream chairman Allen Paulson said at the time he was negotiating with an investment firm to prepare a bid. Chrysler Technologies also includes Electrospace Systems Inc., a defense electronics company headquartered in Richardson, Texas, which is still for sale, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: IBM Says It Has Produced 16-Million-Bit Computer Chip
DOC.TEXT: IBM said today that it has become the first company to start pilot production of a 16-million-bit computer memory chip, which has four times the memory capacity of today's most advanced chips. Currently, the largest-capacity chips in commercial use hold 4 million bits of information. A bit is the smallest piece of information processed by a computer, and can be thought of as the digits 1 or 0. It represents an electrical switch either being turned on or off. A 16-million-bit chip can store the equivalent of about 1,600 pages of double-spaced, typewritten text. International Business Machines Corp. announced just last June that it had started commercial production of the 4-million-bit chip. IBM spokesman Paul Bergevin said the company, based in Armonk, N.Y., has been researching 16-million-bit chips for several years. The company said it recently began producing the chips on a trial basis at its semiconductor plant in Essex Junction, Vt., on an existing chip assembly line. Bergevin said commercial, volume production of the new chip could be 18 months to two years away. All the chips IBM makes are used in its own computers. Other companies are known to be working on 16-million-bit chips, but none so far has announced production, Bergevin said. Last month, IBM announced that it had entered into a joint venture with Siemens AG, the large West Germany electronics company, to develop a 64-million-bit chip, which would be the next gereration of chips. Because of the way chips are constructed, advances usually take place in intervals of four times greater capacity than the previous generation.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Aide Says Lincoln Spent $55 Million in Exam
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 8 grafs new with today's testimony; picks up 7th graf pvs, I'm trying. This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Lincoln Savings and Loan Association spent $55 million _ more than Phoenix millionaire Charles H. Keating Jr. paid for the thrift _ in an 18-month battle with federal examiners over its loans and investments, Keating's key aide said today. Judith Wischer, president of the thrift's holding company, American Continental Corp., testified in U.S. District Court that an examination expected to be a routine six-month audit escalated into a ``battle of experts.'' Testifying on Keating's suit to undo the government's takeover of the Irvine, Calif., thrift last April, Mrs. Wischer said the government auditors had little or no experience with Lincoln's investments in bonds or large loans for commercial real estate and construction projects. ``It's a shocking number,'' she said of Lincoln's cost in answering questions and demands by the examiners. ``We hired experts to critique the reports their experts critiqued. We estmate the 18-month examination cost of $55 million.'' Keating has said previously that he viewed the 1986-87 exam as harassment and has cited it as a reason for taking his case against the regulators to members of Congress whose political campaigns he helped finance. Mrs. Wischer testified earlier that Lincoln's 26 branches in the Los Angeles area were ``run down'' and ``dirty'' when Keating bought the thrift in February 1984 for $51 million. ``It was a dying institution,'' she said. ``The operation side was almost non-existent. They were still operating with manual typewriters, had no ATMs (automatic teller machines) and no communications system for relaying messages quickly between branches and headquarters.'' Government attorneys repeatedly objected Monday to questions by Keating's lawyers to Mrs. Wischer about a four-year running battle between Lincoln and its regulators. However, U.S. District Court Judge Stanley Sporkin overruled the objections. ``I'm trying to get a backdrop here,'' the judge said. In seven previous days of testimony, the government called Keating, his son and a son-in-law as hostile witnesses in pressing their motion to dismiss Keating's suit. Mrs. Wischer testified that American Continental turned Lincoln from a losing home mortgage lender into a nearly $7 billion empire and an aggressive and profitable investor in stocks, junk bonds and real estate. In its takeover, the government said those investments using federally insured deposits constituted ``unsafe and unsound practices'' that could cost taxpayers up to $2 billion _ losses Keating says never would have occurred if regulators had kept their hands off his business. Mrs. Wischer said American Continental developed interest in acquiring a thrift as a result of a 1982 law that effectively allowed thrifts to directly invest up to 40 percent of their deposits in stocks, bonds and real estate. Using high interest rates to lure new deposits put together by brokers, Keating turned Lincoln from a $1 billion operation to one with $2.3 billion in assets, some $440 million of it in direct investments, within a year. But in February 1985 the new owners began running into trouble with regulators at the 11th District Federal Home Loan Bank in San Francisco, Mrs. Wischer said. Although federal examiners that month gave Lincoln a relatively clean bill of health and California regulators had given it permission to make up to $950 million in direct investments, she testified, the Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco began questioning its operations. ``The examination went extremely well,'' she said. ``But we began having trouble with the supervisory agent'' who reported to a 12-member board at the San Francisco bank ``composed of our competitors.'' Mrs. Wischer said Lincoln vigorously opposed pending regulations before the bank board in Washington that cut allowable direct investments back to 10 percent of a thrift's assets. The proposed regulations were modified several times but when finally adopted in February 1985, Lincoln unsuccessfully sought waivers, including direct appeals to members of Congress. As part of that campaign, Mrs. Wischer said American Continental ``commissioned'' Alan Greenspan, now chairman of the Federal Reserve Board but then a private consultant, to write a report supporting Lincoln's investments and management. The campaign eventually grew to include raising millions of dollars for the political causes of lawmakers ``sympathetic'' to Keating's case _ including $1.3 million for five U.S. senators. The five _ Sens. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; John McCain, R-Ariz.; John Glenn, D-Ohio; Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., and Alan Cranston, D-Calif. _ are now under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee on charges they improperly interceded with regulators on Keating's behalf.

DOC.HEAD: Manufacturer Recalls Fishing Kit
DOC.TEXT: The manufacturer of a fishing kit sold for children aged 1 to 5 is voluntarily recalling the product because one part may pose a choking hazard for young children. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said last week the potential danger is presented by the casting plug contained in the Tadpole Fishing Kit, Model K401, manufactured by the New York-based FinTek, Inc. The kit includes a rod, a reel with line and the black rubber casting plug. Labeling near the base of the rod reads ``FinTek Tadpole'' and ``ST330.'' The agency said about 9,800 of the kits for ``Baby Anglers ages 1-5'' were sold nationwide between December 1988 and May 1989. They should not have been sold for use by children under age 3, the commission said. Neither the commission nor Fintek is aware of any injuries associated with the kits, the agency said, but consumers should take them away from younger children. Consumers with questions may contact FinTek at 1-800-237-5537.

DOC.NOTE: $adv23
For release Friday Feb. 23
DOC.HEAD: Prospects Vary, But For Some a New Dynamism Is Possible
Last in a Series
LaserPhoto
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press asked two experts on Eastern European economics to present their views on the prospects for free markets in the region. Marshall I. Goldman, associate director of Harvard University's Russian Research Center and Soviet economics professor at Wellesley College, writes that if history is any guide, the outlook is discouraging. Charles H. Movit, senior economist of PlanEcon Inc. in Washington, D.C., writes that despite enormous obstacles, change is possible. Below is Movit's contribution.

Eastern European nations are undergoing sweeping political and economic change. There promises to be a most difficult transition ahead with respect to both. These economies have found that the growth model formulated under Stalinist domination cannot provide satisfactory improvement in living standards, with the gap between East and West growing and the price of bureaucratic mismanagement brought home more sharply day by day in terms of worker unrest. What are the prospects that reforms can restore economic dynamism to Eastern Europe? The prospects vary considerably. The two major determinants of likely success are financial health at the outset and the extent to which reformers are willing to privatize and integrate with the rest of the world. In some, in an effort to prop up living standards in the face of sagging growth, former regimes oversaw the buildup of an overwhelming debt. This debt took two forms _ foreign loans and a lack of domestic investment. In all these countries, bureaucratic mismanagement and artificially set prices have resulted in serious imbalances and poor preparation for changing world market conditions. To maintain cheap basic goods and avoid unemployment, intricate subsidy systems have been established. This has led to shoddy goods, higher inflationary pressure and reduced incentives for people to work hard. The answers for the economies of Eastern Europe lie in privatizing them to restore incentives to workers, pulling down artificial barriers between domestic and international markets, spurring the efficiency of domestic enterprises and allowing the inflow of Western investment. Privatizing means both absorbing some of the financial liquidity of the population in the disposal of state-owned productive assets and relying more directly on the profit motive. Western investment would bring in resources to renovate aging capital stock, inject more up-to-date technology and improve the competitiveness of exports. Service sectors have been neglected and offer fertile ground for enterprises, attractive in some cases to Western investors. Even in the countries with the brightest prospects _ Czechoslovakia, East Germany and Hungary _ reforms must go radically in the direction of a dominant private enterprise sector. This will mean a painful transition during which much economic and social dislocation is bound to take place. Will Western investors respond to the opportunities offered in Eastern Europe? There are a number of reasons to think that even prudent investors can find them attractive. The region offers the lowest labor costs of all industrialized countries. Workers are relatively well-educated and highly skilled. Expected movements in exchange rates will mean, moreover, even more favorable comparison of wage rates vs. potential investments elsewhere. Turning around East European economies will certainly require determination, farsightedness, a helping hand from Western governments, a reawakening of entrepreneurial spirit at home, and a good deal of luck. There is no reason to believe, however, that an appropriate combination of radically new policies could not bring new dynamism and a real transformation for some of these economies, with a timeframe of about 15 years or somewhat longer.

DOC.HEAD: American Companies Proceed with Caution in Last Economic Frontier
Fourth in a Series
With BC-EUR--Marriott
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: When Sybron Corp. negotiated a joint venture in Budapest, talks stalled while attorneys for the Hungarian partners grappled to translate ``profit.'' ``It was difficult to put the word profit in the contract in Hungarian so we wrote it in German,'' said Donald Rackl, chief financial officer for the Milwaukee manufacturer. Sybron weathered that and many other problems starting its first business in Eastern Europe. The company expects to dance around bigger business potholes when its microscope-slide plant starts production this year. Even a veteran like PepsiCo Inc., after years of operating in the region, has altered the way it normally does business in order to cope with problems alien to the West. Pepsi plants in Czechoslovakia sometimes run out of bottles due to late shipments. In the Ukraine, state officials snatch soft drink delivery trucks to haul harvested wheat, said Richard Norton, PepsiCo vice president for Eastern Europe. Adapting to such inconveniences is part of reality in countries still shaking off the dust of communist rule. Less easily overcome are structural and economic problems: rapid inflation, huge foreign debt and inconvertible currencies that make it difficult to turn profits into dollars. In many respects, the revolution in Eastern Europe remains only a promise. Several countries haven't written laws on foreign ownership and joint ventures. They lack legal systems and courts, leaving Western businesses vulnerable if, for example, suppliers don't deliver and customers don't pay. Yet for all the problems, Eastern Europe may well represent the greatest commercial and financial opportunity since the rebuilding of Western Europe after World War II. The region's 136 million consumers crave everything from french fries to shoe polish, telephones to computer disks. For companies with global aspirations and patience for profits, Eastern Europe is ``a pot of gold,'' said Chicago University business professor Marvin Zonis. ``There are real possibilities out there and they ought to be pursued,'' Zonis said. The Commerce Department's own analysts have said firms dealing in agriculture, health care, telecommunications, energy, tourism, and housing may have the best chance of gaining entry and prospering in East European markets. There are plenty of reasons for American companies to invest. Cheap labor is one of the biggest. The average hourly manufacturing wage in Hungary, Poland and Yugoslavia in 1988 was $1.35 to $1.71, said PlanEcon Inc., a Washington research concern specializing in Eastern Europe. Wages could even fall in dollar terms because of an expected decline in exchange rates. Moreover, East European workers are relatively well educated and highly trained compared with Third World counterparts. Low labor productivity may be a concern, but some economists say that's correctable. ``Workers get lazy and depressed when they get stuck with guys who are doing a bad job of running things,'' said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Perhaps the biggest incentive for U.S. corporations to invest in Eastern Europe is global competition. U.S. giants like General Electric Co., International Business Machines Corp. and General Motors Corp. are already there, but so are rivals Suzuki Motor Co.; Siemens AG, West Germany's giant electronics company, Ferruzzi Finanziara SPA, Italy's leading chemical and agribusiness company, and British Telecom. Others are on the way. Eugene Theroux, an attorney in the Washington office of the international law firm Baker & McKenzie, said it's a mistake for American businesses to sit back and watch. ``They should make at least a minimum of time, effort and expense necessary to examine the alternatives,'' said Theroux, who advises companies doing business in communist countries. Many companies apparently are doing just that. The Commerce Department and Chamber of Commerce said they are receiving at least 10 times as many inquiries as last year from American companies _ on everything from investment laws to opportunities and licensing. Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher opened an information office on Eastern Europe in January to handle all the calls. Lawyers, travel agents and public relations firms are leading the way, establishing offices and advertising for Western clients. ``Cautious optimism has been replaced by opportunism,'' said Richard W. Edelman, president of New York-based Edelman Public Relations Worldwide, which has opened offices in Hungary and is scouting elsewhere. But American executives already experienced in Eastern Europe warn newcomers to calculate the risks. Many early joint ventures in the Soviet Union failed for lack of a careful business plan. Those who decide to go should be prepared to stay awhile. ``This is an investment that will have long-term rewards instead of a short-term immediate impact,'' said Andrew B. Somers Jr., general counsel for American Express Corp., which has offices in several East European countries. ``This is not something you dabble in.'' Companies in the vanguard also must be prepared to sacrifice time andnald's discovered opening its first restaurant in Moscow. The opening took McDonald's 14 years, $50 million and its own supply system that bypasses the deadly Soviet bureacracy. While the Soviet Union is considered more treacherous for enterprising Westerners, economists say Eastern Europe is similar. ``Right now if I were an American company I would think the prospects were very risky given the political and economic transition,'' said Georgetown University professor Stewart Brown. Congress has authorized $300 million in aid for private enterprise in Poland and Hungary as well as other assistance. The federal Export-Import Bank will guarantee loans up to $200 million to Hungary and Yugoslavia. But U.S. companies will have to rely largely on their own resources to establish outposts in Eastern Europe. ``Anyone not prepared to suffer losses should not go in,'' Brown said.
