DOC.HEAD: Trading Bloc Assists Eastern Europe With Mixed Feelings
With BC-EUR--Germany
DOC.TEXT: Western Europe is proffering aid eagerly to the deprived East, but some European Community members see the aspirations of their neighbors as both a benefit and danger to the economic bloc's own integration. Political upheavals in the East bloc have raised new commercial opportunities. At the same time, some worry that the huge task of aiding Iron Curtain economies could be deemed more politically urgent than the Community's plans to remove the economic barriers dividing the dozen West European nations. Furthermore, some of the Community's poorer nations such as Portugal and Greece worry that the group might direct resources to the East at their expense. ``The Community ... is running enormous risks because the pace of events has fueled the debate on European integration,'' said Jacques Delors, president of the European Commission, the trading bloc's executive body. ``The Community must speed up the pace of European integration if it is to remain a focal point for others,'' he said in a recent speech to the European Parliament, the Community's legislative body. An ambitious integration plan by the Community scheduled for 1992 envisions a European-wide market of 320 illion consumers, unfettered by trade barriers. The plan would create a monetary union with a common currency and central bank and fashion closer political cooperation in such areas as foreign policy. Belgium, Britain, Denmark, France, West Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Portugal and Spain make up the Community. Integration plans have not met blanket approval. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, for example, is reluctant to make British monetary policy subject to a single European monetary union. But leaders of the Community, also known as the Common Market, have been united in the desire to help the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe convert their centrally planned economies into free-market systems. The new governments must deal with poor economic growth, high inflation, a lack of investment money and infrastructure and, in some cases, huge foreign debts. Heavily indebted Poland, for instance, has virtually no banking network to support the free enterprise system needed for a market-driven economy. ``There are real doubts as to whether this thing can go through tidily ... even whether the transition (to market economies) can be carried through at all completely,'' said Peter Ludlow, director of the Center for European Policy Studies, a Brussels-based think tank. The Community already has directed substantial resources toward Eastern European economic revitalization in the aftermath of the region's political upheaval. Aid ranging from free food to technical assistance and cash for improving agricultural and industrial production has been sent or promised to Hungary and Poland, for example. The Community last summer was put in charge of a 24-nation effort to devise an economic aid package for Poland and Hungary. Pledges have been received for a special $1 billion fund for Poland, and the West European nations recently agreed to establish a development bank to provide low-cost loans and other technical and economic assistance to Eastern Europe. Delors has suggested, using what he called an extreme example, that it could take $23 billion a year over the next five to 10 years to help achieve economic reform in Eastern Europe. However, any call for a sizable increase in Community spending likely would cause heated debate. The Community's 1990 budget has been set at about $56.5 billion, with just over half designated for farm programs. An aid package for 66 poor nations in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific recently was pegged at $14.5 billion over five years. Willy De Clercq, chairman of the European Parliament's external economic affairs committee, acknowledged that poor countries might be concerned about future aid. But he said it would be a wrong for the trading bloc to ignore other parts of the world. There also is speculation that the rich nations, especially West Germany, will be more inclined to channel money to the East than to the southern nations of Spain, Portugal, Italy and Greece, the Community's weak spots. ``A mark for Leipzig is a mark less for Lisbon'' _ goes one saying, a reference the possible spending of West German capital in East Germany rather than in Portugal. De Clercq and others maintained the Community would not neglect its own interests. ``We don't see developments in Eastern Europe as a possible enemy of the Greek economy,'' said a Greek official, who asked not to be quoted by name. After joining the Community in 1981, Greece received $6.2 billion over seven years to help modernize. Agricultural groups are concerned that tariff reductions and other special treatment for products grown by Eastern farmers may hurt their markets. ``We know we must help these countries ... but we must be careful not to create big difficulties here,'' said Andre Herlitska, secretary-general of the Committee of Professional Farm Organizations, a group of Community farm unions. The European Commission already has negotiated broad trade agreements with Poland, Hungary and the Soviet Union to lift import limits and give their products greater access to West European markets. There is a smaller arrangement with Czechoslovakia, likely to be expanded, and bargaining for accords with East Germany and Bulgaria is under way. The Community also is taking steps to improve ties with Romania. Trade between the Community and East bloc amounted to $54.6 billion in 1988, about half with the Soviet Union. By comparison, two-way trade with the United States that year was more than three times that amount.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Suffers Fourth-Quarter Loss, Year's Earnings Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with quotes, detail; ADDS byline; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. said today it had a fourth-quarter loss of $664 million, including one-time restructuring charges of $577 million. Chrysler said the costs included idling plants in Detroit and St. Louis, discontinuing some car lines and reducing the white-collar work force. ``It's called restructuring to compete,'' Chrysler Chairman Lee A. Iacocca said at a news conference. More than half the fourth-quarter restructuring charge of $577 million was for supplemental unemployment benefits and retirement benefits connected with plant closings, Iacocca said. The charge sliced $2.48 off per-share earnings. Chrysler said the loss was equivalent to $2.90 a share, compared with fourth-quarter net earnings of $433 million, or $1.85 a share, in 1988. Sales for the quarter sagged to $7.9 billion, compared with $9.3 billion a year earlier. For the year, Chrysler reported net income of $359 million, or $1.55 a share, on revenue of $34.9 billion. That compares with 1988 net income of $1 billion, or $4.66 a share, on revenue of $34.2 billion in 1988. Iacocca said the results would mean no profit sharing for hourly workers and no bonuses for salaried employees at the nation's third-largest automaker. The earnings report came shortly after Chrysler announced it had agreed to sell its Gulfstream Aerospace corporate jet manufacturing unit for $825 million in a cash-raising move. Chrysler said it had a fourth-quarter after-tax loss of $87 million, or 38 cents a share, prior to the one-time restructuring charge. Chrysler said Dec. 6 it was considering selling its Chrysler Technologies Corp. subsidiary, of which Gulfstream is a part, to raise cash and refocus on automaking. The company has cut back excess manufacturing capacity, shutting down its Jefferson Avenue assembly plant in Detroit and announcing plans to close its St. Louis car assembly plant this September. The company announced a cost-cutting program in October with a goal of cutting $1 billion from its $26-billion annual budget by the end of this year, including eliminating 2,300 salaried jobs. It since has boosted the goal to $1.5 billion. Iacocca called the results commendable during what he called a full-blown recession in the auto industry in the fourth quarter. ``I am not in the least disappointed,'' he said. ``Our cash position just got better, and we're focused.'' Without the cuts, Iacocca said, ``We probably could have muddled through, but we chose not to. We chose to get ready for the '90s.'' The country's top two automakers, General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co., are expected to report earnings later this week. GM reported a profit of $4.9 billion on revenue of $110.2 billion in 1988, and Ford reported earnings of $5.3 billion on revenue of $92.4 billion.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares End Slightly Higher
DOC.TEXT: Stocks finished slightly higher on London's Stock Exchange Tuesday after an erratic session marked by thin volume. Dealers said investors showed little interest in equities for most of the day, which was dominated by worries over the direction of West German and British interest rates, and the outlook for U.S. corporate profitability and its impact on Wall Street. But at midafternoon in Europe, stocks were pushed broadly lower in New York and London by news that the board of directors of the U.S. investment company Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. would meet later Tuesday to consider seeking bankruptcy protection. However, a late afternoon London rally carried London stock prices back into positive territory, on the perception that Drexel's junk bond losses were an isolated problem. ``We went from a plus to a minus,'' said one head of market making in London. ``But just as quickly, the news seemed to be of little lasting consequence to the London market.'' By the end of the European day, the Dow Jones industrial average was off just 3.37 points at 2,615.77, after shedding more than 20 points at one stage. At London's close, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 6.3 points, or 0.3 percent, at 2,293.2. The Financial Times 30-share index was up 7.5 points at 1,818.1 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 1.74 points to close at 1,250.38. Volume amounted to a light 435.3 million shares, compared with Monday's 338.5 million shares.

DOC.HEAD: FAA Tentatively Orders Changes in Boeing 737s
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 10-12, In Seattle, with Boeing comment. This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Aviation Administration today tentatively ordered changes in the control panels of Boeing 737s to prevent a rudder control problem that is one focus of an accident hearing underway in New York. The changes would make it less likely that pilots or cockpit visitors might accidentally move a rudder trim control knob that could reduce the pilot's ability to control the plane or force an aborted takeoff, the FAA said. The work would be relatively simple and cost about $820 per plane, the FAA said in issuing a proposed airworthiness directive. The directive would become final after a 60-day period for comment. The order came as the National Transportation Safety Board opened a four-day hearing in New York City into the Sept. 20 crash of USAir Flight 5050 that killed two people. The plane skidded off the end of the LaGuardia Airport runway into the East River and broke into several pieces in an aborted takeoff, and investigators are examining a possible rudder control problem. The FAA order would cover all 737-300 and 737-400 models, affecting 641 airplanes worldwide. Although FAA orders do not directly apply to planes flown by foreign airlines, they usually comply. The alteration, designed by Boeing, would replace a rudder trim knob located at the rear of a console between the two pilots and install a protective guardrail behind the knob to prevent it from being inadvertently knocked out of alignment. The new knob would be round and fluted instead of wedge-shaped. Investigators into the crash of Flight 5050, which was to take off for Charlotte, N.C., said the rudder was set all the way to the left although evidence showed that pilots made all the proper checks during the aborted takeoff. The Air Line Pilots Association on Monday blamed the design of the rudder trim control for the crash of Flight 5050. ``We feel the rudder trim system is what actually precipitated the USAir accident,'' said ALPA representative Tom Kraemer on Monday. In Seattle, Mark Hooper, spokesman for the Boeing Commercial Airplane Group, said Boeing had redesigned the trim switch knob following reports of rudder trim being changed inadvertently. Hooper said the design change, adopted Jan. 17, was the result of Boeing studies begun last May and subsequent reviews by the FAA. He said there had been reports of visitors in cockpits who had placed their feet on the aisle console and may have accidently turned the knob, or the possibility the knob might have been jarred by manuals tossed on the console. NTSB Chairman James L. Kolstad, who was conducting the New York hearing, said that in addition to rudder control design, the hearing would cover cockpit crew training and crew coordination, the effects of the recent merger of USAir with Piedmont, FAA surveillance of USAir operations and runway design.

DOC.HEAD: Paramount Petroleum, Monticello Acquisition Agree to Merge
DOC.TEXT: Paramount Petroleum Co. Inc. and Monticello Acquisition Corp. have agreed in principle to merge their oil and gas operations effective July 1, the companies announced Tuesday. William E. Simon, former secretary of the Treasury, and Alvin V. Shoemaker, former chairman of the board of First Boston Corp., are heading the new entity. The merger brings together Paramount, a leading exploration company in the Southeast based in Houston and Jackson, Miss., and Dallas-based Monticello, a privately held company whose major shareholders are Simon and Shoemaker. The new company will retain the Paramount name with Shoemaker serving as chairman.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Drexel Plans To File for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy Protection
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs; Edits throughout; No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The parent of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. plans to file for federal bankruptcy court protection today in a move that would cap the downfall of one of Wall Street's most powerful firms of the 1980s. The decision on whether to seek protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy law was expected to be approved by Drexel's board of directors, Drexel officials said. Drexel Chief Executive Frederick Joseph told employees on the firm's internal communications system that the parent company and certain subsidiaries would file with U.S. Bankruptcy Court today. Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. said it had defaulted on about $100 million in loans and a lack of cash was threatening other defaults. The board meeting was scheduled to start at 4 p.m. EDT to vote on whether to file for bankruptcy court protection, but the Drexel official, who asked not to be named, said the decision already appeared to have been made. The official said bankruptcy papers were expected to be filed today. Wall Street traders and other sources said Drexel was barely functioning and was liquidating its huge portfolio of government securities. Few companies were reported to be trading with the firm that rose to prominence through the risky junk bonds that also have marked its downfall. Drexel also was said to be transferring customer accounts to Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co., which acquired Drexel's retail brokerage business last year. Smith Barney said it was considering taking over the accounts but no decision had been made. The accounts were said to be employee or employee-related and include all types of securities, including stocks and bonds. Drexel today also voluntarily withdrew from making markets in 228 stocks traded over the counter through the National Association of Securities Dealers. The firm was able to maintain its duties as a specialist on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange when another firm, Speer, Leeds & Kellogg, agreed to clear Drexel trades and guarantee their financial obligations. Drexel owns the specialist firm Pforzheimer & Co. Drexel said in a statement that a Chapter 11 filing would exclude the broker-dealer subsidiary, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., and Drexel Burnham Government Securities Inc. The statement said Drexel ``intends to engage in an orderly liquidation of its positions'' in government securities. Drexel said Monday it was seeking a major investor or merger partner in an effort to raise additional capital. Drexel blamed the bulk of its problems on the deteriorating market for high-risk, high-yield ``junk'' bonds that it helped to create in the 1980s under now-indicted executive Michael Milken. Drexel's announcement followed several days of negotiations with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Federal Reserve Board and the New York Stock Exchange over how to prevent a financial panic over its troubles. The dire problems at the investment firm threaten confidence in the nation's financial markets because of Drexel's preeminence in the $200 billion junk bond market, which has been slumping since last fall, when several companies failed to meet financing terms on their junk bond debt. The firm also was hammered by its decision to plead guilty to six felonies and pay $650 million to the government to settle federal charges related to insider trading and other offenses. Drexel was forced to restructure as part of a civil settlement with the SEC and has cut its work force to 5,300 from 10,700. In Monday's statement, Drexel said its senior members had concluded it should seek outside assistance because ``unsettled markets, particularly in the high-yield area, have adversely affected the liquidity'' of its parent. Drexel said its securities subsidiary ``continues to have good liquidity and has satisfactory excess regulatory capital.'' The firm last week began to shift cash to the strapped parent from its securities subsidiary, but the move alarmed officials at the Fed and the SEC, who felt it might weaken the subsidiary. The SEC stated today in Washington that it had moved to protect the assets of the brokerage firm by barring the subsidiary from transferring net capital to the parent without prior, specific approval. ``Inventory schedules and other detailed financial information submitted by Drexel Burnham Lambert indicate at this time the registered broker-dealer has positive net worth and remains in capital compliance,'' the SEC said. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York issued a statement saying it would ``carefully monitor'' Drexel's decision to liquidate its position in government securities in consulation with the government, Drexel's securities subsidiary and other market participants. The bank said Drexel still was designated as a primary dealer in government securities. Junk bond professionals said prices of those securities were trading slightly higher in a chaotic morning session as rumors swirled around Wall Street on whether Drexel would file for bankruptcy protection. Dealers in Treasury securities said there was concern that by selling off its large portfolio Drexel would add supply to the market and depress prices _ pushing interest rates higher. ``You want to talk about an end of an era?'' said Joan Greenberg, a senior vice president for high-yield bonds at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Analysts said Drexel's capital base has been reduced to ``a minimum level'' and that without an infusion the firm could fail to meet federal requirements. Led by Milken, who pioneered use of the low-grade debt securities for multibillion-dollar takeovers but left after his indictment last year on fraud and racketeering charges, Drexel was a symbol of the high-flying, takeover-driven 1980s on Wall Street. Drexel reported a loss of $40 million on $4.1 billion in revenue for last year, when it settled the fraud charges, slashed its work force, sold its retail brokerage business and overhauled its internal operations under the SEC civil settlement. The firm had made a net profit of $523 million _ $951 million before taxes _on revenue of $5.3 billion in 1986.

Prices were narrowly mixed in late trading on Wall Street today as concerns about interest rates and the growing troubles of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. eased somewhat. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 5.41 to 2,624.55 as of 3 p.m. EST. Declining stocks were ahead of advancers by a margin of 5 to 4 in trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 634 rising, 803 falling and 491 unchanged. The market opened lower after the government announced robust retail sales figures for January, and took a further dive after Drexel's parent said it might seek federal bankruptcy protection for most of its operations. But prices began to come back slowly as the market digested both developments. The Commerce Department said retail sales, driven by renewed automobile sales incentives, climbed 1.6 percent in January, the steepest increase in more than a year. The news, intepreted as a show of economic strength, at first led traders to fear the Federal Reserve would be unlikely to relax credit and allow interest rates to fall. However, analysts said, on closer inspection many traders decided the surge might be a one-time event. The Drexel announcement came as only a small surprise to Wall Street, as many traders had been aware of the investment firm's problems, analysts said. Once investors overcame their uncertainty about possible fallout from a Chapter 11 bankruptcy court filing, some buyers saw an opportunity to go back into the market, the analysts said. Among blue chip issues, IBM was up 1| to 102}, AT&T rose ] to 40, General Electric fell [ to 62[, and Philip Morris was unchanged at 38|. Chrysler fell [ to 16{ after announcing its fourth-quarter earnings, and as expected, said it was selling its Gulfstream Aerospace Corp. for $825 million to a partnership of Gulfstream Chairman Allen E. Paulson and the New York investment firm Forstmann, Little & Co. Volume came to 125.17 million shares with one hour of trading left. The NYSE's index of all its listed common stocks was up 0.21 at 182.76. On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index fell 0.82 to 358.05.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices End Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Prices closed mixed on Wall Street today as concerns about interest rates and the growing troubles of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. eased somewhat. The market opened lower after the government announced robust retail sales figures for January, and took a further dive after Drexel's parent said it might seek federal bankruptcy protection for most of its operations. But prices began to come back slowly as the market digested both developments. The Commerce Department said retail sales, driven by renewed automobile sales incentives, climbed 1.6 percent in January, the steepest increase in more than a year. The news, interpreted as a show of economic strength, at first led traders to fear the Federal Reserve would be unlikely to relax credit and allow interest rates to fall. On closer inspection, many traders decided the surge might be a one-time event, but the market remained cautious. The Drexel announcement came as only a small surprise to Wall Street, as many traders had been aware of the investment firm's problems, analysts said. Once investors overcame some of their uncertainty about possible fallout from a Chapter 11 bankruptcy court filing, buyers saw an opportunity to go back into the market, the analysts said. However, there was still some concern that Drexel's troubles could affect the rest of the securities industry, analysts said.
