DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Reports $664 Million Quarterly Loss
With AM-Chrysler-Gulfstream, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. on Tuesday reported a $664 million fourth-quarter loss and a two-thirds drop in annual earnings for 1989, mostly due to costs of closing plants and cutting jobs. The results mean no profit-sharing for hourly workers and no bonuses for salaried employees at the nation's third-largest automaker, Chrysler Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Lee A. Iacocca said. But Iacocca said the belt-tightening moves were needed to compete in a slow automotive market. ``We looked at ourselves in the mirror back in May and we looked a little fat. And we looked at the market for the early 1990s ... and it looked a little grim,'' Iacocca said. Much of Chrysler's first quarterly loss since 1982 was from a one-time restructuring charge of $577 million. That covered costs of closing plants in Detroit and St. Louis, discontinuing some cars and paying pension and severance costs to trim the white-collar work force, the company said. Chrysler also said that to raise cash it had agreed to sell its Gulfstream Aerospace subsidiary for $825 million, to a partnership of Allen E. Paulson, chairman and founder of the Savannah, Ga.,-based maker of corporate jets, and the New York investment firm of Forstmann, Little & Co. ``We've got our capacity down. Our cash position just got a little better, and we're focused,'' Iacocca told a news conference. ``It sounds like back to the basics,'' said auto analyst Mary Anne Sudol of Fitch Investors Service in New York. ``It's a more vicious competitive environment, for sure. The race is to the lowest-cost producer.'' Iacocca explained that the loss came during what he termed a full-blown recession in auto sales, necessitating rebates of more than $1,200 a car just to keep sales limping along. ``I am not in the least disappointed,'' he said. The quarterly $664 million net loss, equivalent to $2.90 a share, compared with net earnings of $433 million, or $1.85 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1988, the company said. Chrysler said sales and revenues for the quarter sagged to $7.9 billion from $9.3 billion a year earlier. For the year, the company reported net income of $359 million, or $1.55 a share, on revenues of $34.92 billion, down 66 percent from $1.05 billion, or $4.66 a share, on revenues of $34.15 billion in 1988. The one-time $577 million charge was partly offset by a $309 million gain on the sale of Mitsubishi Motors Corp. stock, the company said. United Auto Workers President Owen Bieber and Vice President Stan Marshall, who directs the UAW's Chrysler Department, said they regretted earnings didn't trigger profit-sharing for hourly workers. Under Chrysler's UAW contract, they said in a statement, ``At least there will be some equality of sacrifice and Chrysler executives will have to go without bonuses as well.'' Chrysler has cut back excess capacity, shutting down its Jefferson Avenue assembly plant in Detroit and announcing plans to close its St. Louis car assembly plant this September. The company also announced a cost-cutting program in October aimed at cutting $1 billion from its $26 billion annual budget by the end of this year, including elimination of 2,300 salaried jobs, and has since boosted the cost-cutting goal to $1.5 billion. ``It's called restructuring to compete,'' Iacocca said. ``We probably could have muddled through, but we chose not to. We chose to get ready for the '90s. It's all part of our plan.'' The country's top two automakers, General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co., are scheduled to report earnings Thursday. GM reported profits of $4.9 billion on revenues of $110.2 billion in 1988, and Ford reported earnings of $5.3 billion on revenues of $92.4 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Goodyear Reports Earnings Decline
DOC.TEXT: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., despite improved profitability of its tire segment, said Tuesday its fourth-quarter earnings dropped 74 percent from the same period in 1988. The Akron-based company attributed the lower profit to higher taxes on foreign earnings and a first-time inclusion of pipeline expenses. Goodyear reported earnings of $14.7 million, or 25 cents per share, on sales of slightly more than $2.7 billion, compared with earnings of $56.4 million, 98 cents per share, and sales of $2.8 billion in the same period a year earlier. For the full year, Goodyear's earnings of $206.8 million, $3.58 per share, represented a 41 percent decline from the 1988 earnings of $350.1 million, $6.11 per share. Sales for the year virtually matched the $10.8 billion of 1988. The company's 1990 earnings outlook was not good, Tom H. Barrett, Goodyear chairman, indicated in a statement. ``We expect the competitive market place and the slowdown in the U.S. auto industry to continue to impact both our tire and general products businesses through at least the first half of 1990,'' Barrett said. ``To meet the challenge, we are working to reduce manufacturing and operating expenses as we continue to improve the efficiency of our production and distrubution operations.'' Barrett said that in 1989 the company incurred higher taxes on foreign earnings, while in 1988 Goodyer benefited from a tax credit associated with pension asset reversion. The chairman said inclusion of depreciation and operating and interest expenses on its All American Pipeline System reduced earnings in the fourth quarter by $26.4 million. In the company's tire segment, operating income declined 8.4 percent in the fourth quarter to $130.7 million, despite improved business conditions in the United States, where Goodyear experienced lower raw materials prices and a better product mix to offset a 3.6 percent sales decline. Although the company's engineered products segment did well, the industrial products and chemical products segments declined.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Down
Precedes LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mostly higher in quiet trading Tuesday, although the prospect of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s parent filing for federal bankruptcy protection eroded some of its earlier gains. Gold prices declined after a mixed performance overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $417.60 a troy ounce, down $1.60 from late Monday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $417.50 an ounce, off $1.20. Currency dealers said technical factors were largely responsible for pushing the dollar higher. But they said an announcement from Drexel that it planned to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection because of scandal and financial problems depressed the dollar. Linda McLaughlin, a trader with Chemical New York Capital Markets Group, said the market was concerned that a Drexel filing would force the Federal Reserve to provide more liquidity in the market, thereby lowering interest rates. Lower interest rates tend to depress a currency's value. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar closed down 0.24 yen at 144.48 yen. It was quoted at 144.25 yen in London, and 144.345 yen in New York, down from 144.37 yen. The dollar was stronger against the British pound. Sterling fetched $1.6907 in London, down from $1.6960 late Monday, and $1.6895 in New York, down from $1.6918. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's quotes, included: 1.67625 West German marks, up from 1.6755; 1.4975 Swiss francs, down from 1.5005; 5.7015 French francs, up from 5.6965; 1,245.75 Italian lire, down from 1,246.00; and 1.20095 Canadian dollars, up from 1.20065. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Monday: 1.6760 West German marks, up from 1.6695; 1.4960 Swiss francs, unchanged; 5.6995 French francs, up from 5.6785; 1.8980 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8890; 1,248.00 Italian lire, up from 1,242.00; and 1.9950 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2023. Gold fell in London to $418.65 an ounce from $419.50 late Monday. In Zurich, gold rose 75 cents to $419.75 an ounce. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $5.17 to close at $419.58 an ounce. Silver prices headed higher. Silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.314 a troy ounce, up 2.8 cents. Silver rose in London to $5.35 an ounce from $5.32.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers Present Arguments in Smoker Death Case
DOC.TEXT: A man who started smoking as a child and later died of lung cancer should have been warned by the American Tobacco Co. that cigarettes posed a health risk before the government required warning labels, a lawyer told a jury Tuesday. But a lawyer representing the cigarette company said the victim, George Kotler, was free to stop smoking and chose to continue his habit. Attorneys on both sides presented their opening arguments in a federal lawsuit against American Tobacco, marking one of the rare smoker-death cases to reach the courtroom. ``This is not an anti-smoking case,'' said Garry Inge, who represents Kotler's widow, Joanne Kotler. ``This is a warning case. This is a case of informed consent.'' ``We admit that if George Kotler knew what American Tobacco knew, they didn't need to warn him,'' he said. In the last 20 years, only a handful of smoker-death lawsuits have made it to court, as cigarette companies have spent millions of dollars to fight accusations of liability. The first damages judgment came in 1988, when a federal jury in New Jersey awarded $400,000 to Antonio Cipollone, whose wife died of lung cancer. But an appeals court last month overturned the jury award and ordered a new trial. In the Boston lawsuit, the case centers on Kotler's smoking habits before 1966, when government warning labels were placed on cigarette packs. Kotler, who lived in Cambridge, was 55 when he died in 1986, but he started smoking around age 11. Inge told the jury that American Tobacco, a subsidiary of American Brands Inc. in Greenwich, Conn., had information as early as the 1930s indicating cigarettes posed a health risk. But the company instead insisted that cigarette smoking was not harmful, he said. ``American Tobacco put profits ahead of lives,'' he said. ``A whole generation of people could have been saved.'' Andrew Lane, representing American Tobacco, told the jury they should consider not only whether Kotler had adequate information but also whether it would have made any difference. Lane said the controversy surrounding cigarette smoking was reported in the press during the 1950s, and the surgeon general issued a highly publicized report in 1964 on the dangers of smoking. Since then, millions of Americans have quit smoking and thus have reduced their risks for lung cancer, Lane said. But the first time Kotler showed the ``slightest interest'' in stopping smoking was in 1975, when he went to see a doctor because he was suffering from chest pains, he said. Kotler stopped smoking for several weeks, but when his health improved, he resumed smoking, Lane said. ``He smoked because he wanted to, because he liked to,'' he said. Lane also argued that in 1968, Kotler switched from the Pall Mall brand, an American Tobacco product, and started smoking cigarettes made by other companies. The suit originally named two other tobacco companies, Philip Morris Cos. Inc. and Liggett Group Inc. But U.S. District Judge Walter Skinner, who is presiding over the case, last year ruled that the claims were only valid before 1966.

DOC.HEAD: Crazy Eddie Founder, Hunted for Days, Turns Himself In
DOC.TEXT: Eddie Antar, the Crazy Eddie Inc. founder sought by authorities since last week in connection with a government insider-trading case, surrendered Tuesday to face contempt charges for not answering demands he return $52 million to the United States, authorities said. U.S. Marshal Arthur Borinsky said Antar was released pending court action on the contempt charge, delayed until the judge assigned to the case returns from vacation on Feb. 27. He said Antar's attorney, Jack Arseneault, called marshals to arrange the surrender at U.S. District Court here, where the marshals have offices. ``He turned himself into me,'' Borinsky said. ``He didn't say where he had been and I really don't know where he's been.'' Antar and other top officials of the Crazy Eddie discount electronics chain were accused of insider trading in a lawsuit filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The agency charged that Antar directed a ``massive financial fraud'' to falsify the company's income, and reaped illegal profits through the sale of his stock at artificially inflated prices. The SEC won an order that $52 million be transferred from Israeli bank accounts to a court-appointed trustee, but Antar has not yet complied with that order, an SEC attorney said. U.S. District Judge Nicholas H. Politan had ordered Antar to repatriate the money by Feb. 7, but Antar refused through his attorney, citing his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination. Politan said from the bench Feb. 7 that Antar would have to appear in person if he was going to use the Fifth Amendment, and he gave him until last Thursday to appear in court. On Thursday, Antar's attorneys said they needed an extension. Politan then ordered Antar to appear in court on Friday, but Antar again stayed away and the judge told marshals to ``spare no expense'' to capture Antar on contempt charges. ``His surrender today more or less took care of the arrest warrant,'' said SEC Attorney Richard E. Simpson, in Washington, D.C. Simpson said no bail was set because it was a civil case. No other conditions have been set on Antar's freedom except that his attorneys must report on his whereabouts twice a week, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Airline Owes Tax on Drinks Sold On Flights Over State
DOC.TEXT: A state judge ruled Tuesday that Wisconsin officials could collect a 5 percent sales tax from an airline for the drinks it sold while its jets flew over Wisconsin. Dane County Circuit Judge James Boll ordered the former Republic Airlines to pay Wisconsin $90,622 in overdue sales tax for drinks consumed on its flights over the state from 1981 to 1984. Boll rejected Republic's argument that a law authorizing a sales tax on drinks consumed ``in this state'' did not mean ``over this state.'' The judge ruled the state had the right to impose its sale tax on flights overhead for any airline that had some definite link to the state, such as offices based in Wisconsin or incorporation within the state. State officials could not be immediately reached for comment on whether they would seek to impose the tax on other airlines and seek back taxes. Republic Airlines, which was purchased in the mid 1980s by Northwest Airlines, contended that applying the state sales tax to flights violated the due process clause of the U.S. Constitution. Liquor consumed in ``overflights'' was not liquor consumed ``in'' Wisconsin, the airline argued. The airline appealed an order of the Wisconsin Tax Appeals Commission that it owed the tax, leading to the court case. Before it was bought by Northwest, Republic maintained offices in Wisconsin, had equipment and personnel located at airports in the state and flew regularly scheduled flights in and out of Wisconsin cities. Republic said it did not keep records of whether its aircraft were in Wisconsin's air space or over another state when it sold drinks. Attorney Frederic Brouner, who represented Republic, said he did not know whether Northwest would appeal. Brouner called Wisconsin's attempt to collect the tax after the fact was ``particularly onerous.'' ``But it's a very quick, clean way to pick up revenue,'' Brouner said. ``How many are going to be unhappy? Hey, only the vendor, and corporations don't vote,'' he said. Boll said a test for determining when taxation by a state violated the commerce clause of the U.S. Constitution was set forth in a Supreme Court case that held a tax would be sustained if it was applied to an activity with a ``substantial nexus'' with the taxing state, was fairly apportioned, did not discriminate against interstate commerce and fairly related to services provided by the state. ``The (tax) department contends that the substantial nexus test is satisfied by the fact that Republic maintains offices, equipment and personnel in Wisconsin and is incorporated in Wisconsin,'' Boll said. ``This court agrees.''

DOC.HEAD: Junk Market Shows Surprising Resilience to Drexel News
DOC.TEXT: The $200 billion junk bond market survived a day of jitters Tuesday after the nation's biggest broker of high-yield securities said it planned to seek refuge from creditors under federal bankruptcy law protection. The market's resilience under the circumstances given its recent steep slide surprised some analysts, who had predicted a free fall after Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s announcement Monday that it was seeking a merger partner and needed money. In announcing Tuesday that it would seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, Drexel's parent company said it had defaulted on about $100 million in loans and a lack of cash was threatening other defaults. Nonetheless, mutual funds that invest in the high-yield securities, those with low credit ratings or no ratings at all, said there was no immediate rush by investors to sell. ``We expected an above-normal reaction and there were more calls than usual for redemptions but by and large investors have taken it in stride,'' said Steve Norwitz, spokesman for T. Rowe Price Associates Inc. in Baltimore, which manages a $700 million junk bond fund. Fidelity Investments in Boston, which has about $1.5 billion invested in high-yield securities, said it had not received any unusual redemption requests. ``The Drexel situation and problems have been so well documented that it hasn't come as a shock,'' said Fidelity spokeswoman Tracey Gordon. ``Besides, the market is not just Drexel anymore.'' Steve Radis, spokesman for Kemper Financial Services Inc. in Chicago, said Drexel's problems had not impacted the company's $1.4 billion high-yield fund. ``Drexel hasn't been supporting the secondary market for high-yield bonds for sometime so it shouldn't impact trading of high-yield issues,'' Radis said. Fund representatives said that despite recent losses in the junk bond market, they had built up cash reserves lately and did not expect to have to sell bonds to pay off redemptions. Market observers nevertheless predicted Drexel's troubles could be damaging for market psychology, at least in the short term. Drexel pioneered the junk bond market. ``Quite frankly, their very serious problems are likely to add to the skepticism with which investors currently view junk bonds,'' said John Lonski, senior economist with Moody's Investors Service. Prices of most high-yield junk bonds slid two points or $20 per $1,000 in face amount on Monday but recovered Tuesday as many investors went bargain-hunting, traders said. The high-risk, high-yield corporate securities market has been under intense pressure due to a weakening economy and an enormous amount of corporate debt created by the merger wave of recent years. Among immediate investor worries are that Drexel would default or have to liquidate its own huge inventory of junk bonds, which would put further downward pressure on prices. The market already faces a scarcity of buyers. For example, many ailing thrifts, once important buyers of junk bonds, have been forced to get out of the junk market by federal regulators. Insurance companies also have come under pressure to divest their junk bond holdings. The average weekly new issue volume has plunged 86 percent from the average weekly volume in 1989, according to Moody's. The average net asset value of high-yield mutual funds is off 6 percent since the start of the year, Lonski said. Meanwhile, prospects for junk-bond defaults have risen. Moody's now projects the default rate in 1990 at 10 percent, up from 6 percent in 1989. Standard & Poors forecasts a similar rate. Nevertheless, many junk bond analysts believe the current slump reflects a temporary transition phase. Some contend the junk bond market will emerge a stronger, more mature entity. Because of their high yields, junk bonds have remained attractive to many investors despite the risk. Average yields now exceed Treasury yields by nearly 7 percentage points, well above the historical average of 4 percentage points, said Lonski. The average yield on a cash-paying junk bond was 14.9 percent as of Monday, compared with the yield on a 10-year Treasury note of 8.37 percent. ``The depth of the problems in the junk bond market has been overdone,'' said one market researcher who asked for anonymity. ``News of the death of the junk bond market is premature.''

DOC.HEAD: Energy Markets Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil futures pulled back Tuesday while prices of refined petroleum products moved ahead, led by a strong advance in wholesale home heating oil. Gloom over the future of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., a major operator in futures trading, permeated the markets. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the March contract for West Texas Intermediate, the main grade of U.S. crude oil, fell 13 cents to $21.90 per 42-gallon barrel, erasing a portion of Monday's 29-cent gain. The April crude contract lost 2 cents a gallon, settling at $21.82. Contracts for later delivery posted modest increases. Among refined products traded on the New York Merc, No. 2 heating oil for March delivery jumped 0.90 cent to 56.85 cents a gallon, adding to Monday's increase of 0.87 cent. The April contract rose 0.87 cent to 56.14 cents and May added 0.64 cent to 55.25 cents. March wholesale unleaded gasoline, which rose 0.84 cent on Monday, increased 0.02 cent to close at 60.42 cents a gallon. But later contract months declined; April fell 0.45 cent to 60.96 cents a gallon. Analysts said there was little news to move the energy markets so traders were preoccupied with speculation about Drexel. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said Drexel's futures subsidiary was in compliance with the regulatory agency's capital standards and was meeting the commission's requirements governing the segregation of customer funds. Drexel was said to be adjusting its positions in the energy market, assessing its obligations to other companies and determining how to meet them.

DOC.HEAD: Two Union Carbide Plants Being Sold to Japanese Company
DOC.TEXT: Union Carbide officials said Tuesday they intend to sell two polysilicon plants to Kamatsu Electronic Metals Co. Ltd. of Tokyo. The plants in Moses Lake and Washougal, Wash., employ a total of 270 people in the two communities, and had 1988 sales of about $35 million, according to Union Carbide Corp., based in Danbury, Conn. Terms of the impending sale were not disclosed under an agreement between the two companies, said Harvey Cobert, a spokesman for Union Carbide. No job reductions are anticipated because of the sale, said Sam Footer, manager of the Moses Lake plant. The Moses Lake plant, the larger of the two plants employing 220 workers, makes polysilicon, a material used in the manufacture of silicon wafers for computer chips and other electronics. The Washougal plant has about 50 employees, Footer said. The sale is expected to ensure the long-term operation of the polysilicon business, the companies said in a news release. ``In the long term we're a more viable operation with KEM because they are a major consumer of polysilicon,'' Footer said. ``All we are is a producer.'' So far, the two parties have signed only a letter of intent involving the sale. The transaction must still be reviewed by the U.S. and Japanese governments, and a final agreement must be reached. The Japanese buyer is an affiliate of Komatsu Ltd., one of the world's largest makers of construction equipment. Komatsu Ltd. employs about 4,000 people at its various U.S. affiliates. Union Carbide said the sale should produce a modest after-tax gain for the company. The two companies have a history of working together. The polysilicon production at Moses Lake was based on technology Union Carbide obtained from KEM under a 1981 licensing agreement. KEM is presently the largest customer for the polysilicon.

DOC.HEAD: Reuters Posts A 43.2 Percent Profit Gain
DOC.TEXT: Reuters Holdings PLC, a British news agency and financial information group, on Tuesday reported a 43 percent rise in its 1989 after-tax profit over the previous year. Reuters said earnings for the year ended Dec. 31 totaled $305 million, or 74 cents per share, compared with $213 million, or 54 cents a share, in 1988. Sales rose 18 percent to $2 billion from $1.69 billion. Chief Executive Glen Renfrew said the company's core infromation and transaction products performed ``very well,'' despite a slowdown in the world's financial markets, on which the company depends for most of its revenue. Reuters did not break out quarterly or half-year results. It isn't required to under British law.

DOC.HEAD: Copper Futures Surge on Stock Market's Resilience
DOC.TEXT: Copper futures prices surged Tuesday on New York's Commodity Exchange in reaction to the stock market's resilience amid reports that the parent of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. would file for federal bankruptcy protection. On other major commodity markets, precious metals were mixed; sugar futures tumbled; energy futures were mixed; grains and soybeans were mostly lower; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Copper futures settled 3 cents to 4.55 cents higher in New York with the contract for delivery in February at $1.0545 a pound, its highest level in about four weeks. The copper market has been taking its cues lately from the stock market as a forecaster of the nation's economic climate, and Tuesday's activity demonstrated how closely the two markets are tied. Copper is used heavily by industry and in home and office construction, so the shape of the economy is perceived as an indicator of copper demand. Copper futures opened lower, reflecting expectations that the troubles at Drexel would trigger a drop in the Dow Jones industrial average. The Dow did drop in early trading, falling about 19 points before buyers came in and pushed it up to a 5-point gain by the close. Analysts said the Dow's reverse sparked a turnaround in copper futures, which then took on a life of their own, soaring into the close as technical buy signals were tripped. Randolph Donney, an analyst with the brokerage Elders Futures Inc., said the Commerce Department's report of a 1.6 percent rise in retail sales last month also supported the copper market. Precious metal futures were notably quieter Tuesday after rallying sharply Monday amid concerns about possible supply disruptions in South Africa. Gold futures finished $1.60 lower across the board on the Comex with February at $417.60 a troy ounce; silver futures were 2.8 cents to 3.3 cents higher with March at $5.333 a troy ounce; platinum futures settled $1.40 to $1.70 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange with April at $522.50 a troy ounce. Sugar futures fell sharply on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange after West German statistician F.O. Licht forecast record world production of 107.9 million metric tons for 1989-90. Sugar futures finished .27 cent to .38 cent lower with March at 14.56 cents a pound. Petroleum futures ended mixed on the New York Merc ahead of the American Petroleum Institute's release of its weekly U.S. stocks report. In the report, which was released after the close, the API said U.S. gasoline stocks rose by 7.5 million barrels last week compared with market expectations ranging from 1 million to 3 million barrels. The Washington-based trade association said crude oil stocks fell about 2 million barrels, as expected, while supplies of petroleum distillates, including heating oil, rose by 870,000 barrels compared with market expectations for an increase of up to 3 million barrels. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 13 cents lower to 29 cents higher with March down 13 cents at $21.90 a barrel; heating oil was .62 cent to .90 cent higher with March at 56.85 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .45 cent to .05 cent higher with March at 60.42 cents a gallon. The wheat market led a decline in grain and soybean futures on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting improved crop weather for winter wheat and South American soybeans, and signs of disappointing foreign demand. Wheat settled unchanged to 4{ cents lower with March at $3.85{ a bushel; corn was 1 cent lower to \ cent higher with March at $2.41} a bushel; oats were unchanged to { cent higher with March at $1.39{ a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 1} cents lower with March at $5.64 a bushel. Live cattle futures fell slightly amid concerns about sluggish retail beef movement. Hog futures were lifted by forecasts for snow and cold temperatures moving into the Midwest and possibly slowing the movement of hogs to market. Live cattle futures settled unchanged to .10 cent lower with February at 79.57 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .22 cent higher with March at 82.07 cents a pound; live hogs were .23 cent to .50 cent higher with February at 49.77 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .05 cent to .35 cent lower with February at 49.50 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Announces 43 Percent Rise in Fourth-Quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: ITT Corp. reported a 43 percent jump in fourth-quarter earnings Tuesday, attributing the performance to stronger results in nearly all the conglomerate's business segments except insurance. The company said earnings totaled $257 million or $1.79 a share in the three months ended Dec. 31, vs. $180 million or $1.26 a share in the year-earlier quarter. Fourth-quarter revenues totaled $5.1 billion vs. $5.2 billion a year earlier, a 2 percent decline that ITT attributed to the divestiture of its Communications Services subsidiary, flat insurance premiums and the strength of the U.S. dollar, which translated into lower revenues overseas. For the year, ITT earned $922 million, or $6.30 a share, up 13 percent from $817 million, or $5.68 a share, in 1988. Revenue climbed 4 percent to $20.1 billion from $19.4 billion. ITT said 1989 results were impacted by the repurchase of 11.9 million common shares at an average price of $59.24, mainly in connection with its newly formed Employee Stock Ownership Plan. ITT's businesses include automotive, defense technology, electronics, pulp and timber, insurance, hotels, finance and telecommunications. The company's electronics components was the only sector that did not register higher operating earnings last year, due to lower margins and volumes in semiconductors, power systems and worldwide distribution operations, ITT said.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses To Help FDIC Recover on Sindona Losses
DOC.TEXT: The state's highest court refused Tuesday to allow the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to sue two former associates of renegade international financier Michele Sindona for almost $5 million. Sindona, who controlled the defunct Franklin National Bank of New York, died in 1986 in an Italian prison. In a 6-0 decision upholding a lower court ruling, the Court of Appeals said the FDIC wanted the court to expand state law governing the financial liability of those working with possible debtors. ``It is not for us to write such a remedy into the statute by judicial construction,'' said the court's unsigned opinion. In its suit, the FDIC said Sindona's associates, Daniel Porco and Mary Bosiack, transferred $4.87 million from some non-Franklin stock transactions to a Swiss bank account for Sindona in 1975. The FDIC said it wanted the two to come up with that amount, even though there was no allegation, noted the Court of Appeals, that ``they benefited in any way from the transfer.'' ``I'm very pleased,'' said Carol Roberts, a lawyer representing Porco and Bosiack, of the Court of Appeals ruling. ``As a result of their friendship and association with Sindona, they have been put through the mill.'' The FDIC, which had taken over Franklin, argued that because the money transfer took place after the FDIC had begun legal action against Sindona to recover funds from the bank's failure, his former associates should be held liable for transferring any assets on his behalf, even those that weren't connected to the bank. The FDIC's legal action against Sindona, begun in 1974, culminated in 1980 with a $6 million judgment against him, said Ira Hyams, a lawyer representing the FDIC. While a state trial judge ruled the FDIC could sue Porco and Bosiack to recover the transferred money as a means of helping settle the $6 million judgment against Sindona, a mid-level state appeals court threw out the FDIC's lawsuit.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Gets Cash; Paulson Scores 1-2 Punch With Gulfstream, Lear Deals
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, The all-cash, to RESTORE dropped word `million'. SUBS 14th graf pvs, Glantz said... to DELETE erroneous date reference.
DOC.TEXT: Allen Paulson scored a 1-2 punch in corporate aviation Tuesday when he acquired Chrysler Corp.'s Gulfstream Aerospace subsidiary, which he heads, and the troubled Learjet Corp. in separate deals. Paulson gained a corner on the corporate aviation market with Gulfstream's small and medium-size jets and the sleek and speedy Learjets. Chrysler's goal of concentrating on car and truck production was enhanced with the $825 million cash it received for Gulfstream, while Paulson's $60 million letter of intent for Learjet coincided with the Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing of Learjet's corporate parent, Integrated Resources Inc. The all-cash Gulfstream deal helped ease Chrysler's $664 million fourth-quarter loss, which included $577 million in write-offs for auto plants it is in the process of closing. It was Chrysler's first quarterly loss since 1982. Paulson remained Gulfstream chairman after he sold the company to Chrysler in 1985 for $637 million. He teamed up with New York-based investors Forstmann, Little & Co. to buy back the company, which Chrysler put on the block with the rest of its Chrysler Technologies Corp. subsidiaries in December. Forstmann will control slight less than half of Gulfstream. Paulson founded Gulfstream, a Savannah, Ga.-based aircraft manufacturing company, in 1978. It has about 5,000 employees at three plants in Georgia, Oklahoma and California. Paulson said owning Gulfstream again ``is like having your baby back.'' While Gulfstream has been profitable, analyst Charles Brady of the New York investment firm Oppenheimer & Co. said it was ``a luxury Chrysler chose not to afford. They've got a lot of joint-ventures going here and there. It's nice to be liquid.'' Chrysler's bank account was bolstered last September when it sold about half of its 21.8 percent stake in Mitsubishi Motors Corp. for an after-tax profit of $310 million. Chrysler is implementing a cost-cutting plan to pare $1 billion in expenses from its $26 billion annual budget by the end of this year. ``The acquisition of Gulfstream never made any sense,'' said auto industry analyst Ronald Glantz of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in San Francisco. ``Chrysler was talking about synergy'' between the auto and aviation businesses, he said. ``There was no synergy.'' Chrysler still has its Electrospace Systems and Airborne Systems for sale. Both are defense-oriented companies Chrysler wants to shed because of a slowdown in government contracting due to the thaw of the Cold War and political changes in Eastern Europe. ``I have no interest in the other Chrysler Technologies companies. I took the crown jewels out of Chrysler Technologies,'' Paulson said at a news conference. Ford Motor Co. also has its Ford Aerospace subsidiary for sale. General Motors Corp. has said it has no plans to sell its GM Hughes Electronics Corp., which includes Hughes Aircraft Co. Glantz said a popular story when Chrysler bought Gulfstream was that Chairman Lee Iacocca, prohibited by the federal government from having a corporate jet during the years when Chrysler was recovering from its near bankruptcy, proved the company's recovery was complete by buying a jet-maker instead of a single jet. Government loan guarantees helped Chrysler survive in the early 1980s. When Learjet went on the market last August, Paulson suggested that Chrysler buy it, but the board rejected his idea. The purchase of Wichita, Kan.-based Learjet is expected to be completed within 60 days and also involves Forstmann, Little & Co.'s financial backing. Stephen Weinroth, chairman of Integrated, said the company had entertained 12 serious bids for Learjet. ``The $60 million price is fair value in that we solicited those 12 bids. We felt it was the best alternative,'' said Weinroth, declining to disclose if Paulson's $60 million bid was the highest. Iacocca, meanwhile, said he was happy with the price Chrysler received for Gulfstream. ``Allen Paulson certainly knows Gulfstream and its strengths,'' Iacocca said. Paulson predicted Gulfstream would function more efficiently without its association with Chrysler. Chrysler stock closed at $16.37{ on the New York Stock Exchange, down 25 cents.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Buys Overseas Distribution Rights to Orion Films
DOC.TEXT: Columbia Pictures Entertainment will pay at least $175 million for the right to distribute Orion Entertainment Corp. films overseas, the two companies announced. Columbia, which was recently acquired by Sony Corp., said it will make a $175 million advance payment to Orion as part of the deal. ``Orion definitely can earn more than the $175 million advance if their pictures perform,'' said Alan Levine, president of Columbia's filmed entertainment division. After Orion's current contracts are satisfied in 1991, Columbia will have international distribution rights to all of Orion's theatrical releases for the next six years, Levine said Monday. The deal also grants rights to Orion's next 50 home video releases and licensing rights to a number of its television features. ``This deal gives us a lot more pictures to distribute, which gives us more clout internationally,'' Levine said. ``It's the first major deal to be undertaken by the new chairmen, Peter Guber and Jon Peters, and indicates the emphasis they place on the international marketplace,'' said Victoria Cohen, vice president and secretary for Columbia. Distribution of Orion films has been handled by several companies, including Warner Bros. International in Japan and 20th Century Fox Film International in Italy. Orion Pictures President Bob Meyers said his company decided it would be more efficient to select one distributor. Orion films include such box-office hits as ``RoboCop,'' ``Platoon'' and ``Bull Durham.''

DOC.HEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert Developments At-A-Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief rundown of developments Tuesday in the financial crisis facing Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.:
DOC.HEAD: BANKRUPTCY FILING
DOC.TEXT: Drexel, the leading purveyor of high-risk securities known as junk bonds, said its parent company planned to file for protection under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy code, which could give the company a reprieve from creditors while it attempts to stabilize and continue operating. The company defaulted on $100 million in loans Tuesday after banks refused to give it more credit. Drexel also said a severe cash squeeze threatened to cause more defaults. Management told employees at Drexel's New York headquarters they would get paid Thursday but the company couldn't guarantee anything thereafter.
DOC.HEAD: IMMEDIATE IMPACT
DOC.TEXT: Few on Wall Street believe Drexel will survive. Many stock and bond traders refused to do business with Drexel. The company's market-makers and brokers were openly soliciting jobs on the New York Stock Exchange floor. The firm began liquidating positions in billions of dollars worth of goverment bonds, mortgage-backed securities and other financial instruments; negotiated to transfer customer accounts to Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co.; withdrew as a market maker in more than 200 over-the-counter stocks; and put entire business units up for sale. The junk bond market showed surprising resilience to the Drexel news and prices rose. But market experts said the long-term implications of Drexel's demise could severely affect confidence in all financial markets and hurt the ability of companies to raise capital.
DOC.HEAD: WHO COULD GET HURT
DOC.TEXT: Besides Drexel's own workforce of about 5,300, a broad range of investors including mutual funds and pension funds could feel the impact of Drexel's problems, mostly via further price declines in the junk-bond market. Drexel's creditors, which include a broad range of banks, also could face risk. The broader U.S. economy also could feel the impact if a prolonged depression in the financial markets forces interest rates higher.
DOC.HEAD: BACKGROUND
DOC.TEXT: Drexel is a diversified investment house headquartered in New York. Its principal source of revenue has been from sales of junk bonds, high-yield debt securities of companies with credit ratings below investment grade. That market has weakened severely in the past year, as several major junk-financed companies have run into trouble paying their debts. Drexel also has businesses in corporate finance, commodity trading, equity trading and research, fixed-income securities such as government and mortgage-backed bonds, and other areas. Once the nation's fifth-largest securities firm, Drexel has shrunk severely, forced to restructure after a government investigation into its trading activities. Drexel last year pleaded guilty to six felonies and paid $650 million to the government to settle criminal charges and overhauled its structure to settle civil Securities and Exchange Commission charges. Drexel is a privately owned firm and as such is not required to disclose earnings. But the firm has said it lost $40 million in 1989 and $167 million in 1988, vs. profits of $130 million in 1987 and $523 million in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Korea Sign Pact To Study Expansion of Trade
DOC.TEXT: Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher and Korea's trade minister signed an agreement Tuesday to create a joint committee on commercial cooperation designed to expand trade and reduce friction. The committee will develop opportunities for cooperation in trade and investment, exchange information on mutually beneficial development projects and exchange technical information. ``Our ability to address areas of potential cooperation will lead not only to expanded trade, but reduced friction,'' Mosbacher said after the signing with Korean Minister of Trade and Industry Han Seung-Soo. ``South Korea's announcement yesterday of a $100 million award to General Electric to provide equipment to the Ildo Power Prodject demonstrates the long-term commitment that U.S. firms are making to the Korean market,'' Mosbacher said. ``It's another brick in the strong foundation that exists for trade expansion between our two countries.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Mixed After Drexel Chapter 11 News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf to DELETE extra digit in Dow Jones industrial average.
DOC.TEXT: Prices closed mixed on Wall Street Tuesday as the stock market mulled a likely Chapter 11 filing by the parent of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Stocks opened lower after the federal government announced robust retail sales figures for January, and then took a sharp dive after Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. said it might seek federal bankruptcy court protection for most of the investment firm's operations. Drexel said Tuesday it had defaulted on about $100 million in loans and a lack of cash threatened other defaults. Prices for blue chip stocks began to come back slowly as the market digested both developments. However, analysts, who said traders remained in a negative mood, predicted the market would turn downward within the next few days. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 4.96 to 2,624.10 after falling more than 26 points earlier in the session. The broader market lagged the industrials. Declining issues outnumbered advancers by a margin of about 5 to 4 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 675 up, 804 down and 489 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 144.44 million shares, up from 118.39 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 176.24 million shares. The Drexel announcement came as only a small surprise to Wall Street, which had been aware of the investment firm's problems. But the news cast a pall over trading as ticker services reported Drexel developments throughout the day. Alfred E. Goldman, an analyst with A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis, said that during more positive times, Drexel's problems would likely not have affected the market. But against a backdrop of economic uncertainty and the market's recent losses, traders ``will focus on obvious negatives,'' he said. Analysts said investors were concerned that the rest of the securities industry would be hit by fallout from a Drexel Chapter 11 filing. Goldman said there were no fundamental reasons for the recovery in blue chips. Most of the buying came from program traders, bargain hunters and investors adjusting their positions, he said. After the Commerce Department's report that retail sales climbed 1.6 percent in January, Wall Street repeated what has become a familiar process in the financial markets. The figures were first interpreted as a show of economic strength, and tradrs sold the market lower, fearing the Federal Reserve would now be unlikely to relax credit and allow interest rates to fall. On closer inspection, many traders decided the surge might be a one-time event. Big-name stocks like IBM came back, but the overall market remained cautious. IBM was one of the day's few big winners, picking up 2[ to close at 103\. Chrysler was off \ to 16] after announcing its fourth-quarter results, and as expected, said it was selling its Gulfstream Aerospace Corp. for $825 million to a partnership of Gulfstream Chairman Allen E. Paulson and the investment firm Forstmann, Little & Co. Exxon was up [ to 47\, AT&T was up ] to 40, and USX advanced [ to 35[. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market gained $4.269 billion, or 0.13 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.30 to 182.85. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 1.03 to 382.31, and S&P's 500-stock composite index advanced 0.94 to 331.02. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 0.63 to 425.75. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 358.45, off 0.42.

DOC.HEAD: Co-Pilot of Ill-Fated Flight Recalls Rudder Problem
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This stands for AM-FAA Order, list on AM-News Digest. A longer version moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The captain and the first officer of an airliner that skidded off the end of a La Guardia Airport runway crossed signals at a crucial point just before their plane slid into the East River, according to their testimony Tuesday. The transcript from the last moments of USAir Flight 5050 on Sept. 20 shows Capt. Michael Martin saying, ``... got the steering.'' Martin told the National Transportation Safety Board he said: ``You've got the steering.'' His first officer, Constantine Kleissis, said he heard Martin say: ``I've got the steering.'' Two people died and 31 others were injured in the mishap, which occurred on a rainswept runway late at night, after long delays. USAir Flight 5050 ended with the plane in several pieces just off the end of the runway. Both members of the crew testified that they were having trouble with the plane's rudder prior to the accident, and that rudder is a focus of the NTSB hearings, scheduled to last four days. Boeing has since redesigned the rudder control on the 737, and the Federal Aviation Administration announced Tuesday it had ordered airlines to make that change on existing planes. Officials said the FAA-ordered changes in the 737 control panel would make it less likely that pilots or cockpit visitors might accidentally move a rudder trim control knob that could reduce the pilot's ability to control the plane or force an aborted takeoff, the FAA said. The work would be relatively simple and cost about $820 per plane, the FAA said. The directive would become final after a 60-day period for comment. The FAA order would affect 641 airplanes worldwide. Although FAA orders do not directly apply to planes flown by foreign airlines, they usually comply. The Air Line Pilots Association on Monday blamed the design of the rudder trim control for the crash of Flight 5050. ``We feel the rudder trim system is what actually precipitated the USAir accident,'' ALPA representative Tom Kraemer said Monday.

DOC.HEAD: U-Haul Plan Would Cost Workers with Unhealthy Lifestyles
DOC.TEXT: U-Haul International has a message for its smokers and couch potatoes: Start leading a healthier lifestyle or get lighter in the wallet. Starting April 1, the company will begin docking the pay of the obese, the anorexic and the nicotine-needy by $5 per paycheck _ up to $130 per year. Employees who quit smoking or get their weight under control within two years will get refunds. The idea is not to harass employees who fall into those categories but to save some of the company's $17 million-a-year outlay for medical insurance and medical costs, executive vice president Harry DeShong said. ``What we are trying to do is encourage people to maintain a state of wellness. I suspect it's going to have a profound impact on the organization,'' DeShong said. Two attorneys who specialize in labor relations said the idea made them sick. ``It's ridiculous, grotesque,'' said Stanley Lubin. ``You don't dock people for part of their pay that way. Pay is an agreed amount of money given for an agreed amount of work. The company well may be violating its employer-employee agreement if it docks people's pay.'' Lawyer Charles Santaguida said the policy was too simplistic. ``Many persons with weight problems, such as those linked to diabetes, for example, are physically disabled,'' Santaguida said. ``And addiction to nicotine is considered to be a mental disability under federal statutes, which prohibit discrimination on the basis of either physical or mental disability.'' Santaguida predicted the company would have to change the policy. DeShong said Santaguida was representing a client against U-Haul in another labor matter. ``What's he going to do _ say something good about us?'' he said. DeShong said the plan was introduced company-wide through an in-house newsletter last week and had met almost no opposition. There is no organized effort to oppose implementation, he said. ``All of our employees are stockholders in the organization, and the (medical) costs are such that we all suffer. Our medical-benefits package affects 13,000 of us, and yet fewer than 150 employees comprise 80 percent of what we spend in medical claims,'' DeShong said. ``Those people, and all of us, need to be more health-conscious,'' he said. ``We're not trying to decrease the amount of coverage. We're trying to maintain the coverage we have. U-Haul Chairman Edward J. ``Joe'' Shoen was overweight and recently lost 23 pounds to fall within the guidelines, and DeShong said he was familiar with anorexia because of the struggle of a member of his immediate family. U-Haul has no policy against hiring the obese, anorexic and smokers, but DeShong said the company had been testing for drug use by work applicants in Arizona, where it employes 2,300, for about a year. About 7 percent of the applicants either fail the urinalysis or don't show up for the test. Alcohol abusers aren't included in the policy because of the difficulty in monitoring borderline cases, but the company does recognize alcoholism as a health threat and has programs in place to help its workers break the addiction, DeShong said.

DOC.HEAD: Important Dates in Drexel History
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to UPDATE with board agreeing to file for bankruptcy protection.
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of major developments in the recent history of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.: May 12, 1986 _ The Securities and Exchange Commission charges Dennis Levine of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. with making $12.6 million in profits from illegal trading on inside information since 1980. June 5 _ Levine pleads guilty to four felonies, agrees to cooperate with the government's investigation and surrenders $11.6 million in illicit profits and restitution. Nov. 14 _ Stock speculator Ivan Boesky agrees to pay a $100 million penalty to settle charges of trading on insider information supplied by Levine in 1985 and 1986. He also agrees to cooperate with investigators in a much broader investigation of Drexel and its chief financier, Michael Milken. Early 1987 _ Drexel posts a $523 million net profit for 1986, reaping the riches of a booming market in corporate takeovers that it helped fuel with its innovative use of high-risk, high-interest ``junk bond'' financing. Feb. 20, 1987 _ Levine is sentenced to two years in prison and fined $362,000 on charges of securities fraud, tax evasion and perjury. April 23 _ Boesky pleads guilty to a single charge of conspiracy to lie to the SEC, punishable by five years imprisonment and a $250,000 fine. Dec. 18 _ Boesky is sentenced to a three-year prison term and no fine. Aug. 4, 1988 _ A grand jury indicts five partners in the investment concern Princeton-Newport Partners and a former Drexel trader over an alleged multimillion-dollar fraud and racketeering scheme, the first-ever racketeering charge against securities professionals. Defendants deny wrongdoing and their attorneys call the indictment a pressure tactic to force their cooperation in a much larger investigation of Drexel and Milken. Sept. 7 _ The SEC accuses Drexel, Milken and three other employees of violating a wide range of securities laws, most in connection with Boesky. Drexel and the others deny the accusations. Nov. 30 _ Intense secret negotiations are reported between Drexel and federal prosecutors in an attempt by the firm to avert an indictment, particularly racketeering charges, which carry enormous penalties. Dec. 7 _ Princeton-Newport Partners liquidates because of what defense lawyers call brutal government misuse of the racketeering laws to coerce their clients into cooperating in the Drexel investigation. Dec. 21 _ Drexel agrees to plead guilty to six felonies and pay a record $650 million in fines and restitution to settle the biggest securities fraud probe in history. Under the settlement, Drexel must also settle the related SEC litigation and cooperate in the government's pursuit of other alleged wrongdoers. Jan. 25, 1989 _ The government files formal charges against Drexel, publicly detailing for the first time the accusations to which it will plead guilty. Most are related to the firm's alleged relationship with Boesky. Feb. 10 _ Milken asks a federal judge to reject or modify the plea agreement on the grounds it violates his rights by forcing Drexel to fire him and withhold his multimillion-dollar 1988 pay. Milken charges Drexel was coerced into signing the pact because of the threat of racketeering charges. March 10 _ Drexel reportedly agrees to ban Milken for life from the firm as part of the SEC settlement. March 22 _ Drexel assistant bond trader Lisa Jones is convicted of lying to a federal grand jury during an investigation into stock parking allegations between Drexel and Princeton-Newport Partners. The perjury conviction is the first in the government's investigation of Drexel. March 29 _ A federal grand jury indicts Milken, his brother Lowell Milken and former Drexel trader Bruce Newberg on 98 counts of racketeering and fraud. Potential penalties and fines under the counts amount to more than $12 billion plus possible prison terms. April 7 _ Michael and Lowell Milken plead innocent to all charges at a federal court arraignment. April 13 _ Drexel and the SEC announce a settlement of the civil fraud case that subjects the firm to federal monitoring for three years and forces it to sever ties with Michael Milken. Drexel also announces that former SEC chief John Shad _ who was instrumental in starting the investigation that led to the fraud charges _ would become its chairman. April 18 _ Drexel announces it is selling its retail brokerage unit, which has 2,300 employees and 1,200 brokers, partly because of continued bad publicity over its legal troubles. June 15 _ Milken resigns from Drexel after 19 years and announces formation of his own consulting firm that will not trade any securities. Nov. 9 _ Drexel confirms plans to eliminate about 300 jobs in a continuing restructuring that reduces employment to 5,300 at year's end from a peak of 10,700 in 1988. Feb. 4, 1990 _ Drexel posts a loss of $40 million after taxes for 1989, compared with a loss of $167 million in 1988. Feb. 12 _ Drexel says it is seeking a major investor or merger partner because of deteriorating conditions in the junk-bond market. Feb. 13 _ The board of Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., the parent of the securities firm, agrees to file for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy law.

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Filings Rare in Brokerage Industry
With AM-Drexel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The broker-dealer arm of Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. is not seeking bankruptcy court protection because federal law bars firms that deal in securities from reorganizing under Chapter 11. The parent company of onetime braggart securities firm Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors Tuesday in what is believed to be the largest bankruptcy plunge in securities industry history. Under the law, firms that underwrite stocks or bonds or handle securities transactions with the public are not eligible for Chapter 11, where companies can attempt reorganization without fear of creditors' claims. Brokerages can seek to liquidate their holdings under Chapter 7 of the code, a move that the Drexel unit has not made. Drexel could try to liquidate outside of bankruptcy court, though. ``It was thought by Congress too difficult to have a true reorganization where you have customer claims for securities that are in the possession of the stockbroker,'' said New York bankruptcy attorney Richard Lieb. ``What's really needed is to liquidate the positions.'' But Lieb said it was rare for a securities firm to survive a bankruptcy filing by its parent. ``I am unaware of a successful reorganization out of bankruptcy or by other means of a stock brokerage firm,'' he said. Securities firms typically hold and use securities owned by other parties. Because firms control but don't own such assets, it is difficult to determine who gets what in a reorganization. Instead, brokerage firms that go belly-up are protected under a federal agency known as the Securities Investors Protection Corp., established about 10 years ago. The corporation appoints an independent trustee who administers the liquidation and a federal insurance fund to protect customers of an insolvent brokerage firm. The fund is supported by contributions from securities firms. Experts compare the agency with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., which protects commercial bank deposits. Typically, the net proceeds of the securities on hand are pooled and distributed among the various holders of a security.But since brokerages manage their holdings actively, often there isn't enough of the security to go around. In the case of the shortage, the federal insurance fund can cover at least some of the difference, bankruptcy experts said. There have been two bankruptcy court filings by brokerage parents in the last year. L.F. Rothschild Holdings Inc., whose subsidiary was severely damaged in the 1987 stock market crash, sought Chapter 11 protection last June. Earlier this month, J.T. Moran Financial Corp., parent of a 3-year-old over-the-counter brokerage, filed amid a shortage of capital and a host of legal problems. The largest near collapse was by E.F. Hutton & Co., the retail brokerage that faced a damaging credit downgrade after the 1987 crash before it was resuced by what is now Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. Drexel's filing is believed to be the largest on record. Bankruptcy experts could come up with no other filing that would compare.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Ottawa accord reached. Picks up 7th graf, `Deep problems ...' Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Germanys agreed Tuesday to begin formal talks on making the West German mark the official currency of East Germany, a move that could lay the economic foundation for reunification. In Ottawa, the United States, Britain and France agreed with the Soviet Union and the two Germanys on a formula to reunite the two states after 45 years of division. Under the two-stage plan, talks between East Germany and West Germany would begin soon after East Germany holds its March 18 national elections. Later, the foreign ministers of the two Germanys would meet with the foreign ministers of World War II allies _ the United States, France, Britain and the Soviet Union _ to discuss security questions. The Soviets want a neutral Germany, while the United States is pressing for NATO membership. The agreement was reached at an East-West meeting on aerial surveillance. Deep problems, meanwhile, still exist between the government of West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and the rickety Communist coalition of East German Premier Hans Modrow. ``We still have a difficult stretch of road ahead of us before fulfilment of German unity,'' Kohl told reporters after his meeting with Modrow. Their brief summit produced an agreement to set up a joint commission to devise a way how to make the West German mark the official currency of both nations. Although the commission, which is to begin talks next week, will deal with an important component of reunification, any system it comes up with would not be put into effect until after Modrow's lame-duck government is succeeded in March. The opposition groups want all important decisions on economic recovery put off until after March 18. But some West German officials who are championing reunification warn that East Germany's economic state is so dire that it could be bankrupt even before the elections. Kohl said more than 85,000 East Germans have fled to West Germany during the past six weeks. The West German chancellor proposed monetary union a week ago as a means of giving East Germans confidence of immediate relief. But expansion of the mark into East Germany would demand complete conversion to a market economy and would effectively deed economic control to West Germany's central bank. Modrow pressed for immediate steps after March 18 to join the German economies, but made clear that no action could be taken before then. The premier instead appealed for $9 billion in ``solidarity aid'' to tide over East Germany. West German Finance Minister Theo Waigel said massive loans could not be made when so little detail of East Germany's financial profile has been made public. Modrow claimed his nation has much to contribute to a unified Germany, declaring that national wealth totals $850 billion, more than half the gross national product of the wealthy West German state that is three times larger. That statistic illustrated the difficulty Western officials have in translating socialist valuations in non-convertible currency into assessments of comparable worth in hard currency. In addition to Bonn's uncertainties over East Germany's financial state, the Kohl government is reluctant to provide aid to the Modrow government that is virtually assured of being ousted in the elections. The Communists are widely distrusted because of the corruption that was rampant under former leader Erich Honecker, who was ousted last year. West German political parties are aiding the new, disorganized and diverse groups campaigning for parliamentary seats in East Germany. But the Western parties, singling out the most compatible East German parties, are mainly interested in having a ready power base in the East once unification takes place. West Germany's opposition Social Democrats contend that Kohl's conservative-led government has deliberately overstated the East German economic crisis in order to pressure the Soviet Union and the other World War II victor powers into supporting reunification. Kohl, who hopes to use the reunification issue to boost his own popularity, won assurances from Kremlin leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev during a weekend summit in Moscow that the Soviets would respect Germans' desire to live as one nation. Social Democratic Party leader Hans-Jochen Vogel denounced Kohl's chief foreign policy adviser, Horst Teltschik, for telling reporters prior to the Moscow trip that East Germany could be insolvent ``within a few days.'' Modrow spokesman Wolfgang Meyer denied East Germany was on the brink of bankruptcy, and the stir created by Teltschik's forecast appeared to put a wedge between Kohl and Modrow.
